HEADLINE: Deals and Discounts

BYLINE: By JANET PIORKO

 BODY:

MUSICAL NICE -- The Nice Convention and Visitors Bureau has put together a package combining hotel stays with tickets to the Nice Jazz Festival on the French Riviera from July 11 to 18. Performers scheduled to appear include the Neville Brothers and Gato Barbieri. The Nice Festival '97 package includes five nights' accommodation, daily Continental breakfast and tickets to festival performances on three evenings. Prices start at $200 a person, double occupancy, and range up to $416; more than 90 hotels are participating. Air fare is additional. Information: (212) 719-5750 or (800) 847-4249.
 
SOUTH AFRICA FARE -- South African Airways has announced a round-trip fare of $2,004 for travel between New York and Cape Town through June 15 and from Aug. 1 to Sept. 30. Passengers buying tickets at the fare can get a companion ticket free. There is a minimum stay of seven days, maximum of one month; there are penalties for cancellation. Information: (212) 826-0995, (800) 722-9675. 

HOMES FROM HOME -- A company called Country Cottages in Boca Raton, Fla., is offering a one-week house party package in Britain or Ireland priced from $2,896 (low season) for a group of four people, including round-trip British Airways flights from New York or Boston and use of a two-bedroom cottage and midsize rental car with unlimited mileage. The same package starts at $4,092 for a group of six, including a three-bedroom cottage and minivan. Grandparents and grandchildren in a party of six get a $50 discount apiece. Two people traveling together can get a similar package starting at $1,572 for two in a one-bedroom cottage and an economy car. All the cars are standard transmission; the midsize and the minivan can be upgraded to automatic for $70.
Those prices are for Nov. 1 to Dec. 11 in Britain; in Ireland, the low season prices are $1,992 for two people, $3,376 for four and $4,776 for six. In high season, June 15 to Sept. 15 and Dec. 12 to 24, prices are $2,350 to $2,550 for two; $4,116 to $4,596 for four and $5,982 to $6,582 for six. Shoulder season prices are also available. Country Cottages has an inventory of more than 10,000 privately owned homes for rent in Britain and Ireland. For more information: (800) 674-8883 or (561) 988-4000.
 
ST. LUCIA SUMMER -- The Caribbean island of St. Lucia is offering off-season packages good from now to Nov. 30. Prices start at $619 a person, double occupancy, for a three-night package and $768 for seven nights, including air fare from New York and hotel. Participants receive a Summer Adventure Card valid for discounts on tours, shopping and dining. The packages are put together by a variety of tour operators; reservations are made through travel agents. Information: (212) 867-2950 or (888) 478-5824. JANET PIORKO

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN: DENVER

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE; JAMES BROOKE is chief of the Denver bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
When the cameras zoom in on Denver, where a three-day economic summit of world leaders will be held this month, some residents may try to ward off the international exposure with an outdated protective mantra: "Cow town, brown cloud; cow town, brown cloud."
Far from a cow town, Denver is a clean, park-filled city, low on crime and fueled by high-tech businesses, set against a Rocky Mountain backdrop. And instead of the brown cloud of pollution that once hung over the skyline, visitors will discover that the mile-high city gets plenty of sun. Since 1972, when the Federal Clean Air Act took effect, traffic in Denver has doubled, but the number of days in violation of carbon-monoxide limits has dropped from 125 to 0. 
 But with the population already growing and traffic slowing, it makes Denverites nervous to see Fortune rank their city second only to Seattle on the magazine's list of best cities to live and work in.
The leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Russia and their host, President Clinton, will converge on the city June 20 to 22. Their meetings will be held at the Denver Public Library, in the quirky, turreted, copper-clad new wing that looks out onto the lawns and classical architecture of the Civic Center. Most visitors may prefer to wait until the leaders have dispersed before exploring the city's wealth of museums and theaters, the zoo and the baseball stadium.
 
Events
 Across from the library, the Colorado History Museum, at 1300 Broadway, is featuring "Cheyenne Dog Soldiers" through Aug. 3. The exhibit displays and decodes ledgers filled with colorful drawings left by Cheyenne warriors who fought the Army in the late 1860's. The museum, with exhibits that are a key to understanding this young, rapidly changing state, charges $3 admission, $2.50 for people 65 and over and for students, and $1.50 for children 6 to 16; (303) 866-3682.
Midway between the Civic Center and Lower Downtown -- LoDo -- at the corner of 14th and Curtis Streets, the Denver Center for the Performing Arts has eight theaters with a total of 9,200 seats -- fewer only than Lincoln Center among American performing arts centers. All summer, the cabaret theater, the Garner Galleria, will present "Always . . . Patsy Cline," a charming and high-spirited musical comedy about the early 1960's country-Western singer. Tickets are $25 and $29 from (303) 893-4100.
Even for the sports illiterate, attending a Rockies game at Coors Field, at 20th and Blake Streets, is a real joy. Opened two years ago at the northwestern edge of LoDo, this red brick stadium captures the intimacy of old-time baseball -- some seats are closer to the batter than the pitcher is. At a twilight game, fans can watch the sun sink behind the mountains that gave the team its name.
The Rockies will have home games against the San Diego Padres, Florida Marlins and Atlanta Braves Wednesday through June 11, and the Texas Rangers on June 17 and 18. The San Francisco Giants are in town June 26 to 29, followed by the Anaheim Angels June 30 and July 1. Tickets: $4 to $28; (800) 388-7625.
Coors Field, of course, is named after a brewery, and the Denver area is a major beer-making center. On June 14 and 15, 38 microbreweries will join with 5 wineries and 10 area restaurants in the Denver Post Lower Downtown Beer, Wine and Food Festival. These establishments will peddle their wares at the Coors Field parking lot, 19th and Wazee Streets, and 20 bands will perform. Tickets: $5, $3 in advance; (303) 458-6685
 
Sightseeing
 The No. 1 attraction is the 16th Street Mall, a milelong pedestrian promenade dotted with cafes. A free shuttle bus along the mall links the Civic Center with Denver's bohemia -- the 26 red-brick blocks of lofts and entertainment spots of LoDo.
Near the Civic Center end rises the Denver Art Museum, 100 West 14th Avenue Parkway, (303) 640-2295. Besides an excellent collection of pre-Columbian and Spanish colonial art, the museum is noted for its 17,000 pieces of American Indian art. Admission: $4.50, $3.50 for students and seniors; free on Saturday. Closed Monday.
Also just off the Civic Center end of the mall is the Museum of Western Art, 1727 Tremont Place, (303) 296-1880, in a discreet brick building that used to be a gambling hall and bordello. Instead of crimson satin wallpaper, the walls are now decorated with a collection of Western art, from Albert Bierstadt to Frederic Remington. Admission: $3, $2 for those 65 and older and students. Closed Sunday and Monday.
At the other end of the mall is LoDo, once skid row and now home to jazz and comedy clubs, art galleries, restaurants and brew pubs -- and the Tattered Cover, 1628 16th Street, (303) 436-1070, a bookstore with overstuffed chairs, espresso and an invitation to browse.
For the footsore, Punt the Creek offers rides in flat-bottomed boats (punts) imported last year from England. They push off from a pocket park at 14th and Larimer Streets, taking tourists on a 45-minute tour of LoDo on placid Cherry Creek. Tickets: $7, $3.50 for children and $6 for seniors; (303) 893-0750.
The Denver Zoo, 2300 Steele Street, (303) 331-4110, celebrated its 100th anniversary last year by opening Primate Panorama, seven-acre home to 25 primate species, ranging from tiny squirrel monkeys to 400-pound gorillas. There is also Tropical Discovery, a rain forest under a bubble that offers humid refuge from Denver's bone-dry climate. Open daily. Admission is $6, $3 for children 4 to 12 and people 62 and older.
Nearby, the Natural History Museum, 2001 Colorado Boulevard, (800) 925-2250, opened its own blockbuster exhibit last year, Prehistoric Journey, exploring 3.5 billion years of evolution. Admission: $6, $4 for children 3 to 12 and people over 60.
 
Where to Stay
 Denver offers three hotels from the 1890's -- the Brown Palace, Oxford and Castle Marne -- that are listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
Castle Marne, 1572 Race Street, (800) 926-2763, fax (303) 331-0623, is a three-story, nine-room lava-stone mansion that is now a luxurious urban bed-and-breakfast. Rescued from its 1980's use as a processing center for parolees, Castle Marne was painstakingly restored to its turn-of-the-century opulence: Oriental runners on the oak staircase, rococo gilt mirrors and a comfortable parlor for reading by a fireplace. Doubles are $85 to $200.
In August, a large addition will open at the Adam's Mark, 1550 Court Place, (303) 893-3333 or (800) 444-2326, fax (303) 626-2544. At the Civic Center end of the 16th Street Mall, the Adam's Mark will roughly double its present size to 1,225 rooms. Rooms start at $79 and go to $190.
Budget: Just outside downtown is the Broadway Plaza Motel, 1111 Broadway, (303) 893-3501, fax (303) 893-8514. This 40-room motel was recently remodeled and is within walking distance of the library and convention center. Doubles are $55.
The Downtown Super 8 Hotel, 2601 Zuni Street, (303) 433-6677 or (800) 282-0711, fax (303) 455-1530, is about one mile west of LoDo. It has 155 rooms at $58 and $68.
Luxury: President Clinton and the American delegation will be staying at the Brown Palace, 321 17th Street, (800) 321-2599, fax (303) 293-9204. This 1893 landmark has been host to every American President since Theodore Roosevelt, with the exception of Calvin Coolidge. Sparkling after a $10 million restoration of its mostly Victorian decor (some rooms are Art Deco), the 237-room hotel is centered on an eight-story atrium with a skylight. Doubles are $195 to $205, suites $255 to $775.
In LoDo is the 81-room Oxford Hotel, 1600 17th Street, (800) 228-5838, fax (303) 628-5413, which also houses McCormick's Fish House, one of the city's best restaurants. In the hotel corridors, black and white photographs give a sense of place, French and English antiques furnish the rooms, each with a different look, and the Cruise Room is an Art Deco saloon. Corner rooms with a view of LoDo are $199; others, $89 to $299.
 
Where to Eat
 Denver has the thinnest population, according to an obesity study of the nation's 33 largest cities released last year. Given the fine fare in local restaurants, residents must be working off the calories in the mountains.
If there is any symbol of Denver cuisine, it is the buffalo. Low in fat and cholesterol, and high in protein, it is a specialty at The Fort, 19192 Route 8 in Morrison, a western suburb, (303) 697-4771. A copy of Bent's Fort, an 1833 fur trading post in southern Colorado, the adobe restaurant is a culinary-history museum. President Clinton plans to use it to show off Western American history and cuisine at a state dinner.
Highlights from the regular menu include roast buffalo marrow bones ($7.95); elk medallion steaks with huckleberry sauce ($24.75); mesquite-grilled Arctic char with rice pilaf and seasonal vegetables ($26.95), and a variety of buffalo steaks, at market prices. Dinner for two, with wine, is around $80 to $100.
Four blocks from the Civic Center is the Denver Buffalo Company, 1109 Lincoln Street, (303) 832-0880, which also ships buffalo steaks across the land (888 528-2833). There are at least 13 different buffalo entrees, ranging from liver and onions for $14.95 to a 16-ounce porterhouse Buffalo steak for $38.95. There are also veal, lamb, quail, duck, chicken and trout. Dinner for two with wine is $75 to $100.
A 10-minute cab ride from downtown, Highland's Garden Cafe, 3927 West 32d Avenue, (303) 458-5920, offers summer dining in a flower-filled garden. The menu changes a lot but recently included quail stuffed with goat cheese as an appetizer ($8.50) and bouillabaisse with fresh lobster, shrimp and clams and served with saffron ($24). Dinner for two with wine is about $70.
On the inexpensive side, Wynkoop Brewing Company, 1634 18th Street, (303) 297-2700, a large brew pub, offers excellent burgers and a boisterous atmosphere in the heart of LoDo. Off the grill, there is a half-pound buffalo burger ($5.95) or char-broiled elk medallions ($15.95). From the oven, there is a baked salmon ($13.95) and shepherd's pie of Colorado lamb ($6.50). Railyard Ale, Wilderness Wheat and Patty's Chili Beer are among the brews that go well with such fare. Dinner for two with beer is about $35.
Just across the city line, in Lakewood, the neon lights of Gordo's, 599 Sheridan Boulevard, (303) 237-8536, mark a 73-year-old family Mexican restaurant whose name roughly translates as "Fatso's." The service is amiable, the food delicious and the portions generous. A plate of enchiladas goes for $5.50, a plate of fajitas $8.50, and the burrito dinner $7.75. Dinner for two with beer is $20 to $25.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Dr. Philip E. Austin;
Money, Partnerships, Planning at UConn

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
ON April 17, Dr. Philip E. Austin was inaugurated as the 13th president of the University of Connecticut. Dr. Austin, 55, raised in North Dakota and a graduate of North Dakota State University, began his career as provost at Bernard Baruch College in New York in 1978, after service in Vietnam.
He went on to become president of Colorado State University and then chancellor of the University of Alabama system in 1989, a post he held until his move to UConn. Now, he oversees the 116-year-old flagship of the state's university system, with more than 22,000 students at eight campuses. 
 Dr. Austin wasted no time taking charge: within days of assuming the top post at UConn, he sent a five-page letter to faculty and staff detailing some of his plans, including outside review teams to inspect academic departments, improved relations with legislators and businesses, and a marketing campaign to attract students and staff.
He also told the university community that he will not live full-time on campus (he is the first president of UConn to do so). He and his wife, Dr. Susan Gates Austin, have bought a home in Farmington.
Dr. Austin recently answered some questions about UConn in an interview. Following are some excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Some alumni think UConn has had a rather rapid succession of presidents in the last 20 years. Do you intend to be here long?
A. The fact is, the average university president serves less than six years. Here, your last three presidents have stayed longer than average.
Q. Your proposal to bring in outside teams to assess the job being done in academic departments -- is that likely to generate ill will?
A. I don't think it will among the good people. There are faculty members across the campus who are dedicated to quality, who are dedicated to making UConn a better place, and they understand the importance of being evaluated by peers. I'm sure there are some people who are worried, but I have heard nothing but support. People have told me, "This is right now; this is the way to do things."
Q. Has that been tried elsewhere?
A. Most of the Big Ten do it already. And we do a lot of it already at UConn. We have accreditation of individual programs, and the decennial college-wide accreditation, which we recently went through with flying colors.
Q. You have vetoed a plan to move the West Hartford campus to downtown Hartford, which the legislature endorsed. Is that likely to create a backlash?
A. I haven't sensed a good deal of opposition. I rather laid it on the line from the start -- we have a perfectly good operation going in West Hartford, and that could have been jeopardized by moving it to the downtown. But that said, the university has a major role to play in the revitalization of our capitol city, and I have been looking for opportunities, including putting some of our programs into space in the proposed higher education complex downtown. We don't want to compete with Trinity College or the Hartford Graduate Center, but where there is demand and we have programs to meet it, we will provide them.
Q. You've talked about expanding the school's relationship with Connecticut business. At what point do you become too close?
A. The point at which we cross the line, from the very good -- mutual reinforcement -- to the very bad -- business calling the shots -- is the moment that the faculty does not make the decisions regarding the direction of research.
But to the extent that the research interests of faculty members and corporations coincide, and we follow all the traditional academic rules regarding publication in a timely manner and not withholding information from academic peers, I think both sides can benefit. In many respects that is just a contemporary version of the way we started, as a land grant university, consulting with farmers
Q. The UConn 2000 program will put $1 billion into infrastructure over 10 years. How difficult will it be to convince the legislature to give you an adequate operating budget once it is completed?
A. If you visualize the university as the platform for the state's economic revitalization, you realize you are going to need resources to assemble a high quality academic instruction and research program.
Private giving, historically, has not been very important to public universities. It has increased at UConn at rates that were not only unpredictable but unbelievable. For many years UConn raised less than $1 million a year. We made a commitment to increasing that, including hiring a vice president for development, and last year they raised $12 million. This year there's $18 million in the bank and it's looking like they will hit $20 million.
But you can't sustain a high level of quality on private donations. You can use that to endow scholarships to make sure you have students from all kinds of backgrounds, for instance. But you simply have to have a state appropriation somewhere near the middle of what our peer institutions receive. We're not there.
Q. You've said UConn has the potential to become a great university. What were the signs, and how would you define "great university?"
A. I saw a strong commitment to quality around this campus. And I saw UConn 2000, which showed that elected leaders realized the only way we're going to attract jobs to replace all those lost in defense and insurance and manufacturing is to have a strong state university.
We will know we have achieved it when faculty around the country want to come here, when this is seen as a place of intellectual vibrancy and vitality, when young people in Connecticut see us as competitive with or above the level of private colleges. Then when we get there, it will be a constant struggle to maintain it.
Q. Do you anticipate reallocation of resources? Which departments will be winners? And losers?
A. We have closed the Russian language program, and there will be more of that -- de-emphasizing certain areas, and redirecting resources to areas that are of high quality and consistent with the demands of Connecticut students. If there's a program that is excellent and nobody wants to study it, what good does it do to offer it?
There are programs among the professions that have already proven their excellence: the law school, the business school, the pharmacy school. With modest additional resources, they could be among the top programs in the country. The same for certain areas in biotechnology, material sciences, photonics, marine biology and psychology.
Q. Given some of the advances in interactive technology, does UConn still need a branch campus network?
A. Certainly, we don't need to replicate the programs we offer here on any other campus. There will always a place for this type of residential campus, the main repository for intellectual resources, and then the other campuses will slowly evolve into their own special missions.
Avery Point, for instance, offers courses for undergraduate students who would not for whatever reason have an opportunity to come here. But the main mission for Avery Point will be marine biology, since it is right on Long Island Sound.
Q. Have tuition increases made UConn inaccessible?
A. I don't think it's reached that point. In comparison to other New England public schools, three years ago we were No. 3 in terms of tuition. Last year we were No. 4, and this year we're No. 5. And we will continue to watch our tuition levels closely. But it's important to realize tuition is a direct function of state support. It is inversely related to the level of our state appropriation.
Q. Given the success of the UConn basketball program, there's been a lot of discussion lately about the balance between academics and athletics. Do you think UConn has struck the proper balance?
A. The University of Connecticut is an academic institution where there exist a number of ancillary activities for the development of our students, and among those ancillary activities are athletics.
A couple of years ago, by chance, I turned on one of the women's basketball games. The announcer said something to the effect that these women maintained a 3.85 grade point average, and they all graduated in four years. I think that shows that we've achieved the proper balance.
We are an academic institution, that's why we are here, period.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Philip E. Austin, UConn's new president, sees a pivotal economic role for the university. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1455 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Joining MSNBC in Secaucus, N.J.;
In the Meadowlands, a Studio City for Harmon Cove

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FROM the outside it does not look much different from others in the sea of bulky buildings that are its neighbors at the Harmon Cove industrial park in the Secaucus, N.J., Meadowlands.
But inside, carved from the shell of the 115,000-square-foot warehouse, is MSNBC's new headquarters. On April 7 the 24-hour cable news channel and Internet service, created by Microsoft and NBC, started airing from its New Jersey home, fueling a 10-year plan to turn a chunk of the 770-acre park into a Burbank of the East called Harmon Studio City. 
 The owner, Hartz Mountain Industries, plans to create up to 5 million square feet of space for television and film production, related uses and multimedia businesses by recycling old warehouses and developing new buildings, said Emanuel Stern, president of the real estate division of Hartz. His division has transformed its Meadowlands property from marshland into a distribution hub, a factory outlet center, offices and two hotels.
Mr. Stern said Hartz was pursuing its latest plan because of a studio space squeeze in Manhattan and in anticipation of growth in the media and entertainment industry. He is also betting that the high-ceilinged, column-free spaces that fill Harmon Cove and remain a rarity in Manhattan will draw interest.
The Meadowlands is one of several areas in New Jersey, among them Fort Lee, and others in the region, such as Stamford, Conn., where state and local officials are offering tax abatements and other incentives to lure media and entertainment industry users.
Developers also embrace those businesses as a way to diversify their tenant base. In New Jersey, the developer of Fort Lee Executive Park, a 600,000-square-foot office complex near the George Washington Bridge, says it is planning a "mini Hollywood on the Hudson." The developer, the Orlian Group, of Fort Lee, intends to develop up to 400,000 square feet of production and related space at its campus, and up to 600,000 more square feet on a nearby site.
The project would return to Fort Lee a piece of its history as a film center. "The reasons studio heads came here 100 years ago are the same reasons they will come today," said Robert Miller, the park's project manager. Key among them, he said, are cost savings and proximity to Manhattan.
In Stamford, local officials are working with developers to create 300,000 square feet of such space initially in a state-designated entertainment media district, said Kip Bergstrom, the city's Economic Development Director.
Each location already is home to a cadre of media firms. Those with Stamford operations include Time Warner and Group W Satellite Communications, a CBS division devoted to cable and other nonbroadcast distribution. In New Jersey, they include CNBC, WWOR and now MSNBC, which selected Secaucus after looking at more than 200 sites in the New York metropolitan region, said Michael Sherlock, the MSNBC executive vice president in charge of technology.
With studio space tight and costly to create in Manhattan those involved in the separate plans hope their locations will become less expensive alternatives. Under each plan construction will start once a tenant has leased space.
"There may be a spillover to areas outside of Manhattan, but the question is how big will the demand be," said Alan B. Weisman, senior managing director of the Manhattan office of Grubb & Ellis, a national commercial brokerage concern. "The answer is nobody knows."
The number of feature films shot in New York City rose from 157 in 1994 to 201 last year, according to the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater & Broadcasting. The office added that more than 100 television programs were filmed in the city each year.
In New Jersey, 69 feature films and 99 television programs were shot last year, up from 41 feature films and 89 television programs in 1994, figures from the state's Motion Picture and Television Commission show.
CABLE stations also have channels to fill. And the change in the delivery of television signals that enables stations with one channel to deliver five or six could spur "an incremental demand for space," said John Reidy, media analyst at Smith Barney.
A 1996 study now being updated by Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, estimates that jobs in the new media industry will double to 92,000 next year in the metropolitan region. That industry includes online services, Internet and CD-ROM publishers and developers.
No statistics exist on production space in Manhattan and the region. "Quality space -- with ceilings of 20 feet or higher and wide column bays -- is limited in Manhattan and users have compromised their space needs because of the lack of options," said Brian Given, executive managing director at the Manhattan office of Williams Real Estate, a national commercial brokerage. Areas outside Manhattan with attractive buildings and rents "will fill a need for some users," he said.
Moreover, said officials and developers in New Jersey and Stamford, other expenses in their areas -- from real estate taxes and utilities to labor and operating costs -- are also lower.
Some industry experts caution that the need for production space is cyclical and leaving Manhattan is an impediment for the media and entertainment industry. "The ability to draw on the city's diversity and intellectual capacity is critical and something many users don't want to risk," said Mary Ann Tighe, executive managing director at the Manhattan office of Insignia/ESG, a national commercial brokerage.
Meanwhile, studio production space already exists elsewhere in New York City, including Kaufman Astoria Studios in Astoria, Queens, which says it is fully booked, and the Silvercup Studios in nearby Long Island City, which says it has space available, and Chelsea Piers on the Hudson River waterfront in Manhattan, which is almost fully booked. More space is being planned in Manhattan.
One project calls for transforming the desolate piers between 52d and 55th Streets into a 400,000-square-foot film and television production center. And Trinity Real Estate -- the real estate arm of Trinity Church -- is contemplating creating 75,000 square feet of production space for a user by stitching together space at 345 Hudson Street, between Charlton and King Streets, with a structure that could be built on an adjacent parking lot.
"For many users if they can't be in Manhattan there is no second location," said Steven Heyman, Trinity's director of commercial real estate leasing. "We are testing the waters."
So are the developers and officials in New Jersey and Stamford. They said their sites would complement, not compete with, Manhattan and that decisions like MSNBC's would continue to be made. "We are inextricably bound to New York, so by enhancing the region as an entertainment and media hub, we both win," said Gualberto Medina, commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Commerce and Economic Development.
Mr. Bergstrom, Stamford's Economic Development Director, said that his city's intent was "not to raid New York," but to position Stamford "as an alternative location."
At Harmon Cove, Mr. Stern of Hartz said that, with MSNBC as a 15-year tenant, his company had the critical mass to recreate a Burbank in the Meadowlands. Years ago, he continued, naysayers said Harmon Cove would not draw distribution users from Manhattan, but when Panasonic moved its operations there in 1971, the park was stamped as a legitimate location. The hope is that the same will result from the MSNBC move, he added.
"In terms of economics, the numbers are compelling," he said, noting that rents for unimproved warehouse space at Harmon Cove are $5 to $8 a square foot. And the roads, utilities and buildings are in place to support such users, he said, adding that 800,000 more square feet of space could be built.
Mr. Sherlock, of MSNBC, said the site had been chosen because it met his company's goals. It wanted a building accessible to employees with high ceilings and room to grow, and a location near NBC's Manhattan headquarters and its other cable station, CNBC in Fort Lee. Other factors were favorable economics and the state incentives, such as the sale of $150 million in bonds to help buy equipment and convert the warehouse -- a process that took nearly a year. The building includes an 18,000-square-foot newsroom, a 6,400-square-foot production studio, editing rooms and a fitness center.
Ruminating on the future, Mr. Stern said the logic was there for Harmon Cove to become a "production destination." For now he can take some satisfaction that a bit of reality has been given to his vision. When MSNBC newscasters sign off they say: "Reporting from Harmon Studio City."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
A Megamall Cornerstone for a Waterbury Revival

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: WATERBURY

 BODY:
UNTIL the 1950's Waterbury was the queen city of a prosperous Naugatuck Valley industrial corridor. But over the years its major factories moved away and its economy sagged.
Last year, the commercial-property vacancy rate downtown reached 48 percent before dropping back to 37 percent with rentals of some professional offices, restaurants and stores. 
 Now the city is reinventing itself as a regional retail and entertainment center. Its cornerstone will be the Brass Mill Center, a 1.1-million-square-foot, $160 million shopping mall nearing completion on 87 acres off Interstate 84. The project will supply some 2,600 full-time jobs. But even as construction on the mall nears completion, the effects that the shopping complex, and another nearby, will have on Waterbury's downtown remain unclear.
The project had it genesis three years ago when Homart, a Chicago mall developer, began the arduous task of removing the site's 118,000 tons of contaminated soil and 63 vacant and deteriorated buildings where the historic Scovill Brass Works had operated for 200 years. The yearlong cleanup and demolition of Scovill closed the book on Waterbury's history as Connecticut's industrial engine.
In 1995, General Growth Properties of Chicago bought Homart from Sears; the company began construction of the mall last spring. It is scheduled to open Sept. 17.
Anchored by Filene's, Sears and J. C. Penney stores, the complex is to have 150 additional shops, a 12-screen theater with 3,506 seats, four restaurants, 8 fast-food stalls in an 800-seat food court, about 5,800 parking spaces and a linear park where shoppers can relax alongside the Mad River.
A museum dedicated to the history of clocks will be installed by Timex, which is based in the suburb of Middlebury, in two restored Scovill buildings. General Growth is also constructing a 200,000-square-foot supplemental mall called The Commons on the same site. It will include Lechmere's, an electronics and appliance department store; a Sears automotive supply store, Barnes & Noble, Kids "R" Us, Toys "R" Us, Boston Market, Office Max, a furniture store, a microbrewery/pub and two banks.
Both malls were designed by Arrowstreet, a Somerville, Mass., architectural firm, with Patricia Cornelison as lead designer. Arrowstreet is also currently working on Park Square West, a retail enclave in downtown Stamford, as well as malls in New Haven, Waterford and Stonington. The firm is also designing theaters for Hoyt Cinemas worldwide, including the multiplex at the Brass Mill Center.
Filene's and Sears are building their own stores, and will own and manage them, vacating their existing locations at Waterbury's 28-year-old, 575,000-square-foot Naugatuck Valley Mall a mile and a half north of the Brass Mill Center.
According to Patricia L. Ritchie, the older mall's general manager, its 50 individual stores "have taken a dive."
"We have an empty four-screen theater and a 25 percent vacancy rate," she said.
Many stores are temporary tenants, she added, reflecting the mood of uncertainty among retailers unsure of getting space in the new mall.
These days traffic around the Brass Mill Center creeps at a snail's pace through the developer's road-widening projects and bridge construction, and owners of rundown housing and businesses in the area anticipate their suddenly desirable real estate will start selling for higher prices.
East Main Street, running across the north side of the mall and into downtown three blocks south, is scheduled to be widened to four or six lanes as part of the city's plan to link the mall with downtown and thus revitalize it.
If current plans are realized, visitors will be able to attend Broadway shows and concerts at the 3,200-seat Palace Theater, an elaborate 1920's vaudeville and movie house due for restoration, as well as be able to dine at new restaurants and browse through new shops.
Mayor Philip A. Giordano pointed to the added attraction of the city's six-block historic district, which contains a handsome green, a Georgian City Hall, a new state courthouse, the 1909 landmarked railroad station and the Mattatuck Museum and Historical Society designed by Cesar Pelli.
"The mall will bring 10,000 people a day from outside the city," the Mayor said. "We want to lure them into the downtown area and give them something else to do."
But getting people downtown could be a challenge, considering the access ramps that the developer is building from Interstate 84 directly into the mall, and a state-of-the-art supermarket going into The Commons. "The concept is to provide the consumer with one-stop shopping," said William Fox, in charge of leasing for General Growth Properties.
OTHERS said it was open to question whether downtown would benefit. "The history of megamalls entering downtown areas has been stark," said David Obarowsky, a Waterbury lawyer. "Either the downtown flourishes or perishes."
Mr. Obarowsky is a member of Downtown Initiative, a year-old group of private citizens working with the city and its development agencies to lure investment into Waterbury. "Our office market will clearly pick up," he said, "because we are focusing on it as an information-technology center."
At the city's request, the General Assembly is considering a bill that would create such a center with tax abatements to draw appropriate businesses into the city, providing relief from a punishing tax rate of $74.64 per $1,000 of assessed value -- one of the highest in the state.
Despite the high taxes, there have been some successes, such as the 3-story, 90,000-square-foot Brown Building, which sold for around $400,000 two years ago and recently was resold for about twice that amount.
Local realtors estimate that commercial rents downtown, ranging from $5 to $15 a square foot, will compare favorably with rents at the mall, which are expected to hover around $35 a square foot.
Waterbury's limited manufacturing sector "has firmed up with a 5 percent vacancy rate," said Tom Hill, owner of Tom Hill Realty and Investments in Waterbury, adding that the residential market remained flat in the city relative to the suburbs.
"We are seeing up to 15 percent increases in prices for homes that are still a bargain at $150,000 to $200,000," he said, citing houses in the surrounding suburbs of Southbury, Middlebury, Naugatuck and Watertown. "Successful Waterbury people tend to move there, and the more southerly suburbs are getting in-migration from Fairfield County," he said.
The blighted 40-block area north of the mall will be rehabilitated by Neighborhood Housing Services, a local nonprofit agency that will buy up dilapidated housing and demolish or refurbish it. It then plans to sell back renovated housing to existing tenants, who will make their purchases with state subsidies.
The project will take an as yet undetermined number of years. Funds for work on the first 20-house block, said Adele Strelchun, director of Neighborhood Housing Services, will be provided by a no-interest $200,000 loan, as well as a $800,000 grant from the state and a $15,000 grant from the Community Economic Development Fund, a quasi-public state agency.
Ms. Strelchun said that she expected that similar funds would be available on an annual basis. But she voiced concern that developers would buy some of the property involved in foreclosure "before we get a chance."
Joseph Begnal, owner of the Brown Derby Bar and restaurant on East Main Street opposite the mall, had looked forward to brisk business from the 400 mall construction workers. But, he said, "they never come for lunch -- they carry their own -- and they never come in after work."
Now a real estate agent, Ralph Calabrese of Ralph Calabrese Realty, is putting together a number of small parcels on the block, including the bar, and marketing them for big-box stores.
"It's the land that's worth something, not the businesses," said Mr. Calabrese. But, he cautioned, "the owners have to realize that there's only a certain number a retailer will pay for an acre -- maybe $250,000 to $500,000 split among anywhere from three to seven parcel owners."
Mayor Giordano said the city was prepared "through purchase or eminent domain" to acquire a total of about 10 acres for the highway widening and for sale in parcels to appropriate developers.

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Beyond Betting: A Good Day at the Track

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY

 BODY:
IN Atlantic City, this was the scene one morning at the sprawling Taj Mahal casino, which like all gambling parlors has no windows to let the sun in:
Hundreds of people, each locked in their own private world, grimly fed coins into slot machines. Few conversed amid the Muzak of money, the downpouring din of coins clattering into slot machine trays designed to chant the promise of jackpots. 
 Seventy miles up the Garden State Parkway, meanwhile, this was the scene a few hours later at another gambling joint, Monmouth Park Race Track:
Frank Hughes, spiffy in a top hat, red hunting coat and shiny black riding boots, marched out of the tunnel from the paddock and halted beside the winner's circle. Smartly, he hoisted a four-foot heraldic trumpet to his lips and blew the silvery flourishes of the call to the post. The crowd stirred, a tossing sea of color in the stands. In a few minutes, the thunder of horse hoofs and the grandstand's roar built in a crescendo.
"It's all part of the protocol of the track," explained Mr. Hughes, who teaches music and directs the band at Toms River High School, as he headed back to the clubhouse to wait for the next race. "There's such beauty in it."
Yes, a race track is a place to gamble money.
But when Monmouth Park opened for the summer the Saturday before Memorial Day, it was also a good place to wander in the tumult and reflect on the internalized casino culture that is threatening the merry social culture of horse racing.
Monmouth Park opened in 1870. By the early 1890's, President Grant had a box there. Following a long hiatus legislated by anti-gambling bluenoses, the track reopened after World War II and went on to become a premier East Coast showcase for quality two- and three-year-old thoroughbreds.
To enter such a track is to recall that first summer vision of Yankee Stadium's emerald green, in the days before corporations confiscated the good seats and relentless advertising smothered ball park ambiance while mascots danced in aisles and scoreboards instructed the crowd how to respond.
At the race track, you see cascades of red geraniums in flower boxes on the stands, not billboards selling beer and banks. Trainers walk the horses under beech trees, while children watch with their parents. Fountains splash beside picnic tables. Armani suits mingle with Levis; cowboy hats perch beside baseball caps, bowlers and summer bonnets. Lizard boots stride next to Nikes. And nobody hollers at the codger in a windbreaker puffing his cigar.
People talk to strangers, who don't react as if a gun has been pulled on them. "So who do you like in the third?" a man in a white silk suit asked a men's room attendant, who replied at length.
At the paddock, a woman frowned at a tautly muscled 2-year-old bay. "This one looks persnickety," she told a stranger, a middle-aged man studying a racing form that conveyed information on many variables -- a horse's pedigree, its performance under various conditions, the weight it carries, its peculiarities, its jockey. But not its moods.
"You know, you're right, miss," the man told her, and trotted off to adjust his bet.
The cultural morning line says that horse racing -- a sport that requires expensive horses, expert players and at least a semblance of fans' analytical skill -- is doomed by casinos. In New Jersey, casinos have diverted more than $7 billion from horse racing since 1976. In 1976, attendance at Monmouth Park was one million. Last year, it was 696,000. Other tracks, doing worse, now depend heavily on television simulcasting that gives them the elan of O.T.B. parlors. Delaware's tracks are crammed with slot machines. Pennsylvania's and New York's may follow.
Given the cold economics, it's unclear how much longer New Jersey will be able to prevent someplace like Monmouth Park, a track as beautiful as Saratoga's, from becoming merely a slot-machine joint with some horses. Luckily, powerful casino owners like Donald Trump, for their own obvious reasons, have vowed to fight any legislation to allow slots in Jersey's race tracks. Still, some people think it's just a matter of time.
Meanwhile, like a vintage carousel, a race track beats on against the tide. "Monmouth Park is old enough, with all this quaint charm, to draw good crowds in a summer meet," said Bobby Kulina, the track's vice president for thoroughbred racing, and himself the son of a trainer. "All we have to do now is not mess it up."

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1361 words

HEADLINE: Demand Grows For Hourly Workers

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
IT is 8 A.M. on a weekday, and as a crush of highly paid executives heads for work along a strip of corporate office parks in Tarrytown, Linny Dung, 23, puts on a checkered apron at the Westchester Marriott Hotel and prepares for the long day ahead. A determined worker, Mr. Dung wants to save enough money to open a restaurant of his own someday. But for now the Vietnamese immigrant is content to be known as the waiter who tells jokes as he serves meals -- earning $3.64 an hour plus tips but honing the skills he will need for the future. 
 At 68, George Zaccagnini, a worker at the county-operated Maple Moor Golf Course in White Plains, earns $5.20 an hour, yet he is similarly gratified to be employed, low wages notwithstanding. Although the former ceramic tile worker planned carefully for his later years, he said he has discovered that his savings do not cover all of his expenses. "Besides, I don't want to fade away just sitting at home," he said. "Working keeps me young."
In yet another section of Westchester, Oscar Flores, 35, works as a landscape foreman for Sprain Brook Nursery in Scarsdale, also for hourly wages, installing handsome green lawns and bushes for wealthy customers. Though his earnings are limited, the native of El Salvador dreams of sending his children to American colleges someday so they will be able to live in large houses like the ones their father works on.
Mr. Dung, Mr. Zaccagnini and Mr. Flores are representative of low-paid hourly workers in one of the country's richest areas, where 18 municipalities were listed in Worth magazine among the 300 wealthiest in America.
And while almost 50 percent of Westchester's households have incomes above $50,000 a year, only 14.4 percent, according to the 1990 census, earn less than $15,000 a year -- which, translated into hourly wages, converts to less than $7 an hour based on a 40-hour workweek.
Noreen L. Preston, an economist with the County Planning Department, observed that while Westchester ranks among the highest in the United States in terms of average household income, it is also a county of "tremendous diversity -- from the very wealthy to the poorest."
National trends show that despite their lack of skills and formal education, low-wage workers are increasingly in demand. The economy, in its sixth year of recovery after the last recession, is seeking fast-food workers, office clerks, factory assembly workers, laborers, hotel workers, gardeners and others at the bottom of the income scale.
With the unemployment rate at 4.9 percent nationally -- less than 4 percent in Westchester -- those workers are in high demand, and the trend is that employers may have to pay more in the future to compete for them. Hourly workers are also benefiting from the first increase since 1995 of the minimum wage, which is now $4.75 an hour.
In the first quarter of this year, figures showed that the weekly wages of full-time, adult workers in the lower 10 percent of the wage spectrum rose at a 4.4 percent annual rate, bringing the top of that group to $259 a week or $6.48 an hour. By comparison, the median weekly wage rose 3.5 percent in that period, to $536 a week or $13.50 an hour.
Nationally, the higher wages have attracted more black women, older men, immigrants, teen-agers and Hispanic people -- swelling the work force.
Frank M. Surdey, an economist with the State Department of Labor said that 40 percent of all job opportunities require only short-term on-the-job training, making it easier for applicants with limited education to obtain work.
But some economists and sociologists in Westchester say that the county is not hospitable to the workers it needs to groom the golf courses, clean the parks, serve up fast food and tend the manicured gardens of the wealthy.
"Westchester has a fairly vibrant economy that needs hourly workers, but there are few places for them to live," said Andrew A. Beveridge, assistant professor of sociology at Queens College, explaining that most of the county's working poor live in virtual ghettos in cities like Yonkers, Mount Vernon, New Rochelle and White Plains.
As a result of a shortage of affordable housing and the high cost of commuting from other areas, Westchester employers are hard pressed to find an adequate labor pool, observed Thomas J. Spitznas, an economist in Mount Vernon.
"The county has to scramble to find a labor force," Mr. Spitznas said. "I see 'Help Wanted' signs appearing everywhere."
The Marriott is one of many employers eager to hold on to its labor pool, so what the hotel chain cannot afford to offer in terms of dollars an hour, it tries to make up in terms of employee satisfaction.
Leo Nemetz, the general manager at the Marriott, said he starts with the premise that there are "jobs that need to be done, and there are people who need these jobs: In that sense, it's a good fit."
In all, the Marriott in Tarrytown employs 368 hourly workers in its restaurants and housekeeping department and at its pool.
Priding itself on being a caring employer, the chain has a variety of offerings for its hourly workers, like tuition reimbursement plans, social-service benefits and programs for fathers, like seminars on being a responsible parent. It also assists the many workers who want to learn English in a multicultural atmosphere, which Mr. Nemetz recently described as "a small United Nations."
Indeed, the dining room where Mr. Dung works is staffed with employees from South and Central America, Jamaica, Haiti, Pakistan, Mexico, Cambodia and Vietnam, among other countries. It is much the same in the housekeeping division where Magdalena Kovacs, a Slovakian immigrant, works. She spoke little English when she joined the Marriott staff at $4.25 an hour 15 years ago, having gleaned a few phrases from watching cartoons on television.
She described her fellow employees as "my second family" and said they encouraged her to rise to the position of supervisor of the linen room, a top level in her department, which pays $9.57 an hour.
While immigrants, students and older workers make up much of Westchester's work force of hourly wage earners, many of those forced off the welfare rolls in recent years have also filled those ranks. The Marriott recently instituted a Pathways to Independence program in conjunction with welfare departments throughout the country, although that program is not yet in effect in Westchester.
In the county, about 18,000 former welfare recipients have graduated from a Pride in Work program -- which helps remove people from welfare rolls by helping recipients to get jobs -- although it is not known how many actually hold jobs now, said Norman Shaw, a spokesman for the Department of Social Services.
The county government is the largest single employer of hourly workers, hiring about 700 people in the spring and summer months for a variety of jobs at golf courses and public parks.
"We couldn't do it without them," said Salvatore A. DeSantis, Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Conservation.
Explaining that the county uses a cross-section of people from students to retirees, he said, "We generally catch people at the beginning of their work lives or at the end."
Tha Samreth, 20, a student at Berkeley College in Manhattan, is typical of hourly wage earners first entering the work force. A bespectaled business major, he manages the Derby, the fast carousel at Playland Park in Rye, earning $7.05 an hour, which he puts toward his college expenses.
With more low-end jobs available and workers in short supply, Mr. Samreth said he was able to choose among many offerings for summer employment.
But not all hourly workers have taken jobs for the money. Some, like Irwin Katz, 65, a retired chief financial officer of a mid-size manufacturing concern, said his job these days "is for love."
Mr. Katz began his work life as a caddie "when I was 10 years old." Mr. Katz, who works with Mr. Zaccagnini at Maple Moor Golf Course, added: "So after working 60 hours a week for 40 years in a high-pressure job, I decided it was time to finish my career the way I started it -- on a golf course."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
U.S. Toughens Program On Unruly Air Travelers

BYLINE: By Betsy Wade

 BODY:
With complaints by airlines about disruptive passengers on the rise, Government efforts to prosecute offenders are being expanded. A test program was begun at Honolulu and Los Angeles International Airports on Nov. 1, 1996, and the Department of Transportation plans to extend the program to the three major New York airports: Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark. In mid-May, Bill Mosley, spokesman for the department, said no date for the extension had been set. In the program, the Federal Aviation Administration, part of the transportation department, works with airlines, crew members, local law agencies, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and assistant United States attorneys to see that reports of passenger interference with crew members are investigated.
In addition, Sam Podberesky, in the enforcement division of the department, said that it would offer help to the airlines in rewriting the legal language on their tickets to warn that they could refuse to carry passengers found guilty of interfering. 
 An F.A.A. report on the test of enhanced coordination was made at an international conference held by the Air Line Pilots Association. This report said that from Nov. 1 to April 30, seven United States and five foreign airlines flying into Honolulu and Los Angeles reported 24 incidents. The agency is pursuing 14 civil actions as a result.
In one case, a male passenger flying from Los Angeles to Hawaii made sexual gestures, struck a female flight attendant and seized a male attendant by the arm. The suspect pleaded guilty to assault, a misdemeanor, and, according to Ed Jones of the F.A.A. security office at Los Angeles International Airport, was sentenced to two years' probation in addition to a day already spent in jail. The judge levied no fine because the passenger was unemployed. A female passenger who slapped a pilot and bit a first officer was sentenced to a day in jail and fined $750.
Nancy McFadden, general counsel at the Department of Transportation, said that the agency was working on ways to let passengers know what they risked if they did not fulfill their responsibility to behave aboard planes -- possibly by spreading the information on the Internet. BETSY WADE

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
New Car Rental Rates From Rail Europe

 BODY:
For travelers who want the convenience of both train and automobile, Rail Europe, the company that sells train travel to Americans before they leave home, is offering three free days of economy-car rental from Avis to those who buy more than $1,000 worth of air travel from Rail Europe before June 30. Depending on the country selected, the incentive is worth up to $299.
In addition, Rail Europe offers a free rail day and a free car day to those who buy the Europass Drive or the Eurail Drive pass, also before June 30. The value of this incentive can be as much as $140, depending on type of car. The Europass Drive pass provides three days of unlimited first-class rail travel and two days of economy-car rental for $259 a person for two people traveling together in France, Italy, Spain, Germany and Switzerland. Up to 12 additional rail days may be bought for $42 a day for each person. Three types of cars are available: economy, compact and intermediate. Extra car days can be added, ranging from $55 to $85 a day per car. 
 The Eurail Drive pass is good in all 17 countries served by Rail Europe. It offers four days of unlimited first-class travel and three days of car rental, beginning at $345 a person for two traveling together. Up to five additional rail days may be bought for $55 a day a person, and extra car days range from $55 to $85 a day.
Prices of most regular Eurailpasses -- for train travel only -- remain unchanged from last year. For example, the one-month Eurailpass, good in first class, costs $838 a person and gives unlimited travel in 17 countries. There is at least one change from last year, however: the two-month Eurailpass is now $1,188, a 3.5 percent increase.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Imagination, Packed Up and Ready to Travel

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
JUST as it's surprising how much can be stuffed inside a suitcase, it's also a revelation how much meaning can be packed into an exhibition built around suitcases. In "Art + Suitcase, Will Travel" at the Shoestring Gallery here, nine artists have opened up what may be a whole new genre.
Bill Barrell, who runs the gallery and whose work is included, says the show grew out of his desire to put together an exhibition that could travel easily. Galleries and museums are attracted by shows that can be transported economically, and Mr. Barrell said he figured that a show of works that each fit into a suitcase, as well as incorporate that suitcase, might be the ticket. The whole exhibition could be checked as luggage. 
 His co-curator, Ron Morosan, supplied some of the art-historical validation for the concept. He pointed to Marcel Duchamp's "Valise," a suitcase full of miniature reproductions of Duchamp's most famous pieces, including the urinal he titled "Fountain" and the painting "Nude Descending a Staircase." "Valise" is a concise summary of Duchamp's life work, and its portability symbolizes the ease with which art ideas travel in the modern era.
"Art + Suitcase" is strikingly animated. Nothing is content just to lie in its case; items seem to burst from their would-be confines. There is no soft-sided luggage in the show; all the suitcases are emphatically cases, rather anachronistically hard and unyielding, and thus fine foils to their lively contents. On each piece, Mr. Barrell has slapped identical, colorful travel stickers bearing the name of the exhibition and that of his gallery, in the hope that each suitcase will become plastered with various stickers and baggage tags as it travels.
His contribution is a plywood cut-out figure of a striding man who represents the Janus face of the art world. The figure, "Artist/Collector," is double-sided. The collector side is a man in a suit, with a determined look on his face. He holds a painting under his arm, and between his fingers is a fat cigar that emits plastic-foam puffs of smoke. On the flip side, the smiling artist who holds a suitcase is wearing a breezy striped shirt like the ones Picasso made his trademark. The composite figure consists of several pieces hinged together, so that it can easily come apart and be stored in the case.
The work by Mr. Morosan, who lives in Manhattan but has a studio in Jersey City, is the meditative opposite of Mr. Barrell's. "Dogs Don't Watch TV" is a partly open case lined with shredded paper, and among the contents are a white shirt and a cap bearing the likeness of a large dog of undeterminable breed. But the work's focus is several framed drawings of the dog pondering various pieces of modern art. In one of the best, the dog stares at an abstract sculpture that looks very much like his own pointy ears. The actual abstract sculpture in the show was shipped from Detroit by Bob Sestok. It's a trunk standing open and on end with several red panels bolted onto it; the resulting sculpture suggests a cardboard box with all its flaps out.
Karen Shaw from Islip, Long Island, and Nancy Cohen from Jersey City have fashioned pieces whose contents stretch far beyond the limits of their suitcases. Ms. Shaw's study in circularity, "The Great Escape," uses a hatbox equipped with wheels from a skateboard. Emerging from the box are two springlike forms: one is large and covered with gold foil; nesting in its coils is a more slender spring, reminiscent of a Slinky toy. The springs extend to a distant wall of the gallery, and the spot where they end is covered by a large, wide-brimmed straw hat. If Ms. Shaw projects insouciance, Ms. Cohen turns nostalgic with "Trousseau." Her overnight case is from her grandmother's attic, and out of it comes a long necklace that ascends to the ceiling.
Kurt Novak, who lives in Manhattan, travels to other dimensions with his daft but appealing "Transmigration of Souls." From his suitcase, lined with red satin, shoot out several Mason jars strung on taut lengths of twine. Each jar is stuffed with the sole of a different type of shoe.
The only fixed, recognizable destination alluded to in the exhibition is "Rockies From the Air," by another Manhattanite, Mimi Gross. The pitch-black inside of her case is the backdrop for many jagged yellow lines, the craggy contours of the mountains. Josie McKee's "Suitcase Boy" presents a small figure in a top hat, reminiscent of a conjuror, who stares at a small scrim painted with mountains and a bright sun. Ms. McKee, also of Manhattan, takes advantage of the firm exterior of her suitcase, which serves as a stage or platform.
But the tantalizing mystery resides in D. Capobianco's "Game." Mr. Capobianco is known for drawing rebuses, and "Game" seems to be a three-dimensional rebus. In what looks like a casual arrangement, waiting for the viewer to form a phrase from them, are, among other objects, a skull with a red ball for a nose; dice; a ladder; a battered clock face; a clown's hat and glove that might have belonged to Emmett Kelly; a rose, and a reproduction of a Matisse painting. Rather than encourage travel, this piece can transfix.
 
ART + SUITCASE, WILL TRAVEL
 Shoestring Gallery
111 First Street, Jersey City
Through June 14. Hours: Saturdays, noon to 4 P.M.; other times by appointment.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
As Demand Grows, a Rush to Redo Large Spaces

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WITH demand for office space growing, new owners have begun or are about to begin renovating sprawling campuses that were once used as offices for American Cyanamid and International Business Machines.
Over the last four years, the complexes had been largely shut down, their future so unclear that they were once considered as housing for the elderly. 
 The vacant or nearly vacant buildings, together totaling more than 1 million square feet, are now being renovated and put back in the race for corporate tenants.
The sites -- Cyanamid in Wayne and I.B.M. in Franklin Lakes -- are among the handful of large blocks of available space of 300,000 square feet or more in the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office market. Such blocks have dwindled as the improving economy and renewed corporate expansions of the last two years absorbed much of the space left over from the recession of the late 80's and early 90's.
At the end of 1996, there were 11 blocks of Class A space of 100,000 square feet or more, down from 22 in 1993, and the number fell to 7 as of the first quarter of this year, says Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage.
Developers have responded to the scarcity of space by starting eight buildings, totaling 816,000 square feet. But much of that space was preleased, leaving the same lack of larger areas of space for tenants looking for sooner rather than later, brokers said.
Cushman & Wakefield reports that some 55 corporations are searching the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut region for 100,000 square feet of space or more.
Those are the prospects the owners of the former Cyanamid and I.B.M complexes want to attract.
Called Pointview, the 194-acre Cyanamid site, off Bredan Avenue and overlooking the Pointview reservoir, was acquired for slightly less than $20 million in February by Wellsford Commercial Properties, a subsidiary of Wellsford Real Properties. The parent is a publicly traded Manhattan real estate company.
The site includes two empty, interconnecting main buildings with 548,000 square feet of space in all that will be renovated at a cost of $10 million. Two smaller buildings on nearby Valley Road that were also part of the sale will be marketed separately. Since Wellsford entered the state's market less than a year ago it has acquired 1 million square feet in six buildings, including those at the Cyanamid site.
The 200-acre former I.B.M. campus along Old Mill Road, which has yet to be renamed, was purchased in December by MSGW I. The company, a partnership of Gale & Wentworth, a real estate services and investment company based in Florham Park, and Morgan Stanley, the Manhattan-based investment banking firm, buys commercial properties using its own equity.
The partners, who paid $25 million for the 6-building, 575,000-square-foot complex, are investing $3.5 million more to upgrade it. Western World Insurance Group, which occupies 60,000 square feet, is the only tenant at the campus.
The purchase brings to 12 the number of buildings, totaling 1.6 million square feet, that the partners acquired in the last 8 months. Gale & Wentworth is also putting up two 100,000-square-foot office buildings, and is about to start a third with 175,000 square feet at its 168-acre Park Avenue at Morris County campus in Florham Park.
THE acquisitions reflect the steady appetite investors have for offices. As of May 1, there were 13 transactions, totaling 3.7 million square feet this year, up from 6, totaling 959,000 square feet in the similar period last year, according to Cushman & Wakefield. The 13 sales this year totaled $316 million, against $120 million by May 1, 1996.
Among the factors stoking the activity are the availability of capital, and the increasing demand for offices. That has reduced the vacancy rate over the last year by 3.3 percent to 15.4 percent. Average asking rents also rose, with Class A space at $23.79 a square foot, up from $22.54 a year ago.
New construction remains limited and the cost of buying an existing building averages 25 percent less than the cost of constructing a new one, brokers said.
"There is no indication that investor interest in buying properties will slow in the next 12 to 24 months," said David Csontos, managing director of the Saddle Brook office of Insignia Capital Advisors, the investment sales division of Insignia/ESG, the national commercial brokerage. "But the real question is, is there enough interest from sellers to sell."
Mark Twentyman, a vice president at the Morristown office of Galbreath/Summer, a commercial real estate firm, added that with fewer Class A buildings available investors have been, and will continue, looking for secondary buildings. "The nature of the game is staying ahead of the curve," he said.
A few investors are also buying well-situated industrial or quasi-industrial buildings. Last February, Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust in Melville, L.I., bought such a building, with 200,000 square feet, in Clifton at the intersection of Route 3 and the Garden State Parkway and will turn it into offices.
The former I.B.M. campus, near the intersection of Interstate 287 and Route 208, was closed in 1993 as part of the company's restructuring. At one time it was seriously considered as the site for a housing community for the elderly until the Borough of Franklin Lakes rejected the idea in 1995. While I.B.M. retained the complex, leasing the 60,000 square feet of space to Western World, it continued to search for a buyer.
Mark Yeager, president of Gale & Wentworth Commercial Group, said MSGW I purchased the complex because in a mature market like Bergen County, where there is no new construction, it represents the "only new supply of space." It is also typical of the "value-added" purchases the partners look for, said Mr. Yeager. He described them as well-located, but underutilized, suburban office buildings that can be purchased at or below the replacement cost and improved, adding additional value.
The preference is to lease the former I.B.M. property to fewer than five tenants, each occupying at least 100,000 square feet, because "that is where the market is," added Mr. Yeager. But, he said, the partners also have the flexibility to divide the space into units as small as 50,000 square feet.
The renovation of the complex is to begin this summer and will take two months to complete. It involves upgrading mechanical systems as well as common areas of the property like lobbies and parking lots. Asking rents will be $24 a square foot, Mr. Yeager said.
A similar path was followed at the Cyanamid site. In 1994 when American Home Products, based in Madison, acquired the company, the Wayne property was declared surplus and its "highest, best and quickest reuse was housing," said Peter D. Blanchard, senior vice president at the Garibaldi Group in Chatham. The brokerage marketed the site for American Home Products and continues to do so for Wellsford.
IN 1995, the property was targeted for housing for the elderly, but Wayne township ultimately did not approve the plan. By the time it was put back on the market in the fall of 1996 the office climate had improved and Wellsford, which outbid four other buyers, purchased the site, not far from Route 208 and Interstates 80 and 287.
Richard R. Previdi, Wellsford's chief operating officer, called the purchase "a calculated risk." He said buying at a price that is below "50 percent of the replacement cost" gives his company the opportunity to improve the property and increase its rents.
He said it was also the right time to invest given the firming market in New Jersey where large blocks of space are scarce and there are barriers to new development, including lengthy approval processes and high construction costs.
In its renovations, the company is focusing on the larger of the two buildings, which has 388,000 square feet of space. The work, to be completed this fall, includes the installation of new windows and mechanical systems.
"We are marketing the space to one user or two users max," said Mr. Blanchard, noting that creating large blocks of space will give the property a competitive edge. Rents, though not yet set, "will be below the market," he added.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
Towns Find Credit Cards Don't Always Mean Easy Money

BYLINE: By CARRIE BUDOFF

 BODY:
The credit card program sounded too good to be true for some of New Jersey's cash-strapped municipalities. Without raising taxes, they could raise revenues by earning 1 percent on every credit card purchase made by residents using their town's signature charge card.
Twenty-two municipalities jumped on board, hoping to see the same high returns as South Orange, an Essex County community of 16,390 that pioneered the program in 1994. Since then, the village has raised $60,243, all earmarked for downtown redevelopment. But most towns have been struggling to gain cardholders, let alone duplicate that success. 
 Hillsborough Township is second in revenue, but still lags far behind with $29,045.
Clifton, Paramus and Wall Township have yet to see a dollar. Glassboro, where 194 residents signed up for the borough's card, has raised only $1,142. "I wish I knew what magic South Orange was using," said JoAnne M. Shaefer, chief financial officer for Glassboro. "We would utilize that."
The secret? Show residents the money.
"If they can't see where the money is going, the card is not going to sell," said William R. Calabrese, the Mayor of South Orange.
In the early 1990's, business after business moved from the South Orange shopping district in nearby malls. The remaining stores closed early because the streets were empty by dusk. There were more vacant buildings than occupied ones along South Orange Avenue and adjoining streets.
The economic outlook in South Orange is considerably brighter today, due in large part to the money generated by the credit cards. A total of 26 businesses, including some of the newer shops, have each received a $1,400 matching grant to spruce up their facades or buy new signs. A part-time employee who picks up trash on weekends is paid $8 an hour through the credit card fund. Between 15 and 20 merchants now occupy once-vacant storefronts. There were no bakeries; now there are three. New restaurants and coffee shops have opened.
"Everytime we do something with the card, we make sure people know," said Barbara K. Sacks, chief financial officer of South Orange. "It's reawakened in people a sense of civic pride to take ownership of their downtown."
In Hillsborough, older residents wanted exercise equipment and children needed soccer goal posts. "So far, everyone is pleased with what we purchased," said Randy W. Bahr, chief financial officer. "People like to see that money coming back to the township."
Barnegat also earmarked money toward recreation, but has not seen the same high returns. Judith Capello, chief financial officer, said she thought that the problem was the interest rate of 16.9 percent. "This is not the community to do it in," she said. "It's residential. There is no industry, no business district. It is still growing. Maybe it will be better in the future."
But Ms. Capello is not complaining about the $2,800 the township has earned so far. "It is just easy revenue that we didn't have to do anything for," she said. "The banks sends out the cards. We get the check."
