HEADLINE: Awesome;
In Kids' Pop Culture, Fear Rules

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
Her laugh turned to a moan at the first ripple in her bones. She tensed her thighs and abdomen to will the change on, and clutched the night air like a lover as her fingers lengthened and her nails sprouted. Her blood churned with heat like desire. The night, she thought, sweet night.
-- Jacket blurb for "Blood and Chocolate" by Annette Kurtis Klause, a werewolf novel for 13-year-olds. 
BOY meets she-wolf. She-wolf falls for meat (boy). And parents and educators wonder where, oh where, have Nancy Drew and the Hardy Boys gone?
Terror is stalking children's popular culture.
It lurks in the pages of glossy paperbacks, where bodies dangle from nooses like "heavy ripe fruit" and teens suffer from really serious skin problems, involving ripping, clawing and puddles of blood.
It glows in darkened living rooms where, according to the Nielsen TV ratings, on typical nights more than 1.3 million children below age 11 are watching "The X-Files," the hit occult detective series, and 600,000 wait eagerly for "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" to skewer a throbbing heart.
And last week across the country, in entire multiplexes devoted solely to screenings of the phenomenal blockbuster "The Lost World," it gripped millions of pre-teens in an orgy of primordial mayhem: for starters, the film offered up a picnicking girl as a snack for baby dinosaurs, and raced on to show a frightened innocent performing the gymnastics routine of her young lifetime to escape rampaging velociraptors.
Kids have long enjoyed having the bejeezus scared out of them, but never before have the movie, TV and publishing industries seemed so adept and sophisticated in indulging their dark fascinations. A range of educators and childhood experts cite dead-on production values and marketing savvy as key factors behind a slew of books, TV programs and films that are grittier, scarier, edgier and more violent than ever before. At the same time, they say, it also appears that the audience for kiddy horror is getting younger and younger.
 
Younger Targets

"The opportunities to find scary things are increasing," said Joanne Cantor, a communications professor at the University of Wisconsin in Madison who has studied children's reactions to frightening TV shows and movies for 15 years. With cable TV, she notes, there are more chances for children to happen upon frightening programs. And, she added, even movies marketed as family fare are ratcheting up the terror level.
Referring to the picnic-idyll-turned-nightmare opening of "The Lost World," she said: "My research shows that one of the scariest things for a young child is when a child is a victim. And yet these programs are marketed to the entire family, and kids are begging to get in." The film is rated PG-13, which amounts to a signal to boundary-testing pre-teens that this movie is for them.
In publishing, the youth reading market is dominated by the scores of works by R. L. Stine -- both his "Goosebumps" series, published by Scholastic Books, and his "Fear Street" novels for older, "young adult" readers, published by Pocket Books.
Marilyn Payne Phillips of the University City Library in Missouri says the surfeit of Stine titles leads to younger kids reading inappropriate material. "I have third- and fourth-graders who want to read the books, and they can't distinguish between R. L. Stine writing for children and R. L. Stine writing for young adults," she said. "That's the scary thing to me as a children's librarian." The shelves are also full of Mr. Stine's imitators, and scary spinoffs capitalizing on popular television programs like "The X-Files" and "Tales From the Crypt."
Alice Joinaitis, an editor at Random House of books for young readers, suggests that a form of horror inflation is at play in the visual and print media, explaining that "the world is a more sensational place.
"I don't know how to say this without making it sound terrible," she said, "but we just try to make books as interesting as television, books that are interesting and exciting to read -- and not artifacts of some old, duddy age."
And publishing executives note that, in giving kids what they want, the scary fare is at least enticing reluctant readers to crack open books. But such defenses -- finding justification in the demands of the youth marketplace -- don't wash with some parents, who have led scattered and largely unsuccessful efforts to ban Mr. Stine's books from schools and libraries. Experts on child behavior are worried too.
"I see more and more kids with nightmares in psychotherapy," said Mary Pipher, the author of "Reviving Ophelia: Saving the Selves of Adolescent Girls." "Three-year-olds and 5-year-olds are watching shows like 'The X-Files,' and they're just not ready for the material."
In her research on fright, Professor Cantor noted many reports of children driven into their parents' beds by frightening TV programs. She said one mother complained after her 7-year-old son watched an "X-Files" featuring "a man who had a sore on his stomach that was actually his twin brother who would growl during the day and kill at night."
"The boy woke up in a fit and for a week insisted on sleeping with his parents," Ms. Cantor said.
It is a commonplace of the publishing industry that young boys are the most voracious consumers of fright fiction, but librarians and some publishing executives say girls are actually their chief readers.
"We debate that," said Nancy Pines, a publisher for young readers at Pocket Books. "But we see fan mail for our 'Fear Street' series mostly from girls. I think boys do read them, but if I had to venture a guess I would say it's 60 to 40 for girls."
Some librarians worry about the impact on girls, who are often featured as victims of violence. There are also female characters who can dish out violence as well as take it -- the high-school heroine of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," for example. Are TV portrayals of feminine aptitudes for violence a good thing? A bad thing? Both?
Ms. Pipher advises parents to form small co-operatives to share information about books, films and television programs appropriate for their children. "My grandmother used to tell me to choose your books like your own friends," she said.
Grandma never had friends like these.

HEADLINE: Journal;
Let the Trial Begin!

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
Now that the Supreme Court has spoken, let Bill Clinton's trial begin! There are two vital reasons why it is in the national interest that Paula Jones have her day in court -- and that it be the longest day in court American jurisprudence can provide.
1. The country is bored, desperately bored. No matter that the economy is booming, there's peace abroad and the new welfare law gives us permission to stop worrying about the poor; Americans have been spiraling into depression since O. J. left the stage. What good is guilt-free prosperity if we suffer from entertainment deprivation? 
 Oh sure, the pundits all promised us that the Timothy McVeigh trial would fill that vacuum, but what a sadly bitter bust it has turned out to be. Efficient, brief, professional, untelevised and possibly even just, it is enough to leave anyone bemoaning the fallen state of a legal system whose ability to generate months of riveting soap opera was only yesterday the envy of the civilized world.
Despite some promising tabloid headlines, no other case is rushing in to fill the vacuum. Up in Massachusetts, a baby sitter is letting sleeping Kennedys lie. The air went out of the Marv Albert scandal once the Arlington police refused to strip the defendant of his rug for his mug shot. Nor, it seems, is there any great public clamor for Frank and Kathie Lee Gifford to take their marital troubles to court. A trial would only guarantee still more air time for the overexposed Kathie Lee -- not to mention the blinding prospect that she might be interviewed on CBS by the one TV personality who can match her in aggressive perkiness and on-camera baby-wielding, Susan Molinari.
With such a parched summer ahead, is it any wonder that the nation is reduced to watching "The Lost World"? The only entertainment alternatives are to attend museum exhibitions about the dinosaurs of "The Lost World" or to stay home and watch TV news reports about the weekend grosses of "The Lost World."
2. The President needs to give his second term some "distinguishing characteristics." Far from being too busy to go to trial, as his lawyers ineffectually argued to the Court, Mr. Clinton is clearly a man in need of a mission -- and one that might actually be of benefit to the nation.
The last time the President earned his keep was during his last State of the Union Address, when his avalanche of empty promises offered a tranquilizing diversion during the excruciating wait for the verdict in the O. J. civil trial. Since then, the education President has negotiated a balanced budget that offers not a penny to rebuild the nation's decrepit public schools. What's more, the anti-tobacco, pro-childhood-development President secured his empty budget deal by killing a bipartisan measure that would have raised cigarette taxes to buy poor children health care.
Now Mr. Clinton is shifting from the disingenuous to the nonsensical. Ten days ago, when Hillary Clinton and Tipper Gore played host to the editors of women's magazines, fashion magazines included, at the White House, the President gave a speech decrying the fashion world's "heroin chic" -- but to a meeting of mayors in another room. It's bad enough that the anti-drug President can't stand up to Mexico -- a far bigger source of our current drug woes than a grotesque fashion fad that's run its course -- but to the editor of Vogue?
Equally odd was the President's proposal the next day for a V-chip to regulate porn on the infinite sites of the Internet, just as it's dawning on the public that his election-year gimmick of a ratings-driven V-chip can't even regulate the few dozen channels on TV. And what about Mr. Clinton's hollow call to develop an AIDS vaccine within a decade? Though the President likened his own speech to John Kennedy's 1961 call for putting a man on the moon, he, unlike his predecessor, put no money on the table. The real historical analogue is Richard Nixon, whose sweeping 1971 declaration of a war on cancer has left cancer death rates virtually unchanged in the 26 years since.
If Mr. Clinton isn't going to do anything else worthwhile, it behooves him to go to trial and at least fulfill his solemn obligation to entertain the country. If he decides to shirk this duty, too, by settling out of court, then let the televised impeachment begin.

HEADLINE: Clinton, at West Point, Says Bigger NATO Lessens Chance of War

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WEST POINT, N.Y., May 31

 BODY:
President Clinton told graduating West Point cadets today that the mere prospect of NATO's expansion into the former Soviet bloc had increased stability in Europe and decreased the chances that they "will ever be called to fight in another war across the Atlantic."
Mr. Clinton's commencement address at the United States Military Academy served as a coda to his trip this week to Europe, where he promised that the United States would remain engaged on the Continent. In Paris on Tuesday he and other NATO leaders signed a cooperation and security pact with Russia that opened a new chapter in the post-World War II history of Europe. 
 The Russia-NATO agreement paves the way for the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization to begin the process of taking in new members from Eastern and Central Europe at a summit meeting in Madrid in July.
With his speech today, Mr. Clinton stepped up a campaign to make sure that the Senate supports the extension of formal security guarantees to former Soviet bloc nations when it is called upon to approve the arrangement sometime next year.
But the President did not address the question that has left the United States at odds with many of its own allies: How many nations should be invited in the first round to join the alliance. While the United States supports the entry of the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland, a majority of NATO members want the expansion in July to include Slovenia and Romania as well.
On a hazy day, with the uniformed cadets arrayed in front of him in the academy's Michie Stadium, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that the addition of new members to the alliance was not "cost- or risk-free."
He told the graduates that NATO was extending its "most solemn security pledge," which means "that you could be asked to put your lives on the line for a new NATO member, just as today you can be called upon to defend the freedom of our allies in Western Europe."
But he said he was convinced the "gains decisively outweigh the burdens" of bringing former Warsaw Pact nations under the security umbrella of the West. He said the enlargement would strengthen NATO for the future, cement democracy's gains in Central Europe and eliminate the dividing line of the cold war.
"The bottom line to me is clear," he said. "Expanding NATO will enhance our security. It is the right thing to do. We must not fail history's challenge at this moment to build a Europe peaceful, democratic, undivided, allied with us to face the new security threats of a new century."
He said the prospect of joining NATO had already led fledgling democracies emerging from Communism to deepen democratic reforms, put their militaries under civilian control and open their economies. He said Central and Eastern European nations had also settled more than half a dozen ethnic and border disputes.
"That in turn makes it less likely that you will ever be called to fight in another war across the Atlantic," he said, drawing loud applause.
He added that the alliance was strengthened by adding new members and pointed to the fact that American troops in Bosnia had been deployed from a staging ground in Hungary.
Mr. Clinton took issue with critics who say the expansion is not ending cold war divisions but simply creating a new line across Europe closer to Russia's borders.
"NATO's first members should not be its last," he said. "NATO's doors will remain open to all those willing and able to shoulder the responsibilities of membership."

HEADLINE: Southeast Asia Bloc Admits Burmese and Two Others

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 31

 BODY:
Defying the wishes of the United States and brushing aside concerns over human rights abuses, the Southeast Asian political and economic bloc known as Asean announced today that it would embrace Myanmar as a member this year.
The announcement, at a meeting of the bloc's foreign ministers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, came after months of debate and lobbying and was a significant gesture in defining the political philosophy of the region, one of the world's fastest growing economically. 
 The seven-member group, formally the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, agreed to expand its ranks to include three new members: Myanmar, formerly Burma; Laos, with its tiny and isolated economy, and Cambodia, where political infighting is raising new fear of national disintegration.
Despite doubts about the political or economic readiness of all three nations, there has been strong pressure within the bloc to enlist them, thereby expanding to include all 10 nations of the region at the group's 30th anniversary meeting in July.
The three nations had been admitted in November as observers, but their acceptance as full members remained in question until today.
"It was unanimous," said Foreign Minister Abdullah Badawi of Malaysia, describing what appeared to have been a hard-won consensus. "There were no reservations on the part of any Asean member."
The United States had lobbied against the admission of Myanmar, citing a continuing record of "severe repression" by the military Government. The United States imposed economic sanctions on Myanmar this month.
Its admission, as well, came despite a plea, in a smuggled videotape, from the leader of Myanmar's democratic opposition, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. She said in the tape that Asean's endorsement would make Myanmar's military leaders "even more obdurate and oppressive."
In recent months, Myanmar's Government has severely restricted the activities of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, a winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, and arrested a number of her supporters. Today's step was taken in the midst of a crackdown in which the opposition says that more than 300 members of her National League for Democracy have been detained.
They say the detentions -- which the Government denies -- appear to have been aimed at preventing a convention meant to mark the seventh anniversary of a general election in 1990 that was won by Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's party, but annulled by the military leadership.
Though there has been debate within Asean, the announcement today marked a success by its most influential members, Indonesia and Malaysia, and their philosophy of "constructive engagement."
The other members of the bloc are Thailand, Singapore, the Philippines, Brunei and Vietnam, which was admitted two years ago.
The constructive engagement approach involves a hands-off policy toward the "internal affairs" of other nations and the primacy of economic relationships over political and human rights concerns. It flies in the face of the American approach -- by which, to varying degrees in different situations -- economic engagement is linked with issues of political freedom, labor rights, environmental policy and measures to combat drug trafficking.
Political analysts said that one reason for today's action was an assertion of regional autonomy, and they suggested that public pressure from the United States might have backfired with such independent-minded leaders as Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore and President Suharto of Indonesia.
"To save face, Asean will have to admit Burma," Foreign Minister Surapong Jayanama of Thailand had said earlier this month.
At a Senate hearing last week, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said, "We have tried very hard to get the Asean countries to follow our steps, but they don't seem to be interested in it."
Asked today whether the announcement was a signal to the West that the region would not brook outside pressure, Mr. Badawi of Malaysia replied: "It was not a signal. We signal to nobody."
Southeast Asian leaders have also expressed concern that antagonistic actions like the economic sanctions against Myanmar just imposed by the United States could push it into a closer alliance with China, whose growing power and assertiveness are a big source of regional concern.
Political analysts agree that the sanctions themselves are largely symbolic, given the vigorous economic involvement of Myanmar's Southeast Asian neighbors in the country.
On Friday, after the United States imposed the sanctions, Myanmar announced that it had signed a broad economic and trade agreement with Beijing, further consolidating a growing network of ties with the Chinese, to the north.
By admitting Myanmar to Asean, Foreign Minister Ali Alatas of Indonesia said, "we are also taking into account the overall long-term consideration of peace and security and tranquillity in our part of the world."
"By having all three enter Asean, we are complete now," he added. "And we are in a better position to contribute to peace and stability in our region."
Asean was founded at the height of the Vietnam War in 1967, when there were fears that Communism might spread through an economically struggling region.
Since then, much of Southeast Asia has transformed itself into a capitalist showcase, with some of the fastest-growing economies in the world.
The region's nations have, in general, worked out a successful system of relationships based on consensus that permits for a range of political systems, from the freewheeling democracy of the Philippines to the authoritarian controls of Singapore and Indonesia to the lingering Communist strictures of Vietnam.

HEADLINE: For Families, Trial Leaves Haunting Questions

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER, May 31

 BODY:
As the trial of Timothy J. McVeigh drew to a close, leaving the jury to deliberate whether he set off the bomb that killed 168 people in Oklahoma City two years ago, many relatives of the victims watched the proceedings from 500 miles away, over closed-circuit televisions at the Mike Monroney Aeronautical Center in Oklahoma City.
For some, that was much too far away. 
 Since the first hearing in the case was held more than 14 months ago, Oklahomans have lined up in a steady stream as early as 3 A.M. to claim a seat in the second-floor Federal courtroom here. The group includes at least four victims' relatives who have scarcely missed a session.
"I wanted to see everything that happens -- I wanted to hear everything that happens," said Charles Tomlin, whose 46-year-old son, Rick, an enforcement officer for the Federal Transportation Department, was killed in the blast. "I had also wanted to know why. I wanted to look up and see McVeigh, a nice-looking man, and try to understand what drove him to kill this many people."
Did he succeed?
"I never got answers to those questions," he said.
Mr. Tomlin, 69, a retired elevator supervisor with the Continental Grain Company, has been staying with a brother who lives in Aurora, Colo., a suburb just east of Denver. Each day he drives his brother's truck to and from the Federal Courthouse, in downtown Denver, and keeps his three brothers and four sisters apprised of events, using a free telephone service set up for relatives and friends of the victims.
Over the months, Mr. Tomlin said, he has come to know other victims' relatives who have attended most of the court sessions, including Marsha Kight, who lost her 22-year-old daughter, Frankie Ann Merrell; Jannie Coverdale, whose two grandsons, Aaron, 5, and Elijah, 2, were killed, and Roy Sells, whose wife, Leora Lee, 57, was killed.
In addition to the regulars, at least a dozen other relatives of victims have sat in the courtroom; a lottery system awarded space for 12 relatives each week.
Dan McKinney, who lost his wife, Linda, 47, a Secret Service agent, and a niece, Shelly Turner Bland, 25, an employee of the Drug Enforcement Agency, said he had come to Denver only because his daughter had won a lottery seat and offered it to him.
At first, he declined. "This has been too painful for me," said Mr. McKinney, who had been married 3 years, 3 months and 28 days at the time of the blast. "I've been a bundle of nerves for two years.
"I came with so much anxiety, anger, pain and frustration," Mr. McKinney said. "But now that I've been here and heard firsthand all the evidence, it has helped me a lot."
Like Mr. Tomlin, Mr. McKinney said he believed that Mr. McVeigh was guilty. Yet he, too, said the trial had left questions unanswered.
"I'd like to ask him about statements he made about hating the Government so much he wanted to change it," Mr. McKinney said, referring to witnesses who testified that Mr. McVeigh had been outraged when about 80 people died in a siege of the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex., four years ago. "I want to tell him that you could blow up every Federal Building in the country, and it's not going to change our system one bit."
Another Oklahoman wanted to tell Mr. McVeigh something. Ann McVey came here this week with her husband, Bill, and when she walked into court, she turned toward the defendant and told him exactly what she thought of him. And what was that?
"I can't say it," Mrs. McVey said soberly, acknowledging that her comments had included offensive language. "I felt like I had to get it over with. I needed to see Timothy McVeigh in person and say to him what I thought about him. And I did."
Mrs. McVey, a state economic developer who worked in a building adjacent to the one destroyed by the blast, the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, was hurt when a door flew off its hinges and hit her in the head.
She said that ever since Mr. McVeigh had been charged with the bombing, she and her husband had felt the need to apologize for their name "every time we introduce ourselves."
The similarity continues to haunt her. "My injuries have healed," Mrs. McVey said. "My emotions have gotten better. But, still, it's like opening up a new wound every time I hear his name, and it's the same as our name."

HEADLINE: The Clinton Conundrum

 BODY:
As the first summer of Bill Clinton's second term approaches, that peculiar mixture of the admirable and degrading continues to distinguish his Presidency. How else to describe the twin spectacles of last week? There was Mr. Clinton, elder statesman baby boomer, confidently bantering with Prime Minister Tony Blair in London and rewriting the political map of Europe, even while becoming more enmeshed at home in what surely are the most lurid accusations ever directed against a sitting President. The American economic boom is helping to keep Mr. Clinton's approval ratings at an all-time high, yet a sense of personal scandal makes this a Presidency constantly on the edge.
The precarious feeling about this White House derives partly from what the office has become. The historian Michael Beschloss says that Mr. Clinton's Presidency may be a reversion to something more common in the 19th century, when Presidential success depended on cooperating with, and often yielding to, a powerful Congress. The modern Presidency was elevated by two developments, he says -- the expanding Federal Government and the central role of the cold war in American thought. With both these factors now in eclipse, the Presidency seems to be shrinking, as does any individual executive's ability to dominate the national consciousness with security issues or to transform the lives of Americans with domestic reform. Mr. Clinton tried at least some of that in his first two years, by declaring that he would complete the New Deal and Great Society in health care. The ensuing debacle insured that the rest of his time in office would consist of emotionally unsatisfying mini-steps. 
 The highly partisan nature of the political landscape in Washington has also clouded the perception of the Presidency and its capability. Fifty years ago, the last time the United States had a Democratic President and Republican Congress, President Truman confronted his foes and then took his case to the people. Mr. Clinton used confrontation in 1995, but has now achieved a remarkable parliamentary majority that has brought progress toward a balanced budget and the first arms control agreement to win Senate approval in many years. Whether you agree with the results or not, it is obvious that this President is as skillful as any in modern times in finding and occupying the political center of gravity -- at least for certain moments in a campaign or legislative battle.
Fortune magazine has declared this month that the United States economy is stronger than it has ever been before. Since Mr. Clinton would get much of the blame if it failed, he is entitled to claim some of the credit. On a practical level, prosperity is probably his greatest shield against scandal. There is much of this Presidency that remains admirable above and beyond the blessings of good times. Mr. Clinton's actions on trade, budget policy, gun control, the environment, tobacco and affirmative action are impressive. We wish he showed more backbone on welfare, insisting on the means to employ the people who may be kicked off the rolls in what is probably the scariest instance of social engineering toward the poor in our time.
But it is not disagreement on such policy issues that creates the mutable, muddled feelings that surround Mr. Clinton. The ragged edge of Mr. Clinton's Presidency, its novelistic quality, has to do with the outsized character questions dogging him since 1992. What he did while Governor of Arkansas, in a hotel room or with a failed real estate deal, does not of course directly relate to his accomplishments. Just the same, if talk show banter is any guide, the public remains troubled and confused by the President's behavior -- riveted and wanting to averts its eyes at the same time. History will have a hard time defining the emotional complexity of many people's reactions to a man of such remarkable talents that he is almost like a great athlete at the top of his game, and yet flawed by lack of discipline, by self-pity, defensiveness, a volcanic temper and being too eager to please.
The President may never be able to fix this undercurrent of concern. Recently, Senator Bob Dole summed it up well when he called the President a "likable rogue" who is "always pushing the envelope." If Mr. Clinton were truly to center himself in the hearts of Americans, he would have to come clean over what happened with Paula Corbin Jones, reaching a settlement in the best interests of all involved, not to mention the country, cooperate fully with the Whitewater and related investigations and put these issues as well behind him. That he has handled these personal and legal crises so badly while doing some parts of his job so well is part of the drama -- indeed, the psychodrama of the Clinton Presidency. It also helps explain why a country basking in prosperity cannot shake a lingering wariness about the gifted but imperfect and uncandid man in the White House.

HEADLINE: Child-Care Solutions in a New World of Welfare

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
At the knee-high white plastic table in a living room crammed with toys and books, Tanya Holmes dealt out sheets of paper imprinted with letters of the alphabet and crayons to color them.
 "Breana," Ms. Holmes said, "I'm going to give you purple. Tashad, you get green." Lavonte Briggs, 4, asked, "Can I have blue?"
Ms. Holmes ran these children like clocks, from coloring and counting to a stomping, tambourine-thumping rendition of "B.I.N.G.O." 
 "You've got to have a routine so they know what's next," Ms. Holmes said. "Routine is a key word in day care."
Ms. Holmes, a robust and exuberant 22-year-old single mother who tends to children in her home, could hold another key, one that may be vital to solving a vexing question for the new world of welfare: As parents are pushed into the work force, who will take care of their children?
A promising answer, say many states, is licensing the kind of service that parents like Ms. Holmes provide, known as family day care.
To grant the license, states must be assured that the children are safe and well cared for and that they are being prepared for school. In return, Illinois pays Ms. Holmes up to $90.65 a week per child for the five or six children she normally cares for, with an assistant.
There is another important benefit: For former welfare recipients like Ms. Holmes, child care is a ticket off public assistance. In allowing women to earn a living by caring for the children of others, the states both create jobs for welfare mothers and pave the way for the mothers of the children they keep to go to work.
"They get a two-fer," said Wendell E. Primus of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research group in Washington.
While it is too soon to measure the new welfare law's effect on family day care, Illinois, which already has more than 9,000 providers of day care like Tanya Holmes, is expanding the service. Among other things, it has begun a program to train mothers at Cabrini Green, Chicago's big housing project.
Nationwide, in part because of earlier programs to encourage recipients to work, the number of homes licensed to care for children climbed to 299,000 last year from 193,000 in 1988, according to the Children's Foundation, a research organization in Washington.
But licensed family care is eventually unlikely to meet the expected demand, child-care advocates warn. They predict that late next year, as the welfare law's mandate to work reaches the majority of the nation's four million welfare families, and as more of the working poor seek day care for their children, some parents will be left without any care. This, in turn, could encourage wider use of unqualified child-care providers.
In Chicago, as in some other big cities, an acute shortage of child care is already developing, confronting mothers with the agonizing choice of earning a paycheck while leaving their children untended or staying at home and losing their welfare check.
But states say it is in their own best interest to make the welfare overhaul work so that parents will not have to make such choices. The welfare law gives the states $4 billion more in Federal support for child care over the next six years than they would have had otherwise, and many states are increasing their own spending beyond that.
A bustling economy has been a big help. In generating more and more jobs for everyone, the economy has helped drive down the number of welfare recipients and thus the costs of supporting them.
This has produced a windfall for states by freeing money from cash assistance programs and matching Federal welfare grants. In his budget proposal for the next fiscal year, Gov. Jim Edgar of Illinois, a Republican, is asking for $350 million for child care, $70 million more than this year. New Jersey is doubling its spending for child care over two years.
New York, Minnesota, Oregon and North Carolina are making similar uses of their savings from declining welfare recipients. Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, a Republican, is raising the state's child-care subsidies enough so that a low-wage family's cost of care comes to no more than 16 percent of its income.
For many states, licensed family care has become a workable and cost-efficient compromise between day-care centers and the largely unregulated care of baby sitters.
For one reason, it is convenient. Unlike the typical day-care center, Ms. Holmes's home is just doors from those of many welfare recipients, so they can walk their children over. And it is relatively inexpensive. In cities like New York, Chicago and Boston, normal day care for just one child can cost as much as the $190 that a minimum-wage worker earns in a week, or more than twice the cost of Ms. Holmes's care.
For child-care providers like Ms. Holmes, nearly all states require training, and they oversee the homes, with regulators typically stopping in unannounced.
Connecticut, for example, lets a licensed provider take in six preschool children, though no more than two infants, and the provider must have a high school diploma or 540 hours of experience as a child-care aide.
Georgia requires one worker, a high school graduate, to care for three children up to 1 year old and two workers to watch up to six children. Delaware requires that providers have considerable preparation beyond high school, for example, a college degree in child development or six months' experience.
Still, states' redoubled support of child care has not gone far enough in cities like Chicago, with high concentrations of welfare-recipient job seekers, in part because of the crunch of the working poor who are also seeking day care.
The welfare law requires that recipients be working within two years and terminates their cash assistance in five, so by then they must be able to support themselves and their children. The result here is severe shortages of low-cost day-care workers and centers to handle a load that by all accounts is rapidly increasing.
"We get 110 calls a month for two openings a month," said Thomas F. Layman, director of the government- and charity-supported North Avenue Day Nursery on the West Side of Chicago. North Avenue enrolls 175 in its day-care center and eight licensed-care homes.
Barbara Jacob, family services manager at the Lutheran Family Mission, which operates three centers and oversees the mission's 186 family care providers, said, "We tell them it's going to be a year or two years before we can take their child."
Faced with day-care shortages, Illinois like most states lets parents turn to the inexpensive, unregulated, sometimes indifferent, care provided by a neighbor or relative.
The state asks the child's parent and the child-care provider to sign a form stating that the day-care home is safe, with guns and poisons locked up, and that no one there abuses children. In return, the state pays the child keeper $8.98 a day per child. For the child-care providers who are on welfare, the state counts their service as work, permitting them to keep their benefits.
But even as it subsidizes programs like this one, the state actually goes no further than that in regulating them. "Nobody looks at the home except the mother," said Michele Piel, manager of child-care development at the Illinois Department of Public Aid.
In a study two years ago, the Families and Work Institute, a research group in New York, determined that only 9 percent of such informal arrangements in several cities provided good quality care.
"This is make-do tripe," said Marie C. Wilson, president of the MS Foundation for Women, which is sponsoring programs to train people to become licensed child-care providers. "Look at what it does for a field we are trying to upgrade. It implies that anyone can do it."
Ms. Holmes, by contrast, received training for four months last year at one of the Lutheran Family Mission's day-care centers. "I went 3 times a week," she said, "9 to 12."
In the vestibule of Ms. Holmes's duplex, everyone, children and visitors, must take off their shoes. Ms. Holmes uses the parlor and adjoining room for most of her work. The walls are covered with shelves with books, toys, tapes of children's songs, plastic musical instruments and instructional materials.
Ms. Jacob of the mission said: "She's a real active provider. She really does her curriculum and different types of learning things we want for the children."
Like all the states' licensed providers, Ms. Holmes and her assistant, Shanda Dortch, 20, work under some supervision. The Department of Public Aid, which licenses her, sends an inspector once a year. The Federal Department of Agriculture, which provides the children's meals, visits once a year without warning to check on her kitchen.
Day-care managers from the mission and another, similar service, Chicago Commons, visit once a month, sometimes unannounced. They also telephone. "They'll ask if there's anything I need," Ms. Holmes said, "or they check on the status of a particular child."
In return, the mission and Chicago Commons refer the children of working welfare mothers and of the working poor and pay the providers state-subsidized fees of $90.65 a week to care for children under 2 1/2 years old and $66.50 a week for older children. On a scale based on incomes, the children's parents reimburse the state from 25 cents of the cost up to $62 a week. Ms. Holmes has one private client who pays $85 a week.
This produces an income of about $24,000 a year, Ms. Holmes said. But as an independent contractor, she must pay her assistant and her taxes and buy most of her equipment. The assistant is paid the minimum wage of $4.75 an hour.
Ms. Holmes does not pay rent because her mother, who lives downstairs, owns the house.
She said she is relieved to be free of the dole but does not expect to live much better than she does now. "If you are going to do child care," Ms. Holmes said, "you have to do it for the kids. Don't do it for the money."

HEADLINE: In French Race, Economy Will Sour the Victor's Future

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 31

 BODY:
Francois Barbey, unemployed like 12.8 percent of the rest of the French working-age population, plans to vote for President Jacques Chirac's conservatives Sunday in the decisive round of the French parliamentary elections. But he says he fears that social and economic turbulence will lie ahead no matter who wins.
"The only way France will ever get going again is by joining the global economy," Mr. Barbey said, "with a common European currency that will enable our economies to stand up to the dollar and compete effectively with big American companies." 
 "But we have been spoiled for so long by the welfare state that no party is capable of getting people to make the sacrifices required for this," added Mr. Barbey, 55, who lives in the working-class Paris suburb Fontenay-sous-Bois. "It may take a civil war to get people to face reality. Things will have to blow up."
On the eve of the vote, polls showed the opposition Socialist Party, which has been out of power since 1993, within reach of a dramatic comeback that could put its leader, Lionel Jospin, in the Prime Minister's office next week.
That is not what Mr. Chirac had in mind when, seeking a mandate for the deficit-cutting required to get France into the common European currency in 1999, he called this election a year before the end of the legislative term.
The conservatives could still salvage a victory from their disastrous showing of less than 30 percent in last Sunday's first round, a result that forced Prime Minister Alain Juppe to say he would step down. But even if they do, the possibility of economic and political deadlock over the next five years has increased dramatically, with far-reaching implications for Europe as well.
Mr. Chirac now appears condemned to a result that will make it more difficult to pursue the austerity policies on which Germany and the European Union bureaucracy have been insisting to get the currency off to a strong start.
But Germany is having as much trouble as France in getting its budget deficit down to the required limit. And bankers and money market speculators are saying that the currency project might be delayed, or the currency itself watered down, unless things change.
Even without the goad of the euro, as the common currency is called, Mr. Chirac has said repeatedly that reductions in the deficit and lower taxes are necessary to get the economy into the 21st century.
But all the likely candidates to replace Mr. Juppe, including the conservatives, having heard the message that fed-up voters sent last Sunday, are now united in promising to make jobs a bigger priority.
Mr. Juppe, the personification of the impersonal European technocrat to many French voters, tried to cut back the welfare system and trim budget deficits to qualify France for membership in the currency plan. But he had to back off from his boldest step after a five-week national transportation strike at the end of 1995. He had sought to make engineers in the state rail system work past the age of 50 before retiring at nearly full pay.
As Serge Dassault, the French aviation magnate, put it, "The drama in France, and in the end the drama for the right, is that liberalism has never been tried here." He was referring to the kind of market capitalism that the United States and Britain are familiar with but that France has always resisted, with state intervention.
"Bureaucratic, labor-union, tax and financial constraints weigh too heavily on business executives," Mr. Dassault told the daily Le Figaro. "Anyone who hires people is paralyzed later if he can't let them go. So it's simple -- he prefers not to hire."
Philippe Seguin is campaigning as if he had Mr. Chirac's blessing to become Prime Minister if the conservatives win on Sunday. He took with him, wherever he went this week, France's leading free-marketeer, Alain Madelin, whom Mr. Juppe dismissed as Finance Minister after only three months in 1995. Mr. Madelin had wanted to make big cuts in pay and benefit plans for millions of French state employees whose jobs are guaranteed for life.
Mr. Jospin's Socialist platform makes no promises about cutting Government spending or trying to cap welfare payments to get France's deficit down to the limit of 3 percent of gross domestic product by the end of this year, as required by the Treaty on European Union in 1992.
"We are on the verge of an event that is going to astound Europe and raise magnificent hopes in Europe," Mr. Jospin said this week, meaning that a Socialist victory would breathe new hope into the left all over the Continent.
But the French Socialists and Communists also say they want the European currency criteria loosened so they can create 700,000 new jobs, half of them in the private sector, and get both Italy and Spain into the project from the outset. French textile manufacturers and agricultural producers fear that a strong European currency with France in and Italy and Spain out would enable those countries to undersell France on world markets.
An opinion poll taken three days before the election and published in the Swiss daily Tribune de Geneve predicted that the Socialists could win 283 votes in the 577-seat legislature on Sunday, nearly enough to govern by themselves. They would have a majority if the Communists won the 32 votes predicted by the poll, which forecast 260 seats for the conservatives.
But the Communists differ with the Socialists on several important issues. For example, they insist that the workweek be reduced immediately, with no cut in salaries, to 35 hours from 39, where Mr. Jospin has proposed to introduce the reduction over five years.
For the conservatives, Mr. Seguin says he wants to create jobs by lifting the burdens that France's state-run health and retirement pension systems place on employers, who pay about two-thirds of the cost of those programs in payroll taxes while employees pay the other third. But he does not say he will cut any of the benefits -- only that he will somehow find other ways of paying for them.
On the euro, he said the other night, "I will never go back on what France has put its signature to," even though he opposed the common currency plan in a closely fought referendum in 1992.
"All our obligations will be scrupulously fulfilled," he said, "but we will say clearly what's on our minds -- that is, to give the European central bank system the primordial assignment of favoring economic growth and jobs instead of monetary stability alone."
There is nothing in the European Union treaty to prevent Mr. Chirac, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and other European leaders from being flexible when they meet next spring to decide which countries are close to meeting the budget deficit criteria, laid down by central bankers led by the Germans.
But German leaders have not yet convinced voters in their country that the euro would be as sound as the mark, which most Germans believe brought them prosperity after it was established in 1948. And they have steadfastly resisted all attempts by the French or anybody else to let the new currency be more malleable, for example by allowing it to cost less in dollars than the Germans would like it to.
Opposition politicians both left and right have suggested that if the left wins on Sunday, Mr. Chirac should draw the consequences and retire, as his political mentor, de Gaulle, did after a similar fiasco in a referendum in 1969.

HEADLINE: One Teacher's Struggle To Encourage Tolerance;
In This Third-Grade Class, the Curriculum Includes Reading, Writing and Respect

SERIES: ROOM 3-223: Getting Along

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
Daniel Hessel thought he was being helpful when he urged a fellow third grader to put away his toys one afternoon in April.
It was a time when they were supposed to be working on their science projects. But the boy startled Daniel by telling him to mind his own business, capping his admonition with an insult. 
 "He called me a white bitch," said Daniel, whose parents are Polish immigrants.
For Daniel's teacher, Ted Kesler, the remark -- like others that have singled out students for their hair or skin color or accent -- was a sad reminder that preparing his pupils for the fourth grade and beyond entails more than just teaching them how to read and multiply.
Mr. Kesler has also struggled to teach them to avoid bigotry and to be wary of the sharp cut of some words. If they do not learn those lessons at age 8 or 9, Mr. Kesler fears, they may never learn them.
As Daniel put it one day: "Everyone knows we'll have to work with different kinds of people when we're adults. I think that the time to learn how to do it is while we're still in school."
But the lessons have not always come easily to the 30 inhabitants of Room 3-223 of Public School 75 in Manhattan. Even with the end of the school year just four weeks away, Mr. Kesler has been scrambling to retool his strategy. He has found, for instance, that using examples from literature to provide models of open-minded behavior has not been enough. So recently he has tried to coax his students to go out of their way to be kind to each other, by inviting someone to jump rope or by giving a compliment.
Yet Mr. Kesler says he is aware that the underlying tensions between his students originate far beyond the classroom and that many confront prejudice every day, whether on the subway, in a store or in their neighborhoods.
The classroom, he says, offers a perfect laboratory for them to learn how to deal with diversity. A third of Mr. Kesler's students are first-generation Americans whose parents were born in Haiti, Bangladesh, India, Egypt, Poland, Jamaica, Costa Rica and the Dominican Republic. Of his students, 11 are black, 7 are Hispanic, 7 are white, 2 are Asian and 3 are of mixed race. Mr. Kesler, 35, is the son of Eastern European immigrants, both Holocaust survivors.
The students are varied in their economic standing, as well. Some live in a nearby housing project, the Frederick Douglass Houses, others in majestic co-ops on Riverside Drive.
Much of the time, Room 3-223 is a fairly harmonious place. Simone Rivera, 9, said she felt comfortable enough in class to answer honestly when another girl, Caroline Sepulveda, asked her if she had both a mother and father at home. "I said, 'No,' " Simone recalled the other night, her mother at her side. "She said, 'Why?' So I told her, 'Because my mom is gay.' "
And Hillary Fertig, the class's 23-year-old student teacher, who attended only Jewish day schools and yeshivas until age 18, said she was greeted enthusiastically when she asked several black students to teach her the rap song they were singing. "I said, 'I'm white. Do you think I can sing it the same way as you?' " Ms. Fertig recalled. "They said, 'Of course.' "
But sometimes, the students demonstrate flashes of intolerance.
Ms. Fertig said that she once watched a Hispanic girl snatch a book from a classmate, saying, "You can't touch it because you're black." Jyoti Sharma, who has picked up many of the vocal cadences of her parents' native India, said a classmate had derided her accent as "weird."
And Seiji Iino said a boy had called him a "nigger" in the lunchroom. "He doesn't even know what it means," concluded Seiji, whose family is from Japan and Austria.
Other students say they have been taunted, not because of their race, but for other perceived weaknesses. Christopher Barrett, an excellent basketball player who is 3 feet 9 inches tall, said he had been hurt by the catcalls of girls during games at recess. They call him Shorty.
Throughout the year, Mr. Kesler sought to eradicate his pupils' biases by presenting them with role models and road maps for how best to get along. The books he has read to them feature main characters who are about their age, but whose backgrounds are mixed.
The protagonist of "J. T." is a 10-year-old boy who lives in a Harlem tenement. "Sadako and the Thousand Paper Cranes" is about a 12-year-old Japanese girl. ". . . And Now Miguel" tells the story of a shepherd boy in New Mexico.
"I choose these books first and foremost for the quality of the writing," Mr. Kesler said. "But I also want them to see that kids from all over have the same concerns, the same struggles."
Poetry, too, has figured prominently, and the students have often recited the poem, "If They Hate Me," by Arnold Adoff: "If they hate me they are sick and hurt and need some kind of help. I will stay right here."
Whenever a flash point arose, Mr. Kesler spoke with those involved in the hallway, then brought the lesson back before the class. "You're not allowed to call people names," he has told them more than once.
By keeping a firm hand on the students, Mr. Kesler said he believed he was keeping the peace. Until he saw how his class behaved when they thought he was not around. One morning in early May, during a free period when he was supposed to be outside the room, Mr. Kesler watched in disbelief as his students made it impossible for a substitute teacher to give them a math lesson.
"Out of my way!" one boy bellowed at another as he stormed from his seat, unaware that Mr. Kesler was working in a far corner. "He said that because he's stupid!" a girl shouted after a classmate gave a wrong answer. And, in a brazen attempt to distract the teacher, a boy tumbled headfirst over a bench, dissolving the room in laughter.
Unable to watch any further, Mr. Kesler called his class to order.
"I see we need to do a lot more work about learning to get along, about caring, about treating people the way we wanted to be treated," he told his charges.
At that moment, Mr. Kesler says, he realized that the helpful tips he was doling out sporadically, in an effort to build respect for others, paled in contrast to the intensive effort he was devoting to other subjects. He also discovered he was not giving his students a chance to practice what they had learned.
"I realized that it's not enough to just model good behavior for them," Mr. Kesler said. "I realized they need the same rigorous training in it as they do in social studies, as they do in math, as they do in reading."
And so, over the next few days, he made some changes.
Before, when it was time to line up for lunch, Mr. Kesler permitted the students to choose their own partners. The result: the white pupils tended to pick the white students, the black students the blacks. Now Mr. Kesler assigns the partners, making sure they do not know each other well. Initially, he said, watching the pairs find common ground was like "watching George and Elaine try to talk on 'Seinfeld.' "
"They were groping in the dark," he said. It is still awkward. But sports talk, particularly for the boys, has proven an icebreaker.
Mr. Kesler has also set aside time each day for the children to devise at least five "put-ups," compliments for classmates that are the opposite of "put-downs." They then share them, as if sending out song dedications on a radio station.
"I have one for Shanee," Lizbee Collins-Wildman said the other day. "I think she's a great group member."
For additional help, Mr. Kesler has again turned to literature, but this time to an unlikely author: Dear Abby. Last week, to illustrate the concept of "random acts of kindness," Mr. Kesler read a letter from a woman who described how a family of strangers had driven her 240 miles from an airport to a hospital to visit her sister, who was critically ill. Never mind, the writer told Abby, that she is white and the strangers were black. "They saw a person in desperate need," she wrote.
Now, every day, the students must share random niceties that people have done for them, and that they have done for others.
Is the new strategy working?
It's only been a few weeks, but Mr. Kesler says he thinks he sees progress. Last Friday at recess, for example, seven boys who had never really played together chased each other around for a game of tag. But on the same day, a girl balked at pairing up to take a spelling test with an unfamiliar classmate, saying, "She's so stupid."
Seiji says he has noticed one marked difference: the boys who play basketball each day at recess, most of whom are black, have been welcoming him into their game lately. But he says some of his classmates still act up outside the range of their teacher.
"I'm happy it's being addressed," Seiji said. "But it doesn't always make for much change."
 
Room 3-223
 
Third-grade teachers in schools throughout New York City are trying to meet Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's goal for the school year: by summer, all third graders should be able to read at grade level. Previous articles described the efforts of Ted Kesler and his students to succeed. This is the eighth article. The series is available to computer users at The New York Times on the Web, at http://www.nytimes .com/library/national/teach.html.

HEADLINE: Albright Chides Balkan Chiefs On Flouting of Peace Accord

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, May 31

 BODY:
After a flurry of activity meant to underline the United States' commitment to peace in Bosnia, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright swung through the Balkans today, lecturing President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia and President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia about their failure to comply with the Dayton peace accords.
In meetings in Zagreb and here in Belgrade, Ms. Albright warned both leaders that their countries could face still stronger penalties if they did not do more. Washington wants them to turn over people indicted on war crimes charges and allow refugees to return to their homes as promised. 
 She even visited tiny villages in Croatia in a highly orchestrated effort to register outrage at the plight of refugees who in recent weeks have tried to return to homes they fled during the civil war, only to face harassment and violence.
"The Government at the top is thinking this is normal," she said, furiously scolding one of Mr. Tudjman's ministers, Jure Radic, after visiting a family of refugees in Donji Kukuruzari, near the border with Bosnia. "It is not normal. You should be ashamed of yourself."
For all her criticism, though, Ms. Albright received nothing concrete in return.
Mr. Tudjman resisted the pressure, as he has in talks with other American officials in recent weeks. In a meeting this morning at his presidential mansion in the hills outside Zagreb, he made it clear that his Government had no intention of allowing Serbian refugees to return, even as he disputed that it had condoned violence against refugees.
"He came right back at her," one official said afterward.
The tension of the meeting, which the official described as one of the most contentious in Ms. Albright's four months as Secretary, persisted into a joint news conference that included unusually sharp exchanges.
Ms. Albright said Croatia's future lay in the "democratic community we are building" in Europe. She appeared contemptuous toward Mr. Tudjman. "We hold Croatia to the standards of that community," she said, "not to the standards of this region's autocratic and violent past."
Mr. Tudjman, for his part, recited a litany of complaints about Serbs' treatment of Croats during the Balkan war -- as he had when meeting privately with Ms. Albright.
"Such incidents," he said of the attacks on refugees, "cannot and should not be viewed in isolation from the past."
The meetings today reflected the frustration of American efforts to force Mr. Tudjman, Mr. Milosevic and the Bosnian leaders to comply with pledges they made in the peace accords, which, 18 months after they were negotiated near Dayton, Ohio, have stalled.
Ms. Albright's aides insisted that they had not expected to win dramatic concessions, but rather had hoped to pump new energy into efforts to create a single, unified state in Bosnia.
Her visit here came a day after the United States and its NATO allies concluded a conference in Portugal with a declaration warning the parties that they faced further economic and diplomatic penalties. In particular, the allies demanded that the Balkan leaders stop harboring people indicted for war crimes and allow thousands of people forced from their homes in "ethnic cleansing" to return.
It remains to be seen whether the Administration's reinvigorated drive -- or at least reinvigorated words -- can produce significant results. Ms. Albright's predecessor, Warren Christopher, made a similar push when he flew through the Balkans in February 1996 only to see resistance to Dayton's principles pick up again.
The depth of the enmity that remains in the Balkans was clear this afternoon as Ms. Albright toured the Croatian villages. In Prevrsac, a small group of Croats forced from their homes in Serbian-held parts of Bosnia gathered to watch the spectacle of an American Secretary of State holding a news conference in front of a home burned out earlier this month by a mob protesting the return of Serbian refugees.
"During the war, they killed our people," one of them, Luka Vuckovic, said. "How can we live with them now?"

COUNTRY: CROATIA (98%); UNITED STATES (96%); BOSNIA & HERZEGOVINA (96%); SERBIA (94%); SERBIA & MONTENEGRO (92%); EUROPE (79%);

China's Pride Rises as Days Count Down for Hong Kong
The return of Hong Kong, in just a month, is becoming a national preoccupation in China. To recover Hong Kong, in the Chinese view, is one of the most glorious events in modern history, righting a pernicious wrong of the 19th century. But lurking underneath the pride is an uneasy mix of jealousy and superiority. 1

After today's elections, France faces an increased possibility of economic and political deadlock, with far-reaching implications for Europe. HEADLINE: For New Jersey Voters, A Primary Confusion

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: LINDEN, N.J., May 31

 BODY:
Did Pauline Halas, a longtime resident of this working-class city and a dedicated Democrat, know which candidate for governor she would support in the Tuesday primary?
"Oh, yes, for sure," Mrs. Halas, 66, said the other afternoon, standing by a bus stop on North Wood Avenue and nodding vigorously. "Just give me a minute and I'll think of his name." 
 After a moment, it came to her: United States Representative Robert E. Andrews, a resident of southern New Jersey who is running for the Democratic nomination against State Senator James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge and Michael Murphy, a former Morris County prosecutor who lives in Chatham. Mrs. Halas, who is fighting plans to build a toxic-waste incinerator here, said she had settled on Mr. Andrews after reading his positions on the environment.
"He sounds like he's against dumping and polluting," she said. "So I'm going to take a chance."
If conversations on Thursday with two dozen people who live and work in Linden are any indication, Mrs. Halas is not the only one whose thoughts about the Democrats hoping to challenge Gov. Christine Todd Whitman are muddled.
Although most people interviewed said they would vote in the primary, fewer than half knew whom they would support. Only a few were familiar with the candidates' backgrounds and positions. Their comments suggested that even in a city where Democrats outnumbered Republicans by a 10-to-1 ratio, the primary race had proved uninspiring.
But the voters in Linden did seem to have one firm goal in common: making sure that Mrs. Whitman, a popular Republican who is uncontested in the primary, does not win re-election in November.
The candidate who appears to have the best chance in Linden, an aging industrial city just off the New Jersey Turnpike in Union County, is Mr. McGreevey, whose hometown of Woodbridge is just 10 miles down the turnpike. He has the support of the county Democratic organization and Mayor John T. Gregorio, who says Mr. McGreevey, the Mayor of Woodbridge, understands the problems facing cities. And since he is more or less a local boy, people are far more likely to recognize him than Mr. Andrews or Mr. Murphy, who hails from the affluent suburbs of Morris County, about 25 miles away.
"That one who's the Mayor in Woodbridge, he's the one that's spouting about reducing the auto insurance, right?" said Harold Dorin, the owner of Nason's, a department store. "I know him better than the others, but I'm going to do a little more reading first."
Even geographical proximity is not necessarily enough to give Mr. McGreevey a high profile in Linden, whose 36,700 residents are mostly white and middle-aged, with no college education. They are people like Carol Furnback, a single mother who said she worked 80 hours a week running the All Aboard Cafe, next to the train station, and had no time to watch television or read newspapers. Ms. Furnback said she knew nothing about the three Democratic candidates. But she said she would vote for anyone but Mrs. Whitman.
"Her I don't like at all," Ms. Furnback, 41, said. "She tells us she's going to do so much, then she doesn't do anything. I have a friend whose taxes dropped $30 a year after her tax cut, but then his property taxes went up $500. Where's the good in that?"
Ms. Furnback voted for Mrs. Whitman in 1993. So did 43 percent of the voters here, a startling number given the strong Democratic presence in town. Several of the self-described party faithful here said they had rebelled four years ago and voted for Mrs. Whitman. They were annoyed at Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase, they said, and excited by the prospect of a female governor. But the novelty has worn off, they said. In particular, many blamed Mrs. Whitman for their high car insurance rates.
"I'm not crazy on politics, but I want to get rid of Christie Todd Whitman," said Neil Suydam, 25, a salesman who said he paid $2,500 a year to insure his 1985 Cadillac. "All of the sudden my car insurance went through the roof this year, and I don't see her doing anything about it."
Chris Quinn, a school crossing guard who has three children, said she supported Mrs. Whitman in 1993 even though she was a registered Democrat. But while Mrs. Quinn, 48, said she appreciated Mrs. Whitman's tax cuts, she said she resented the Governor's mostly paying for those cuts by reducing state pension contributions by more than $3 billion.
Mrs. Quinn and her husband, also a public employee, oppose the Governor's plan to borrow $2.75 billion to help close a deficit in the state pension system.
"She's not from my level of economics," Mrs. Quinn said, standing on the corner in her orange crossing-guard vest. "She doesn't know what it's like to be in our shoes. She's born of a higher class than we are, and she doesn't know what it's like to struggle."
While most people interviewed here said they had no idea whether Mr. Andrews and Mr. Murphy empathized with the working class, several believed Mr. McGreevey did. He grew up in Carteret, a hardscrabble city with almost as many oil refineries as Linden. And as the Mayor of Woodbridge, they said, he might understand the plight of cities like Linden, whose tax base has shrunk as factories have closed.
"They say he cleaned up Woodbridge a little bit," said Steven Cohn, 35, a city employee for 17 years. "Maybe he'd try to keep our property taxes down and stop that toxic incinerator."
Mr. Gregorio, the Mayor, said that despite the apparent lack of interest, turnout in Linden would probably be heavy on Tuesday because the three local Democratic clubs had called every registered Democrat in the city and urged all to vote. On Tuesday, volunteers will call Democrats who have not voted by late afternoon and remind them, he said.
Most people interviewed said they needed no reminding -- only guidance on whom to support. Howard Rosen, who has owned the Linden Travel Bureau on South Wood Avenue since 1950, said he liked Mr. Murphy's proposal to raise the cigarette tax by 25 cents a pack to support education -- but only after a reporter told him about the proposal.
"I'm very much a Democrat, but somehow this primary has passed me by," Mr. Rosen, 70, said. "I do like the fact that in the debates, they have emphasized Whitman's faults and not each other's. But none of these guys really jumps off the page. Where's the brilliance? Where's the humanity?"
Part of the problem, Mr. Rosen said, is that many voters believe no Democrat has a chance against Mrs. Whitman, whose popularity has diminished only slightly recently.
"I just don't see her losing," Mr. Rosen said. "I can't imagine any of these guys are going to make a difference."

HEADLINE: TOP E.P.A. OFFICIAL NOT BACKING DOWN ON AIR STANDARDS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
Major industry groups are protesting, senior members of Congress are complaining and the White House economic advisers are balking. But Carol M. Browner, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, continues to doggedly defend the agency's proposal to toughen air-quality standards.
In one forum after another, from grueling daylong Congressional hearings to public debates with her opponents, Ms. Browner has insisted that nothing she has heard in six months has changed her fundamental view that the current standards do not adequately protect the public from the effects of breathing soot and smog. 
 Toughening the standards, as the E.P.A. proposed in November, would put hundreds of counties out of compliance with the Clean Air Act and force states to impose costly controls on emissions of ozone and fine chemical particles, mostly caused by burning fuels.
A final rule has to be issued in July, and as the E.P.A. prepares its ultimate recommendation, an intense debate over the best course to take is roiling the Clinton Administration.
While Ms. Browner has staunchly defended the proposed rule, the White House has maintained almost total silence about it. No top officials there have spoken out in defense of her proposal. And in closed meetings, other aides have sought to water it down, people involved in the review said.
With the deadline approaching for a decision on what could be the most significant environmental rule making of the decade, one question is whether the political dynamics strengthen Ms. Browner's hand or weaken it.
There are Republicans and Democrats on both sides of the issue, and major geographical fault lines as well, with Northeastern states favoring tougher standards and Midwestern ones tending to resist them.
The decision is especially significant because Vice President Al Gore will play a major role -- probably the decisive one -- in deciding whether to back up Ms. Browner, who has long been a close associate. Mr. Gore's actions could well affect how enthusiastically environmentalists support his Presidential effort in 2000.
"Since this is the top priority issue for the national environmental community at this time, any weakening of public health protection by the White House would certainly be a huge negative for Vice President Gore that would not be forgotten," said Gene Karpinski, president of U.S. Public Interest Research Groups.
Mr. Karpinksi is chairman this year of a committee of leaders of major environmental organizations known as the Green Group.
Ms. Browner's adamant defense of tougher standards is something of a personal gamble. She has gone far enough out on a limb that any significant weakening would be widely viewed as a chastening defeat. A decision to move forward with the new standards would be a significant show of her influence in the Administration.
In the last few years, Ms. Browner has fought and won other environmental battles, over the agency's budget and Republican efforts to weaken environmental regulations.
Ms. Browner insists that the law and the science of air quality support her stance and that the mountain of comments filed by advocates and opponents alike have not swayed the agency in any fundamental way.
"While I have not made a final decision, I can tell you that we have not found anything in the public comments, no new science, that causes us to question the science of what we are proposing," she said in a panel discussion on Wednesday at the National Press Club.
But environmentalists said they were worried that the White House would overrule Ms. Browner and weaken the proposed rule.
The President's economic advisers have pushed for a set of standards that would be much closer to the status quo than what the E.P.A. proposed in November. For most of the last year, economic advisers have been sympathetic to industry's complaints that the rules would cost far more than they are worth.
Kathleen McGinty, the White House's top environmental aide, insisted in an interview that the ultimate decision would be based on public health, and not costs.
"It is not at all about the money," she said of the review that is under way. "These are health standards."
The Clean Air Act explicitly requires that the standards be set without regard to cost.
"The requirement that needs to be met at the end of the day is you have to protect the public health with an adequate margin of safety," Ms. McGinty said, citing the language of the Clean Air Act. "That is the policy decision. What constitutes the adequate margin of safety? Because there is always more protection you could give. There is always more that you can do."
Ms. McGinty is just one of the White House advisers with a role in the discussions. Others are Sally Katzen, the top regulatory official at the Office of Management and Budget, and Gene Sperling, assistant to the President for economic policy.
Ms. Browner has described Mr. Sperling's role as "honest broker" between competing views.
Advocates of the tougher standard, meanwhile, say they are hoping that beyond the epidemiological studies showing that air pollution is linked with sickness and death, the White House will pay attention to new polls that show that pollution is still a potent political issue.
A survey done for environmental groups this week by Penn, Schoen & Berland Associates, a public opinion agency that also conducts polling for the White House, found that 56 percent of respondents strongly favored stricter standards, with 27 percent saying they somewhat favored the proposal. Twelve percent opposed toughening the rules and 5 percent said they did not know.
There is not much support for tougher standards in Congress, but polls like the one this week suggest that Congress might be reluctant to overturn such a decision.
Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, who has great influence over environmental matters, has proposed moderating the E.P.A. approach.
Mr. Chafee would maintain smog standards at the current level of stringency while changing somewhat how violations are measured. He would commit the agency to regulate fine particles of soot later if further research proved that such pollution caused illness.
Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, is leading a similar effort among House Democrats against the rules.
Congress has the right to reject any major Federal regulation, under a law enacted in the 104th Congress.
The new rules have generated extensive opposition from major industries, including oil, utility and automobile companies, and from many state and local officials. But public health agencies in the states have spoken out in favor of the rules, as have many governors, including William F. Weld of Massachusetts and other Northeasterners.
The National Association of Manufacturers, which is leading the drive by electric companies, oil and coal producers, auto makers and other major industries against the proposed standards, has called for its members to lobby President Clinton to reject the E.P.A. proposal.
