HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices End Mixed on Rate Concerns

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, after a strong manufacturing report raised the specter that the Federal Reserve might again increase interest rates. The report offset good demand from European investors who were looking for a safe haven after a Socialist-led coalition won French elections.
The National Association of Purchasing Management index in May rose to an unexpectedly strong 57.1 from 54.2 in April. Traders said that the losses yesterday were limited since the market is technically in good shape. They added that early gains had been made on data indicating a weakening in personal spending and income. 
 The 30-year bond rose 4/32 to a price of 96 19/32, pushing its yield down slightly to 6.90 percent, from 6.91 percent on Friday.
Dr. Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities, said that the purchasing report for May underscored broad-based strength in manufacturing. A strong economy is often accompanied by inflation, which erodes the value of long-term securities like bonds.
The purchasing index hit its highest level since November 1994, and the underlying components point to further strength in the months ahead, Dr. Cooper said.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said, "With orders moving up sharply and the supplier delivery component also putting in a strong performance, it is hard to continue touting the story of a collapsing economy."
"Over all, many investors began to worry that the robust orders component in the N.A.P.M. may translate into higher production levels and faster employment growth," he said. "The big fear is that the slowdown in consumption during the second quarter may only be a pause, rather than a signal of continued moderate growth in the quarters ahead."
On the supply side of the Government securities market yesterday, the Treasury auctioned $30 billion of 14-day cash management bills, as well as holding the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, which has been totaling about $15 billion a week.
Analysts called the outcome of the weekly bill auction average to mediocre, with the three-month bill priced to produce an average rate of 4.93 percent, down from 5.03 percent last week, and the six-month bill rate an average of 5.22 percent, down from 5.26 percent.
For now the supply of bills remains tight, in the face of strong demand. Also helping the short end of the market was speculation that there would be a bill pass by the Fed, but sellers used the up ticks in the market as selling opportunities. A bill pass is when the Fed enters the market to buy various maturity bills to add reserves permanently to the banking system; the Fed never discusses a pass until it finishes one.
A rally in the dollar yesterday also proved a key for bonds, since a strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors. because of the potential gains from currency exchange.
"It was a decidedly quiet day which probably exaggerated any positive or negative spin you could put on Monday's action," said David Ader, regional director of fixed income at Technical Data in Boston. "With that major caveat in mind, you still come away impressed with the price action. The market responded well to strong N.A.P.M. numbers. This is the first read on the May data, and the market is closing higher in spite of it."
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auctions of new three-month and six-month bills, as well as of the 14-day cash management bills:

HEADLINE: Study Ranks Software as No. 3 Industry

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The computer software business has risen rapidly to become America's third-largest manufacturing industry, paying wages twice the national average, according to a new study.
The study provides the most detailed portrait to date of the jobs and wealth generated by the fast-growing software business. The industry-sponsored research will be presented in Washington tomorrow by a group of computer executives led by Bill Gates of Microsoft and Andrew Grove of Intel. 
 The study is partly a lobbying tool. It is intended to emphasize the rising importance of the software industry at a time when Congress is considering legislation on a number of issues that affect the business, like export curbs on data-scrambling software and new laws to protect intellectual property.
After presenting the study at a news conference, the computer executives have scheduled meetings on Capitol Hill and at the White House.
"We see the study as a framework for saying to leaders in Washington that software is a major engine of the modern economy," said Robert Holleyman, president of the Business Software Alliance, a trade group that sponsored the research. "And as we move to a new generation of software -- software used and distributed on the Internet -- it is essential to have policies that encourage innovation and protect intellectual property."
The study, conducted by Nathan Associates, an economic consulting firm in Arlington, Va., found that the American software industry generated revenues of $102.8 billion last year. Since 1990, the software industry has grown at a rate of 12.5 percent annually, nearly 2.5 times faster than the economy as a whole.
The computer industry is often regarded as a textbook example of the rising "wage gap" -- an increasing difference between the high incomes enjoyed by skilled workers in fields like software and the far lower incomes of other workers.
That view is confirmed by the new study. The 619,400 Americans employed in the software industry last year made an average of $57,300, or more than twice the national average of $27,900.
Workers in the packaged software business, used in personal computers, did even better. They averaged $64,500. "The average wages are phenomenal," said Robert Damuth, director of policy studies for Nathan Associates. "The incomes are extraordinary because software is a knowledge-intensive industry that is thriving, and workers are getting compensated for their skills."
Calculating the size and employment is tricky in most industries, but especially so in high-technology fields. The industry classifications used in Government statistics were set long ago. Those definitions have not been revised to keep up with the changes in fast-paced industries. Software, for example, has been defined as a service for years, but when new classifications are adopted in 2000 it will be defined as a manufacturing industry.
Still, Mr. Damuth said his firm tried to be reasonably conservative in its definition of the software industry. It included only three of nine possible categories in the broad grouping of Government industry statistics called "computer programming, data processing and other computer services."
In comparing software with other manufacturing industries, Nathan Associates employed a value-added measure, which excludes an industry's purchase of other goods used in production. The value-added calculation more accurately measures an industry's contribution to the economy rather than counting the production of its suppliers as its own.
On the value-added basis, software ranked third after automobiles and electronics. In a 1995 study, software ranked fifth, behind the aircraft and pharmaceutical industry as well as autos and electronics. The study also estimated the "ripple effect" of the software industry, saying that software was responsible for 1,445,600 jobs in other industries. The total direct and indirect employment of 2,065,000 million people last year, the software study projected, will reach 3,435,000 million by 2005 -- or nearly 3 percent of American workers.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 41.64; Broader Stock Indexes Up

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday, as the shares of some overlooked smaller companies rose at the expense of larger blue-chip issues.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 41.64 points to 7,289.40. Beyond the blue-chip market, however, gainers outpaced losers by a margin of 1,543 to 1,002 on volume of 433.2 million on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 "We're continuing to see some rotation out of big stocks and into small stocks," said Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Fahnestock & Company. "The Dow has made a strong move over the last couple of weeks, and it looks like some people are cashing in now. There are a lot of economic numbers ahead."
Broader market measures also rose. The Russell 2000 index of small stocks added 2.76 points, to 383.52; the American Stock Exchange index edged up 1.79, to 607.17, and the Nasdaq composite index, which is heavy in technology issues, added 4.47, to 1,404.79.
Analysts said that economic data, including the monthly employment report due on Friday, would probably dampen demand for blue-chip stocks in the next few days.
Even after yesterday's decline, the Dow industrials stand nearly 900 points higher than on April 11. In contrast, smaller stocks have only recently begun to shake off a malaise that had lasted more than a year.
Heightening investors' caution was the release of the week's first important economic indicator, the National Association of Purchasing Management index.
The index, a gauge of manufacturing activity compiled by purchasers for about 300 major corporations, rose to 57.1 in May, eclipsing economists' forecasts of a 53.9 reading, as well as April's level of 54.2. A reading above 50 percent signals that manufacturing is growing while one below that level points to contraction. Traders fear that strong growth could lead the Federal Reserve to again raise interest rates.
Analysts said some of the strength in stocks yesterday appeared to be linked to special factors, like the end of a strike at a Chrysler motor plant. But even after such factors, analysts said the index hinted that the forthcoming jobs report would be a strong one. "Employment really drives that number a lot," said Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Kemper Funds. "Manufacturing can only be strong if employment is strong."
Mr. Froehlich said a muted response to the report in the bond market might have reflected strong global demand for American assets, particularly from Europe, where currency issues and political uncertainties have mounted.
"It's going to be months before we figure out the impact of the elections in France and Great Britain," he said. "In the interim, a lot of foreign money is coming into this market as a hiding place, so to speak."
Among Dow industrial index components, Procter & Gamble fell 4 1/4, to 133 5/8, after Smith Barney downgraded the shares to outperform from buy. P.& G., up 56 percent this year, is the most expensive and therefore the most heavily weighted stock in the Dow average. Pepsico rose 1, to 37 3/4, after the company said it would reorganize its North American beverage business, creating a separate unit for its bottling operations.
Tobacco stocks were the market's biggest laggards, as concern over the industry's legal problems spread. The Philip Morris Companies, which sell Marlboro cigarettes, fell 1 1/4, to 42 3/4; RJR Nabisco Holdings, the maker of Camel cigarettes, fell 5/8, to 31 3/4, and UST Inc., which sells Copenhagen tobacco products, slid 5/8, to 27 7/8.
In Nasdaq trading, G & K Services Inc. fell 2, to 30 3/4, after the company said it would acquire the uniform-rental business of National Linen Service for about $287 million. National Service Industries, parent of National Linen, slipped 5/8, to 43 1/4, on the Big Board.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.92, to 846.36.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.24, to 441.54. The average price per share fell 2 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index, the market value of Big Board, American and Nasdaq issues commonly known as the Wilshire 5000, finished at 8,044.46, up 5.96 or seven-hundredths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Average Falls 41.64, But Smaller Stocks Climb
Stocks ended mixed, as the shares of some overlooked smaller companies rose at the expense of larger blue-chip issues. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 41.64 points to 7,289.40, with one component, Procter & Gamble, falling 4 1/4, to 133 5/8, after Smith Barney downgraded the shares.
But gainers outpaced losers by 1,543 to 1,002 on the New York Stock Exchange, and several broader market measures rose, despite investor caution. The Nasdaq composite index added 4.47 points, to 1,404.79. [Page D10.] 

Treasury securities' prices were also mixed, after a strong manufacturing report raised fears that the Fed might push up interest rates again. The yield on the 30-year bond edged down to 6.90 percent. [D20.]
 
Beverage Battles At McDonald's
The beverage wars among the nation's top three soft-drink producers heated up on two fronts. Pepsico said that it would create a division for its $6.14 billion company-owned bottling operations. Separately, Coca-Cola, the industry leader, confirmed that it was trying to banish Dr Pepper/Seven Up, the nation's third-largest beverage company, from thousands of McDonald's restaurants. [D2.]
 
Chrysler Sales Fell in May
Sales of cars and truck made by Chrysler fell 16.6 percent in May compared with May 1996. The other auto makers are expected to report similar declines when they announce their results today and later this week. [D6.]
 
Seagate Sees Faltering Earnings
Seagate Technology said that its quarterly results would be below analysts' expectations of $1.06 a share because of weak demand for its computer disk drives. [D8.]
 
Enron Settles With Phillips
Enron said that it would pay $440 million to settle litigation with Phillips Petroleum over an agreement to buy high-priced natural gas from a North Sea field and would take an after-tax charge of $450 million. [D6.]
 
Software Industry Grows Rapidly
The software business has risen by a rapid 12.5 percent a year to become America's third-largest manufacturing industry, according to an industry-sponsored study. [D2.]
 
Smith Barney Dismisses Executive
Smith Barney said it had dismissed Robert B. Maloney, its New England regional director, whose role in raising campaign contributions for his brother, Representative James H. Maloney, Democrat of Connecticut, is under investigation by Federal authorities. [D10.]
 
Czech Republic Stumbles
Vaclav Klaus, Prime Minister of the Czech Republic, has been forced to admit that he made mistakes in taking that country from Communism to capitalism. Last week he froze wages and cut Government spending, hoping to bolster the Czech crown, which fell 10 percent after the central bank allowed it to float in value. [D4.]
 
Judge Limits 'Pain and Suffering'
Seeking to place definable limits on juries' awards for "pain and suffering" in civil cases, a Federal judge in Brooklyn issued statistical guidelines as part of his judgment in three cases involving women who sustained arm, wrist and hand injuries while using computer keyboards made by Digital Equipment. [D4.]

LENGTH: 1140 words

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains as Traders Bet Euro Will Be Weakened

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, June 2

 BODY:
Faced with a Socialist victory in France and an unusual domestic spat between the German Government and the central bank, currency traders headed for safe harbors today. They quickly bought up American dollars and British pounds while pushing down the value of both the French franc and the German mark.
Analysts said today's activity reflected a sentiment that Europe's two biggest economies were moving away from strict fiscal and monetary austerity and that the proposed single European currency, the euro, would be weaker than the rock-hard currency akin to the German mark that European leaders have promised. 
 Until the political landscape settles down, currency traders are avoiding holding the franc and the mark and are betting that the dollar and the pound will strengthen as safe currencies of choice for now.
In currency trading in New York today, the dollar settled at 1.7300 marks, up sharply from 1.7063 marks on Friday, and at 5.8320 French francs, up from 5.7595 francs. The British pound fell to $1.6359 from $1.6410. The dollar was also higher against the Japanese yen, rising to 116.58 yen from 116.22 yen
Late today, there was the first sign of hope that one battle might soon end. Germany's Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, signaled that the Government might be willing to back down on its hotly contested plan to reduce its budget deficit this year with a bookkeeping maneuver to revalue the central bank's gold reserves. The plan would inject some of the gain into the Government treasury and bring Germany's deficit closer to the strict criteria called for in the plan for a single currency.
Last week, when the central bank objected to the timing of the plan, the German Government said it would go ahead anyway. The Bundesbank wants to revalue its gold hoard but not before May 1998 when the European Union will have decided which countries will initially participate in the single currency. Doing it sooner, the bank declared, threatens its independence and weakens the new currency.
But late today Mr. Waigel said, "We will discuss this with the Bundesbank," adding, "We will try to do this in mutual agreement." He did not make clear what he had in mind but if he delayed the plan by a year, as the central bank prefers, Germany's budget deficit would exceed the criteria set out for the creation of the euro and would probably undermine its strength.
Regardless, most analysts say the credibility of the euro has taken a serious blow.
"What we have to conclude is that European Monetary Union will get off the ground, but as a much weaker currency," said J. Paul Horne, an economist for Smith Barney in Paris. "The two principal actors seem to be saying, 'Let's get to the altar in the easiest way.' "
In theory, a weaker euro would hurt the United States by making American-made goods more expensive. Conversely, a strong dollar and a weak euro would make European-made goods less costly.
European stock markets reacted calmly to the Socialist victory over the conservative coalition of President Jacques Chirac of France. On the Paris Bourse, blue-chip stocks in the CAC-40 index initially plunged by nearly 3 percent but then regained their value and ended the day slightly above Friday's close. The German market closed up 1.63 percent; the London stock exchange ended down 1.27 percent.
The results puzzled some market analysts, particularly because the Socialist victory in France should in theory spell bad news for French business. But analysts said the stock market's sanguine reaction was partly because investors had furiously sold off French stocks through much of last week, after the first round of elections on May 25 signaled that Mr. Chirac's Government was in deep trouble.
Beyond that, they said, the movements in both markets reflected a general notion of less strict economies. More relaxed economic policies could easily add some zip to the depressing level of economic activity in both countries, but they could also lead to a much weaker and less credible euro, which is scheduled to make its debut in 1999.
The French Socialist leader who was named Prime Minister today, Lionel Jospin, has adamantly insisted that countries should not be forced to meet the strict numerical targets for deficits, debt levels and inflation that now determine who will and will not be a part of the new euro. In a deep break with German views, moreover, he has called for opening the euro to countries like Italy that fall well short of the monetary union's strict criteria.
The French shift and Germany's new attempts to fudge its own deficit problems through bookkeeping maneuvers have both increased the chances that the new monetary union will have a wider but weaker membership.
"We have been predicting for some time that the European Monetary Union would be relatively wide, and both these events push things in the same direction," said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, global economist for Salomon Brothers in London. "It should not be surprising if the euro begins somewhat weaker" than politicians have hoped, he added.
Sylvain Hefes, managing director for Goldman, Sachs & Company in Paris, said France's leftist Government would bring less change than expected because the Government had very little money to work with.
"The Socialists asked for a complete audit of public finances today, and what they are going to find is that they have almost no maneuvering room," Mr. Hefes said. "They will not be in a position to do a lot of things."
That now leaves Europe's political leaders, particularly in Germany, with a painful decision. Should they plunge ahead with the euro, even if it would be significantly weaker than the vaunted German mark or even the French franc? Or should they delay the start of the euro until countries have their economies in better order?
Most financial and political experts believe that European leaders have staked so much of their political careers on the euro that they have long since passed the point of no return. The rise in the dollar, they said, signals a belief that the euro will be started but will be weaker. If investors believe the euro will be delayed or scrapped entirely, that generally sends the German mark up in value because investors would be no longer be expecting the mark's replacement by a weaker currency.
Nevertheless, tensions between France and Germany over the euro are likely to increase. Even under the conservative coalition, France repeatedly battled against Germany's seemingly ironclad determination to impose firm and unchangeable numerical fiscal requirements on countries that would participate in the euro. They have also carried on a running battle over whether political leaders should retain some oversight over the new European central bank -- a French idea that is anathema to the Germans.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

INTERNATIONAL A3-11
 
Liberal Party and Chretien Win Canadian Majority
Prime Minister Jean Chretien and his Liberal Party retained a slim parliamentary majority in Canadian elections, preliminary results indicated. In his home town of Shawinigan, Mr. Chretien clung to a slim lead over his separatist opponent. A1
 
Socialist Is French Premier
Conservative President Jacques Chirac of France appointed the Socialist leader, Lionel Jospin, Prime Minister. Mr. Jospin will take office today, ushering in France's third period of "cohabitation," or divided government, in 11 years. A8
 
The German Government insisted that the Socialist victory in France's parliamentary elections would not dilute Chancellor Helmut Kohl's commitment to strict rules and a rigid timetable for the introduction of a single European currency. A8
 
Blair Criticizes Welfare State
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain visited a decaying public housing project in London and denounced the culture of government dependency that he claimed was responsible for long-term unemployment. Mr. Blair called for "radical" welfare reform, although he stopped short of proposing that single parents find jobs or lose their benefits. A3
 
Expressing regret about Britain's role in the potato famine that devastated Ireland 150 years ago, Mr. Blair criticized the Government in London for "standing by" while a crop failure led to one million people dying of starvation in what was then part of the richest and most powerful nation in the world. A3
 
Fighting in Sierra Leone
Ships, planes and troops from Nigeria and other West African nations sought to subdue a military coup in Sierra Leone, where they encountered heavy resistance. Nigerian soldiers were reportedly pinned in several places, including the main international hotel in Freetown. As a warship shelled the headquarter of the rebellious soldiers and their allies, the Revolutionary United Front, Nigerian soldiers said they had seized an airfield. A10
 
Palestinian Threats Cited
Israeli security forces have information that 16 Palestinian dealers involved in selling land to Jews have been targeted for death, including three land dealers killed over the past month, an Israeli newspaper reported. The Palestinian Authority has denied responsibility for the murders, but its leaders have not denounced an edict declaring that Arabs convicted of selling land to Jews would be sentenced to death. A5
 
U.N. Warned Over Reforms
Carol Bellamy, the executive director of Unicef, publicly warned that proposed reforms at the United Nations could strip the agency of its independent voice for children around the world. As part of a general restructuring of the United Nations, Unicef would be folded into a group dealing with development, while other duties would be subsumed by a separate emergency relief team. A11
 
NATIONAL A12-20
 
McVeigh Is Convicted In Oklahoma Bomb Case
Timothy J. McVeigh was convicted of bombing the Oklahoma City Federal Building, the worst terrorist act in the United States. Later this week there will be a penalty phase of the trial at which the same jury will decide whether Mr. McVeigh will be executed or serve life in prison. He was found guilty of 11 counts of conspiracy and murder, with jurors concluding that he, Terry L. Nichols, an Army friend, and others unknown used a truck bomb to destroy the building on April 19, 1995, killing 168 people and injuring hundreds more. A1
 
After the verdict was announced, survivors of the blast and families of victims cheered and sobbed with relief at the lot where a building once stood. A1
 
The Government may have more trouble in its prosecution of Mr. Nichols. Some witnesses that could tie him to parts of the conspiracy appear to be less credible than those that were presented in Mr. McVeigh's trial. A19
 
Departure After Adultery
The commanding general of the Aberdeen Proving Ground will retire after acknowledging that he committed adultery. Several male drill sergeants at the base in Maryland have been charged with or convicted of sexually harassing and assaulting female recruits. A tip led to an investigation of the commander, Maj. Gen. John E. Longhouser. A12
 
Action on Herbal Stimulant
The Food and Drug Administration plans to regulate the use of ephedrine, an herbal stimulant used for body building and weight loss that has been blamed for 20 to 30 deaths. The agency wants to reduce the amount of ephedrine in supplements, restrict its marketing and require warning labels. A14
 
Reporter Still Causes Anger
A California journalism association today will consider a request by a member that it revoke an award given to Gary Webb, the reporter for The San Jose Mercury News whose articles linked the C.I.A. to drug dealing in Los Angeles by supporters of the Nicaraguan contras. The revocation is not consider likely, but the request shows the anger still aroused by Mr. Webb and the articles, which his own paper has admitted were flawed. A12
 
30 Hurt at Water Slide
At least 30 people were injured, 10 critically, when an amusement park water slide in Concord, Calif., collapsed after a group of teen-agers on a graduation outing ignored a lifeguard's warning and went down the slide together. Some fell as far as 75 feet. A12
 
Justices to Rule on Chases
The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether someone injured from a high-speed chase must show that the police officer involved acted with "reckless disregard" for public safety to sue successfully, or whether the plaintiff must meet the higher standard of showing that the police behavior "shocked the conscience." A14
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-7
 
Betty Shabazz's Grandson Arraigned in Attack on Her
Malcolm Shabazz, the 12-year-old grandson of Malcolm X, was arraigned in Family Court in Yonkers, charged with setting a fire that left his grandmother clinging to life. The boy had apparently been badly neglected by his mother and had been institutionalized in February after trashing the apartment he shared with her in Texas, according to police records and friends who described the boy's troubled life. A1
 
Inquiry on Art Auctions
Prominent Manhattan art dealers said they believed Federal officials were investigating the possibility of collusion and price fixing among art dealers buying at auctions. Investigators have subpoenaed truckloads of financial documents from more than a dozen dealers and from Sotheby's and Christie's, the world's largest auction houses, in what appears to be a wide-ranging antitrust investigation. It has long been rumored in the art world that some dealers try to buy on the cheap, by forming rings of dealers who agree to refrain from bidding against one other at auctions. A1
 
Mayor Speaks for Rent Law
Mayor Giuliani went to Albany and called on Governor Pataki to abandon his proposal to phase out rent regulations. Mr. Giuliani said it was up to the Governor to resolve the dispute in the Legislature over the rent laws, which expire in less than two weeks. B1
 
New Jersey Primary Today
The Democratic candidates for Governor of New Jersey ended their last day of campaigning before today's primary. A change in state election laws has allowed county party organizations, for the first time in more than 15 years, to endorse gubernatorial candidates and place them on the ballot next to familiar local candidates. Many votes are expected to vote for candidates simply because their names are next to a popular candidate for a local office. B4
 
Purse Snatcher Is Killed
A man who had snatched purses from three women in Brooklyn died after a confrontation with relatives of one victim, the police said. The cause of his death had not been determined. The police had not filed any charges against the relatives. B3

Currency traders bought up American dollars and British pounds while pushing down the value of both the French franc and German mark. D1

The index of corporate purchasing rose to its highest level since November 1994. The report indicates that the economy may be growing more strongly than had been believed. Most statistics published in recent weeks, including those on retail sales, have suggested that growth slackening. D1

CORRECTION-DATE: June 04, 1997, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article and an entry in the News Summary yesterday about Malcolm Shabazz, the 12-year-old grandson of Malcolm X who is accused of having set the fire that critically injured the boy's grandmother, referred incorrectly to a court hearing in the case on Monday. It was a detention hearing, to determine whether the boy would remain in custody; technically, there are no arraignments in Family Court. The summary also misstated the status of the hearing. It was adjourned until yesterday; it was not completed on Monday.
In addition, articles yesterday and on Monday misstated the date of Malcolm X's assassination. It was Feb. 21, 1965, not May 21.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off on Eased Concern About Credibility of the Euro

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower yesterday on eased concerns about the credibility of Europe's single currency and hints from Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka of Japan that interest rates there would rise soon.
A surge in the Japanese stock market to its highest level this year and comments by a Federal Reserve policy maker suggesting the United States economy is slowing also contributed to the dollar's weakness. 
 But the currency's movement was confined to narrow ranges in the absence of significant news, and traders said dealings were light ahead of the Friday report on May unemployment. That data could provide clues on whether the Fed will raise interest rates at its policy-making meeting on July 1 and 2.
"I think we're really on hold until we see the unemployment figures," said Michael Malpede, senior foreign-exchange analyst at the Refco Group of Chicago.
In New York, the dollar settled at 1.7275 marks, down from its nearly four-week high of 1.7300 on Monday when apprehension about the prospect of a weak single currency in Europe helped the dollar. The dollar cost 116.03 yen, down from 116.58. The pound cost $1.6351, down from $1.6359.
Traders said the main reason for eased concern about Europe's monetary union was the Bundesbank's apparent victory in a dispute with the German Government over revaluing Germany's gold reserves. The Government wanted to reappraise the reserves this year using current prices to satisfy the strict fiscal criteria to participate in the single currency, called the euro. The Bundesbank opposed the plan on the ground it was an accounting gimmick that would undermine the euro.
Finance Minister Theo Waigel said late yesterday that he had modified plans for the revaluation to satisfy Bundesbank concerns. Currency traders interpreted his announcement as a capitulation by the German Government on the plans.
Earlier in Asian dealings, the dollar fell slightly after Mr. Mitsuzuka told the Japanese Parliament that citizens suffering from Japan's record-low interest rates should be patient and that "a little bit more endurance is needed." His remarks were interpreted as a possible sign that rates could rise soon.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Latest Front For Veterans Is Rent War

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
"ONE thing worries me," reads an inscription carved into the glass blocks of the Vietnam Memorial in lower Manhattan. "Will people believe me? Will they want to hear about it, or will they want to forget the whole thing ever happened?"
Forgetting has not been easy for some veterans who gathered there recently. Many of them served in Vietnam and returned stateside to face a new front as they looked for a job and a place to live. Some are still looking. Kelvin Murry, a lanky Air Force veteran with a deep voice and a calm manner, has lived in a veterans' residence in Harlem since 1992. Home is a 14-by-16-foot cinder block room, little more than a glorified shelter to him. 
 "It's transitional housing," said Mr. Murry, an unemployed steamfitter who still wears his hard hat out of habit and hope. "That's what I'm trying to make it."
With the future of rent regulation uncertain, Mr. Murry worries that he may never be able to afford a real apartment if the current laws are scrapped. While the policy debate is filled with martial metaphors about battle lines and declarations of war against tenants, landlords and politicians, it rings hollow to those who saw combat in the bush and not in the legislature.
Does anyone remember, Ed Daniels asked, that one reason for the extension of rent regulations in the 1940's was to help the thousands of men returning from the war? Is anything owed to their successors?
"You're getting rid of the one thing that allows a vet to be stable," said Mr. Daniels, who served in Southeast Asia with the Air Force. "They believe since the cold war is over there will be no more wars. They don't understand that we sacrificed so they can have what they have."
IN recent weeks, Lee Covino has been trying to tell that to the lawmakers who will decide the future of rent regulations. Mr. Covino is an Army veteran who was spared combat duty in Vietnam when he was called home after his father suffered a massive stroke. Out of guilt and duty, he has been trying to help those who served.
The country may no longer be fighting, but the peacetime closings of military bases will result in more veterans looking to find a place in the civilian world. Mr. Covino said their service should have earned them consideration and protection. In turn, the veterans could use their skills to keep apartment buildings clean and safe.
"You're going from where the government gives you clothing, food and housing and into a whole other fishbowl," he said. "The city or the state should address the veterans. These folks have something to do with us being here and being free. That goes back to World War II and us not goose-stepping."
Jay Russell Outlaw remembered leaving the Army and returning to Harlem in 1946, unable to find an apartment. He settled into a succession of rooms he rented in other people's homes until his brother gave him his apartment after he moved to a housing project.
Mr. Outlaw now lives on 135th Street and Broadway, a neighborhood that he likes for its easy access to subways, buses and the highway. He has noticed a lot of digging in the streets in recent years, with work crews replacing water mains and electrical lines. With the talk of doing away with rent laws, he wonders if it all wasn't part of a larger plan for the neighborhood.
"All that's missing is good housing," he said. "They'll get rid of us and put in high-rises. They won't tell you you can't live here. The price alone will tell you. We'll end up living in the boondocks."
OR maybe on the street, which is where Mr. Murry landed 10 years ago after losing his job and apartment. For a while, subway cars and public beaches offered meager comfort. He spent six years in a shelter before moving to the veterans' residence.
On a sunny day, he walked around the memorial commemorating the war he will never forget. Bouquets of dried flowers, slender stems topped by tissuelike tufts of color, lay on a ledge near rosaries and religious pictures taped to the memorial's glass blocks.
Soon, Mr. Murry was surrounded by a group of schoolchildren visiting from Public School 32 in the Bronx. Someone had told them he had been in the war in the early 70's, and they eagerly asked him questions. One of them, Anthony Jenkins, even asked for his autograph.
"He was in the service," Anthony said. "He could have died. But he didn't. He's a survivor."
With some unexpected practice, Mr. Murry now waits to sign a lease.

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Fall; Economists Yawn

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
The most widely followed index for predicting the economy posted its first decline in 15 months during April as 6 of 10 components moved lower, the Conference Board reported today.
Economists largely dismissed the decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in the index of leading indicators as a temporary statistical blip. 
 The two biggest drags, higher claims for jobless benefits and lower stock prices, have both reversed course since April and the index, specialists said, should quickly rebound.
"We would be looking for a higher reading next time," said Eric Green, economist at Paribas Capital Markets in New York.
The leading, or predictive, index is intended to signal turning points in the economy but its compilers have long insisted this requires that changes be significant in size, duration and scope, conditions that have not yet been met. Five consecutive negative months at the beginning of 1995 were not followed by recession.
Analysts also criticize the index for providing little new information since most of its separate components had already been published. "It's like calculating the grade point average for somebody who already knows all their individual grades," said Brian M. Jones, economist at Salomon Brothers.
The index has shown little vigor, with only two advances of more than two-tenths of 1 percent since February 1996, the month following what had been its most recent decline. Some analysts called this evidence of the hoped-for deceleration of the economy that could make it unnecessary for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
Companion indexes published by the Conference Board, a business-backed research organization, showed coincident and lagging indicators up one-tenth of 1 percent and two-tenths of 1 percent, respectively, in April.
Except for higher first-time claims for unemployment benefits, which swelled because of strikes and floods, and lower stock prices as gauged by the Standard & Poor's 500, the declines in the leading index were negligible.
These involved fewer building permits, lower consumer expectations, a decline in new orders for factory goods and speedier supplier deliveries.
The main positive contributor was a rise on the M-2 money supply followed by an increase in new factory orders for consumer goods, a longer average workweek and a wider spread between overnight interest rates and rates on 10-year Treasury bonds.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Petroleum Is Lower As U.S. Backs Extension of Iraqi Deal

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Petroleum futures fell sharply yesterday after the Clinton Administration said it would support the six-month renewal of a deal to allow Iraq to sell $2 billion in oil in return for humanitarian aid.
On other commodity markets, coffee futures rebounded from recent losses, while corn prices rose on concerns about weather and soybean futures retreated sharply. 
 The United Nations Security Council was expected to allow Iraq to export oil for another six months after the State Department and White House said the Administration favored renewing the deal. Kofi Annan, Secretary General of the United Nations, recommended on Monday that the arrangement continue; approval is expected soon.
Iraq has been under an oil embargo and trade sanctions since its 1990 invasion of Kuwait but received an exemption that went into effect on Dec. 10 to bring food and medicine to Iraq's residents.
Iraq has since been shipping between 700,000 and 800,000 barrels a day of crude to Western markets, which has caused prices to fall to just above $20 a barrel from about $26 a barrel early this year.
Crude oil and petroleum products were also pressured by expectations that weekly industry production reports would show that refiners are operating at close to capacity, which is likely to bring ample new supplies of gasoline to relieve tightness caused by the start of the summer driving season.
Crude oil for July delivery fell 65 cents, to $20.33 a barrel, the lowest since May 9; July gasoline fell 1.55 cents, to 61.44 cents a gallon, and July heating oil fell 1.70 cents, to 54.62 cents a gallon.
Coffee futures rose on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York amid uncertainty about whether a crop-damaging frost would hit Brazil in coming weeks, reducing world supplies.
July coffee rose 10.25 cents, to 2.642 a pound.
Corn prices advanced a second day on the Chicago Board of Trade amid forecasts of continued poor weather for growing in the Midwest, which could hamper growth.
July corn rose 3.5 cents, to $2.775 a bushel, and July soybeans fell 15.25 cents, to $8.60 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Move Higher

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, approaching the top of their most recent trading range as two reports on the economy and comments by a Federal Reserve official suggested that the economic growth rate was slowing.
In a question-and-answer session after a speech on the prospects for the Alaskan and United States economies in Anchorage, Robert Parry, head of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, remarked that the key to whether the Fed would raise interest rates again "is clearly whether this economy slows down or not to a sustainable rate of growth." 
 "We were growing at a 4.1 percent rate between the first quarter of 1996 and the first quarter of 1997," Mr. Parry added. "I think that is a rate that is not sustainable. And after a while it would generate inflationary problems."
Also affecting the market yesterday, the Conference Board reported that its index of leading indicators unexpectedly fell one-tenth of 1 percent in April, the first drop since January 1996. And a five-tenths of 1 percent drop was reported for retail sales last week.
Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc., called the drop in leading indicators minor and only slightly below expectations, "so who cares?" The weekly retail sales were soft, but the market did not react strongly to that, he said.
"I'm still very positive that interest rates will decline," Mr. Guild said, "but with the Fed move not necessarily right away."
The price of the 30-year bond rose 12/32 yesterday, to 96 31/32, pushing its yield down to 6.86 percent, from 6.90 percent on Monday.
Trading was thin. Mr. Guild said, "People are mostly waiting for this Friday's all-important jobs data, which will probably be benign and show a 5 percent unemployment rate, with the number of jobs added to the economy in May at about 225,000." The market will also be watching the hourly wages data and its potential impact on inflation, which remains benign and is down 2.50 percent over the last 12 months, he said.
"Today market participants made more of Robert Parry's remarks, which reinforced the notion that the economy will slow dramatically from the 5.8 percent surge in the first quarter," Mr. Guild said. Nevertheless, he added, many people still expect the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee to tighten credit in July or August.
For some investors, the Friday jobs report may confirm suspicions that the economy is slowing from a strong first quarter, thereby lowering the chances of an interest rate increase by the central bank at its next monetary meeting on July 1 and 2. Others, however, still see the economy leaning toward strong growth, making another rate increase to stay ahead of future inflation more likely.
Longer maturities were down early yesterday on hedging against a large supply of corporate debt expected to be priced this week, but bounced back after good demand from oveseas investors emerged for some deals. France's election of a Socialist government has prompted some European investors to seek a safe haven in America.
In the global debt market, the Ford Motor Company's Ford Motor Credit unit will price $1 billion of bonds today through the joint managers Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley. Yesterday the Asian Development Bank priced a $1 billion global issue through the joint lead managers Goldman Sachs International, SBC Warburg and Tokyo-Mitsubishi International.
The bonds, due in 2007, were given a 6.75 percent coupon and priced to yield 6.83 percent, or about 18 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than a comparable United States Treasury note.

HEADLINE: Wide Open Once Again?;
Chicago Exchanges Seek to Loosen Yoke of Regulation

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
It takes sharp elbows and a strong constitution to survive a day in the Eurodollar pit at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Contracts representing millions of dollars in short-term interest rate futures turn over every second in a cacophonous blur of hand signals and shouted orders. Moments of relative quiet are punctuated by frenzy as the electronic boards ringing the pit record tiny movements in the Eurodollar's value.
Busy as the Eurodollar pit is -- nearly 100 million Eurodollar contracts were traded in 1996, making it the most actively traded financial future in the world -- Mercantile Exchange officials say they are losing business to over-the-counter traders, foreign exchanges and private swaps deals. The reason: futures traded off the Chicago exchange are subject to virtually no Federal regulation. 
 From their earliest days as marketplaces for agricultural commodities, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade and the rough-and-tumble traders who work there have chafed at Government supervision.
Now they want relief and have gone to Congress to get it.
Futures traders are sophisticated consenting adults engaged in legal transactions, exchange officials argue in public statements and in legislation now before Congress that they largely wrote. It is in their own interest to police the action on the floor, they say; they don't want or need meddling Federal chaperones from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission looking over their shoulders.
"What we have is a regulatory model built for another time and another marketplace, when most of the trading was in agricultural products," said John F. Sandner, chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. "Now, 90 percent of our trading is in financial instruments by large institutions. And our regulation, which is supposed to be oversight, has become micromanagement."
It seems an odd moment for traders in some of the world's riskiest financial products to be pleading for regulatory relief.
The recent history of costly failures in the trading of financial futures, swaps and other complex financial products known collectively as derivatives justifies a vigorous regulatory and enforcement program, say Federal market overseers, who themselves have more often been criticized for being weak than severe.
They cite a litany of derivatives trading debacles: Barings; Sumitomo; Orange County; Procter & Gamble, MG Futures Inc. The losses are measured in the billions of dollars.
Brooksley Born, the 56-year-old securities lawyer named to head the Commodity Futures Trading Commission last fall, asserted in an interview that the exchanges were seeking to trade effective and necessary Government oversight for their assurances of "Trust me."
"Essentially, the C.F.T.C. has regulated the futures markets primarily through surveillance to try to detect fraud or manipulation in its incipiency," Ms. Born said. "If we lose that power, we would be relegated to pursuing enforcement after the fact. Billions of dollars could be lost to consumers and businesses. Pricing at the service station and the grocery store, the prices plumbers and electricians pay for copper pipe and wire -- all are profoundly affected by the price-setting mechanism of the exchanges."
She said that the regulatory freedom the futures markets sought would result in "grave dangers" not only for market participants but also for the public at large, whose pension funds, bank deposits, insurance accounts and mutual funds would be put at risk.
The longstanding friction between the exchanges and their watchdogs at the commission is nearing a critical point. Bills now before the House and Senate would eliminate most record-keeping and auditing requirements, speed approval of trading in new contracts, lift margin limits and create a "professional market" of largely unregulated big traders. The commission would be left with power to punish violators but few tools for detecting them.
Intense closed-door lobbying and negotiations about the bills have been under way for the last several weeks. But in public, both sides are staking out strong rhetorical positions in hopes of swaying Congress.
Exchange officials cite statistics showing that off-market trading in currencies, interest rate swaps and Eurodollars has grown three to ten times as rapidly as that on the exchanges.
Thomas R. Donovan, the blustery president of the Board of Trade and a former aide to Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago, noted that trading volume in interest rate futures on his exchange has fallen the last two years, while over-the-counter trading in interest rate swaps, which are similar hedging products traded privately between two parties, are commanding a growing share of the corporate risk-management market.
The reasons are simple, Mr. Donovan said: the commission's "oppressive" rules and "protectionist" mind-set.
"Are they doing what they're supposed to? I think not," Mr. Donovan said. "They've lost their focus. It makes me wonder if they have a vendetta against the Board of Trade."
Hardly, Ms. Born replied. She acknowledged that a large volume of derivatives trading had shifted from American exchanges to overseas markets, whose regulations are not as restrictive as this country's.
But as a result of recent problems, foreign financial regulators are now looking at ways to strengthen their power. In Britain, Gordon Brown, the new Chancellor of the Exchequer, has said that securities self-regulation is insufficient to protect the public interest and is proposing ways to enhance the Government's hand to police markets. Regulators in France, Germany, Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore and elsewhere are meeting regularly to draft global rules governing the nearly instantaneous trading of trillions of dollars in derivatives.
Industry officials counter that futures trading is inherently risky and no regulatory regime can eliminate fraud or foolishness. Besides, they argue, most major problems have been uncovered by the affected institutions themselves, not by regulatory cops on the beat.
The two exchange chairmen, using their considerable political connections and their sizable political action committee treasuries, prevailed upon influential members of Congress -- including Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the chairman of the Agriculture Committee -- to introduce bills that would free their trading in financial instruments from all commission regulations, except those governing fraud and market manipulation.
The Mercantile Exchange's political action committee contributed a total of $539,655 to Presidential and Congressional candidates in 1995-96; the Board of Trade's political arm spent $414,848. Mr. Donovan contributed $1,000 to the Presidential primary campaigns of President Clinton and three Republican Senators, Mr. Lugar, Bob Dole and Phil Gramm.
The industry-supported bills, now before the Senate Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry Committee and a subcommittee of the House Agriculture Committee, would create a "Pro Market" for trading in financial futures for sophisticated individual and institutional players.
Senator Lugar is co-sponsor of the industry initiative, along with two Democratic Senators, Tom Harkin of Iowa and Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont.
"I take seriously what the exchanges are saying," Mr. Lugar said. "They are competitive people. They want to expand their business and keep it in the United States and I'm in favor of that."
The Senator acknowledged that the bill now before his committee probably tilted too far toward the futures industry's anti-regulatory stance. He said that he hoped to find middle ground in a series of discussions under way among industry officials, lawmakers, regulators and the Administration.
Mr. Lugar's bill would allow the exempted Pro Market trading in financial products, but not agricultural commodities. Ultimately, he said, Congress will probably maintain what he called the "sinews of regulation" for futures markets, despite industry's pleas for broader relief. Proper oversight, Mr. Lugar said, not only protects the public but also makes markets attractive to investors who seek the security of a regulated environment.
In the House, Representative Thomas Ewing, a Republican who represents a largely rural district in Illinois, has introduced a measure that takes a more assertive deregulatory posture.
Mr. Ewing said that the exchanges had been put at a competitive disadvantage by burdensome regulations. His bill would allow professional market trading in agricultural commodities as well as financial futures, though farm interests would likely not seek that freedom now.
Still, he too suggested that the bill that emerged from Congress would retain some form of market surveillance by the commission and reporting requirements.
"We're not threatening to eliminate them," Mr. Ewing said. "We just want to see how we can make them better. We don't want to just turn these traders loose with no oversight at all."
Ms. Born's plea for a continued strong Federal role in market supervision has found few ardent supporters. Wall Street has, for once, allied itself with the Chicago exchanges to assure equal treatment of the complex financial products it designs for its clients' hedging needs. Consumer groups have been largely silent on the issue and most lawmakers have not studied the intricacies of regulating esoteric financial instruments.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned in a speech earlier this year against "one size fits all" financial market regulation, a statement that was universally read as a call for looser scrutiny of derivatives trading among sophisticated investors.
"Migration of activity from government-regulated to privately regulated markets sends a signal to government regulators that many transactors believe the costs of regulation exceed the benefits," Mr. Greenspan said, warning that traders have already voted against American regulation with their portfolios.
Mr. Greenspan did, however, cite a need for protections against fraud and market manipulation for retail customers.
The commission position has found support from managers of government investment and pension funds, who believe that the $1.7 billion 1994 Orange County derivatives debacle underscored the need for careful regulation of the investment of public money.
And Ms. Born has an ally in John Rainbolt, a former head of the commission and an author of the Commodities Exchange Act of 1974 that established the agency.
Mr. Rainbolt, now a lawyer in Washington, said that the United States sets the standard for the world in market regulation.
"If you exempt seven-eighths of exchange trading from C.F.T.C. regulation," he said, "it's easy to see what happens next -- a quick race to the bottom for all regulators worldwide."

As futures trading heads overseas, the Chicago exchanges rely more on derivatives, but private deals are swamping that business. HEADLINE: Nigeria, Set Back by Sierra Leone Rebels, Flies In More Troops

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, June 3

 BODY:
A day after suffering an embarrassing setback in its efforts to reinstate a civilian leadership overthrown by a military coup, Nigeria flew troop reinforcements into Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone, today in preparation for a new showdown with the coup leaders.
The reinforcements, from a peace-keeping force in neighboring Liberia, arrived as the United States evacuated 1,200 foreigners from Freetown after a day of fierce fighting Monday between the Nigerian force and insurrectionist troops of the Sierra Leone Army. 
 Today's buildup came after Nigerian tropps, working under the banner of the West African Economic Community, abandoned most of their positions around Freetown.
At the annual summit meeting of the Organization of African Unity, in Harare, Zimbabwe, one delegate after another supported Nigeria's efforts, saying that the May 25 coup by junior officers against Sierra Leone's first democratically elected leader, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, must not be allowed to stand.
At the meeting, Sierra Leone's delegate to the United Nations, James Jonah, told Reuters that Nigeria would resume its military action once it had built up its forces.
"When that is finished," he said, "they will go ahead with their objective, which is to remove these thugs who are parading as the Government of Sierra Leone."
The American evacuation today, conducted from a United States warship, the Kearsarge, was the third since the coup.
Landing in the seaside suburb of Aberdeen, about 350 marines loaded terrorized foreigners onto helicopters for transport to the American warship bound for Guinea.
The scene of the two previous evacuations, the Mammy Yoko Hotel, was nearly destroyed in Monday's ferocious combat, which pitted about 50 lightly armed Nigerian soldiers against 150 or more fighters from the Sierra Leonean Army and rural rebels who have joined the coup.
These attacked the hotel, which the Nigerians appeared to be using as an operational base, in retaliation for a heavy round of shelling of rebel positions by Nigerian warships.
With more than 600 foreigners taking shelter in the basement of the Mammy Yoko Hotel, witnesses said, the Sierra Leone forces laid siege to the building on Monday, attacking it with heavy machine guns, mortars and rocket-propelled grenades.
"I have never seen anything like that in my life, and hope never to see anything like it again," a Lebanese man who had taken refuge in the hotel said in a telephone interview. "The building was on fire from all of the hits we had taken, and we were just left to shudder through the whole day. Many of us assumed that our lives had reached their end."
The evacuees included about 30 Americans, believed to be among the last United States citizens in the country, and the British High Commissioner to Sierra Leone, whose departure signaled the closing of the country's last Western embassy. With the completion of the Western evacuation, diplomats said, the country's crisis is shifting into a new phase in which Nigeria, West Africa's military and would-be political powerhouse, faces stark choices about its future commitment there.
According to international and Sierra Leonean radio broadcasts, there was no new fighting in Freetown today, and life began to regain a semblance of normalcy. With the entire city heavily looted by rebellious soldiers, and most businesses either destroyed or closed, thousands of people wandered the city in search of scarce food, fuel and other supplies.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Offer Plan for 0.5% Spending Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 3

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, who has declared that reducing the Japanese budget deficit is his top priority, announced a plan today to cut spending by about half a percent next year.
The plan, which had been expected, is the Prime Minister's first concrete step toward reining in one of the world's highest fiscal deficits. It would cut allocations for social welfare and public works projects, the two biggest components of Japan's budget. It would also reduce military spending and foreign aid, two areas that had been considered immune from cuts. 
 But economists criticized the plan for not adequately addressing the subsidies paid to farmers, who have been hurt by the liberalization of Japanese agricultural trade under international trade agreements. Farmers are a potent political force in Japan, and spending cuts have been resisted by the governing Liberal Democratic Party.
"Prime Minister Hashimoto's plan is something of an achievement and it's a positive move," said Yasunari Ueno, a chief market economist at the Fuji Securities Company, "but failing to cut subsidies to the agricultural sector makes a mess of it."
In moving to reduce its deficit, Japan is being watched by American officials, who want the Japanese to import more from the United States. They are concerned that Japanese domestic demand might weaken.
The package, for the fiscal year that begins next April, was drawn up by a task force led by Mr. Hashimoto. The Cabinet has authorized the spending cuts, which will be presented for approval to the next session of Parliament this fall.
Economists have warned that failure to reduce the deficit would hurt economic growth. The deficit has swollen this decade as the Government has poured as much as 66 trillion yen, or $569 billion, into public works projects since August 1992 to stimulate growth. That spending has had only limited success.
Economists estimate that the deficit constitutes 6.4 percent of Japanese economic output, far surpassing the 1.5 percent to 2 percent recorded lately in the United States. And with Japan's population aging, social welfare costs have increased, further enlarging the deficit.
The Japanese goal, approved by the Cabinet in December, is to cut the deficit to 3 percent of output, or less, before 2005.
Mr. Hashimoto's plan calls for the Government to trim next year's public works spending by about 7 percent, or 679 billion yen, from 9.7 trillion yen in the current fiscal year. Public works accounts for 22 percent of this year's general spending.
The Government would also extend by three years its 10-year, 630 trillion yen public works spending program.
By reducing medical coverage, the Government aims to cut 3.4 percent, or more than 500 billion yen, from social welfare outlays. It also intends to raise from 65 the age at which retirees can receive national pensions and to limit the amounts received by those with high incomes.
Japan will reduce a military spending package of 25.15 trillion yen by about 3.7 percent, or 920 billion yen, over the next three years. It will not allow any increase in next year's military budget.
It also plans to cut next year's assistance to developing countries by about 10 percent.
With regard to farmers, the Cabinet in 1994 agreed to slightly more than six trillion yen in subsidies through the end of the century -- almost $52 billion at current exchange rates -- and to set aside money in each year's supplementary budget. It has now decided to extend the program by two years, and it will not trim the total amount of the program.

LENGTH: 704 words

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Grow Up, Mr. President

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
So now we have the lawyer of the feminist President comparing Paula Jones to a dog. A dead dog.
"The President of the United States is not going to apologize," Robert Bennett said on ABC's "This Week." "And if she insists on a trial, we'll have a trial. . . . I had a dog like that who just wanted to catch cars, and he successfully caught one one day, and I have a new dog." 
 For rhetoric like that, the President may as well retain Sammy Gravano. But Paula Jones is engaged in a risky pursuit, trying to force Bill Clinton -- a master at wiggling out of messes and leaving others to clean up -- to take responsibility.
We will see a legion of men, prompted by the President's lawyer, come forth and accuse Ms. Jones of being a jade who wore short skirts and flirted. Imagine.
But Mr. Bennett is merely the latest Clinton henchman to slime himself trying to prettify the boss.
Mr. Clinton has long enjoyed the services of a machine designed to do whatever was necessary to deflect stories about his erotic misadventures, including smearing women who dared to suggest that there had been trysts. In the 1992 campaign, Michael Isikoff reported in The Washington Post, Betsey Wright stopped what she called "gold diggers" or "bimbos" by hiring the San Francisco private investigator Jack Palladino and paying him more than $100,000 in what were delicately termed "legal expenses."He would dig up dirt on the women and offer to shred their reputations if they went public.
Feminists, who have been loath to support Ms. Jones, were shocked to hear Mr. Bennett last Sunday on "Meet the Press" threaten to root around in the lingerie drawer of the President's accuser. The lawyer was full of blustery intimidation, making sure the press knew that he had installed one of her old lovers in a posh room at the Willard Hotel and had taken a sworn statement about Ms. Jones's habits.
"Bennett is trying to revive the old argument, 'This is a trashy woman,' for no other reason than to back her down," said Patricia Ireland, the president of NOW. She said she once talked to Mr. Bennett about sexual harassment cases and he had said his daughter and female colleagues would keep him "honest" about using a strategy that discredited women by suggesting they had imagined it or asked for it.
Ms. Ireland conceded it was difficult for her organization to set itself in opposition to feminist/misogynists. "It's harder for us to deal with the bad behavior and bad treatment of women by men who stand with us on policy," she said, sounding weary. "We've been getting a lot of E-mails and phone calls from women saying: 'How can you go after Clinton? He's appointed more women, blah-blah-blah.' Clinton made that comment about the Astroturf in the back of his truck. It showed his desire to be seen as a 'real man.' You can be a womanizer and yes, even women can find that attractive. . . . I keep wanting to turn to him and say, 'Grow up.' "
At the moment, The Improvident One is trying out his familiar circumlocutions. He did nothing wrong and he does not remember ever meeting Ms. Jones, but it is possible that she was in his hotel room and that he might be willing to dig himself deeper in debt by contributing $700,000 to her favorite charity.
But what reputation is Bill Clinton trying to protect? A new poll in USA Today shows that even though 72 percent of Americans believe that something happened between Mr. Clinton and Ms. Jones, 57 percent still approve of the President's job performance. They know what his character is, and they have accepted its good and bad parts.
So the President should quit besmirching Paula Jones and settle the case, before people stop seeing him as a likable rogue and start seeing him as an unlikable rogue. It won't affect his place in history, which is set. He will be known as a weak, affable man who presided over a prosperous economy but mistook celebrity culture for political culture, who had distinguishing characteristics but not distinguished character, who relied on his entertainment value and the disappearing attention span of his country to get him out of trouble.
The President should stop kidding himself. His hagiographers will not have much to go on.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 575 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Ford to Build Vehicles Using Ethanol or Gasoline
Ford Motor announced that it would build 250,000 cars, pickup trucks and mini-vans to run on either ethanol or gasoline. The effort, beginning late next year and to last over a period of years, is the largest alternative fuel vehicle program ever in the United States.
Chrysler is expected to announce a similar program, and General Motors is considering the idea. Environmentalists were critical. Under a loophole in Federal law, building dual-fuel vehicles will help Detroit sell more big profit, big-engine, gas-guzzling trucks and sport utility vehicles. Their strong sales are putting Ford and Chrysler at risk of violating Federal fuel-economy standards. [Page A1.] 

General Motors became the second American auto maker, after Chrysler, to report sales fell in May. G.M. had an 8.1 percent drop. [D4.]
 
German Government Yields on Plan
In an embarrassing turnabout, the German Government abandoned a plan opposed by the powerful Bundesbank to cut its budget deficit by revaluing gold reserves. The maneuver was intended to help the country qualify for the single European currency, and the surrender is likely to force a big change in the assumptions underlying the euro. [A8.]
 
Setback to Big Airline Alliance
The General Accounting Office is expected to testify today that because of their proposed alliance American Airlines and British Airways ought to give up a number of their valuable landing rights at London's busy Heathrow Airport. [D2.]
 
Leading Indicators Off in April
The most widely followed index for predicting the economy posted its first decline in 15 months during April. The Conference Board reported a drop of one-tenth of 1 percent in the index of leading indicators, as 6 of 10 components moved lower. [D2.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities moved up in response to the report and to remarks by a Fed official that traders took to mean the economy was slowing. The yield on the long bond dropped to 6.86 percent. [D20.]
 
Stocks Mixed; Dow Advances
Stocks ended mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 22.75 points, to 7,312.15, but technology shares skidded after new profit warnings, pushing the Nasdaq composite index down 19.88 points, to 1,384.91. [D10.]
 
Executive Chosen to Run I.R.S.
Charles O. Rossotti, the chief executive of a Virginia computer company, American Management Systems, has agreed to take on the political and technological problems of running the Internal Revenue Service, Clinton Administration officials said. [D2.]
 
Mexico Sets Growth Targets
The Mexican Government, affirming its economic policies despite electoral setbacks expected for the long-dominant Institutional Revolutionary Party, set goals through the year 2000, including average annual growth of 5 percent. [D22.]
 
Japan Eases Into Budget Cuts
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, under pressure to reduce the budget deficit, offered a plan to cut spending in the next fiscal year by one-half of 1 percent, largely affecting social programs, foreign aid and military costs. Subsidies to the nation's politically powerful farmers were left intact. [D22]
 
Pepsico Faces Regrouping
Pepsico, which intends to spin off its fast-food divisions before the end of the year, has some regrouping to do, as a result of the departure of John F. Antioco, president and chief executive of its Taco Bell unit. [D22.]
