HEADLINE: It's Young vs. Old in Germany As the Welfare State Fades

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, June 3

 BODY:
Timm Gossing is about to start his first full-time job, writing tourism brochures about towns in the former East Germany. And already he feels certain that he will not be shepherded down life's byways in quite the same way as his forebears.
Though the prospect seems distant, he doubts that his retirement years will be underwritten with the sort of generous state pensions available to his parents' generation. And, more immediately, he believes that his first paycheck will leave little for luxuries after the Government deducts its share of pension and social welfare contributions. 
 "We are living out the modernization of Germany," Mr. Gossing, 27, said in an interview in Berlin, one of several with people in the former East and West Germany. "'And it's going the American way: people will have to work harder for less money. The security that they had in the past just won't be there."
Mr. Gossing is describing a squeeze that many Americans and other Europeans might recognize. It is the common assumption that the guarantees of the welfare state need to be reined in if future generations are to inherit a healthy economy.
But the burden will fall heavily on the young adults of today, and they can reject it at the polls. That choice is playing out all across Europe these days, and it helped to bring down the conservatives in the parliamentary elections in France last Sunday.
In Germany these problems have a special force. And a vivid illustration is what could happen to the country's pension plan -- an outlook more dramatic, even, than the worst scenarios drawn up for Americans' Social Security.
Germany, Europe's economic cornerstone, may once have been viewed as economically invulnerable, but now it stands at a tricky intersection of historical forces.
Just as its leaders are concluding that they can no longer afford the pensions and other benefits that a previous generation took for granted, Germany is laboring under the costly burdens of reunification and pressure for greater austerity to achieve its cherished dream of a single strong European currency.
Mr. Gossing is entering Germany's workforce of 40 million people at a critical moment: unemployment is stubbornly high, the Government in Bonn talks increasingly of paring benefits and two generations have become rivals for the substantial leftovers of Germany's prosperity.
The conflict taking shape is between the retirees, who worked long hours for Germany's economic miracle of the 1950's and 1960's and thus feel entitled to comfort, and the 20-and 30-somethings who increasingly are being called on to finance that generation's retirement.
"This is the looming problem," said an official of the Education Ministry in Bonn, who spoke in return for anonymity. "We are not talking left/ right as the basic social division, but young/old."
 
Caught in the Middle, Young Ask for Justice
Indeed, for the young, the newspaper Die Woche said recently, "The prospect of lower pensions at the end of a working life marked by higher contributions is causing many young employees to doubt the validity and justice of the system."
The reason for such prognostications is that, under a system dating to Bismarck and the original German unification, in 1871, pensions paid out today are financed by the paychecks of people like Mr. Gossing, whose late entry into the job market is not unusual for German college graduates.
The system means that, as people of his age pay pension withholdings, the money is not put aside to grow for future pensions, but is used to pay the needs of those now retiring. In other words, some Germans maintain, the old exploit the young.
Additionally, as German society ages and birthrates dwindle, more and more old people will be looking to a shrinking younger generation to support them, meaning that either the old could get smaller pensions or the young may have to pay more to support them.
The American Social Security system is somewhat similar, in that current workers pay much of the costs of benefits for retirees, but the benefits are not as generous as Germany's and the demographic disparities are far less severe.
In Germany, as in the United States, the young seem oddly disadvantaged. While Germany's 16 million pensioners are not organized in the same powerful lobby as are the 35 million retirees in the United States, they are among the nation's most conscientious voters, meaning that political parties court them.
By the year 2030, Government statisticians forecast, more than one-third of the population will be over 60.
One idea for addressing these problems was to gradually increase the retirement age for women to 65 years, from 60, and for men to 65 years, from 63; that proposal became law last year.
Another suggestion this year drew howls of protest by proposing higher taxes on retirees. At present, retirees qualify for state pensions worth 70 percent of the salaries they earned in their final years at work. The Government's idea is to reduce that to 64 percent.
 
Demographic Changes Stagger the System
Germany's pensions system looked like a winner in Bismarck's day, Chancellor Helmut Kohl is fond of saying. Life expectancy for most Germans then was 45 years or less, while the retirement age was 65. These days, people often live well into their 70's and 80's, young people postpone their entry into the workforce as long as possible, and many people try to retire at a younger age under the lucrative plans offered by some employers.
Even then, the system might work if Germans had large families to feed into it, but, particularly in the former East Germany, they do not. Along with Italy and Spain, Germany has long had one of the lowest birth-rates in Europe. According to European Union figures, in the median-sized family in Germany, there are a statistical 1.26 children, compared with 2.05 in the United States.
This means that fewer and fewer young people will enter a workforce on which more and more old people depend for their welfare.
The problem is embedded in a broader question bedeviling the Germans as they reach what Ingeborg Allihn, a retired musicologist and part-time journalist, refers to as a "change of epoch."
"The problems are so big in this society that it cannot go on like this for long," she said in an interview in her high-rise apartment in the former East Berlin. Her remarks reflect a broad sense that change is creeping up on old certainties.
Gotz Platscher, a 32-year-old bank employee who lives in the western part of Berlin but works in the eastern part, said, "It's not as if everything is catastrophic in Germany." . He expressed particular concern about European Union plans to introduce a single currency called the euro. "The euro, for instance," he asked. "What will happen to my money?"
The uncertainty is perceived differently by easterners and westerners, divided still by what some call a spiritual and mental version of the Berlin wall.
For easterners, the challenges to Germany's welfare state, which arise from global economic pressures and the dictates of European economic integration, come as a second rude shock after reunification seven years ago confronted them with a society that many see as offering far less security than Communism.
The old East Germany, Mrs. Allihn said, was "a cozy, warm, very comfortable place for people who wanted to exist with a minimum of effort."
Reunification has been costly for western Germans, not least because they took over the pension obligations of the bankrupt east.
For those westerners looking for a scapegoat, the easiest targets are people perceived to be milking the system without paying their dues -- predominantly eastern Germans and ethnic Germans from the former Soviet Union, millions of whom qualify for state pensions paid in hard marks, even though they paid in pension contributions in now-worthless rubles and East German marks.
"Our pension funds are paying for these people although only a fraction was put in from their side," said Helmut Breiderhoff, 60, a former railways technician from Oberkassel, across the Rhine from Bonn. He took early retirement two years ago as the railways privatized, and found he was taking home slightly more as a pensioner than he earned as a worker.
The German state pension scheme is based on a system of points earned for each year at work, so that the longer people work, the higher their pensions will be.
 
Vast Differences Among Retirees, Too
Elisabeth Obliers, who lives across the street from Mr. Breiderhoff, has a different vision of the system's benefits. After raising three children and working part-time much of her life, Mrs. Obliers, now 60, collects about $600 a month in state pension. "When people say pensioners get a lot, it isn't true for us," she said.
Mr. Breiderhoff, by contrast, spent his career as a communications technician for what was then a state-owned rail system. He takes home just under $2,000 a month. His wife works in a Government ministry in Bonn and stands to get the same when she retires soon.
At the other end of the age scale, Mr. Gossing, starting his first job in Berlin, has secured a job contract guaranteeing him $2,400 for every three-week assignment he completes; working a full year, he would earn more than $40,000. But he said he expects to see 40 to 50 percent of his gross pay withheld, for the state pension, social security, health care and taxes.
Typically, Germans are obliged to contribute a fifth of their gross salaries into the state pension fund, with the employer matching one half of the employee's contribution.
The wealth of many young Germans is clouded by a coincidence of history and demographics that, according to the Government's accounting, will produce a staggering amount of inheritances in the next five years, benefiting the heirs of some 1.7 million thrifty Germans and turning more than 40,000 Germans into overnight millionaires, at least in marks.
Moreoever, many retirees, like Mrs. Obliers and Mr. Breiderhoff, already own inherited homes.
Beyond such windfalls, other statistics illustrate the growing strain on pension funds. According to the Labor Ministry in Bonn, the number of retirees on pension grew by 1.2 million between 1993 and 1995 to some 16.8 million. That is more than a fifth of the population of some 80 million.
In Germany 15.3 percent of the population is 65 or older, a much higher number than in the United States, where the figure is 12.8 percent.
At the same time, Government policies meant to cement the unity of the two Germanys increased eastern German pension levels to 82 percent of the western average of about $1,200 a month.
The total amount paid out in state pensions in 1996 was around $180 billion, of which one-fifth came from Government subsidies added to the amount raised from paycheck withholdings. That figure, representing a doubling of pension payments over 10 years, does not include payments from private pension funds, savings and investments.
In the United States, a Federal advisory panel recently recommended steps to solve the long-term financial problems of Social Security. The panel said workers could get higher rates of return if some of their payroll taxes were invested in the stock market rather than in Government securities, the only investment allowed for the Social Security trust fund under current law. Social Security pays cash benefits to 44 million people, of whom 31 million are retirees.
Other demographic trends are gripping Germany. Women in eastern Germany especially have shied from pregnancy since reunification. "In the old East Germany, I would already have a five-year-old child," said Petra Sagert, a 26-year-old bank clerk in eastern Berlin, where, in the Communist era, the authorities provided day-care centers that gave every woman the chance to go to work. "But now it's difficult," she said. "If I have a child, I have to give up my work."
The implications have already inspired many young people to abandon their parents' expectation of a substantial state pension for their old age.
"A lot of people say they must do something for themselves because the Government won't do anything," said Mr. Platscher in Berlin.

HEADLINE: White House Offers to Alter Tax Package For Education

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration offered today to make changes to its proposed package of tax breaks for college expenses, dropping some frequently criticized elements and adding new ones in an effort to win Congressional support for an initiative that has generated little enthusiasm in either party.
Faced with the likelihood that their original proposal would be rewritten by Congress or cast aside entirely, Administration officials sought to reshape the plan while keeping its central elements, a $1,500 per student tax credit for the costs of each of the first two years of college and a separate deduction of up to $10,000 per family each year for college tuition and fees. 
 Administration officials said they were dropping their requirement that a student maintain a B-minus average to receive the credit for a second year. College administrators had warned that the requirement would create further grade inflation by putting pressure on professors to make sure that students did not lose the tax benefit because of low grades. Republicans had also complained that the requirement would be an administrative nightmare, potentially requiring the Internal Revenue Service to review grades.
Responding to complaints from liberal Democrats that the plan did not do enough for low-income students, the Administration reversed itself and said it would allow the full $1,500 tax credit even if a student were also receiving other Federal student aid under the Pell grant program. To make its plan more attractive to Republicans, the Administration added a proposal backed by the Republican leadership in the Senate to make interest paid on student loans deductible, a tax break that was repealed in 1986. Under the plan, interest payments of up to $2,500 a year would be deductible for up to five years.
To pay for the changes to the plan, officials said the Administration would propose phasing in the tax credit over coming years rather than enacting it at the full $1,500 from the start, as the White House originally proposed. Administration officials estimated that cost of the changes to its plan at $5 billion over five years.
"We're doing this primarily to be responsive to the concerns people have raised and to do so while living within the budget agreement," said David A. Longanecker, the assistant secretary of education for post-secondary education. "To those ends we have tried to come up with a package that is more progressive in structure and simpler and less intrusive."
Lobbying groups for colleges and universities said they were encouraged by the changes. But it was unclear how much support the changes would win from Republicans, who will begin drafting legislation next week to enact the five-year, $135 billion, tax-cutting package agreed to as part of the last month's balanced budget deal.
President Clinton won a vague assurance from the Republican leadership during the budget negotiations that $35 billion of the tax cut would be devoted to programs "consistent" with his college tax break plan. But the chief Republican tax writer, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has made clear that he does not feel bound to any specific plan, and even Democrats said they were unlikely to fight for Mr. Clinton's plan.

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS;
Never Mind Titles, Teams Clamor for New Stadiums

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The possibility that the Yankees will move from the Bronx to a $1 billion Xanadu on Manhattan's West Side, a decision that will probably not be made until after the November mayoral election, is only one chapter in a nationwide drama that might be best described as "Stadium Mania."
In every big-time sport, owners by the dozen are asking for, and usually getting, new stadiums and arenas to finance their cash flow reveries, soaring player salaries, loans to buy their teams and estate plans. 
 The wave of construction has spurred a hot public debate: Should millionaire owners coping with the high cost of business reach into their own pockets to build luxurious sports palaces? Or, scared that a team might leave or eager to lure a team from elsewhere, should state and local governments pay for such places?
"You don't measure sports teams just in dollars and cents," said Peter Karmanos, who last month moved his hockey team, the Hartford Whalers, to North Carolina. "You measure it in cultural spirit. Ask people in Hartford what they think it means to the city when they lost the team, or in Minneapolis-St. Paul. Ask if they'd reconsider subsidizing a team to come back there."
Opponents say that subsidies, such as broad-based sales taxes, constitute corporate welfare, mocking the public's need to pay for essential services. In addition, many studies show that there is little economic gain from these kinds of projects, and that spending on stadiums merely diverts spending from other areas.
"Once you take taxes to pay for a stadium or arena, you can't spend it somewhere else," said Mark Rosentraub, a professor at Indiana University's School of Public and Environmental Affairs. "Stadium construction creates no real wealth. It just transfers it."
Still, a hodgepodge of public and private financial resources makes up the construction plans of 44 professional teams (spread over the four major sports) that are seeking, close to getting or building new stadiums or arenas. The list includes two arenas in Miami and possibly two in Los Angeles, plus two stadiums in Cincinnati, Detroit, Seattle and San Francisco. But it excludes a stadium being built for the renascent Browns in Cleveland, and one proposed for the Coliseum's site in Los Angeles, which has lost two football teams since 1995.
In New York, besides the Yankees' desire for a new stadium, the Mets are planning a retractable domed stadium on a site opposite Shea Stadium, for which they may ask government aid. The Islanders are also looking for a new arena to replace the aging Nassau Coliseum, with help from the county.
"One of the main reasons I bought the team was the understanding that there would be an effort to build a new arena," said John Spano, the team's owner.
 
From the Ball Park To the Ballot Box
The stadium and arena action accelerates almost daily: Columbus, Ohio, voters reject a tax increase for an arena and a soccer stadium. The Whalers pay Connecticut $20.5 million over 15 years to become the Carolina Hurricanes. The Minnesota Twins threaten to leave the Metrodome. The Cincinnati Bengals sign a lease through 2026 for a stadium paid for mostly with a half-cent sales tax.
"It's a renaissance," said Jerry Bell, the president of the Twins. But not for the Twins, at least not yet. The State Legislature has not enacted any measures to finance a new ball park, or even bite at an offer by the owner Carl Pohlad to trade the state a 49 percent interest in the team for financial backing.
And the Twins are not alone in seeking public aid:
 *A referendum was being voted on yesterday in San Francisco to decide whether to approve $100 million in public funds for a $525 million 49ers stadium and entertainment complex at Candlestick Point.
*In two weeks, Seattle voters will be asked to approve a $300 million package of financial aid for construction of a $425 million Seahawks stadium in an election that has been financed, with the approval of the Washington State Legislature, by Paul G. Allen, the Microsoft billionaire.
*The Pittsburgh Steelers and the Pirates, uneasy partners at 26-year-old Three Rivers Stadium, are trying this month to put a referendum to build two stadiums on a November ballot. The financing includes a 10-county sales tax increase.
Each referendum is, in a way, a plebiscite on how far governments should go to help finance stadiums and arenas for privately owned teams. Owners say they merit public subsidies because of the intangible psychological benefits of being a major league town and the economic advantages that teams generate. They wield the ultimate hammer, leaving town, which can bring a vulnerable city to its knees or usher in a sweet deal from another city.
"Corporate welfare? Absurd," said Bud Selig, owner of the Milwaukee Brewers and baseball's acting commissioner. He spent nine years cobbling together the money to pay for the team's new home that will be completed in 2000, Miller Park, including $160 million from a one-tenth of a cent sales tax increase imposed on five counties. "This will produce a better return than many of the things that get government funds."
 
Robber Barons Or Good Citizens?
In San Francisco, the Simon DeBartolo Group, which is half-owned by Ed DeBartolo Jr., the owner of the 49ers, and the Mills Corporation, a mall developer, wanted the city to issue $100 million in bonds to help back a $525 million stadium and mall complex. The old stadium, 3Com (born Candlestick) Park, would be razed.
The team and city have presented many studies to show that taxes generated by the complex will easily pay the debt on the project, and vowed to buy insurance to guarantee payments if there is a revenue shortfall. "It's not viable," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College. "The incremental revenues from the mall and stadium won't pay the debt service." He said the city's estimate of $6.1 million in yearly debt payments -- to be repaid with sales taxes -- should be raised to $10 million.
In a city that rejected public aid for a Giants ball park in 1987 and 1989, suspicion reigns. That trend appeared to be continuing last night in the early returns for the ballot initiative on the stadium and mall complex. With 36 percent of the vote counted, the initiative trailed by 10 percent.
P. J. Johnston, press secretary to Mayor Willie Brown, insisted that taxpayer money would never go into the project, which he said would enrich the low-income residential area near the stadium. He added that the city is better off with a new stadium than with spending up to $130 million to repair 3Com Park.
The campaign also featured the carrot and the threat: the National Football League promised three Super Bowls for a new stadium. If there is no stadium, DeBartolo has threatened to move, perhaps to open-armed Los Angeles.
 
A Big Question Of Who Is Neediest
In Seattle, the question of whether Paul Allen, whose Microsoft stock is worth $12.4 billion, deserves help from the public, is frequently heard.
"Remember, Paul Allen was coaxed into this," said Bob Gogerty, a campaign consultant to Allen. "This is a team whose owner was going to move the team in a van and Paul picked up the option. He's saying, 'I'll be a part of this.' "
But skepticism persists. In 1995, voters spurned a referendum providing financing for a $320 million Mariners ball park, then watched the Washington Legislature retool the measure and pass it.
This time, voters are being asked to approve $300 million from lottery games, stadium admission and parking taxes, sales tax credits and deferrals and an eight-year extension of a King County lodging tax. "Who's more in need?" asked Shawn Newman, chairman of Citizens for Leaders with Ethics and Accountability Now. "The guy on the street or the guy who made a billion dollars in a single day?"
But Allen has urgency and leverage. He is paying $4.2 million to hold the election, which state law allows. His option to buy the Seahawks from Ken Behring expires on July 1. And he is spending several million dollars to spread his message on television, in newspapers and through direct mail. "To the opponents, I ask, 'Would you rather not have a vote?' " Gogerty said.
 
In Columbus, Ohio, The Voters Said No
In Columbus, Ohio, a referendum to impose a three-year, half-cent sales tax increase to help finance a $285 million soccer stadium-arena venture failed, hurting a downtown revitalization effort. The referendum was defeated partly by voters not wanting a new tax or not believing the tax would end in three years.
"Subsidizing some people's idea of entertainment is not the government's role," said Richard Sheir of Voters Against Stadium Taxes. "Everyone who voted no knew they would have been subsidizing a private business."
Proponents point to another factor in the measure's defeat: visits by Peter Karmanos, who was city-shopping in Columbus before settling in North Carolina. They say the ballot led in polls before he came to town, but trailed when he left.
They describe him as a gum-chewing swaggerer who vowed to match a deal to run the complex proposed by the conservative Lamar Hunt, who owns the Crew, the Major League Soccer team, and the Kansas City Chiefs.
Karmanos's presence seemed to crystallize doubts about subsidizing a private business owned by a magnate. Greg Haas, the referendum's campaign manager, said, "I've been kicking my tail for three weeks that I didn't keep him out."
But Karmanos disputed that: "I called the $90 million soccer stadium they were going to build a white elephant, which detracted from the arena site.
"And they were trying to play this scam, that the arena wasn't built for a sports team. Hey, no one builds an arena without a team."
Supporters of the Seattle and San Franciso measures doubt that the Columbus vote will affect their referendums, although a double rejection would reverse a trend.
Still, each city's situation is different; many don't use referendums, others want to enhance their reputations by getting a team, regardless of municipal fiscal woes. Team situations differ, too. Are voters being asked to say "yes" to a tax or a lottery to lure a team? Or to help a beloved one? Is the team in first place? Or last?
The odds of passing referendums depend on how they are marketed and explained.
 
Private Money Is Now More Common
Public money will most likely remain a key element of most stadium and arena construction. But Marc Ganis, president of Sportscorp, a consulting firm, said public money is risky. "You add significant cost because the public doesn't build things efficiently," he said. "If a project goes over cost, everyone knows politicians will find extra money."
Private money is becoming more prevalent, with cash coming from rights to a stadium's name, luxury suites and personal seat licenses. The licenses are fees paid for the right to buy season tickets, an option that can't be used everywhere.
Other revenue sources include taxing the main beneficiaries of stadiums and arenas, with levies on player income, broadcasts, advertising, tickets and merchandise. Indiana University's Rosentraub said that if public money must be used, governments should get a stake in the team or a piece of the profits when it is sold.
A $250 million arena for the Los Angeles Kings and Lakers is to be built with private money by the Kings' owners, Philip Anschutz and Ed Roski Jr.
They are also exploring the possibility of building a new football stadium in the city.
"With 230 events each year, it's easier to finance an arena with private money than a stadium, with 30 events," said Tim Leiweke, the Kings' president.
But no project carries the cost of the proposed West Side Yankee ball park. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and George M. Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, are silent about whether the Yankees will leave the Bronx, or how much the state and city will contribute to construction and infrastructure.
Steve Newman, the city's first deputy controller, said the cost estimates of renovating Yankee Stadium "are reasonable, but the money suggested for a new stadium is not." He said the city would use money from its capital budget for a renovation, "but any extra item means something else can't be done."
What Giuliani does or does not do could have ripple effects nationwide.
"If Giuliani gives in to Steinbrenner," Rosentraub said, "he's going to hurt every city in the country."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
State's Bond Rating Is Stable

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Two weeks after it expressed concern about New Jersey's fiscal soundness, Standard & Poor's has decided not to lower the state's AA+ bond rating, an official said yesterday. The rating agency made that decision because the state's overall economy is healthy, said Robin L. Prunty, the chief analyst for New Jersey at Standard & Poor's. 
 But she warned that next year's budget would be "narrowly balanced" because of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to borrow $2.75 billion to help erase a deficit in the public employee pension system and provide $590 million in budget savings for the next fiscal year. The plan would also increase the state's overall debt by one-third.

HEADLINE: McGreevey Wins Democratic Nod for Governor

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
In an extremely tight race to decide who would represent the Democratic Party in its effort to recapture New Jersey's governor's mansion, James E. McGreevey, a 39-year-old perpetual campaigner who has spent much of his adult life pursuing elective offices, defeated his two rivals for his party's nomination yesterday.
With 99 percent of the votes counted and the rest to be counted today, Mr. McGreevey, who is both a State Senator and the Mayor of Woodbridge, held a 5,000-vote lead over his chief rival, Robert E. Andrews, a United States Representative from southern New Jersey. Altogether, more than 350,000 votes were cast, a light turnout. 
 Mr. McGreevey had 39 percent of the votes counted, and most of the remaining precincts were in counties where he had received the party's endorsement.
The third candidate, Michael Murphy, who ran without any of the coveted endorsements from party leaders, had 21 percent of the vote.
Mr. McGreevey arrived at a hotel in Woodbridge early this morning, accepting the nomination and outlining some of the things he is likely to talk about in the campaign.
"Today is the beginning of the end of government by gimmick," he said. "And it is the start of improving our schools, getting auto insurance under control, moving our economy forward and ending our state's terrible addiction to property taxes."
Mr. Andrews conceded early today.
Mr. McGreevey's victory set the stage for a showdown between a little-known Democratic contender and a Republican incumbent with a national reputation, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. In an off year for politics, the race will be one of only two gubernatorial contests in the country. Since Virginia's Governor, George Allen, is leaving office, Mrs. Whitman is the nation's only Governor seeking re-election in November.
While glossy magazine covers and network television have helped to make Governor Whitman a familiar figure in national politics, in New Jersey her image has lost luster as some of her policies, like her vaunted tax cuts, have been attacked. New Jersey provides public dollars for gubernatorial races, and winning the Democratic nomination means that Mr. McGreevey will have the state-allowed maximum of $6.9 million to take on Governor Whitman this fall.
In selecting Mr. McGreevey, a son of the working-class, sprawling communities of central New Jersey, Democrats insured another spirited clash over a $2.8-billion-dollar tax increase approved in 1990 by Gov. James Florio. Mr. McGreevey, a State Assemblyman at the time, voted for the increase.
"We will be happy to talk about Jim McGreevey's support for the Florio taxes," Mrs. Whitman's campaign manager, Tom Wilson, said yesterday.
For Governor Whitman, who ran unopposed for the Republican nomination, the party started early in the evening. She claimed her victory at a celebration in Princeton that cost an estimated $50,000. In a speech, she emphasized her administration's efforts on crime, auto insurance, government spending and welfare. Then she issued a challenge: "I ask my opponent, whomever that may be, to join with me in making that commitment to the people of New Jersey -- that we are not going to trade insults and twist facts."
Republican political analysts had said that Governor Whitman would rather face Mr. McGreevey than Mr. Andrews, in part because of his vote for the tax increase and because Governor Whitman's polish and stature would help her project a mature and strong image over the boyish Mr. McGreevey.
In his concession, Mr. Andrews said, "I have just called Senator McGreevey," he said. "I have offered him, on behalf of my family, my congratulations." He added, "I want him, and voters all over New Jersey to know that they can sign me up" for Mr. McGreevey's fall campaign.
Mrs. Whitman announced yesterday that she would begin her post-primary campaign today in southern New Jersey. In an interview last night, a confident Mrs. Whitman said she would start campaigning in southern New Jersey "because we want to remind everyone that we're not conceding any part of the state."
She said she was not concerned that her support may be wavering among voters in response to the pending vote in the State Senate on her pension bond sale or the ongoing struggle with high auto insurance rates. "We're a long way from the election," Mrs. Whitman said. "I'm not going to worry about that until November."
The Democratic nominee starts the general election campaign as little more than a slingshot-wielding challenger looking up at a gigantic Republican opponent who can easily raise money and attract media attention and is expected to defend her incumbency fiercely. Currently fighting criticism of her proposed $2.7 billion pension bond sale, Governor Whitman has also been stung by the state Supreme Court's rejection of her financing plan for urban school districts and by a petition drive calling for her to force lower automobile insurance rates. The last few weeks she has stayed on the campaign sidelines, as the Democratic candidates hammered away at her record.
Also, while voters may be disappointed that property taxes and auto insurance rates have continued to rise under the Governor, any disenchantment with her first-term performance has not turned into the same brand of venomous anger that undid Mr. Florio in 1993. Still, New Jersey voters are politically fickle: About half the state's 4.4 million registered voters classify themselves as independents. Just as Mrs. Whitman's approval ratings have slipped in recent polls, they could continue to do so up until Election Day, if the nominee can create enough anger among voters about the Governor's administration.
Yesterday's voting ended a primary season that started several months ago but attracted little widespread attention until recent weeks, when the candidates' televised debates and advertising started. Among the initial field of six or seven potential candidates was former Governor Florio, who left the field to the lesser-known names when he announced in February that he would not seek the nomination and vowed to support Mr. Andrews.
Mr. Murphy, 48, the stepson of former Gov. Richard J. Hughes, provided the race with a third contender who, although he lacked party support and money, was able to attract a surprising amount of attention with his offbeat television advertisements, his positive campaigning and his charming wit.
He won Hunterdon, Mercer and Morris Counties, but took less than a quarter of the votes statewide. In a concession speech shortly after 11 P.M., Mr. Murphy said, "We came from close to ground zero, 1 or 2 percent name recognition, people were telling us that this could not be done." One of the biggest questions in the race was just what effect the Democratic county organizations would have on the race. This was the first time in more than 15 years that the county parties were allowed to endorse a gubernatorial candidate, thus giving the candidate a prime spot on the ballot and help with getting people to the polls. Of the 21 county endorsements, Mr. McGreevey had the most, with 12, while Mr. Andrews was endorsed by nine county organizations.

HEADLINE: Ford Pushes an Ethanol Line, But Gas-Guzzlers Profit, Too

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 3

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would begin building 250,000 cars, mini-vans and pickup trucks annually that can burn ethanol or gasoline, in the largest alternative fuel program in the United States since the oil crises of the 1970's produced alarm about American reliance on imported energy.
Chrysler is expected to announce a similar program next week, ethanol and auto industry officials said. General Motors is considering whether to follow Ford and Chrysler's example. 
 Ford officials characterized their announcement as part of a corporate commitment to clean air. The No. 2 American auto maker said it hoped the sharp increase in the availability of ethanol-burning vehicles -- it made just 5,000 such vehicles last year -- would prompt more service stations to sell the fuel. Only 40 stations currently sell ethanol, which is grain-based alcohol mixed with a little gasoline.
But as much as Ford and No. 3 Chrysler trumpet a commitment to the environment, they have an even bigger commitment to something they hold dear: profits. Under a loophole in Federal law, building the dual-fuel vehicles will help them sell more big-profit, big-engine, gasoline-guzzling trucks and sport utility vehicles at a time when strong sales of these vehicles is putting both companies at risk of violating Federal fuel-economy standards.
Environmentalists were skeptical about the plan, contending that it violated the spirit, if not the letter, of the standards.
Ford plans to make dual-fuel versions of the Taurus sedan, the Windstar mini-van and the Ranger pick-up truck. As far as buyers are concerned, the choice of fuels will make no difference, Ford said.
Sticker prices will be identical. Ford will outfit the vehicles with stainless steel fuel systems that can run on either gasoline or ethanol, and they will have a small emblem on the sides of the car representing a green leaf sprouting from a roadway. Drivers will have the option of switching fuels every time they fill up.
Michael T. McCabe, Ford's worldwide marketing manager for alternative fuel vehicles, acknowledged that many people might just put gasoline in the new vehicles. "The customer is totally flexible," he said.
That may be, but environmental groups scoffed at the idea of building such a huge number of vehicles, about 6 percent of Ford's total production last year, when there are currently only 40 stations that pump ethanol, all in the Midwest and Idaho.
Daniel Becker, an energy expert at the Sierra Club, said Ford was inappropriately using a loophole in Federal fuel laws. "Ford's announcement about making cars for which there is no fuel is a cynical ploy to avoid violating a law," he said.
By law, the total of pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans an auto maker sells in a year must have fuel efficiency that averages 20.7 miles a gallon. If Ford and Chrysler sell too many versions with high horsepower and low fuel efficiency their "fleet averages" sink, and they can incur costly penalties. Although auto makers have managed to manipulate production and sales to avoid such fines, they have resorted to a host of methods, including flooding the market with smaller, more full-efficient models, often carrying large rebates, to keep their averages within limits.
Federal fuel-economy laws are administered by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which is part of the Transportation Department. The agency, which has a nonpartisan tradition, declined to comment on Ford's move.
It is difficult to predict exactly how much Ford or Chrysler's overall fuel economy may be helped by selling dual-fuel vehicles. The formula that measures the fuel efficiency of these vehicles is quite complex. Mr. McCabe said, however, that for each such vehicle, Ford could effectively sell two more of its hot-selling, mammoth Expedition sport utility vehicles. But because the formula counts a dual-fuel vehicle as roughly equivalent to a gasoline-powered vehicle the gets 60 miles a gallon, the benefit could be even greater to the auto maker's fuel average.
Auto makers earn this bonus regardless of whether the customer ever buys any ethanol.
Not only is the fuel hard to come by, it is also more expensive to use.
A gallon of ethanol fuel, actually 85 percent ethanol and 15 percent gasoline, sells for about the same or slightly less than a gallon of midgrade gasoline. But because of differences in the energy in each fuel, a car gets fewer miles to the gallon on this blend, known as E85, so the cost per mile can actually be about 15 percent higher, Mr. McCabe said.
Besides the stainless steel fuel system, Ford installs an electronic sensor that continuously measures the proportion of ethanol to gasoline entering the engine and adjusts the operation of several engine parts .
The sensor and stainless steel fuel system currently cost Ford an extra $300 a vehicle, but that should drop with larger-scale production, Mr. McCabe said. Beginning a year from now, Ford plans to make 50,000 to 60,000 Ford Ranger compact pickup trucks a year with dual-fuel engines, he said. Within four years, the company plans to make 250,000 midsize Tauruses, Rangers and Windstar mini-vans annually with dual-fuel engines. All of the enthanol cars will be powered by Ford 3.0-liter V6 engines.
With sales rising year after year for Chrysler's Jeeps and Ford's F-150 full-size pickup trucks, and strong sales in the first year of the Ford Expedition, both auto makers are in danger of violating Federal laws and paying penalties that would run into the tens of millions of dollars.
G.M., the world's biggest car maker, also has some difficulties complying with the fuel-economy rules but is focusing its energy on the development of electric vehicles rather than ethanol-powered cars. Most foreign auto makers, particularly the Japanese, have relatively little difficulty meeting the United States standards because they mostly make smaller, lighter cars and engines that get more miles to the gallon of gasoline.
The N.H.T.S.A. has the authority from Congress to raise Federal fuel-economy standards as technology improves. But the Republican Congress, at the request of auto makers, has blocked it from doing so for the last two years by attaching provisions to the Federal budget blocking any spending for this task and may do so again this year.
Auto executives are convinced that the White House would like to skirt Congressional opposition, although the Administration has not yet introduced any formal initiative to do so. But by building a lot of dual-fuel vehicles, the auto makers could protect themselves from all but the most stringent changes in Federal standards.
Ford's average fuel economy for mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks for the 1996 model year was just 20.6 miles a gallon, while Chrysler's was just 20.3. Ford did not face any penalties because the law allows an auto maker to average any year with the three years before it and the three years after it. But with sales of pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles continuing to rise and overall fuel economy still falling, both auto makers are struggling even to meet the seven-year averages.
Philip M. Novell, the general sales manager for Ford-brand cars and trucks, said in an interview that the company was determined to meet the law. Expanded production of the dual-fuel vehicles "enhances our ability to comply with the law, and we will be in compliance," he said.
In calculating the average fuel economy of an auto maker's vehicles, the Federal Government takes a weighted average based on each vehicle's efficiency in the city and on highways. By an odd coincidence, Brazil, the only large country that switched to mostly ethanol-powered cars after the oil crises of the 1970's, has been switching back to gasoline-powered cars as the Government reduces ethanol subsidies as supplies have proved irregular.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 5, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the Ford Motor Company's plans to build cars, mini-vans and pickup trucks that can burn ethanol, gasoline or a combination of the fuels misstated the scale of production. Ford plans to build 250,000 of the vehicles by 2001, not 250,000 in 2001.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against Pound And Gains a Bit on the Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the British pound yesterday after Britain's top central banker said the pound had risen too quickly against the mark.
The pound has climbed nearly 20 percent against the mark in the last year, and has strengthened recently on expectations that the planned single European currency, the euro, will be weakened by the Socialist victory in France and by the dispute in Germany between the Government and the central bank. 
 Yesterday, the governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, said the pound's strength was "exaggerated."
Britain, which has not decided to join Europe's monetary union, has been viewed as a haven by traders worried that the euro, which would replace the mark and other European currencies, will be weak.
The dollar also continued to gain against the mark amid concerns over the euro.
"The Deutsche mark is weaker based on European problems with the euro," said Doug Schaefer, a director of foreign exchange sales at Bank of Boston.
The dollar rose as high as 1.7317 marks, before settling in New York at 1.7292 marks, up from 1.7275 Tuesday. The pound fell to $1.6324 from $1.6351.
The dollar rose against the yen on speculation that a Japanese tax increase in April would slow the economy, reversing the faint signs of recovery it showed in the first quarter. Traders are also betting Japanese interest rates will not rise soon.
"People are coming to the realization that the yen is fundamentally overvalued," said Anil Agarwal, currency specialist at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. "The domestic economy is in bad shape. I don't think the Bank of Japan is anywhere near raising interest rates."
In New York, the dollar settled at 116.25 yen, up from 116.03 yen.
Even as British officials criticized the pound's strength yesterday, the currency could climb further if British lending rates are raised to take some steam out of the economy.
"Their economy is doing quite well and they need to slow it down a bit," Mr. Agarwal said. "They will have at least one or two rate increases left."
Higher interest rates would make debt and bank deposits denominated in the pound more appealing.

HEADLINE: Computer Stocks Extend Slump; Dow Falls by 42.49

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, as computer issues extended a weeklong slump and financial stocks dropped on concern over higher interest rates.
Since setting records a week ago, stocks have fallen flat, hurt by a string of company forecasts for weaker-than-expected profits and by worries that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates this summer. 
 "The stock market has done a year's work in six months," said Ronald Muhlenkamp, chief investment officer at Muhlenkamp & Company. "If the market's return over time is about 10 percent a year, we're already there."
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 42.49 points yesterday, to 7,269.66, almost 115 points below its record reached on May 27. Still, the Dow is up 13 percent for the year, most of which was accumulated in the last two months.
Bond prices slipped yesterday, pushing the benchmark yield on the 30-year Treasury bond to 6.88 percent, from 6.86 percent on Tuesday.
The rise in rates hurt financial companies and among the Dow's biggest decliners yesterday were American Express, which slipped 1 1/4, to 68 1/2, and J. P. Morgan, which fell 7/8, to 108.
Broader market indexes were also lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 5.37, to 840.11, and has now declined in five of six sessions since hitting a new high of 849.71.
While more stocks fell than rose in trading yesterday, with declining issues topping advancers, 1,365 to 1,178, on the New York Stock Exchange, the market had its share of winners.
Eli Lilly rose 1 1/8, to 93 3/8, on expectations the company would report encouraging results today from studies of its new osteoporosis drug, Evista. The market for such drugs, which help prevent bones from becoming brittle, is expected to reach $5 billion by the year 2005.
Boeing climbed 2 1/8, to 107, amid optimism that the company's plan to buy its rival, McDonnell Douglas, for $14.5 billion in stock would be approved by regulators, said Paul Nisbet, an analyst at JSA Research. Shareholders for both companies will vote on the transaction next month.
The Nasdaq composite index, which is heavily laden with computer-related issues, fell 5.24, to 1,379.67. The memory chip maker Intel, the networking company Cabletron Systems and the disk drive maker Seagate Technology all warned that earnings for the current quarter would be off the mark because of slack demand.
"I think we're sort of in a trading range through the earnings report period here," said Bob Finch, who invests in growth stocks for Aeltus Investment Management, which has $36 billion under management. "People are going to be less willing to chase stocks to new highs, particularly those involving computers and networking products."
The Morgan Stanley high-technology index fell 3.80, to 410.33. In the last five days, the index has fallen 30.68 points, or 7 percent. Intel fell 2 1/2, to 142 1/2, and is now down 13 percent since Friday's announcement. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette reiterated its view that the stock would underperform the market.
The networking products maker Ascend Communications fell 2 7/16, to 47 7/8; U. S. Robotics fell 3 1/8, to 76 7/8; Compaq Computer dropped 1 1/2, to 98 1/2; Cascade Communications dropped 1 9/16, to 32 3/4; Linear Technology fell 2 1/16, to 48 1/2; 3Com slipped 1 7/8, to 44 1/16, and Microsoft fell 1 9/16, to 119 3/16.
Iomega was an exception, rallying 1, to 20 1/4, on speculation the disk drive company could become the object of a takeover bid. Investors also cited the company's announcement that Chicony Electronics of Taipei, Taiwan, would include Iomega's Zip drives in its notebook computers.

HEADLINE: New Cabinet Is Announced In France

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 4

 BODY:
France's new Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, today announced a new Cabinet whose 14 ministers include 2 Communists and a member of the environmentalist Greens party.
Five of the 14 are women. In all, 8 of the 26 new ministers, deputy ministers and junior ministers, or 30 percent, are women -- far more than in the conservative coalition Government the Socialists defeated in last Sunday's parliamentary elections. 
 Mr. Jospin, who promised a slimmed-down Government that would be clean of the corruption scandals that have tainted nearly all French political parties in recent years, consulted France's conservative President, Jacques Chirac, about the list, as required by the French Constitution.
One American diplomat said tonight that the United States and other allies of France would probably have no difficulty working with the new Government. He also said that Mr. Jospin might accompany Mr. Chirac to an economic summit meeting with President Clinton and other leaders in Denver June 20-22.
Mr. Clinton wrote Mr. Jospin a letter of congratulations on Tuesday and said he hoped they could have a get-acquainted meeting soon, the new Prime Minister's aides said.
To coordinate the assault on France's 12.8 percent unemployment rate that Mr. Jospin promised would be his Government's first priority, he named Martine Aubry, a 46-year-old Socialist, as Minister of Employment and Solidarity.
Mrs. Aubry is the daughter of the former President of the European Union Commission, Jacques Delors, who was rumored to be a contender for Foreign Minister. But that post went to Hubert Vedrine, 49, a veteran Socialist foreign policy expert who served as chief of staff to the late President Francois Mitterrand and was one of his closest associates.
Running economic policy for the new Government will be Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the architect of Mr. Jospin's winning election strategy, named at the head of a new super-Ministry of the Economy, Finance and Industry.
Mr. Jospin put Alain Richard, 51, a Socialist budget expert with no previous defense experience, at the head of the Defense Ministry, an indication that he probably does not intend to contest Mr. Chirac's plans to restructure the French armed forces over the next decade to make them smaller and more mobile and to end military conscription.
The Prime Minister named Catherine Trautmann, 46, who as Socialist Mayor of Strasbourg organized a huge demonstration this spring against the far-right National Front party, as his Government spokeswoman as well as Minister of Culture and Communications.
Another Socialist, Elisabeth Guigou, 50, a former Minister of European Affairs, became Minister of Justice. Jean-Pierre Chevenement, 50, a controversial former Defense Minister, took the Ministry of the Interior.
Mr. Chevenement resigned from the Defense post in 1991 in protest against French participation in the Persian Gulf war to push Iraqi forces out of Kuwait. Later, he opposed Mr. Mitterrand's decision to support a European Union plan for a common European currency in 1999. The economic austerity policies of Mr. Chirac's conservative coalition Government were pursued in order to lower the budget deficit -- a condition for the common currency.
Robert Hue, the Communist Party leader, did not join the Government, but persuaded his party to participate, perhaps in exchange for concessions from Mr. Jospin that have not yet been disclosed. Two Communists became ministers, taking the portfolios of Infrastructure, Transportation and Housing, and Youth and Sports. A third became a junior minister in charge of tourism.
Dominique Voynet, of the Greens party, became Minister of the Environment and Land Use.
The new Cabinet, the first Socialist-led one since 1993, will meet for the first time Thursday morning.
Mr. Jospin has pledged to negotiate with France's European partners to loosen the tight budget-deficit requirements for the common currency. Mr. Jospin spoke with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany by telephone this morning, presumably to reassure him about France's continued commitment to the project, French officials said.
Mr. Jospin's Communist allies have been opposed to it. Their 38 seats in the new Parliament provide the votes he needs for a majority in the 577-seat Parliament, but he excluded them from crucial jobs dealing with European issues.
Mr. Jospin made no policy statements today, and may not do so until he makes his first big speech in Parliament later this month.

HEADLINE: Ford Sales Off as Industry Endures a Dismal Spring

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 4

 BODY:
For the auto industry, the spring selling season was as damp and cold as the weather across most of the country.
The Ford Motor Company said today that its sales dropped 3 percent in May as the auto industry reported its second consecutive lackluster sales month. May's auto sales were well below their levels during the corresponding period a year ago, when buyers were snapping up new cars and trucks. 
 Following the industry pattern, Ford's car sales were far weaker than the company's truck sales. Ford sold 153,724 cars in May, down 12.1 percent from May 1996. But it sold 206,087 sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks, up 5.2 percent from the period a year ago. Sales of its wildly popular giant sport utility vehicle, the Expedition, reached nearly 21,000 last month.
The industry as a whole sold cars and trucks at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 14.8 million in May, down 5.8 percent from a year earlier. At this year's pace, the numbers "are not terrible, but they're far from great," said Stephen J. Girsky, an analyst with Morgan Stanley.
The industry's car sales dropped 11.2 percent in May while truck sales rose 2 percent, compared with the period a year ago.
Ford said that the spring sales slowdown, combined with the brisk selling pace during the first quarter, left industry auto sales on track to meet Ford's full-year estimate of sales between 14.7 million and 15.2 million cars, sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks.
"As anticipated, the last couple of months haven't matched the first quarter's sales rate, but year-to-date sales are consistent with our full-year forecast," said Robert L. Rewey, Ford's group vice president for marketing and sales. "The fundamentals in the U.S. economy and our business remain positive -- moderate growth, low inflation and high employment." Some of Ford's most important sellers languished last month. The Taurus sedan saw its sales drop 26.7 percent from a year earlier, despite offers of cut-rate financing. F-series pickup truck sales dropped 10.7 percent compared with the period a year ago. Just three of Ford's cars posted better sales than a year ago: the Ford Escort, up 8.3 percent, Mercury Grand Marquis, up 15.6 percent and Lincoln Continental, up 2.6 percent.
For Ford, sales were strong in early May, weakened in the middle of the month and then began to recover a few days before Memorial Day, said Philip M. Novell, the general sales manager of Ford brand cars and trucks. But he added that it was not clear how long the strong sales in late May would persist.
All of the Big Three auto makers posted May sales declines. Along with Ford's 3 percent drop, the General Motors Corporation said its sales fell 8.5 percent and the Chrysler Corporation said its sales dropped 16.6 percent. Japanese auto makers had mixed results in May: while Toyota's sales fell 6 percent, Nissan said its sales rose 7.8 percent and Honda said its sales rose 4.8 percent. The Big Three ended May with 72.6 percent of the United States auto market, down from 74.5 percent inthe period a year ago. Japanese and German auto makers gained market share at the Big Three's expense in May.
Wall Street analysts have said that Japanese auto makers are gaining ground on the Big Three this year because of the strong dollar and because they have recently introduced popular new products like the Toyota Camry sedan and small sport utility vehicles like the Honda CR-V and the Toyota RAV-4.
But Ford's Mr. Novell questioned the extent to which the introduction of imported sport utility vehicles this year had hurt American manufacturers. The Honda CR-V, for example, seems to have taken sales from the Honda Accord, he said, with Honda selling 27,108 CR-V's since its introduction four months ago but also about 22,000 fewer Accord sedans this year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Brazilians Sell $3 Billion Of Unsecured 30-Year Debt

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Brazil, seeking to reorganize its foreign debt and reduce its future liabilities for interest by at least $160 million, sold $3 billion of unsecured 30-year bonds yesterday, most of which are being exchanged for Brady bonds.
The landmark transaction was an important step on the road that is returning more creditworthy developing countries to the international capital markets. 
 In the market for United States Treasury securities yesterday, wariness over both a big supply of new issues -- Ford Motor Credit is selling a $1 billion issue -- and fear that the market might be unprepared for strong employment data this week, led to an easing in the price of Treasury securities. The 30-year bond slipped 5/32, to a price of 96 26/32, pushing its yield up to 6.88 percent, from 6.86 percent on Tuesday.
The Brady bonds that Brazil and other countries issued are securities that came into being through a plan developed in 1989 under the Bush Administration's Secretary of the Treasury, Nicholas F. Brady, to reduce those nations' outstanding foreign bank debts.
This is the third unsecured global bond deal, bankers said. The securities are registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission and sold to investors around the world. The previous two transactions, both completed in 1993, were a $3.5 billion issue for the Italian Government and another for the Canadian province of Ontario.
Brazilian officials, in New York yesterday, expressed satisfaction at the results of the transaction, in which the bonds were sold at a price to yield 3.95 percentage points more than Treasuries. The deal, they said, would reduce their debt-service costs, return collateral and give their country an important benchmark in international capital markets.
"They're going to save between $160 million and $220 million in net present value terms by exchanging Brady bonds for global bonds," said Charles B. Seelig Jr., managing director in charge of emerging market debt at Goldman, Sachs & Company, which arranged the issue, along with J. P. Morgan & Company. In addition, Brazil is now able to take back some $600 million of Treasury securities it had deposited at the Bank for International Settlements as collateral against the Brady bonds that are being retired in this transaction.
A quarter of the new bonds were issued for cash, with the remaining $2.25 billion issued to retire a total of $2.7 billion of Brady bond debt, bankers organizing the issue said yesterday. "This provides Brazil with a long-term liquid benchmark bond," said Rachel Hines, head of Latin American debt capital markets at J. P. Morgan.
Bankers said they expected other nations with large amounts of Brady bond debt to follow Brazil's lead, with Venezuela, Mexico and Argentina considered among the most likely candidates in Latin America. Last year, Mexico issued $6 billion of bonds to reorganize its foreign debt, but those bonds were secured and not registered with the S.E.C.
Ford Motor Credit priced its 10-year global bonds to yield 7.212 percent, or 59 basis points more than a comparable United States Treasury issue through Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley & Company.
Firms managing bond sales often hedge against possible losses by selling United States Government securities before the sale, while in some cases investors looking to buy the new debt sell Treasuries to raise cash.
Affecting the broad market, a solid gain reported in April factory inventories yesterday by the Commerce Department was stronger than expected, and traders feared that this raised prospects for gross domestic product growth in the second quarter, and with it the odds of another interest-rate increase by the Federal Reserve at its policy meeting next month.
Michael Englund, chief economist at MMS International in San Francisco, said that the strength in factory restocking might have continued through May, given the strength in Monday's report by the National Association of Purchasing Management, and that "this represents additional upside risk in the Friday employment report."

HEADLINE: New York Bartender to Ireland's Kingmaker

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: MOYVAN, Ireland

 BODY:
The most notable public event on a warm recent afternoon in this hamlet in rural southwest Ireland was the arrival of a huge white bus carrying Dick Spring, the local County Kerry boy who made good in Dublin.
And once again, Mr. Spring, who has been Deputy Prime Minister three times in a 16-year political career and is also Foreign Minister and head of the Labor Party, may become the the kingmaker in Irish national politics. 
 On one side in the campaign for the election on June 6 is the incumbent Government coalition of the Fine Gael Party of Prime Minister John Bruton, Mr. Spring's Labor Party, the third largest in Ireland, and the smaller Democratic Left Party. On the other is a coalition headed by Bertie Ahern, a former Finance Minister and leader of the Fianna Fail party, the largest in the country, supported by the much smaller Progressive Democrats.
The issues are taxes, crime, unemployment and choosing a group that would do a better job of working with the British Government to end the sectarian violence and bring peace to the British province of Northern Ireland.
[The latest polls show the Government coalition trailing by 4 percentage points, with 11 percent of the potential voters still undecided.]
Most experts say that the results will be very close and that neither coalition may win the 84 seats needed to form a Government in the 166-member Irish Parliament.
If that happened, Mr. Spring and Labor, which currently has 32 seats, would probably hold the balance of power. He could stick with Mr. Bruton's coalition, but if that still did not give the coalition enough seats, Mr. Spring could switch his support to the opposition group. Although he says he has no intention of doing this, he has not ruled it out categorically. In 1994 he put the Bruton coalition into power after he walked out of a coalition with Mr. Ahern's party.
Mr. Spring, 46, is a tall, slender, soft-spoken former international rugby star and onetime Manhattan bartender. If he is part of another coalition, it would mean that he would, as Deputy Prime Minister, be the country's No. 2 official for the fourth time. Because his own party is too small, he would have little prospect of ever becoming Prime Minister, a job even his political enemies acknowledge he could handle well.
Campaigning recently here in Moyvan, surrounded by green pastures and dairy farms, Mr. Spring moved quickly in a white dress shirt, sleeves still buttoned at the cuffs, in the midday sun, a light breeze carrying the scents of animal fertilizer and newly cut grass, some of it just mowed by Mr. Spring helping people with their lawns.
In 1987, Mr. Spring, who has been in Parliament for 14 years, won a seat here in northern County Kerry by only four votes, as many voters felt he had been spending too much time in Dublin, London, Brussels and New York, where 22 years ago he was a bartender at the Mad Hatter on the Upper East Side and met his American wife, Kristi.
"Don't let the dog get out," a woman said as he entered her fenced yard. "Shake hands with my dolly," said two small girls, waving their dolls' arms at the Deputy Prime Minister.
Small boys tagged after him, one freckled lad making grotesque faces and puffing a plastic pipe as if he had tobacco in it.
Mr. Spring made brief leaflet-spreading visits to Brosan's Bar, Stack's Family Butcher, Molly's Food Store and Betty O'Connor's Food Store, where the proprieter said: "I've a big picture of his father, cut from a newspaper, folded away for 25 years. I will be voting for him."
Mr. Spring's father, Dan, headed the Labor Party for decades. So far, Dick seemed to be the unanimous choice of the people.
Then he arrived on the doorstep of Philip Kiley. First Mr. Kiley asked him to help with funds for a workshop for handicapped children. Mr. Spring took a paper from him and said he would look into it. But Mr. Kiley was not finished. "Tell me 'yes or no,' just 'yes or no,' whether you are for a referendum on abortion," he said.
The abortion issue has been interjected by the Pro-Life Campaign demanding a third national referendum to prohibit abortion, now legal in Ireland only where a pregnancy threatens a woman's life, but still illegal in cases of rape and incest.
"I abhor abortion, personally," Mr. Spring said. But he added that the issue should be handled by parliamentary legislation, not by a referendum, because the two previous referendums left gaps in the law, suceptible to Supreme Court interpretation, and a third one was likely to do the same. Mr. Spring said not many people asked him about abortion, and this seemed confirmed as he walked on.
Cattle farmers are concerned about the economic effect of mad cow disease. Most people seem concerned about the economy, unemployment, particularly long-term unemployment. Of the 250,000 unemployed people in the country, about 130,000 have been out of work for more than a year, giving Ireland one of the highest rates in the European Union.
Still, many people say that in the matter of public spending, the Government has been rather generous.
In the nearby town of Listowel, Mr. Spring is given credit for the creation of a $750,000 Literary Center and the upgrading of a local technical college.
After shaking Mr. Spring's hand, Caroline Maune, standing in the doorway of her neat white tile-roofed stucco house, provided by the local council, said she would vote for him. "He helped me get this house from the council," she said.
"There wouldn't be much crime here," Tom Fitzgerald, 55, a construction supervisor, said, noting that few people locked their doors, many even leaving the keys in the lock.
"I was born here," he said. "I've seen the area go from dire poverty to reasonable living" aided by what he called "sensible government."
That is what Mr. Spring and Mr. Bruton want to hear, campaigning on the improved economy during the two-and-a-half years of their coalition Government. The coalition says it has created 120,000 new jobs and will continue to create 1,000 a week.
The opposition coalition of Fianna Fail and the Progressive Democrats insist that the Government taking this credit is like a rooster taking credit for the dawn, that the upsurge is based on actions taken by Fianna Fail in its 1992-1994 coalition Government, which included Mr. Spring and Labor.
In the Moyvan home of Mary and Pat Leahy, a local Councillor, Mr. Spring and his wife drank tea with rich Kerry cream. Ms. Spring smiled as she recalled a woman she had just spoken to as she went from door to door on her own.
"She had a long list of problems," said Ms. Spring, whose native Virgina accent is now flecked with Irish vowels. "Especially she is against the slaughter of calves. I listened. We don't go around promising everybody everything. And at the end she said she might not even vote."
In the nearby town of Tarbert, Mr. Spring chatted briefly with Charley McGibney, 70, a retired engineer. Would he vote for Mr. Spring?
"Doesn't he represent everything my grandfather and my great-grandfather fought for?" he said. "My great-grandfather went on strike for a 12-hour day and got fired. My grandfather went on strike for an 8-hour day."
For Mr. McGibney to vote for anyone else would clearly be, as the people say in the countryside, a road to no town.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dick Spring, Ireland's Deputy Prime Minister, campaigned last month in Ballybunion, County Kerry. He could swing his Labor Party behind either of two coalition groups after the Irish elections on Friday. (Eamon Farrell/Photocall, for The New York Times)
 
Map of Ireland highlighting Moyvan: Dick Spring mowed lawns for the Labor Party cause in Moyvan.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Despite welfare state origins, Israeli enterprise blossoms.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
NATAN SHARANSKY, the former Soviet dissident who is now the political leader of many of Israel's 900,000 Russian immigrants, was in New York last week to chat up assorted journalists, Wall Street types and power brokers. It's not always a fun job these days. "All people want to hear about is politics," he complained -- an allusion to Mr. Sharansky's pivotal position in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's fractious right-wing coalition.
A subject arguably closer to his heart is his duties as Minister of Trade and Industry, a powerful Cabinet post that reflects both his leverage in the coalition Government and his constituents' focus on bread-and-butter issues. Here Mr. Sharansky is more forthcoming. He reiterated the Government's commitment to cutting the budget deficit in half; last year it ballooned to 5 percent of gross domestic product. "We'll only spend the money we have," Mr. Sharansky promised. 
 And he defended the quickening pace of privatizing Israel's state-dominated industry -- an awkward role for the head of a ministry that runs an awesome patronage machine, dispensing subsidies and protecting favored enterprises from competition. "The $1.6 billion in revenues from privatization this year is more than the last four years combined," he said.
Mr. Sharansky also boasted that the Netanyahu Government had shifted priorities on industrial subsidies. Instead of sinking billions into factories and capital equipment, his ministry's budgetary focus is on training and research.
But Mr. Sharansky was less forthcoming about the tepid performance predicted for the Israeli economy in 1997 and 1998. After growing at a rousing 6 percent for much of the 1990's, because of tighter fiscal policy intended to contain Israel's chronic inflation, the rate is expected to fall to about 2.5 percent this year and next.
That is about the pace of growth of the American economy. And it should be sufficient to keep unemployment from rising, while sustaining Israeli living standards at roughly the level of southern Europe's. But the rate is modest compared with that of other economies with elite work forces: one Israeli worker in three has a university degree. And it hardly secures Israel's position in the economic big leagues: the World Economic Forum's 1997 Global Competitiveness Report ranked Israel 24th among 53 economies rated, behind (among others) Ireland and Thailand.
Israel's core economic problem is no secret. It is a welfare state run amok, a legacy of the country's high-minded social democratic founders and its low-minded pork barrel politics. The competitiveness report ranks Israel 44th in "government," citing its high tax rates, high levels of government spending and stifling regulation, and 33d in "openness," because of subtle trade barriers and an overvalued exchange rate.
Indeed, in light of the obvious impediments to enterprise, the real surprise is how productive the country is. "Israel is the only viable socialist economy in the world," ruefully argued Alvin Rabushka of the Institute for Advanced Strategic and Political Studies in Jerusalem.
One reason many economists nonetheless remain optimistic about Israel's long-term prospects is the success of the technology sector. Unlike traditional industries, high-technology start-ups have been relatively unaffected by Israel's rigid labor laws and busybody consumer regulations. And since the start-ups are largely export-oriented, they do not threaten established businesses that have the muscle to make life miserable for competitors. Among the major success stories: Teva Pharmaceuticals, Tadiran (telecommunications), Scitex (electronic imaging) and Aladdin Knowledge Systems (software).
The interventionist traditions actually seem to be helping transform Israel into what Mr. Sharansky hyperbolically calls "a high-tech superpower." Of some 280 technology projects given seed money by the Government in the last few years, a remarkable 41 percent have managed both to create marketable products and to find private underwriters. Venture capital firms are booming, with nearly $2 billion available for high-risk enterprise. Meanwhile, dozens of foreign companies -- for example, Hewlett-Packard, Intel and Motorola -- have set up research and development operations in Israel to tap the economy's skill base in science, medicine and technology.
Mr. Rabushka cautions that this high-technology end run can never fully compensate for Israel's procrastination in deregulating less glamorous industries, phasing out subsidies, taming featherbedding labor unions and lowering marginal tax rates. "High tech represents just 5 percent of Israel's G.D.P.," he said.
But the blossoming of a far more flexible economy on the old statist hulk is intriguing. There is more than one way, it seems, to skin the socialist cat.
