HEADLINE: Fishing Talks and Fighting Words

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, June 4

 BODY:
If salmon only carried passports, how much easier it would be to determine which of them should by rights swell the nets of Canadian fishermen and which should end their silvery lives in American hands.
But as it is, the Pacific Salmon Commission negotiations, better known as the salmon talks, have degenerated in recent weeks to the point where they are coming to be better known as the salmon wars, replete with charges of gunboat diplomacy, angry accusations of flagrant overfishing and the detention of American fishing vessels by the Canadian authorities. 
 Rarely do relations between the United States and its sprawling, sparsely populated neighbor to the north produce so much friction. But as with many battles, the timing of the salmon spat is strategic: the Pacific salmon season begins in less than three weeks, and a record bonanza is expected in a catch typically worth $300 million a year.
In addition, some United States officials have attributed the recent rise in Canadians' tough-on-America talk to the political atmosphere in the lead-up to the Canadian elections that were held on Monday.
Now that those elections are over, the salmon negotiations, which broke down last month, are expected to resume soon and take up yet again just how much fish each side should be allowed to catch. But with each accusing the other of overfishing, the chances of prompt resolution remain unclear.
"The United States has been overfishing with impunity," said Glen Clark, the Premier of British Columbia. "The Pacific Salmon Treaty says that each jurisdiction should roughly get their share of the fish that are raised or originate in their waters, and the empirical evidence is overwhelming that the U.S. is catching about 900,000 more per year than its Alaskan share would justify. That amounts to 40 million to 60 million Canadian dollars over what they should be getting."
The American side argues that its fishing practices have been consistent with obligations under the Pacific Salmon Treaty, adopted by the two nations in 1985, and that if overfishing is the issue, Canadian fishing practices have been the main problem.
Under the treaty, the amount of fish each country may catch varies in proportion to the size of the salmon runs in its rivers. Both sides agree on that principle, but in practice wrangling arises year after year over specific quotas as fish stocks swell and dwindle.
The dispute escalated into maritime muscle-flexing last week, when the Canadian authorities in Port Hardy, British Columbia, detained four American vessels traveling between the lower 48 states and Alaska, saying they had violated a new Canadian law by failing to check in by radio with officials there and stow their gear below decks.
The skippers were fined about $215 each and allowed to go on their way, but American rancor over the Canadian tactic mounted to the point where the State Department canceled a re-start of the salmon talks that was scheduled for last Friday.
Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, where fishing supports about 73,000 jobs, proposed having Coast Guard escorts accompany American fishing vessels, and possibly bringing in the Navy as well. He also suggested economic retaliation, perhaps a cut in imports of softwood lumber or farm-raised salmon from Canada.
"There is no reason for American fishermen to be used as pawns in this dispute," the Senator said.
Firing his own political guns, Mr. Clark, the British Columbia Premier, has given 90 days' notice that he wants to end an arrangement under which the United States Navy tests torpedoes off Vancouver.
Underlying the whole dispute is the Pacific Salmon Treaty, which governs the salmon catches on the West Coast from Oregon to Alaska. Although it was adopted in 1985, and renewed in 1994, details of its implementation must be worked out each year. If they are not set by the time the season starts, local managers improvise, prompting worries that the lack of coordination will lead to further overfishing. The talks that are currently suspended are yet another round of these annual negotiations, conducted by the Pacific Salmon Commission, made up of members from each of the two countries.
And underlying the problems with the treaty is the fact that nature does not respect national boundaries: the fish from both countries intermingle in the ocean. The Canadians want the American fishing fleet to haul in fewer of the sockeye salmon that head for the Fraser River in British Columbia, while the United States wants Canada to lighten up on its catch of coho salmon off Vancouver Island that head to American waters.
Salmon clashes last got this bad before the treaty's renewal in 1994, when Canada clamped a "transit fee" on American fishing vessels that passed through its waters. That cost American fishermen about $300,000, which the United States Government reimbursed.
With memories of those hassles still fresh, fishermen preparing in Seattle for this year's salmon season say they could do without the added worries.
"It's something we'd rather not be facing again," said Rob Zuanich, executive director of the Purse Seine Vessel Owners' Association in Seattle, which represents 500 fishing-boat owners. "Everyone wants to do the right thing. It's a question of what we're going to have to give up to do it."

HEADLINE: Orders Placed At Factories Gained 1.2% During April

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
Orders placed with factories rose 1.2 percent in April, more than expected, a sign the manufacturing economy remained in high gear after a strong start to the year.
The increase, reported by the Commerce Department today, was in contrast to March's revised 1.3 percent decline. Orders increased in the year's first two months. Analysts had expected an April increase of only nine-tenths of 1 percent. 
 As is the case with every set of major economic data, analysts examined today's report for clues as to whether growth might be strong enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
The April gain in factory orders "suggests the manufacturing sector will continue to provide support to the economy," said Kevin Flanagan, money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
Still, analysts have said that economic growth probably will decelerate in coming months from the first quarter's very strong annual rate of 5.8 percent.
April's gain was led by stronger demand for transportation equipment, fabricated metal products and metal-working machinery. Factory inventories increased six-tenths of 1 percent, faster than March's rise of two-tenths of 1 percent.
Outside of the volatile category of aircraft and other transportation equipment, factory orders increased nine-tenths of 1 percent. Excluding the military industry, they rose eight-tenths of 1 percent.
By category, orders for durable goods, expensive items made to last three or more years, rose 1.3 percent in April after decreasing 2.2 percent in March.
Orders for nondurable goods, such as food and clothing, rose 1 percent in April after decreasing three-tenths of 1 percent in March.
Also, factory shipments, a gauge of current demand, rose 1.2 percent, while unfilled factory orders, a measure of pent-up demand, fell three-tenths of 1 percent, the second consecutive monthly decline.

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
Scarsdale Gets Its Due For Years of Teamwork

BYLINE: By TARIK EL-BASHIR 

DATELINE: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

 BODY:
Most of the players on the girls soccer team at the high school here have been teammates for so long that one of them swears they are telepathic.
"We know each other so well," said Samantha Lang, a senior captain of the Scarsdale High School Raiders, that "it's like you almost know where someone is going to be before they get there." 
 That is not hard to believe, considering that seven of the players, all seniors, have been teammates on varied squads since the third grade. And five of those seven school teammates play on the same club team during the fall.
One look at the on-the-field interaction among Lang, Jessica Helfand, Jenny Bross, Leslie Patent, Jamie Moser and Michelle Edelman (Mandy Weil is one of the seven, but she was injured in the preseason) makes it clear why Scarsdale has the best high school team in the New York metropolitan area.
Not only that, but the Raiders, 17-0, are ranked 16th in the nation by the National Soccer Coaches Association Poll. They are a victory away from the championship in New York Section 1, which holds its girls soccer season in the spring.
"It's very helpful that these girls started out young playing together," said Bob Zayac, coach of the girls and boys teams at Scarsdale. "It also helps that most of these girls play soccer 11 or 12 months out of the year.
"They are all very strong technically," Zayac said. "That is why we are so successful."
On Thursday, the Raiders will face John Jay of East Fishkill in a rematch of last year's championship game. Scarsdale defeated John Jay during the regular season last year, but it failed to win the championship.
"We beat John Jay in the regular season this year, too," Zayac said. "We know that doesn't mean anything. Look at what happened to us last year."
Scarsdale advanced to the championship by defeating Mamaroneck, 1-0, on Tuesday. A goal by Luskin 2 minutes 3 seconds into the second half of the semifinal game propelled the Raiders into Thursday's final.
This team is successful for many reasons, but the one most frequently mentioned is the players' communication on the field. When a player makes a mistake or is about to make one, a teammate will let her know it.
But this team is not all talk; its offense is productive and its defense is suffocating.
The Raiders have outscored their opponents by 65-6 this season, earning shutouts in 12 of their 17 victories. They are 31-1 over the last two seasons.
And all of that offense has come despite injuries to the team's starting center-forward and her replacement.
Linny Zayac, a Scarsdale High School freshman and the coach's daughter, has been more than adequate in their places, scoring 16 goals and making 4 assists.
The team prides itself on its tough defense, and goalkeeper Jenny Bross may be its biggest strength. Though she was not tested often in Tuesday's semifinal, she was forced to make two point-blank saves late in the game.
While the Raiders may be the best soccer team in the area, soccer is not the only sport these Raiders play. Every player competes in at least one other sport.
In fact, Luskin, Merrick Shanahan and Marcy Busch -- all starters on the soccer team -- were on Scarsdale's state championship field hockey team last year.
And just because some of the girls drive luxury cars to practice, it does not mean they act like characters from "Clueless," the popular film comedy starring Alicia Silverstone that stereotypes teen-age girls from an affluent area.
"It is a misconception," Coach Zayac said. "It could not be farther from the truth with this team. I have never had a team that was beaten physically. That is probably the opposite of what someone would expect from a girls team from Scarsdale.
"The community is not only successful economically and socially, it has a work ethic that carries over to the soccer field."
The national ranking is hardly exact, considering that the listed teams rarely play one another. Being listed among the nation's best, however, is enough for this group.
"We are so happy about the ranking," Linny Zayac said. "No one on the team was expecting it. But I think that we deserve it."

HEADLINE: Woman Gets $6.6 Million In Sexual Harassment Suit

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
A Manhattan jury awarded a Bronx woman $6.6 million yesterday for sexual harassment she endured during and after her employment at a Ford dealership in Manhattan.
The six-member jury unanimously found that the dealership had engaged in sexual harassment, retaliation against an employee and intentional infliction of emotional harm. 
 The lawsuit, which was filed in 1994, charged that in 1992 and 1993, a supervisor and employees of Manhattan Ford Lincoln Mercury, at 555 West 57th Street, harassed Maureen McIntyre, a service adviser, after she rebuffed the advances of a supervisor, Steve Czerniuk.
Sexually explicit statements were carved into her desk and Ms. McIntyre was grabbed by the throat by a co-worker, Robert Lusko Jr., the complaint said.
Most of the award, $5 million in punitive damages, was made yesterday in State Supreme Court; compensatory damages of $1.6 million had been awarded on Tuesday, after a two-week trial. The punitive damages were based in large part on the wealth of the dealership, which is owned by the Ford Motor Company.
"I am pleased I told the truth, and everyone believed me," said Ms. McIntyre, who was greeted by supportive jurors after the verdict. Ms. McIntyre, 35, lives in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, where she is married to an auto parts manager for another dealership.
Neither the lawyer representing the dealership, Perry Heidecker, nor a spokeswoman for the dealership immediately returned calls seeking comment last night.
The company has 15 days to appeal the award. Reductions have occurred in other civil suits with large awards, particularly when the punitive damages were substantial.
Murray Schwartz, the lawyer for Ms. McIntyre, said that his client was awarded $100,000 for sexual harassment; $200,000 for emotional pain and suffering and $300,000 for future pain and suffering because of the retaliation; $100,000 for lost wages and $200,000 for future lost wages. She also received $700,000 for present and future pain and suffering for the intentional infliction of emotional harm.
Mr. Schwartz, who represented a centerfold model in a sexual discrimination case against Penthouse magazine in the 1980's, said that the punitive damages were $1 million for sexual harassment; $1.5 million for retaliation and $2.5 million for infliction of emotional harm.
"They fired her because she complained about the sexual harassment and a hostile environment," he said, "and then they protested her right to unemployment insurance, and then she was unable to get a job in the industry." Ms. McIntyre was dismissed on Dec. 17, 1993.
He added that the dealer's claim that Ms. McIntyre was insubordinate was a pretext to get rid of her.
Mr. Schwartz said that Ms. McIntyre was called various derogatory names and given sexual suggestions. "Some of the behavior was pretty awful," he said. "Someone tried to choke her. People who worked there saw red marks around her neck."
The lawyer said that Ms. McIntyre filed a criminal complaint but was afraid to follow through.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Big German Union Accepts Pact Leading to Wage Cuts
A union representing Germany's 600,000 chemical workers agreed to a contract that opens the possibility for troubled companies to reduce wages by 10 percent -- a bow toward workplace flexibility in a country that has lost more than a million jobs in five years.
Business leaders welcomed the pact, which comes at a time of insecurity in German industry over global competitiveness. The contract, covering about 1,700 companies, including Hoechst A.G., BASF and Bayer A.G., was the sharpest departure to date from Germany's ironclad work rules. [Page A1.] 

Factory Orders Up 1.2% in April
Orders placed with factories rose an unexpected 1.2 percent in April after declining by a revised 1.3 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported. The increase was the latest sign that the manufacturing economy remained strong. [D8.]
 
Ford Sales Fell in May
Ford reported that sales dropped 3 percent in May, as car sales fell and truck sales rose. G.M. and Chrysler had more severe declines, 8.5 percent and 16.6 percent. Japanese auto makers had mixed results. [D4.]
 
Airline Alliance Is Opposed
American Airlines and British Airways encountered strong opposition as they sought during a Senate Commerce Committee hearing to win support for their proposed marketing alliance. [D2.]
 
Both Dow and Nasdaq Decline
Stocks fell as computer issues extended a weeklong slump, and financial stocks dropped on concern that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates this summer. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 42.49 points, closing at 7,269.66, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 5.24, to 1,379.67. [D10.]
 
Brazil Sells $3 Billion in Bonds
Brazil sold $3 billion of unsecured 30-year bonds, most of which are being exchanged for Brady bonds, in an effort to reorganize its foreign debt and reduce its future interest costs by at least $160 million. In the United States Treasury market, the yield on the 30-year bond edged up to 6.88 percent. [D8.]
 
Nomura and Ex-Executives Charged
Prosecutors charged Nomura Securities and two former top executives with illegally compensating a reputed racketeer for $430,000 in trading losses. [D4.]
 
U.N. Extends Iraqi Oil Sales
Iraq will be allowed to sell $2 billion in oil for a second six-month period to pay for food, medicine and other essential items for civilians, under a plan extended by the United Nations Security Council. [A3.]
 
Obstacles to Central Asian Pipeline
A proposal for a 870-mile, $2 billion natural gas pipeline from Turkmenistan through Afghanistan to Pakistan has been slowed by political turmoil and lack of financing. Unocal of the United States and Bridas Energy of Argentina have competed to build it. [D4.]
 
Woman Wins Damages in I.R.S. Raid
A Federal judge in Denver awarded $250,000 in punitive damages to a woman whose family business was raided by armed I.R.S. agents four weeks after the woman, Carole Ward, 49, insulted an I.R.S. agent. [D7.]
 
Texans Allowed to Sue H.M.O.'s
Texas will soon become the first state where consumers will explicitly be allowed to sue their health maintenance organizations on charges of medical malpractice or negligence. The state's legislation is one of the sharpest reactions yet in the national backlash to the organizations' power; similar measures are pending in other states, including New York. [A16.]
 
Auto Insurance Fraud Ring Cited
Insurance company investigators said they had discovered the nation's largest organized auto insurance fraud ring in northern New Jersey, involving at least $75 million in bogus claims and probably raising premiums for drivers across the state. Allstate sued 749 people who, it said, were involved. [A1.]

HEADLINE: Hong Kong's Business Elite Tells Americans: Don't Panic

SERIES: WAITING FOR CHINA: The American Connection

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
On a warm spring night last month, the entrepreneurs and billionaires who built modern-day Hong Kong held an opulent dinner here at the Four Seasons Hotel to send the Washington establishment an urgent message: Calm down.
Don't overreact to every Chinese pronouncement about the future of Hong Kong, they warned members of Congress and Administration officials. Don't assume the worst about restrictions on civil liberties. And most important, let us handle Beijing. 
 "We are not in trouble," Victor Fung, a prominent property owner, insisted that night to members of Congress and Administration officials who deal daily with Asia. "We are not panicked."
In truth, the Hong Kong business elite is panicked -- but about how to manage Washington, not Beijing. The executives' fear is that Congress, with no other tools than economic sanctions at hand, might lash out in response to a minor roundup of protesters or a modest political crackdown, and send an already rocky relationship between the United States and China into a costly and bitter deterioration.
Formally, the United States will simply be an observer on July 1 when Prince Charles ends Britain's 155-year-long control over Hong Kong, the booming financial capital of Southeast Asia, and the Chinese reclaim a territory whose success has profoundly changed China's direction. But as a matter of economic Realpolitik, Washington is the central player.
All sides in the arguments and political maneuvering leading up to the turnover agree that America is the key to Hong Kong's future, both as a huge investor and trading partner, and as the single loudest international power calling for Beijing to respect Hong Kong's autonomy.
And in recent months everyone from the departing British to the bullish-sounding billionaires of the Better Hong Kong Foundation, and from labor unionists to Martin Lee, the chief democracy advocate, have come here in hopes of manipulating the political and economic levers in Washington's hands, to their own ends.
The executives are calling for Washington to do nothing, arguing that strong reactions can only anger Beijing. The unions and democracy advocates see the United States as their only brake on Beijing but decline to specify how Washington should use its leverage.
Meanwhile, the Clinton Administration has begun a lobbying campaign of its own in Hong Kong. In a series of strong but precisely worded warnings, it has argued that the markets rather than the White House or Congress will ultimately punish the Chinese if Hong Kong's autonomy and civil liberties are trampled.
"My message is simple," Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said in Hong Kong recently. "There is no firewall between economic freedom and freedom in its many other dimensions.
"The free flow of information, the ability of people to remain free, to enter into transactions, to speak out: these are all the essential elements of free markets and a strong financial system," he said.
The Administration is betting that Mr. Summers' economic credentials make it easier to deflect Chinese criticism that Washington is interfering in its economic affairs.
To Americans doing business in Hong Kong, Mr. Summers is even more direct, cautioning executives about the risks of becoming apologists for the Chinese or the new Beijing-appointed Hong Kong Government. "If the two systems are going to merge," he said, "it is in everyone's interest that China become more like Hong Kong than the other way around."
But it is far from clear that the message is winning converts in Hong Kong. And in Washington, what was once a clear policy to treat Hong Kong as a completely autonomous entity, even after Beijing takes control, has been muddied by the debate about relations with China.
In a nonbinding resolution passed overwhelmingly this spring, Congress threatened to place huge sanctions against Hong Kong exports if China were to crack down on civil rights. Within days, that strategy was bitterly criticized by all sides in Hong Kong, from pro-Beijing executives to democracy advocates and Governor Chris Patten, who said it would "deprive Hong Kong of its livelihood at the moment it most needs support."
Since then, Congressional leaders have backed away from that strategy. But on Tuesday, Senator Jesse Helms, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, opened a new front: He introduced a resolution to deny China "most favored nation" trading status, an annual exercise that this year could turn into a tough fight. He linked the matter to China's handling of the succession.
Mr. Helms declared that it was foolish to treat Hong Kong as a separate entity if the Chinese will not, and argued that China has already reneged on many promises to keep Hong Kong's political freedoms. "Yet the United States has failed to prevent or reverse a single violation" of the 1984 accords on the handover, he said.
On Thursday, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is expected to respond, telling American executives who have pressed for permanent trade status for China that revoking the trade status would "harm Hong Kong in the name of helping it."
 
Primary Investor
Roads Lead to U.S., Not Britain or Japan
Hong Kong is known around the world as a Chinese city with a distinctly British flavor, down to the daily high tea at the Peninsula Hotel. But amid the giant towers of Exchange Square, home of the booming Hong Kong stock exchange, it is taken for granted that the territory's economic interests are far more enmeshed with the United States, whose consulate sits just below the Governor's Mansion.
"There is a reason that everyone with an interest in Hong Kong's future is running to Washington these days, not to London or even Tokyo," said Robert Broadfoot who runs a political-risk consulting firm in the city.
The linkage has been tightened by the long recession and stock-market fall in Japan. Despite China's looming control, many American companies have cut back their Tokyo offices and moved their Asian headquarters to Hong Kong in the last five years, hoping to use Hong Kong as a beachhead into both China and the booming nations of Southeast Asia.
Today there are more than 1,100 American companies with regional bases in Hong Kong, led by investment houses like Morgan Stanley and banks like Citicorp. The American Chamber of Commerce estimates, perhaps stretching the numbers a bit, that American-based companies employ 10 percent of Hong Kong's work force of 2.5 million.
During the cold war, the American Consulate in Hong Kong was a major outpost for the Central Intelligence Agency. Today it is a base for issues at the forefront of American relations with Asia: the crackdown on drug trafficking, organized crime and counterfeiting of American currency and American-made products. "For a long time the U.S. policy in Hong Kong was that the handover is a British problem, and we're sure they'll work it out," said Jeffrey S. Muir, a senior executive for Seagram Asia Pacific who has lived in Hong Kong for more than two decades. "People don't think that way any more."
As a matter of both law and official policy, Washington's stance toward Hong Kong after the transition is to treat it as a completely separate entity from China, building on China's commitment to treat Hong Kong under the doctrine of "one country, two systems."
"We can't insist that China respect Hong Kong's autonomy unless we do as well," Jeffrey Bader, the deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asia, said to Congress earlier this year.
But carrying out that policy creates difficult anomalies. Hong Kong will continue to have a separate textile quota from China's, even though Chinese manufacturers have cheated on those quotas for years by placing Hong Kong labels in Chinese-made goods. The Commerce Department will continue to keep separate trade statistics for the territory, rather than lump Hong Kong trade with China's.
Hong Kong will continue to have its own vote at the World Trade Organization in Geneva, infuriating Chinese officials, who say it is an outrage that the territory belongs to the organization while China is in a tense negotiation to enter. Nonetheless, Hong Kong officials insist that they, not Beijing, will decide how to vote within the organization.
There will even be separate export controls. Electronics makers, for example, will be able to ship sensitive technologies to Hong Kong that could not be sent without licenses to Beijing.
"The whole system presumes that the Chinese will truly respect their border with Hong Kong," a senior Western official said in Hong Kong recently. "The first time some supercomputer whisks through Hong Kong and shows up in a nuclear weapons lab in Shanghai, the assumptions begin to crack apart."
An American official here with a more jaundiced view of the policy -- and of its assumption that Hong Kong courts, customs service and financial regulators will remain completely independent -- put it another way.
"Here's the deal," he said. "After July 1 we pretend that Hong Kong isn't part of China, even though it is. And we still insist that Taiwan is still part of China, even though it isn't."
 
Civics Lesson
Market Strength Is Tied to Freedom
The Clinton Administration's political strategy before the transition is to constantly repeat Mr. Summers's argument that China cannot reap the financial benefits of a booming Hong Kong unless the city remains a place of open dissent, corruption-free courts and markets that are less rigged than in most of Asia.
"This was the best way we could think of to convey our message to the Chinese," a senior Western diplomat in Hong Kong argued recently.
"Lecturing them about human rights is a proven failure," he said. "So we are simply trying to make the point that if you want to have a solid stock market that people trust, you have to have newspapers that are free to write about the Dalai Lama, or the state of the independence movement in Taiwan. These are all subjects that deeply affect the atmosphere for investors."
So far, there are reasons to question whether the message has got through. In interviews in Hong Kong, many of the city's tycoons and market players dismissed that argument as overblown, saying that only Americans believe that free markets require American-style liberties.
Several Hong Kong leaders say that C. H. Tung, Hong Kong's chief executive-designate, has asked many of them, "If it works in Singapore, why not the new Hong Kong?" The Japanese send a similar signal, telling Hong Kong's Government that Japanese investors want stability above all else.
Perhaps the biggest test of Hong Kong's ability to separate the economic from the political lies in how it handles the "red chips," huge state-owned Chinese companies that have become the hottest properties on the Hong Kong exchange.
The companies come from a tradition of enormous secrecy, and they bridle at Hong Kong's requirement that companies publish extensive financial data, including subsidies they received from Beijing. In fact, their chief asset, the one propelling their share prices into the stratosphere, is their "guanxi," or connections to the Chinese leadership.
That means their future is completely bound up in the most delicate political decisions facing China's leadership -- for example, whether the leaders are willing to risk millions of jobs because the world demands that China open its domestic market and strip away the protections that have allowed some state-owned companies to operate as monopolies for decades.
Already some analysts for Western brokerage houses say they feel subtle pressure from their employers not to write anything too critical about the "red chips," for fear that Beijing will take lucrative business elsewhere. They would be hesitant, several said, to declare that a state-run company was cooking its books or bloated with far too many workers.
And Western investors wonder whether, after the transition, Hong Kong regulatory authorities will remain independent and uncowed by their new masters in Beijing, who many expect will press for less strict standards for companies with friends in high places.
"Watch what happens the first time the Hong Kong authorities delist some stock that has plenty of connections," the head of an American brokerage in Hong Kong said recently.
"The risk in Hong Kong," said a British official who is pessimistic about its future, "is that a stifling political correctness sets in." If that happens, he adds, Beijing will discover that the markets are "self-sanctioning."
 
Anxieties at Home
Executives Object To Democracy Card
Hong Kong boosters say that Beijing understands that the markets must be free to exert such discipline on political meddling. The vast lobbying campaign that the city's rich and powerful have waged in Washington was prompted by the fear that Congress will feel compelled to do something anyway, egged on by prominent leaders of the Hong Kong opposition like Martin Lee, who reminded Congress during a visit here in April that the 1992 Hong Kong Relations Act "commits your Government to support a free, elected legislature in Hong Kong."
Mr. Lee's sympathetic reception on Capitol Hill infuriated many of Hong Kong's rich and powerful. "You want to know what would be a good American policy toward Hong Kong?" Ronnie C. Chan, one of the most outspoken of the American-educated members of the Hong Kong elite leading the lobbying campaign in America, asked over dinner recently at Hong Kong's glistening cultural center. "This may sound simplistic, but try it: Leave us alone."
Mr. Chan is hardly alone in that view. So when major American magazines began predicting Hong Kong's demise under Chinese rule, he and other members of the city's wealthy elite began inviting journalists from around the world to visit Hong Kong, at the expense of the Better Hong Kong Foundation, to persuade them to paint a more flattering picture. Other executives have begun denouncing the American media, arguing that it is exaggerating the threat to make a better story when China takes the reins.
"The American view of what will happen is wildly out of whack," said Mr. Fung, who heads the Hong Kong Trade and Development Council. "Look, we have a barometer of Hong Kong's future -- the stock market. And investor confidence is very, very high. Who would have guessed that just a few years ago?"
In fact, polling data suggest a huge perception gap between Americans and Hong Kong residents.
A study just released by Wirthlin Worldwide, a political polling group, found that 60 percent of Americans polled believe that the people of Hong Kong would choose to become independent, but only 14 percent of the Hong Kong respondents agreed. A scant 4 percent of Americans thought Hong Kong would choose to become part of China, while 62 percent of Hong Kong residents thought their fellow citizens would elect Chinese rule. The margin of sampling error in the poll was 4.9 percent.
The poll numbers understate the concerns in places like the soda-can-strewn offices of the Hong Kong Federation of Trade Unions, on the third floor of a neighborhood of bars and brothels where tourists rarely tread.
There, elderly men who mix cement on the edge of Hong Kong harbor and drivers who deliver Coca-Cola say their links to the United States are their best protection after July 1. In April, just a day after Hong Kong's government-in-waiting announced new restrictions on political demonstrations to go into effect within hours of the turnover, a dozen or so of these workers met with John Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
"Political activity is how we fight for workers' rights," Lee Cheuk Yan, the general secretary of the federation told the visiting American labor chief. "Is a strike over wages a 'political activity?' "
When the American union leader conveyed those concerns the next day to Mr. Tung, Hong Kong's future leader offered assurances that unions would not be affected by bans on political actions. But after Mr. Sweeney launched into a brief monologue on why Hong Kong must observe basic rights, Mr. Tung paused for a moment, then remarked, "You're too caring."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
France's New Jacket

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
There was a delightful photo the other day showing President Clinton and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain laughing together in London. Here's a secret: I know what they were laughing about. They were laughing about France.
You see, what Mr. Clinton and Mr. Blair truly have in common is the same tailor. They have both been fitted for the golden straitjacket. The golden straitjacket is all the rules set down by global markets for how a country has to behave economically if it wants to thrive in today's world. What happens when your country puts on the golden straitjacket is that its economy expands and its politics shrinks. That is, growth rises, unemployment falls and political choices on all big issues -- welfare, interest rates, government spending -- contract to the narrow limits set by the markets. 
 What Mr. Clinton and Mr. Blair have in common is that they are comfortable in this straitjacket. They have learned how to loosen it at the waist a little, and in doing so have made it, for the moment, a political winner. The reason they are laughing at France is because the French actually seem to think they can avoid this golden straitjacket and still enjoy the best of all worlds. They actually believe that they can still be a world power and have their truck drivers retire at 55 with nearly full pay, work a 35-hour week, take six-week summer holidays and close their shops for two hours every afternoon.
That must be a real knee-slapper to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Blair. If they could speak frankly to the new French Prime Minister, the Socialist Lionel Jospin, they would tell him this:
"Get real, Lionel. During the cold war you could have all these cushy social benefits and still be a great power, because your greatness came cheap. You got it by puffing yourself up, building a few nuclear weapons and playing off the United States and the U.S.S.R. That world is gone.
"In today's world greatness is not defined by where you are but by what you are. As they say, we've gone from a world where the big eat the small to a world where the fast eat the slow, and France can only be great now if it's also fast. You can't be fast and work only 35 hours a week or retire at 55. You cannot maintain that life style and still be a global power. Because you can't maintain that life style and also do the budget cuts, benefit cuts and privatization of state industries required to join the common European currency.
"And we all know that the common currency is your key to remaining a great power, because a common currency is what would keep you tied to Germany and make the European Union a real global economic player. And since your strategy is to use your relationship with Germany and your dominance of the E.U. to maintain your 'greatness' in the post-cold-war world, you need that common currency. But you have to pay for that. So take your choice: You can be great, or you can have a great life style (for a little while longer). But you can't have both.
"Now Lionel, the golden straitjacket comes in only one size, and you're too fat. We're also laughing because we had Margaret Thatcher and Alan Greenspan to put our countries on a diet of downsizing. They took the flak and now we're reaping the benefits. We're betting that the golden straitjacket will continue to produce enough growth, so that we can keep loosening it, so that those hardest hit won't be too pinched, so that there won't be a political backlash. That's our strategy."
The truth is France has no realistic alternative to the golden straitjacket, and the markets will soon hammer home that reality. Still, there is something appealing about the French struggle to maintain their life style and to resist the constraints, and one-size-fits-all sterility, of the golden straitjacket. It's Don Quixote versus the bond market. You've got to admire it.
Bill and Tony have pretty well given up that fight. They have confined themselves to the politics of the straitjacket, leaving little room to pursue the traditional social justice planks of their parties. If the golden straitjacket continues to grow, so might their political horizons again. If it doesn't grow, their politics will remain shrunken and they will have plenty of time on their hands. Indeed, they will be the only two men free to work a 30-hour week, with two hours off for lunch, without anyone noticing.

HEADLINE: An Agreeable City Council

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
In the partisan hallways of Albany or Washington, the swiftness and hearty handshakes with which the City Council endorsed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's election-year budget last night would have been unimaginable.
The 51-member Council, after all, is 88 percent Democratic, and though it was able to add several important initiatives to the budget, its leaders essentially signed off on the spending blueprint the Republican Mayor devised earlier this year to help him win re-election. 
 The Council's agreeability has allowed the city to avoid the kind of bitter stalemates that have for years made Albany's budget process utterly dysfunctional. But by agreeing to his prosperity budget this year, just as they did in the three previous years of attrition, Council members left the Democratic candidates for mayor with little room to criticize the Mayor's spending priorities. How bad can his budgets have been, Mr. Giuliani might argue, if the Democrats on the Council approved them without serious rancor year after year?
If Ruth W. Messinger or the other mayoral candidates were hoping for a last-minute blast of helpful partisanship from the Council this year, they were dealing with the wrong institution. Unlike their New York State counterparts, Council members show no inclination to bloody the Mayor for political purposes at the expense of a pragmatic budget agreement.
For one thing, the Council leadership is probably closer ideologically to the Republican Mayor than to his Democratic rivals. And the extra spending Mr. Giuliani has included in his budget appeals to Council members both for philosophical and political reasons.
The Council leaders say they are simply doing their jobs. "You have to be responsible, and the price of good government is you have to take some lumps from the partisans," said Kevin McCabe, chief of staff to the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, and a principal budget negotiator. "Some people use budgets as political weapons; others use them as a governmental tool."
The Council, even in its somewhat invigorated incarnation under the revised City Charter, has never been a terribly effective political spearhead, partly because the provision of city services does not lend itself quite as easily to the partisan philosophical debate that occurs at the state and national level and partly because the Council has shown little interest in using the tools at its disposal to fundamentally rewrite the Mayor's budget. Mr. Giuliani may have been striving to burnish his image by spending hundreds of millions on new education programs in this year's budget, but the Council was hardly in a position to object.
"We agree with those things," said Herbert E. Berman, chairman of the Council Finance Committee and a Brooklyn Democrat. "If he's doing the right thing, are we supposed to say, 'Mr. Mayor, we don't want you to do it'? If it's the right thing to do, it's the right thing to do."
Ms. Messinger, the leading Democratic candidate, issued a short statement simply saying the Council had forced the Mayor to face up to the city's troubled economy. But another mayoral candidate, Councilman Sal Albanese, a longtime maverick on budget issues, was far more critical. As one of the very few members to have voted against each of the Mayor's budgets in the years of cutbacks, he said he saw no reason to change his pattern this year simply because more money was available.
"The surplus gives us a great opportunity to say we have a different vision for the city than Giuliani," he said. "Yet the Council is continuing to do what it normally does, which is basically adopting the agenda of the Mayor. It would be better for the Council to assert themselves and come up with a better set of priorities."
There has never been any great love between the Council leadership and Ms. Messinger, Mr. Albanese or the third Democratic hopeful, the Rev. Al Sharpton, and the Council clearly sees no particular need to go out of its way to assist them. The centrist Mr. Vallone, in fact, has always been closer in ideology to Mr. Giuliani than to any of the candidates running against him.
Ms. Messinger, whose uncomfortable position in the polls has already led to comparisons with Bob Dole, is in essence being treated by the Council much as Mr. Dole was treated by the Republican Congress last September when lawmakers passed an immigration bill favored by President Clinton. Mr. Dole had hoped that a stronger bill would draw a presidential veto that he could exploit for political purposes, but the Republicans decided they actually liked the President's version because it served their own needs.
Similarly, Council members are pleased they were able to get the Mayor to agree to several of their own proposals, including restoring about $180 million that Mr. Giuliani had said he intended to cut from various programs. The Council had neither the power nor the inclination to go much further.
"So far since we got power in 1989, every year has been what's best for the city, not what's best for elected officials," Mr. Vallone said. "Whether it's a Republican mayor or a Democratic mayor, that never had anything to do with our negotiations."

HEADLINE: Lift Education Standards, and Wages Will Rise;
Displacing Ignorance

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thomas Geoghegan ("Overeducated and Underpaid," Op-Ed, June 3) may be correct about college graduates being underpaid, but "overeducated"? 
 Never! Mr. Geoghegan does a disservice to everyone by looking at education solely in economic terms. Education does and should have purposes, such as raising the general level of knowledge and tastes -- what traditionally is known as the displacement of ignorance. Maybe next time he will write about the non-economic benefits of education at all levels.
 
JAMES A. BLESSING
Selinsgrove, Pa., June 3, 1997

HEADLINE: In an Election Year, Giuliani Negotiates Budget Deal Easily

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Making use of a record surplus generated by Wall Street profits, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council leaders agreed last night on a $33.4 billion budget that tempers the stringent measures that had led to a steady retrenchment in the size of the municipal government for most of the decade.
Five months before he faces re-election, the Republican Mayor came to terms with leaders of the Democratic-controlled Council with relative ease, avoiding the wrangling that marked the annual budget negotiations earlier in his term. 
 Both sides seemed relieved that there was less pressure to reduce services this year, largely because tax revenues from bountiful earnings in the securities industry are patching holes in the spending plan.
Mr. Giuliani is sure to contend during the campaign that the lack of discord in the bargaining with the Council -- as well as the absence of other budgetary traumas in recent months -- is evidence that he has brought stability to the city's finances.
The embrace of the Mayor's budget by the overwhelmingly Democratic Council might also discourage Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President and the likely Democratic nominee, from attacking the plan. The Mayor can defend himself from criticism of his fiscal stewardship by Ms. Messinger by asserting that the Council endorsed his spending priorities in agreeing on the budget.
Ever since the last recession hit the city in 1989, the municipal government has repeatedly had to grapple with budget gaps that were closed mostly by raising taxes, cutting services or engaging in questionable fiscal maneuvers. But as the local economy has improved in the last year, it has become less arduous to put together the budget.
"This is probably the budget with the least amount of risk that we've seen in a very long time," Mr. Giuliani said at a news conference at 10:45 P.M. He later added, "This budget benefits greatly from tremendous increased revenues."
The city's fiscal problems are by no means over. Even though Mr. Giuliani has slowed the growth of city spending by nearly $3 billion since he took office, the city's expenditures continue to rise faster than its revenues. As a result, the Mayor's budget aides forecast annual shortfalls that will increase to nearly $3 billion by 2001.
And though the new budget will contain less pain than its recent predecessors, the Mayor and the Council are not restoring most of the services that they decided to cut in previous years.
The agreement last night follows the framework of the budget that Mr. Giuliani proposed last month, though the Council leaders extracted some concessions. The Giuliani administration, for example, had projected the city's budget surplus in the 1997 fiscal year, which ends on June 30, at $856 million. As part of the deal, the Mayor accepted the Council's figure of $1.3 billion for the surplus.
Some of the extra money is to be set aside in a $500 million pool for financial emergencies, an idea that Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, has championed. Mr. Vallone had called for the statutory creation of a so-called rainy day fund, but that would require approval by Albany, and was opposed by Mr. Giuliani and other city officials, who said it was not allowed under the city's accounting rules.
The two sides instead agreed to set up an informal pool of money in the budget.
Mr. Giuliani allowed the Council to add $180 million in spending for a range of programs, including money for cultural institutions, libraries, foster care, youth programs, parks and health clinics.
Overall spending would increase by more than 3 percent -- or more than $1 billion -- the largest increase since Mr. Giuliani took office. Taxes would be cut by $319 million, about half of which would come from the elimination of the city's 4 percent sales tax on clothing items under $500.
The agreement still requires the approval of the full 51-member Council, but in practice that is a formality because Mr. Vallone, a Queens Democrat, wields tight control over the Democratic majority. But approval by Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature is also required for nearly all of the tax cuts to become law, and that is by no means assured.
The Council leaders backed several proposals from Mr. Giuliani to increase spending on education, an area that his Democratic mayoral opponents have charged he has neglected during this term. The Mayor called in his budget for the city to give more than $170 million in new money to the Board of Education from the city's operating budget, and close to $1 billion over the next few years from the separate capital budget to buy computers, renovate schools and build temporary classrooms.
In the budget that he proposed last month, the Mayor called for $660 million in spending cuts, spread across the majority of city agencies. Council leaders said most of those reductions would not have a direct impact on services, adding that the money they persuaded Mr. Giuliani to add to the budget would scale back any service cuts.
Under the agreement reached last night, the city will probably trim spending on programs by between $400 million and $500 million -- instead of the $660 million -- even as spending is added to other programs, officials said. That figure is less than any of the annual cuts in the first three years of Mr. Giuliani's tenure.
Among the Council proposals that Mr. Giuliani adopted was one to create a $30 million fund to provide loans and grants to spur the creation of jobs in emerging industries. The Mayor also backed the Council's plan for cutting the unincorporated business tax, a tax on the earnings of small businesses, by $75 million.
Though the budget comes to $33.4 billion, the actual amount of spending for the next fiscal year is greater. The difference stems largely from the way the city must account for the surplus from the current fiscal year. The city is essentially using the surplus to pay for some of next year's expenses this year, but the money is counted under this year's budget, not next year's.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By William Grimes 

 BODY:

First, Thanks Go to Rosie O'Donnell
The Nielsen ratings for the Tony Awards were dandy. But what about the show? It had a lot to prove this time around. Last year at this time, Gary Smith, the show's executive producer, was reeling after the show not only pulled abysmal ratings but also was being roundly criticized as one of the worst productions in Tony history. Some of the Broadway unions were even threatening to create their own show.
Broadway is singing a different tune this week. "I thought it was the best ever, and I've been the first to get on Gary Smith's case in the past," said Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters. "The acceptance speeches were relaxed and genuine, and the extra hour from PBS was a godsend." 
 Alan Eisenberg, the executive secretary of Actors Equity, complained loud and long last year about the way award winners were whisked off the stage. This year, he's happy. "I've had a lot of conversations, and everybody had a positive reaction," he said. "This is one of the best Tonys I've been to in years."
Mr. Smith, after his tar and feathering last year, sounds like a man with a new lease on life. Two factors spelled the difference this year, he said, Rosie O'Donnell, and, just as important, PBS. "In the past, the acceptance speeches and the Broadway material were sacrificed," he said. "You don't have to be a rocket scientist to realize that if you have 22 awards to give out and two hours to do it in, something's got to give."
There were two Rosies on view Sunday night. The television audience got one, a restrained and, some thought, rather nervous version of the full-tilt comedian in charge of her talk show. During commercial breaks, the Radio City audience got Rosie unchained, ad-libbing and slipping in some risque material just before the cameras got rolling again. Sorry, it can't be printed in a family newspaper. "Rosie was very economical," said Mr. Smith. "That was her choice. She did not want to do extensive comic material, just short introductions."
The Broadway consensus on the show? Signing up Ms. O'Donnell and moving the show to Radio City paid huge dividends, despite the objections of the mostly older citizens of the theater world who hated this year's concept.
"Rosie hosting the show was a way for us to get a foot in the door of American popular culture," said Bill Evans, a press agent. "It was the most exciting exposure Broadway has had in the mass media in the 25 years I've been in the business."
Some grumbling can still be heard. "You should not have a show about the theater that is broadcast from Radio City and has a television star as host," said one producer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. With the ratings success of this year's program, a surprising number of normally talkative naysayers have suddenly clammed up.
"One minute into the show, and I don't think it made the slightest difference to anybody, other than a few theater operators, that it was in Radio City," Mr. Landesman said.
 
Broadway Sales Are Up 15 Percent
 The numbers are in. No, not the Tony ratings, the final box-office and attendance figures for the 1996-97 season, which ended Sunday. Broadway theaters took in the most money ever for a single season, $499 million, a jump of 15 percent over last year's total of $436 million. Attendance was 10.5 million, up 12 percent from last year's total of 9.4 million. That figure was exceeded only in the 1980-81 season, when 11 million people attended Broadway shows in a season with 50 new productions, compared with 38 last year.
The road business dipped after five years of strong growth, dampened by the collapse of several major tours, notably "Applause" and "Sunset Boulevard." Outside New York, members of the League of American Theaters and Producers reported $782 million in ticket sales, down from $810 million last season, and a total audience of 17.6 million, down from 18.1 million.
 
Like Minds for Comedy
 Audiences get Nancy Opel sliced three ways in David Ives's "Mere Mortals and Others," a buffet table of one-act plays at Primary Stages. In "Foreplay, or the Art of the Fugue," she steps onto the Lilliput Lane miniature golf course, putter in hand, playing half (or is it one-sixth?) of a competitive couple, presented contrapuntally as three couples. That's the appetizer. For the pasta course, "Speed-the-Play," she gets real loud and real crass as the referee of the Joliet, Ill., Men's Club, gathered to perform a condensed version of the David Mamet oeuvre.
The main course, "Dr. Fritz," is the piece de resistance, a loony synthesis of Kafka and Abbott and Costello. Ms. Opel, smiling insanely as she knits thin air with two clacking needles, slyly torments a desperately ill man with the possibility that she might be Dr. Fritz, the surgeon he desperately needs.
Mr. Ives wrote the piece for Ms. Opel, who has become a mainstay of his ever since she appeared in his one-act play "Sure Thing" at Manhattan Punchline in 1986. "We're of like minds in terms of comedy," she said. "He has a very musical style of writing, and I think I can understand it." Ms. Opel grew up in Kansas City, Mo., studied drama at Juilliard and stepped right into the lead of "Evita" at 22 after sailing through an audition without bothering to study the music. "I was just a little fool," she said. "I didn't know anything." She later appeared on Broadway in "Sunday in the Park With George" and "Anything Goes." Off Broadway, Ms. Opel has been an Ives standby, appearing in his "Don Juan in Chicago" and "All in the Timing." "We've done a lot of 'let's sit around the table and see what we've got here,' " she said. "He calls on me a lot for that. The characters just sort of come out."
 
Footlights
 *The McCarter Theater in Princeton will present the American premiere of a new play by Athol Fugard at the end of next season. "The Captain's Tiger," which will have its world premiere in South Africa in the fall, retells Mr. Fugard's adventures as a young writer aboard a tramp steamer in the South Pacific.
*On June 27, "Forbidden Broadway Strikes Back!" moves within striking range of its victims when it relocates to the new Stardust Theater, on Broadway at 51st Street, right next to "Cats." Gerard Alessandrini has added new material that gives his very special welcome to "Annie," "Chicago" and "Jekyll and Hyde."
*The revival of George Bernard Shaw's "Misalliance" at the Laura Pels Theater at the Roundabout has enlisted the services of Brian Murray, Alan Tudyk, Elizabeth Marvel and Joanna Going in the lead roles. Performances begin July 18.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Platinum Prices Rise Sharply As Talks on Exports Continue

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Platinum futures surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as a halt in Russian platinum and palladium exports continued to leave supplies scarce.
Russian exports of platinum and palladium have been suspended since December. While they could resume in late June, there have been signs of delays as Japanese trading companies continued to negotiate with Russian sellers this week in Tokyo. 
 Traders, meanwhile, said they had stopped quoting lease rates for palladium -- the interest rate charged for borrowing the metal -- because spare supplies were also scarce.
"There's just none of it around," said Marty McNeill, a precious metals trader at Sinclair Group in New York. "The Russians have the metal in the ground, but there's very little of it available."
Platinum for delivery in July rose $25, to $436.60 an ounce, the highest price for a most-active contract since Sept. 19, 1995. September palladium rose 35 cents, to $173.15 an ounce, while the less active June contract, which expires the end of the month, fell $2.65, to $200.15 an ounce.
On Tuesday, the Nichimen Corporation, a Japanese trading house, said it would buy about 4.2 metric tons of Russian palladium and 1.2 metric tons of platinum. A metric ton is 1.1 short tons. Those shipments will begin in July, a precious metals dealer at Nichimen said.
Nichimen is among the Japanese trading and auto companies holding talks this week with officials from the Russian Finance Ministry and Almaz, Russia's official export agency. Japan is the largest consumer of the metals, which are used in automobiles and computers.
But on Wednesday, the Reuters news service cited unidentified precious metals traders in Tokyo as saying that Almaz had not yet secured the export licenses it needs.
Almaz said it expected to obtain those licenses by the end of this week, with the first deliveries of metal from Russia expected about June 20.
Doug Upton, head of commodities at HSBC James Capel in London, said the lack of licenses was a concern to the precious metals market. "Without the licenses, they can't start selling," he said.

HEADLINE: Rent Regulations Fuel Housing Court Chaos

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The economic benefits of vacancy decontrol already exist for landlords in two regulations that allow market rents to be charged for vacated units: "first rent" increase, whenever any rent-controlled apartment turns over to rent stabilization, and the "1/40th" increase when a stabilized unit is renovated (news article, June 3). Vacancy decontrol should be taken off the table so that negotiations on other issues, like luxury decontrol and succession rights, can proceed.
 
THOMAS LIGON
New York, June 3, 1997

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Drop

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
Average interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages fell this week to the lowest level since March. The average decreased to 7.85 percent from 7.94 percent a week earlier, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. It was the lowest rate since the week ended March 13, two weeks before the Federal Reserve tightened monetary policy. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.40 percent this week, down from 7.47 percent a week earlier. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.78 percent this week, down from 5.83 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Lower Against the Yen On Hints of Japanese Vitality

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the yen yesterday on hints that Japan's economy is strengthening, but it had more modest losses in other foreign-exchange dealings, a day before the scheduled release of May unemployment data in the United States.
There was relatively little movement in the currency market before today's release of the Labor Department report, which could provide clues to the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates. 
 Traders said that if the data showed a continuation of healthy job growth in the American economy, the dollar was likely to strengthen, particularly against currencies in Europe where economic weakness and uncertainty over plans for monetary union have been pushing the dollar higher since last week.
"The dollar is still on very firm footing," said Stephen Flanagan, vice president for foreign exchange at Credit Agricole Indosuez in New York. "We didn't go up today, but we are not going down either. There's still a continual demand for dollars, with the backdrop of the European situation."
In New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 115.72 yen, down from 116.25 yen on Wednesday. The dollar slipped to 1.7288 German marks from 1.7292 marks. The British pound rose to $1.6351 from $1.6324.
The yen's value increased in Asian trading after the governor of the Japanese central bank, Yasuo Matsushita, said that "a pre-emptive monetary policy is desirable."
Traders interpreted his remark as a sign that interest rates in Japan, at record lows since September 1995, could start to rise even before emphatic evidence of economic expansion there became obvious. Rising rates in Japan would increase the value of yen-denominated assets.
The yen gained further support from Japanese Government data showing that household spending in April declined only 1 percent from a year earlier despite a tax increase on April 1. Currency traders viewed this as a sign suggesting that Japan's economy is resilient.
"The feeling was that Japanese consumer spending was dead after the tax hike," said Bob Near, vice president for foreign exchange at the Bank of New York. "The market was looking for a bigger decline."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Island of Dreams

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Come with me to the island of dreams fulfilled, to the oasis of idealism in the sands of the city.
Is this the place? This expanse of cement plaza in Upper Manhattan is supposed to be a dream paradise or some kind of cockamamie oasis? 
 Yes, and you can see it every day. Young people rush across the plaza to classes. They can do that because 150 years ago New York decided youngsters without money deserved a chance to go to college, and reap the intellectual and economic rewards.
Almost a million young New Yorkers have earned degrees in the 10 senior colleges opened to them by that decision. Few could even imagine affording college otherwise.
Conjure up the city without the gifts they returned -- Jonas Salk's polio vaccine, the discoveries of eight Nobel winners, Paddy Chayefsky's plays, Oscar Hijuelo's lovely novels, the enterprise of thousands of top business executives; a drearier, poorer city, spiceless. And what about Colin Powell and Edward G. Robinson?
If you had been with me on Tuesday morning, in this plaza in the oldest and best known of those colleges, City College, you would never have asked. You would have seen 2,500 men and women sit in drizzle and chill, aware only that they were to fulfill their dream. Fourteen hundred got baccalaureate degrees, and 1,100 graduate degrees -- in science, arts, education, engineering, computer science.
For years in high school, they worried -- am I good enough to get into C.C.N.Y.? If I do, will I be strong enough in willpower and body to go to classes every day, work mornings or at night to keep myself alive and help my family and return to the library until midnight, for the studying I still have to do? If I am, some year in June will my parents be here to see?
You would have heard these young people take the same "oath of devotion" to their city that the youngsters of Athens took to theirs. They promised to transmit a New York greater, better and more beautiful than had been handed to them. They will.
You would have seen that most of them were black, Hispanic or Asian -- maybe 10 percent white. I will tell you a story.
When I was a student at City, youngsters from all over the city took the subway to a station in Harlem -- boys only, girls had not been invented. We walked six or seven blocks through Harlem to 138th Street and Convent Avenue. On the way, we saw only black people.
In our classrooms, we saw no black students or so few that I can't remember any. What I do remember is the conversation and thought that we, our teachers and City Hall put into the absence of blacks: none. Never came up.
Well, they couldn't make it in, right? Right. The academic entry requirements were too high. So New York faced a choice: keep minority students out for the years it would take to redo the dreadful high school system, or the many decades to solve the problems of parentless families, drugs, crime and joblessness that throttled the youngsters -- or lower the standards and say come in.
In 1969, the city chose "open admissions" and lowered entry requirements for the senior colleges. They made them too low then, I think. And I believe the remedial work so many bright minority students and immigrants need should be taken away from high schools that can't do the job, their budgets docked and the money and responsibility given to remedial private schools -- before entry into college.
Shockingly, some of the six two-year community colleges have allowed students to graduate without passing a simple English test. But that fuss has nothing to do with the requirements at the 10 four-year senior colleges.
At those colleges, entry requirements have been raised and remedial classes reduced. Meanwhile more better-prepared students are entering. Achievers, many inspired by the very fact of being in the college, are doing what achievers do: reach and grasp.
If any New Yorkers who had been in the plaza that morning, seen the light in the face of the graduates and heard their pledges did not understand that they had fulfilled the dream of their lives, and what these young people had accomplished for themselves, the city and American idealism, or did not want to kiss them, then they died last week and somebody should tell them.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Flat Ahead of Labor Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities remained flat yesterday as investors waited for today's release of the employment report for May to see how much strength the economy is exhibiting, an important clue as to whether the Fed will raise interest rates again.
Market participants mostly shrugged off a report of sluggish chain store sales for May and the latest week's surprising jump in weekly initial jobless claims. The number of claims for state unemployment insurance rose 19,000, in contrast to expectations of a decline of 2,000. 
 "The Fed can still claim that tight labor market conditions do not necessarily imply faster C.P.I. growth," said Rick MacDonald, an economist with MMS International, San Francisco, "but another month of solid employment growth and accelerating wages should provide evidence that inflation risk remains to the high side."
The 30-year bond was unchanged from Wednesday at a price of 96 26/32 to yield 6.88 percent.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said, "The issue of whether or not the Fed will tighten monetary policy at the F.O.M.C. meeting on July 2 is very much alive, despite early statistical suggestions of a noticeably more subdued pace of G.D.P. growth in the second quarter and continuing favorable and nonthreatening inflation data.
Mr. Fine said both the extent and duration of the currently softer pace of economic activity were still open to question, and some recently released data, namely the purchasing managers' index on Monday and factory orders on Wednesday, had already begun to raise serious concerns.
"Broadly speaking," Mr. Fine said, "the economy's strong underpinnings and tight labor markets seem to be pointing to another round of Fed tightening." However, he added, the Fed may be a bit more pro-growth than previously thought so may not act until the evidence is clear-cut. Further, he noted, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, "must deliver his Humphrey-Hawkins testimony shortly after this upcoming F.O.M.C. meeting, and would likely prefer not to incur the wrath of Congress unless the economic evidence for a less accommodative stance was compelling."
Today's labor statistics, Mr. Fine said, should provide a great deal of information about employment, wage pressures, the degree of labor tightness and overall economic conditions during the second quarter. Market expectations for the change in nonfarm payrolls vary widely, but a consensus seems to be forming for a gain of about 225,000, higher than in the last two months, and for a jump of four-tenths of a percent in average hourly earnings. Mr. Fine said the unemployment rate might grow, given its surprising drop last month to 4.9 percent, the lowest in nearly a quarter of a century.
"While virtually all forecasters are expecting it to either remain unchanged or move back up to 5 percent or even a touch higher," Mr. Fine said, "the fact remains that a further drop of any degree would unnerve the bond market, and give the Fed apoplexy."
Elsewhere in the credit markets, municipal bonds were little changed with few new issues offered. Only about $250 million of new muni issues were set for yesterday, with about $2.5 billion in new issues set for the week. Analysts report that the lack of supply has pushed up muni prices and with no real supply in sight, they say prices are likely to stay rich.
The Bond Buyer measure of visible supply of bonds over the next 30 days shows about $4.05 billion of bonds, compared with $6.1 billion a year ago.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Then And Now

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
From the steps where George C. Marshall stood 50 years ago, Secretary of State Madeleine Albright spoke to Harvard and the country about America's continuing responsibility in the world. It was a brave speech and a compelling one. But it had an effect that Ms. Albright surely did not intend: to underline the difference between our political leaders then and now, the difference between strength and weakness.
In 1947 Secretary of State Marshall's call for U.S. aid to a shattered Europe went to "an American people weary of war and wary of new commitments," Ms. Albright said. Moreover, a Democratic Administration faced a hostile Republican Congress. 
 But President Truman was not daunted by those obstacles. He took the Marshall Plan to European governments and to Congress. He fought for it. And he won, enlisting this country in the century's greatest constructive act of statesmanship.
Today there are new dangers that we must face, Secretary Albright said. At the head of her list was "ethnic conflict." She spelled out in powerful terms how the genocidal conflict in the former Yugoslavia menaces a civilized world.
"We can summon the same spirit" as Marshall's to deal with the new dangers, she said. "We, too, must heed the lessons of the past, accept responsibility and lead."
But two Presidents have faced that test and failed it. George Bush and Bill Clinton were confronted by this generation's challenge of ethnic conflict, and ran from the responsibility of American leadership.
In the fall of 1991 Serbian forces began shelling Croatian cities: lawless attacks on civilian targets. Months later the Serbs launched their campaign of mass murder and expulsion in Bosnia. "Men and women like you and me," Secretary Albright said, "were abused or murdered not because of anything they had done but simply for who they were."
What did President Bush do about that savagery on the continent where American forces had been posted for 40 years to keep the peace? He averted his gaze. He left it to Europeans to meet the challenge, knowing as he must have known that they would not act effectively without American leadership.
Just imagine that Harry Truman had been in the White House in 1991. Can anyone doubt what he would have done? He would have responded to the Serbian aggression immediately and with all the strength required, as he responded to economic collapse in Europe and to a Communist threat in Greece.
President Clinton came to office in 1993 with a promise to act more vigorously against the aggressors in Bosnia. But if that was his conviction, he did not have the courage to carry it out. Only after years of further slaughter, coming to a climax with the Serbian mass murders in Srebrenica, was he shamed into moving decisively. The result was the Dayton peace accords.
Secretary Albright spelled out in unflinching terms the need for all parties in the former Yugoslavia to carry out their Dayton obligations -- as she had just done on the ground, speaking with tough candor to the leaders of Croatia and Serbia. She emphasized the need for "full cooperation with the International War Crimes Tribunal."
"That tribunal represents a choice not only for Bosnia and for Rwanda," she said, "but for the world. . . . We can presume to forget what only God and the victims have standing to forgive, or we can heed the most searing lesson of this century, which is that evil -- when unopposed -- will spawn more evil."
There was a special quality to Ms. Albright's words and presence: a woman who came to this country as a refugee standing in George Marshall's place. Only in America. "I know I'm not George Marshall," she said the evening before her speech. "But I also know that like him I want America to lead."
But great American ventures depend on Presidential leadership. Its absence was the reason for the tragic failure to meet the Yugoslav crisis, and again for the failure at the end of 1991 and after to give substantial help to Russia in constructing a new economy.
America's role, Secretary Albright said, is to be a "pathfinder -- the nation able to show the way when others cannot." It is an important truth. What a difference it would make to the world if the Presidents of our time understood and acted on it.

HEADLINE: Fritz Leutwiler, 72, Banker; Revamped Currency System

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Fritz Leutwiler, a Swiss central banker who played an important role as the system of floating currency rates was put into place, died May 29 in Zumikon, Switzerland, where he lived. He was 72.
The cause of death was cancer, a spokesman for the Swiss central bank said. 
 Mr. Leutwiler joined the central bank, the Swiss National Bank, in 1952 and worked in its economics and statistics department. He became the bank's president in 1974 and served for a decade, endowing the job with wide influence in Swiss political and financial life.
Mr. Leutwiler presided over the bank during a period of exceptional monetary turmoil as the world slowly adjusted to the inevitability of floating exchange rates.
As Swiss National Bank president, and after 1982 as head of the secretive Bank for International Settlements, the central bank for central bankers, Mr. Leutwiler played a constructive role in managing the world's currency upheavals while faced with conflicting monetary philosophies.
In Switzerland, opinion remained conservative in its support for fixed currency values and their ultimate convertibility into gold. But the United States was pressing for a looser system that would allow currencies to fluctuate on markets according to the perceived strength of their underlying economies.
And even France, while officially espousing the merits of fixed rates, was secretly negotiating with Washington on an amendment to the International Monetary Fund's statutes that would legitimize floating exchange rates.
Amid this turmoil, Mr Leutwiler kept a low profile but worked constantly to contain monetary crises and promote stability in international financial affairs. He sensed that the political wind was blowing against those who favored a return to fixed exchange rates and that the world's economic health now required a more flexible and pragmatic monetary system.
Thus, under his direction, the Swiss National Bank played a leading role in mobilizing a $30 billion war chest to defend the dollar in 1978. And in 1982 as head of the Bank for International Settlements as well as the Swiss bank, Mr. Leutwiler helped the United States Treasury assemble a $1.8 billion package of credits to shore up the Mexican peso at the start of what was to become a debt crisis in Latin America.
In his monetary history of these years, "Changing Fortunes," a former chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker, said that at the time of the Mexican bailout, Mr. Leutwiler, along with the governor of the Bank of England, Gordon Richardson, "instinctively understood what was at stake."
Mr. Leutwiler was also instrumental in arranging emergency credits for countries like Hungary and Brazil when they encountered financial difficulties. As a condition, the countries had to seek long-term arrangements with the International Monetary Fund and commit themselves to corrective austerity programs
In 1985, Mr. Leutwiler became chairman of BBC Brown Boveri A.G. and helped bring about its merger with Asea A.G. of Sweden in 1987 to form ABB Asea Brown Boveri. Mr Leutwiler served as co-chairman of the new company until he retired in 1992.
In the months before his death, Mr. Leutwiler worked with Swiss banks and industry in efforts to set up a fund to compensate Holocaust victims and their families.
Mr. Leutwiler graduated from the University of Zurich with an economics degree four years before he joined the central bank. He worked as editor of a monetary journal and later went to London for training with a Swiss commercial bank.
Mr. Leutwiler is survived by his wife, Andree Leutwiler of Zumikon; a daughter, Sabine Leutwiler of Zurich, and a son, Nicolas Leutwiler.
