SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 590 words

HEADLINE: The Next City Budget Debate

 BODY:
"Mellow" is not a word that normally springs to mind in connection with New York City's Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. But the budget negotiations between the Mayor and the City Council were concluded this week with remarkable ease and serenity. A big pile of money does wonders to improve the political temperament.
Thanks to the continuing stock market boom that generated record Wall Street profits, the city recorded a surplus of more than $1 billion in the current fiscal year. By using much of that money to prepay next year's expenses, the Mayor and Council were able to put together a new spending plan that contains no painful cuts. Bowing to a tradition as ancient and ritualized as Kabuki theater, Mr. Giuliani proposed reductions in money for parks, museums and libraries so the Council could restore them. But outside of the schools, there were no large new spending initiatives. 
 While the Council has always been regarded as the let's-party end of city government, the final deal was more fiscally responsible than Mr. Giuliani's original proposal. It includes a $500 million rainy-day fund championed by Council Speaker Peter Vallone. It reduced the amount of dangerous "one-shot" revenues that would be available in the future. The Financial Control Board estimated that Mr. Giuliani's original budget contained a record $1.9 billion in non-recurring resources. Now the amount is by most estimates well under $1 billion.
Since Mr. Giuliani is running for re-election, this budget will be the last installment in what he promised would be a four-year struggle to put the city on an even keel permanently. Over his term, the Mayor has spent $3 billion less than he would have if the budget had continued to grow at the rate it was when he took office. The city work force is 22,000 heads smaller. The welfare caseload is down by 23 percent.
Yet Mr. Giuliani still has not been able to correct the structural imbalances that keep expenses growing faster than revenues. Since the economy depends far too heavily on the financial district, any serious setback on Wall Street could send New York right back to the miseries it experienced in the late 1980's. New York already faces a projected $2.8 billion budget gap in the year 2000.
The upcoming campaign must therefore include an intelligent argument about how New York can prevent the boom-and-bust cycles it has endured since the 1970's. Mr. Giuliani must explain why he has failed to do so. His opponents must explain how they could do better.
The prescriptions are limited and painful -- a drastic cut in programs, tax hikes or a dramatic change in labor agreements to improve productivity. Mr. Giuliani's own efforts at negotiating labor contracts have had mixed results. He has persuaded the unions to accept wage freezes and modest salary hikes. But he has won very little in the way of changes that would allow the city to manage its work force better, or reduce some of the benefits like extra holidays that workers in the private sector do not enjoy. The teachers' contract contained land mines of concessions that are forcing the Board of Education to hire additional people to perform some of the unionized teachers' old duties.
A fourth solution to New York's unbalanced finances -- additional state and Federal aid -- is the fairest and most desirable. But the Mayor's opponents will have to explain why the public should believe they can do better at extracting money from Albany and Washington than either Mr. Giuliani or his Democratic predecessors.

HEADLINE: Albright's Words: Global Task for U.S.

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's commencement address yesterday at Harvard University . Her remarks were transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.
British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin called the Marshall Plan a "lifeline to sinking men," and it was -- although I expect some women in Europe were equally appreciative. By extending that lifeline, America helped unify Europe's west around democratic principles and planted seeds of trans-Atlantic partnership that would soon blossom in the form of NATO and the cooperative institutions of a new Europe. 
 Just as important was the expression of American leadership that the Marshall Plan conveyed. After world War I, America had withdrawn from the world, shunning responsibility and avoiding risk. Others did the same. The result in the heart of Europe was the rise of great evil. After the devastation of World War II and the soul-withering horror of the Holocaust, it was not enough to say that the enemy had been vanquished -- that what we were against had failed.
The generation of Marshall, Truman and Vandenberg was determined to build a lasting peace. And the message that generation conveyed from the White House, from both parties on Capitol Hill, and from people across our country who donated millions in relief cash, clothing, and food, was that, this time, America would not turn inward, America would lead.
Today, in the wake of the cold war, it is not enough for us to say that Communism has failed. We, too, must heed the lessons of the past, accept responsibility and lead.
Because we are entering a century in which there will be many interconnected centers of population, power, and wealth, we cannot limit our focus, as Marshall did in his speech, to the devastated battleground of a prior war. Our vision must encompass not one, but every continent.
Unlike Marshall's generation, we face no single galvanizing threat. The dangers we confront are less visible and more diverse, some as old as ethnic conflict, some as new as letter bombs, some as subtle as climate change, and some as deadly as nuclear weapons falling into the wrong hands.
To defend against these threats, we must take advantage of the historic opportunity that now exists to bring the world together in an international system based on democracy, open markets, law and a commitment to peace.
We know that not every nation is yet willing or able to play its full part in this system. One group is still in transition from centralized planning and totalitarian rule. Another has only begun to dip its toes into economic and political reform. Some nations are still too weak to participate in a meaningful way. And a few countries have regimes that actively oppose the premises upon which this system is based.
Because the situation we face today is different from that confronted by Marshall's generation, we cannot always use the same means. But we can summon the same spirit.
We can strive for the same sense of bipartisanship that allowed America in Marshall's day to present to both allies and adversaries a united front.
We can invest the resources needed to keep America strong economically, militarily and diplomatically, recognizing, as did Marshall, that these strengths reinforce each other.
We can act with the same knowledge that, in our era, American security and prosperity are linked to economic and political health abroad.
And we can recognize, even as we pay homage to the heroes of history, that we have our own duty to be authors of history.
Let every nation acknowledge: today, the opportunity to be part of an international system based on democratic principles is available to all. This was not the case 50 years ago. . . .
Today, there is no Stalin to give orders. If a nation is isolated from the international community now, it is either because the country is simply too weak to meet international standards or because its leaders have chosen willfully to disregard those standards.
Last week, in the Netherlands, President Clinton said that no democratic nation in Europe would be left out of the trans-Atlantic community. Today, I say that no nation in the world need be left out of the global system we are constructing. And every nation that seeks to participate, and is willing to do all it can to help itself, will have America's help in finding the right path. . . .
As this great university has recognized in the foreign students it has attracted, the research it conducts, the courses it offers and the sensibility it conveys, those of you who have graduated today will live global lives. You will compete in a world marketplace; travel further and more often than any previous generation; share ideas, tastes and experience with counterparts from every culture, and recognize that to have a full and rewarding future, you will have to look outward.
As you do, and as our country does, we must aspire to the high standard set by Marshall, using means adapted to our time based on values that endure for all time, and never forgetting that America belongs on the side of freedom. I say this to you as Secretary of State. I say it also as one of the many people whose lives have been shaped by the turbulence of Europe during the middle of this century and by the leadership of America throughout this century.
I can still remember, in England during the war, sitting in the bomb shelter, singing away the fear, thanking God for American help.
I can still remember, after the war and after the Communist takeover in Prague, arriving here in the United States, where I wanted only to be accepted and to make my parents and my new country proud.
Because my parents fled in time, I escaped Hitler. To our shared and constant sorrow, millions did not.
Because of America's generosity, I escaped Stalin. Millions did not.
Because of the vision of the Truman-Marshall generation, I have been privileged to live my life in freedom. Millions have still never had that opportunity.
It may be hard for you, who have no memory of that time fifty years ago, to understand. But it is necessary that you try to understand. . . .
Today, the greatest danger to America is not some foreign enemy; it is the possibility that we will fail to heed the example of that generation; that we will allow the momentum toward democracy to stall, take for granted the institutions and principles upon which our own freedom is based, and forget what the history of this century reminds us: that problems, if left unattended, will all too often come home to America.
A decade or two from now, we will be known as the neo-isolationists, who allowed tyranny and lawlessness to rise again, or as the generations that solidified the global triumph of democratic principles.
We will be known as the neo-protectionists, whose lack of vision produced financial meltdown, or as the generations that laid the groundwork for rising prosperity around the world.
We will be known as the world-class ditherers, who stood by while the seeds of renewed global conflict were sown, or as the generations that took strong measures to forge alliances, deter aggression and keep the peace.
There is no certain road map for success, either for individuals or for generations. Ultimately, it is a matter of judgment, a question of choice. In making that choice, let us remember that there is not a page of American history of which we are proud that was authored by a chronic complainer or prophet of despair. We are doers.
We have a responsibility in our time, as others have had in theirs, not to be prisoners of history, but to shape history; a responsibility to fill the role of pathfinder, and to build with others a global network of purpose and law that will protect our citizens, defend our interests, preserve our values, and bequeath to future generations a legacy as proud as the one we honor today.
To that mission, I pledge my own best efforts and summon yours.

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 607 words

HEADLINE: Marriott Trying to Buy a Site For Another Times Sq. Hotel

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Marriott International, the largest hotelier in the city, is in negotiations with the Prudential Insurance Company to purchase a development site in Times Square for a 700-room Courtyard hotel, according to real estate sources.
Marriott, which already operates 2,277 rooms at two hotels nearby, has long sought to expand its franchise in the thriving Times Square area where several other hoteliers are also seeking to build. The proposed hotel would sit on an oddly shaped island bound by Broadway and Seventh Avenue, between 41st and 42d Streets. Marriott does not expect the more budget-minded Courtyard hotel to compete with its Marriott Marquis convention hotel in Times Square. The hotel industry is experiencing an unprecedented boom in occupancy and increased room rates in New York. 
 "The market in Times Square is phenomenal right now," said one person familiar with Marriott's plans. "It'd be like adding rooms to the Marriott Marquis."
Prudential officials could not be reached for comment.
Robert Deeley, regional vice president for lodging development at Marriott, confirmed that the company was looking at sites in Times Square, but declined to comment on negotiations with Prudential.
"We have a substantial appetite for limited service hotels in New York," Mr. Deeley said. "We're continuing to explore opportunities in midtown, downtown and Times Square. But we haven't firmed up anything yet."
The site is one of three parcels controlled by Prudential and zoned for large office towers under the Times Square redevelopment plan. In recent years, Prudential has tried to get out of the real estate business and sell the sites to other developers. City and state officials, however, would have to amend the zoning and approve a deal before a hotel could be built.
The site is designated for a 1.2 million square-foot office tower. Marriott would only require about 600,000 square feet and may seek to transfer the unused development rights to one of the other sites, according to real estate executives active in Times Square.
Charles Gargano, the State Commissioner of Economic Development, is aware of the Marriott negotiations and would be happy to amend the plans for the area to allow for a hotel, because it would bring more tourists to Times Square, said Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for the Empire State Development Corporation. Some real estate executives suggested that the Courtyard hotel would undercut efforts by the Tishman Urban Development Organization to build a 45-story, 860-room luxury hotel a block away at the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue, between 42d and 43d Streets. City and state officials selected Tishman two years ago from among three competing hotel developers, including Marriott, to build the hotel and an entertainment complex. Although Marriott had been willing to begin construction immediately, Tishman has another six years to locate financing and start the project. The entertainment complex, however, is moving forward.
Marriott was not content to wait and has been looking for a suitable location for more than a year. The Milstein family and developer Bruce Ratner have also talked of building hotels on the south side of 42d Street, near Eighth Avenue.
Richard Kielar, executive vice president for Tishman Realty and Construction, said the Marriott Courtyard would not pose a problem for developing a luxury hotel catering to tourists and business travelers on his organization's site.
"The Courtyard is not a full-service hotel," Mr. Kielar said. "So we don't think that adding a Courtyard puts us anywhere near the saturation point for hotel rooms."

HEADLINE: Budget Passed, Now the Hard Part

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 5

 BODY:
Five months after promising a deep cut in the income tax and substantial reductions in the state work force, Gov. John G. Rowland ended the year's budget negotiations with a victory pronouncement.
"We can say to everyone in the state that we've delivered," Mr. Rowland, a Republican, said in his speech early this morning closing the legislative session. 
 For the third year in a row, Mr. Rowland had pushed his agenda through the Democratic-controlled State House of Representatives, and through a State Senate where Democrats gained the majority this year. When the dust settled after a three-week budget stalemate, Mr. Rowland had won critical provisions that Democrats had resisted.
Now comes the hard part.
Having achieved the measures he wanted to control state spending and cut the income tax by one-third for a majority of taxpayers, Mr. Rowland must now make sure the measures provide the savings he promised.
"He got what he wanted in the budgetary terms, and now we can see if he can do it in managerial terms," said Michael Levin, vice president of the Connecticut Policy and Economic Council, a nonpartisan research group. "There are proposals in this budget that are still big question marks."
The biggest are two programs that at the start of the legislative session Democrats called "gimmicks." One is an early retirement plan that is supposed to result in the elimination of roughly 2,000 of the state's 43,000 positions. The other is contracting out all state computer services, the largest privatization effort in state history and perhaps the first time that any state has tried to turn over all its data processing to an outside vendor. Together, these two measures are supposed to save $250 million over the life of the two-year, $21 billion budget.
Democrats greeted these proposals in February with skepticism. "Neither of the state's two prior early retirement packages achieved this level of savings, and many computer privatization efforts in other states have been disastrous," State Representative Moira P. Lyons, the House majority leader, said then, adding that savings "could very well not materialize."
Democratic leaders said that since then, they have improved the early retirement proposal by brokering a contract with the state employee unions in April that won -- at least temporarily -- labor's support.
And the impasse over the state budget that delayed a final agreement until the last minutes of the legislative session, they said, was motivated by their effort to oversee the privatization measure. They held out for a provision that gave the legislature veto power over the computer privatization contract if one chamber rejected it by a vote of 60 percent.
Today, Mr. Lyons conceded she still had reservations about both initiatives, but was upbeat. "We think the budget will work," she said. "We voted on it, and it's a good budget."
Of course, politics played a major role in the decision to embrace these measures. Mr. Rowland has made income tax cuts the central issue in state politics. While Democrats have emphasized cutting property taxes instead of the income tax, they also from day one of the budget deliberations promised to deliver big tax reductions, and had to match the tax cuts Mr. Rowland offered.
As a result, Democrats could not afford to reject the savings that Mr. Rowland promised from early retirement and privatization.
Continued improvements in the economy could increase revenues so that the success or failure of these programs will have little impact on the state's finances.
Still, if the budget is to be balanced, Mr. Rowland must shoulder the burden of making these programs work.
Early retirement programs have a poor record nationally in producing savings. Ronald K. Snell, director of the economic and fiscal division at the National Conference of State Legislatures, said, "When you take all expenses into account, it's rare that you save money."
In states that have tried these programs, including Minnesota, Maryland and Virginia, such initiatives have failed to meet goals, he said.
And the way the current measure is structured will make it tough to achieve the expected savings, said Michael Meotti, president of the Connecticut Economic and Policy Council. Because it is open to all state employees over 52 years old who have worked for the state for 10 or more years, the state will have little control over who retires and whether they come from departments that are overstaffed.
Marc S. Ryan, a budget aide to Mr. Rowland, acknowledged that history is not on the Governor's side, but he noted that other governors have not been as committed as Mr. Rowland to shrinking the work force. He said that Mr. Rowland had already cut several thousand jobs, and would see to it that the same happened with this early retirement program.
At the same time, Mr. Ryan noted that Mr. Rowland has a fallback position: he could lay off more employees if the early retirement program failed to achieve its savings goal of $200 million. That, however, could lead to legal action by the state's labor unions.
The plan to privatize the state's computer operations, with a contract valued at $1 billion, may be even more dicey.
State employees unions, which have criticized the measure, say that private contractors who have handled smaller jobs for the state have come in over cost.
Mr. Ryan said large companies have successfully contracted out data processing. "We don't see any reason why that same success can't be mirrored in the public sector," he said.
That will be "one heck of a challenge," Mr. Meotti said, noting that the state lacks the depth of senior management and the financial incentives that exist in the private sector to manage such a transition.
"The Boston Red Sox management have spent years studying teams that won the World Series, but they haven't been able to do it in about 80 years," Mr. Meotti said. "They're a perfect example that the secret is in the execution of the plan."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Average Rises 35.63, As Market Gains Broadly
Stocks moved broadly higher in an unexpected show of investor confidence ahead of the monthly employment report today. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 35.63 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,305.29 
 The broad rally first lifted technology stocks and spread quickly to financial issues, transportation stocks and other sectors. The Nasdaq composite index gained 10.38 points to close at 1,390.05. [Page D5.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities remained flat as investors waited for the May employment report. The 30-year bond yield was unchanged from Wednesday at 6.88 percent. [D14.]
 
Germany Goes After Cybercrime
In Germany, officials are pushing harder than in other Western democracies to govern the seemingly ungovernable reaches of cyberspace, trying to block access to material they consider obscene, violent or a danger to society. Angela Marquardt, a 25-year-old university student, will enter a Berlin courtroom today to face criminal charges for maintaining a home page that provided an electronic link to a left-wing newspaper called Radikal. [A1.]
 
Trinity Fund Seeks Fisher Scientific
Fisher Scientific International said that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer from Trinity I Fund L.P., a group affiliated with members of the Bass family, the Texas investors. Trinity proposed a recapitalization of Fisher or a cash deal worth an indicated $977.6 million to $998.4 million. [D4.]
 
Humana Buys Choice Care
In its second acquisition of the week, Humana has agreed to buy Choice Care, the largest health maintenance organization in Cincinnati, for $250 million in cash. [D3.]
 
Chip Maker Beats Estimates
The revamping of National Semiconductor by its new chief executive resulted in the chip maker's operating earnings exceeding analysts' estimates for the fourth quarter, although it reported a loss. [D2.]
 
Sears Agrees to Settle Claims
Sears, Roebuck agreed to pay at least $165 million to settle claims that it wrongfully pursued more than 200,000 customers whose credit card debts had been wiped out by bankruptcy filings. [D3.]
 
Wendy the Snapple Lady Is Back
A fanciful version of a Manhattan pushcart almost stopped traffic on Fifth Avenue as Wendy the Snapple lady shouted news of her comeback. Snapple's new owner, the Triarc Beverage Group, plans elaborate advertising, marketing and promotional ploys.
Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D4.]
 
A. R. Baron Salesman Pleads Guilty
The star salesman at A. R. Baron & Company, a brokerage house that has been indicted on charges of being a criminal enterprise, entered a single guilty plea and agreed to cooperate with a continuing criminal investigation of Baron. The firm cleared its trades through Bear Stearns before collapsing last summer. [D3.]
 
Are Retailers Under the Weather?
How big a part do cumulus clouds, high-pressure systems and warm fronts really play in the strength of retail sales? It depends. Not on the actual weather, it seems, but rather on the sales. If they are bad, the weather can be culpable. [D3.]
 
German Economy Grows in Quarter
Germany's economy grew an unexpected four-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter over the previous quarter, as rising exports and corporate investment made up for weak consumer demand and a decline in construction activity. Growth was up 2.8 percent from a year earlier. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Co-op Market in Queens Shows Signs of Strength

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
The Queens co-op market has strengthened in recent months, prompted both by the general firming of New York City's real estate market and by the return to financial health of many buildings in the borough, with sales increasing and some landlords bringing apartments they had been renting back to the for-sale market.
While the sales activity is happening in varying degrees throughout the city, the rebound is noteworthy in Queens. By 1990, after the mid-1980's conversion surge had flattened, one of every four of the 80,000 apartments that were converted to co-ops in that borough were left in some kind of financial straits, according to data from the office of Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens. 
 Since then, many of the troubled cooperative buildings have worked out their financial problems, helping to nudge sales along, said managing agents, brokers and sellers. That modest rise in sales is evident in a spate of buildings, especially in good locations, in Queens communities like Forest Hills, Kew Gardens, Kew Gardens Hills, Jackson Heights and Woodside.
Also fueling the rise, many industry professionals said, is the strengthening housing market in general and Manhattan's in particular. At the same time, they said, financing for buying apartments has become more available, mortgage interest rates are reasonable and rents are rising.
In Queens, "there is not an avalanche of sales, but we are seeing movement," said Richard R. Pergolis, partner at Pergolis-Swartz Associates, a mortgage brokerage concern in Manhattan. For many people, "it now makes sense to buy because the monthly cost to own is comparable to the cost of renting," he said.
Charles Rappaport, executive director of the New York Federation of Housing Cooperatives, a nonprofit advisory group with about 650 members throughout New York City, said prices in Queens, as in other boroughs outside Manhattan, had fallen as much as 50 percent since the market's downturn in 1990. In the last year in Queens, he said, his members reported an 8 to 10 percent increase in prices, depending on the size of the apartment and the location and financial stability of the cooperative.
Co-ops in Queens sell on average for $40,000 to $50,000 for one-bedroom apartments and $60,000 to $70,000 for two-bedroom residences, Mr. Rappaport said.
More flexibility on the part of lenders has helped make more sales possible. Lenders often require that 50 percent of a building's apartments be sold before they will grant loans to buyers, and some also require a high level of owner occupancy. But some lenders are offering programs to enable co-op buyers to obtain loans in buildings that are healthy but do not meet such restrictive requirements.
For example, the National Cooperative Bank, based in Washington, offers share loans in qualified buildings that are 30 percent shareholder-owned, said Paulette Bonanno, vice president of the bank's Manhattan office. "This program is particularly important in Queens," Ms. Bonanno said, "because the borough has one of the highest percentages of buildings where less than half the apartments are sold."
Sales at several buildings in Queens reflect the pickup in activity. One is Hyde Park Gardens, a 37-building complex with 750 apartments at Jewel Avenue and 138th Street in Kew Gardens Hills. Last year, the Cheshire Group, a Manhattan-based investment concern, was given control of unsold apartments in the complex as part of a refinancing plan. In January, sales began on the 50 apartments.
Since then, 17 of the 20 vacant one- to three-bedroom apartments have been sold for $43,900 to $68,500, said Susan H. Hewitt, Cheshire's president. The rest of the units would be put on the market as they become available, she said. Cheshire just started a similar program at 92-05 Whitney Avenue, a 94-unit co-op in Jackson Heights. Of the 18 apartments controlled by Cheshire, 6 are vacant and for sale.
Sales are also under way at Boulevard Gardens, a 966-unit, 10-building complex at 54th Street and 31st Avenue in Woodside. Since last December, the co-op has sold 30 of its 80 vacant studio- to three-bedroom apartments for $20,000 to $60,000, said Jimmy Lanza, president of the Boulevard Gardens Owners Corporation. He said the plan was also to sell 300 occupied units that the co-ops took over as part of the refinancing as they become available.
Global Equities and Realty Inc., based in Manhattan, which owns small blocks, of three to five units each, in about 90 different cooperative buildings in Queens, sold 117 apartments this year at an average price of $32,000, up from 88 apartments sold the year before at an average price of $27,500, said Shem Rokeach, vice president of sales.
And some landlords are planning to reopen sales. This fall, sales are expected to begin again at two co-op complexes in Forest Hills converted in 1984 by the Moskowitz family, a large New York landlord. One, with 544 apartments, is on Yellowstone Boulevard and 67th Avenue; the other, with 354 units, is two blocks away.
Over the last 10 months, shareholders sold 17 studio- to two-bedroom apartments at the two complexes for $50,000 to $80,000, a 20 percent price increase over last year, said Karen A. Berman, vice president and director of sales at the Argo Corporation, the Manhattan-based management and brokerage company that is owned by the Moskowitz family. "Prices are strong and there is a demand again for co-ops," she said.
Co-op Equities Realty Partners, which is based in Bronxville, N.Y., reopened sales in the last few weeks for the 37 studio- to two-bedroom apartments it owns at two Queens projects: 84-01 Main Street in Briarwood and 69-40 Yellowstone Boulevard in Forest Hills. Prices are $30,000 to $80,000.
So far, the partners have a contract signed and two more pending on three of the six vacant apartments in the two projects. The remaining 31 apartments will be sold as leases expire over the next 6 to 12 months, said Nathaniel P. Plotkin, executive vice president of S. Goodstein Realty in Manhattan, the sales and marketing agent. "The most important thing that has happened in the Queens sales market," Mr. Plotkin said, "is that buyer hesitancy is over."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
5 Double Plays in Shutout by Reynoso

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN 

 BODY:
So maybe it is still a little early to start printing those Armandomania T-shirts. But with an economical effort, helped by a Mets record-tying five double plays, Armando Reynoso reached an important personal milepost yesterday.
The first shutout of Reynoso's major league career, a five-hit, 6-0 victory over the Florida Marlins, reinforced the surprising effectiveness of the Mets' starting staff. It may also have defined the end of a long road back from arm surgery. 
 More than three years after his previous complete game, and the surgery to transplant a wrist ligament in his right elbow that followed, in May 1994, Reynoso (5-0) used finesse to achieve dominance.
He created 17 outs from ground balls and seven others through strikeouts (4) and popups caught by infielders. Through the first seven innings at Shea Stadium, Reynoso allowed two hits, faced one hitter beyond the minimum of 21 and allowed only three balls to reach outfielders.
"That's the pitcher he has to be," said Bob Apodaca, the Mets' pitching coach. "When he gets in trouble, he can't get excited. He has to remain cool, and he has to get that ground ball."
That's the view from the dugout. The growing sense of anticipation from his infielders is even more significant.
"With Reynoso," said second baseman Carlos Baerga, "you have to be ready to catch the ball."
The Mets won for the ninth time in Reynoso's 10 starts. His success carried an added importance against the Florida starter Kevin Brown (5-4), whose 1.89 earned run average a season ago led to a second-place finish in the National League Cy Young Award balloting. Brown allowed six earned runs in seven innings, for a total of 13 in his last two starts, to raise his e.r.a. to 3.09.
The first of Edgardo Alfonzo's two run-scoring singles put Brown behind in the second, immediately after the right-hander had hit Carl Everett in the left foot to place runners at first and second with two outs.
Reynoso's grounder off the glove of shortstop Edgar Renteria and into center field, Alfonzo's broken-bat grounder past the dive of third baseman Bobby Bonilla and John Olerud's double off the right-field wall increased the lead to 4-0 in the fourth.
Butch Huskey had a pair of leadoff singles, scored two runs and has lifted his average 67 points in the past month to .295. Olerud had his 20th multiple-hit game of the season. Alfonzo has batted .333 since a 2-for-23 start. But Alfonzo's biggest contribution came in the third inning, before the ground balls had become a habit.
Reynoso had allowed Renteria to reach the warning track in right field in the first inning, and he began the third by walking Cliff Floyd. That turned out to be Reynoso's only walk, but with the Mets holding a 1-0 lead, Charles Johnson, the next hitter, nearly created trouble. Johnson pulled a pitch toward third base, between Alfonzo and the bag and apparently headed into the left-field corner. Alfonzo, sensing a breaking pitch, said he had been prepared to move quickly to his right. The necessary elements for a reaction play instantly took shape.
"The ball took a good bounce," Alfonzo said. "Everything was perfect."
He speared the ball with a sliding lunge and made a perfect throw to Baerga at second for the start of the first double play of the day.
"You take two outs with one pitch," Reynoso said.
The five double plays helped limit his pitch count to 100 and allowed Reynoso to consider a possibility that once seemed a long way away. "I started thinking about nine," he said.
Three years ago, when Dr. James Andrews performed the surgery on Reynoso, he informed him that 95 percent of such operations had been successful. But the time frame was something else. Reynoso said he is only now beginning to feel consistently strong. And last year, with Colorado, the coziness of Coors Field compounded his problems.
The trade for Jerry DiPoto last November brought Reynoso to a park that is more fair to pitchers. Yesterday, with Manager Bobby Valentine eager to use Greg McMichael for the first time since Saturday, Reynoso had enough left to earn his shutout. "I usually don't do things for the individual," Valentine said. "I asked him if he wanted it. He wanted it. He got it."
 
INSIDE PITCH
PETE HARNISCH and PAUL WILSON are each scheduled to throw 15 minutes of batting practice before the game tonight at Cincinnati, the start of a five-game trip. . . . LANCE JOHNSON, who has been on the disabled list with shinsplints, is expected to run the bases. HEADLINE: Merrill Lynch to Hire 2,000 for Cash and Tax Incentives

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch & Company, one of New York City's largest employers, has promised to add 2,000 jobs in exchange for more than $28 million in cash and tax incentives from the city and New York State, people familiar with the agreement said yesterday.
The subsidies will help the financial services company purchase 222 Broadway, a 31-story building between Fulton and Ann Streets, from Swiss Bank Corporation for $73 million. 
 Merrill Lynch, which employs about 9,000 people in New York, plans to hire 2,000 workers, mostly middle managers and back office workers, officials said. At its peak, Merrill Lynch employed about 13,000 people in Manhattan.
An employee of Merrill Lynch, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that "the firm was considering several options in terms of expansion, including out-of-state options. This makes it possible for us to stay and grow in New York City."
Officials said the deal, which will be voted on by the city's industrial development authority on Tuesday, would also keep about 1,000 employees of the company's back offices from moving to New Jersey. But a source familiar with the company's negotiations insisted that "there was never a thought of moving Merrill Lynch outside of New York City and New York State. The issue is where to expand."
Under joint agreements with the city's Economic Development Corporation and the Empire State Development Corporation, Merrill Lynch will receive $27 million in city and state sales tax exemptions on capital expenditures, such as the construction of its new offices.
Merrill Lynch will also receive a $1 million grant from a $20 million state fund, Jobs Now, which is intended for companies creating 300 jobs or more, officials said. Those subsidies will come on top of existing property tax incentives for tenants occupying office space in lower Manhattan.
Merrill Lynch already occupies about 3.5 million square feet of office space in Manhattan, including the entire 2-million-square-foot tower at 4 World Financial Center and about one-third of the nearby 2 World Financial Center.
Swiss Bank, which is vacating 222 Broadway and other New York offices to move to Stamford, Conn., had paid $150 million for the 36-year-old, 756,000-square-foot tower nine years ago.

HEADLINE: Swiss, Irked by Critics, Ask 'Why Single Us Out?'

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: ZURICH

 BODY:
After months of being told that their history books were wrong and that Switzerland's war was not a good war, a truculent mood is building here that may turn the nation against making amends for what the Clinton Administration and others depict as complicity with Nazi Germany.
Increasingly, Swiss diplomats, commentators and the general public bristle at what they see as a double standard. Many here feel that the critics, particularly the United States, have unfairly singled out Switzerland for its shortcomings in a period in which many other nations behaved ingloriously. 
 "In our eyes morality can mean other elements," Flavio Cotti, the Foreign Minister, mused in an interview the other day that seemed to reflect a new and uncharacteristic readiness to abandon the niceties of diplomacy. "We could ask the United States why they didn't enter the war until later?"
Although they have learned that comparisons of their wartime behavior with that of others brings them no credit, officials here seem ready to make them if only to reflect their frustration that -- no matter what they say or do -- the image of a perfidious Switzerland will not go away.
"What happened to Dutch Jews, French Jews? It isn't discussed," said Thomas Borer, the country's leading diplomat on the so-called Nazi Gold affair. "We are willing to discuss but the debate is turning sour."
Politically, such sentiments mean that Swiss voters may not endorse what was to have been the centerpiece of the Government's plans to make restitution to victims of oppression, including Holocaust survivors. Documents released in recent months have made clear that Swiss banks traded in looted Nazi gold, and that Swiss businesses made a fortune selling arms to the Nazis.
The Government's plans to increase the monetary value of its gold reserves so as to create a $4.7 billion dollar investment fund whose earnings would be used to pay compensation is subject to a referendum next spring. Additionally, the Swiss Parliament must vote this year to approve a $70 million contribution by the Swiss National Bank to a separate fund for Holocaust survivors.
After plans for the $4.7 billion fund were announced on March 5, opinion surveys registered approval ratings of Swiss voters at 60 to 70 percent in favor. A recent survey, in the weekly L'Illustre, registered 43 percent against and only 40 percent in favor.
What was more alarming was the xenophobic, if not anti-Semitic, message that some read into the swing in public opinion. "The Swiss of today do not need Jews and Americans to take the opportunity of dragging them through the mud," wrote Daniel Pillard, an editor at L'Illustre.
At the beginning of this year, it seemed that Switzerland might just trip lightly out of the opprobrium attached to its wartime past and its dealings with Nazi Germany.
Like a choreographed minuet, bankers, diplomats, American Jewish officials -- and a majority of the Swiss -- all seemed ready to take steps toward the creation of funds, foundations and high-level inquiries that would underpin the process of moral atonement for Switzerland's economic closeness to the Nazis.
But since the publication in May of a withering United States report accusing the Swiss of prolonging World War II by acting as the Nazis' bankers -- a charge the Swiss Government rejected -- the dancers have stumbled. The report was directed by Stuart E. Eizenstat, Under Secretary of Commerce.
All the while protesting friendship with Washington, Swiss officials like Mr. Cotti have taken to saying publicly what many Swiss were already saying in private: If the United States is so troubled by the morality of Switzerland's wartime behavior, why did it not enter the war until over two years after it started? Why did it not bomb the rail lines leading to Auschwitz?
The national obsession with the issue is so pervasive that Swiss television recently devoted a full three hours of prime-time viewing to a debate on the emotional issues that have arisen from the nation's modern history.
There is agreement, to be sure, between Switzerland and the United States about the broad outlines of Swiss wartime actions. Few dispute that the Swiss National Bank bought looted gold from Nazi Germany, that Swiss private banks and businesses did lucrative business with the Third Reich, or that Swiss officials turned away 30,000 Jewish refugees.
And the Swiss authorities are coming to acknowledge that even in the postwar era there was a legalistic obstructionism -- some would call it greed and duplicity -- that shielded German assets from Allied expropriation and blocked survivors' access to the bank deposits of Holocaust victims.
The question for the Swiss, though, is the motive. What Switzerland did in a continent at war was done for survival's sake, the Swiss argue. What Switzerland did, their critics assert, was done out of opportunism and amorality and should be paid for in both moral and financial terms.
Yet many Swiss refuse to accept hostile characterizations of their country's motives and object to the pressure from abroad to do otherwise.
"Swiss-bashing by outsiders does not help," Mr. Borer said. "A lot of Swiss feel treated in an unfair way. They feel we do everything we can and yet the criticism goes on."
Such are the passions that the recent television show became an arena of national division, inspiring Rolf Bloch, the leader of the main umbrella group representing Switzerland's 18,000 Jews, to remark that, rather than worry about what Americans thought, "we should be having a dialogue among us Swiss" to define anew what the nation stands for.
"People still feel they are moral paragons," Mr. Bloch said. "If we can come to the conclusion that we are just normal people -- not angels, not devils -- then we will have learned something."

HEADLINE: Algeria's Sham Election

 BODY:
This week's parliamentary elections in Algeria were not a serious exercise in democratic governance. Rules restricting the legislature's role assured that real power would remain with President Liamine Zeroual and his backers in the army high command. As a result, no end is in sight to Algeria's civil war, which has killed at least 60,000 people in the five years since the army canceled previous elections in order to prevent victory by a fundamentalist party, the Islamic Salvation Front.
Since then Islamic terrorists have targeted women, intellectuals and foreigners as well as government supporters. But the army's counterterror has been equally savage. To end the war, a serious dialogue must be opened between the army and the now-banned Salvation Front. 
 Algerian authorities are not yet prepared to take that route. Even if they did, the front is by no means certain to accept. Nevertheless, outside powers, especially the United States and France, should pressure the Algerian Government toward dialogue. They can do so by limiting financial support to the Government, and discouraging further investment in its oil-export-based economy until the political crisis ends.
Washington has struck a reasonably good balance between fighting terrorism and encouraging democracy. Paris, with a colonial history in Algeria and continuing close involvement, has not. France has stressed order alone, encouraging the regime's resistance to political compromise. The new French Government should re-examine its policies. By settling for the Algerian Government's approach of unlimited repression coupled with empty elections, France is only delaying serious efforts to resolve the Algerian conflict.

HEADLINE: U.S. Envoy in Congo Offers Aid but Wants Progress on Rights

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Congo, June 6

 BODY:
President Clinton's special envoy to the Congo, Bill Richardson, arrived here this afternoon with a team of United States officials who could pave the way for the investment and economic assistance desperately needed by this country, which was reduced to financial ruin during 30 years of Mobutuism.
But Mr. Richardson had a human rights fist in the financial glove. The level of United States assistance is dependent on the new Government making "more progress on human rights," he said, and in particular, he said, the Congo needs to act decisively to protect tens of thousands of Rwandan Hutu refugees now wandering in its forests. 
 Thousands of the refugees were killed by Tutsi elements in Mr. Kabila's rebel army during the civil war that ended last month, according to numerous reports by United Nations agencies and international relief organizations. Mr. Kabila had himself inaugurated as President last week; his Government has repeatedly denied that there have been any deliberate killings of civilians, and has kept United Nations agencies, reporters and diplomats from carrying out investigations.
There is a serious question about how much control Mr. Kabila has over the ethnic Tutsi elements in his army.
"We want reports of those massacres investigated," said Mr. Richardson, who is the United States representative to the United Nations. "We want those involved in those massacres punished."
Mr. Richardson, who is scheduled to meet with Mr. Kabila on Saturday, said his trip would be a success if he made some "breakthroughs" in these areas.
It appears he will be disappointed.
Virtually the same message was delivered to Mr. Kabila on Thursday by ambassadors and senior diplomats from the European Union, Canada, Japan and the United States. They were representing the so-called Support Group on the Congo, which was put together by the United Nations to help get the Congo, formerly Zaire, back on its feet.
For the outside governments the balance is a delicate one: continuing to criticize Mr. Kabila on the Hutu refugee issue undermines his Government. "If he fails, this country will explode," said a senior European diplomat.
During a meeting that lasted two and a half hours and was devoted to the refugee issue, the diplomats made clear that their countries wanted to help the Congo economically, but that the manner in which the Hutu refugees were treated was a stumbling block.
"It was a friendly atmosphere," said a senior Western diplomat. "But in substance it went nowhere."
Another diplomat summed up the message delivered to Mr. Kabila: "All you have to say is that you have a problem, then we can help you."
But Mr. Kabila does not acknowledge that he has a problem, diplomats said. He says that massacre reports are coming from his enemies, and he insists that the only refugees who have been killed have been those who were engaged in combat against his army.
Indeed, many of the men among the refugees had been soldiers in Rwanda when it was ruled by the Hutu, and they fled to Zaire after the country fell to Tutsi rebels, in the summer of 1994. From those camps, they carried out raids into Rwanda. Last fall, Rwanda retaliated with attacks on the camps, and when the civil war here followed, Mr. Mobutu's forces armed the Hutu refugees.
Tutsi units in Mr. Kabila's rebel army hunted down the Hutu as they fled across Zaire, Western officials say. What may have been the last massacre took place a few days before the rebels' final victory, in Mbandaka, a town on the Congo River. According to accounts by residents and priests, nearly 500 refugees were killed, including women and children.
Witnesses have said the killings were carried out by Tutsi soldiers among the rebels.
On Thursday, the diplomats raised the reports of the massacre at Mbandaka with Mr. Kabila. He said he would investigate, but he said that any killing that was done was not by his soldiers and that he believed that only armed men, not women and children, were the victims.
At the outset of the civil war, in October 1996, units from Rwanda did most of the fighting and Rwandan foot-soldiers and commanders were key to Mr. Kabila's victory.
"Command and control" over many of the Tutsi units is still from Rwanda, a senior Clinton Administration official said last week.
"It appears he is powerless to do anything," he said of Mr. Kabila. This presents a problem for the United States and other nations that are criticizing Mr. Kabila's handling of the Hutu refugee problem. He needs international support to survive, and the criticism weakens him. "If we weaken him, we strengthen his dependence on the Rwandans," said a European diplomat.
Mr. Kabila has taken a few steps that are considered hopeful. This week, he appointed a minister with responsibility for refugees. And he has said that a United Nations inquiry on the reports of massacres will be allowed to carry out its work.
Mr. Richardson welcomed these steps. "But we want to see more," he said.

HEADLINE: When Housing Proposals Collide;
Tenants Fear Rent and Welfare Changes Spell Eviction

SERIES: WELFARE NEIGHBORHOOD: Who Pays the Rent?

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Maria Maldonado and Rosemarie Soto -- mothers, welfare recipients, next-door neighbors -- have watched with apprehension as, one after another, Hasidic families have replaced Latino households in their rent-regulated Brooklyn apartment building at 193 South Ninth Street in the heart of Southside.
In the eternal competition between Hasidim and Latinos for living space in Southside , the women believe the Hasidim have greater financial resources. Thus they suspect that the landlords of 193 South Ninth Street, like many Hasidic building owners, are engineering the turnover in tenants in the name of greater economic stability and cultural self-interest. A steady influx of young white emigres from Manhattan has also fueled fears of displacement, particularly among Latinos in the neighborhood. 
 These concerns, which have been festering for years, have recently heightened wildly in Southside with the imminent prospect of two powerful forces of change. The first is welfare reform, which among other cutbacks will eliminate a subsidy that pays more than half the rent for these women and scores of Southside households. The second is rent deregulation, which could allow landlords to raise the rent on apartments that become vacant, raising fears that tenants will be harassed out of their buildings. The two issues have been discussed in isolation from each other in Albany, but their combined impact is not lost on the people of Southside.
"Sooner or later, one way or another, we will be out," said Ms. Soto, a 32-year-old single mother of two boys who fears that dwindling welfare cash and any increase in rents will prove potent.
The landlord of 193 South Ninth Street, Robert Guttman, one of three brothers who operate the building, said there was no explicit agenda for replacing Latino tenants with Hasidic families, and he discounted the widely held belief that Hasidic families were, as a rule, financially better off. But he also made clear his hostility to Latino tenants, his preference for Hasidic families and his appetite for the opportunity offered by a loosening of rent regulations.
"Look at how they live," said Mr. Guttman, disparaging the Latino tenants of South Ninth Street as drug users and welfare cheats with multiple boyfriends. "They are all having a party. They are comfortable with that life. They don't pay the rent anyway. Like every landlord, I would like to see the rent regulations ended. Any landlord who could get $600 for an apartment he now gets $300 for would do it. If I have to put some people out, why not?"
Thus the ingredients of Southside's unease are manifest inside the old tenement on South Ninth Street. Ms. Maldonado and Ms. Soto can pay their rents of roughly $400 because of a longstanding New York State welfare benefit that provides recipients facing eviction with a supplemental housing subsidy. Gov. George E. Pataki's welfare reform legislation, however, would eliminate that supplemental payment.
Currently, 27,000 welfare households in the city -- apartment holders facing eviction -- receive the supplemental shelter benefit to pay their rents. The supplement is known as the Jiggetts allowance, named after the recipient who successfully sued the city's welfare agency in 1990. Close to 200 of those so-called Jiggetts recipients live in and around Southside.
Mr. Pataki's welfare reform plan could seriously affect their ability to pay rent, particularly if they do not find work soon. The Governor has called for reducing the state's basic welfare grant, which averages $577 a month for a family of three, by 10 percent after 18 months, and by significant increments after that. Further, his plan, through changes in the language of the legislation and the consolidation of the welfare payments into one overall grant, would effectively eliminate the Jiggetts subsidy for those facing eviction.
Simultaneously, state legislators are fighting over rent regulations. The leader of the State Senate has threatened to eliminate the laws limiting rents for roughly one million apartments beginning on June 16. Assembly leaders are pledging to preserve the controls. Governor Pataki has proposed a compromise -- a vacancy decontrol plan that would allow landlords to significantly raise rents on regulated apartments only after the tenants have left.
No one expects complete deregulation to occur. But even minor changes loom large for a neighborhood where small bumps in rent can have great consequences and where there has been a long, angry history of landlord-tenant conflict.
The sense of risk and opportunity, for tenant and landlord, is clear on South Ninth Street, where welfare reform and rent control hang in the air, intertwined and ominous.
"I don't know what exactly the landlord will do if there is no more extra welfare money for rent and there are no more restrictions on what he can charge," said Ms. Soto, who receives a $130 Jiggetts subsidy monthly to pay her $416 rent. "I know, though, I won't be able to afford it."
The world of 193 South Ninth Street, then, illuminates several realities in Southside. Welfare reform, complex and far-reaching, does not unfold in isolation, but rather as only one of a number of forces -- immigration reform, educational decline, rent regulation -- at work on a poor neighborhood.
Southside, too, has realized it is a rare hybrid of a neighborhood: impoverished, short on housing for the existing population, but also extremely appealing to prospective, more financially stable tenants.
The growth of a white artist population, under way for years, has accelerated. The neighborhood's easy access to Manhattan -- the Williamsburg Bridge and a direct subway line to Manhattan -- and its location on the East River make it a draw. Meanwhile, the neighborhood's Hasidim, in search of housing for their growing population, are branching out into the Latino sections of Southside, largely, so far, through the purchase of houses and buildings.
Wiping out or relaxing rent regulations has thus become a more explosive concern in Southside than in other welfare-dependent neighborhoods.
"In Southside, you can put it all together," said Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, the Democrat from Williamsburg who is also chairman of the Assembly's Housing Committee. "It could result in the significant displacement of the Latino population of Southside."
Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate Majority Leader, and Mr. Pataki say they will retain protections for poor tenants. Mostly, though, those pledges amount to supporting the building of affordable housing and toughening punishments for landlords who harass tenants.
The exact number of rent-regulated apartments in Southside is hard to determine. According to the 1996 New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey, two-thirds of the rental apartments in the Greenpoint and Williamsburg sections of Brooklyn are rent-regulated. Mr. Lopez estimated that as many as 5,000 of Southside's roughly 7,000 apartments were rent-regulated.
Interviews with residents and real estate brokers in the neighborhood produce consistent conclusions: rents in unregulated apartments are rising, and quickly, in a neighborhood where a $50-a-month increase can have profound ramifications.
Ken Firpo, a landlord and broker in Southside, said unregulated apartments renting for $625 a year ago were going for $725 now, and $700 apartments were currently being rented for $950.
"The Latino landlords are renting to these college kids and the Hasidim, too," Mr. Firpo said. "And if rent control goes, there will only be more motivation for landlords to buy people out or get them out otherwise. Hey, I have squeezed a few tenants out myself in the past. I could get $650 for apartments renting for $250."
Everyone is aware of what is happening in a neighborhood with a long history of landlord abuses, tenant organizing and fights over public housing. Each Hasidic purchase of a building belonging to Latinos is talked about. Longtime residents can tick off the buildings on Grand Avenue that have become occupied by Manhattan emigres.
Rent strikes are under way on numerous blocks. More than 1,000 Latino residents met at the Commodore Theater on Broadway last month and then marched through the streets of Southside chanting, "Hell, no, we won't go."
Indeed, the city, in an attempt to relieve tensions and increase housing, is on the verge of making a commitment to a multimillion-dollar plan to clear the way for more affordable housing for both the Latinos and Hasidim.
Some who are players in the transformation recognize the awkward dynamic.
"The fears of the Latinos are sensible, not hysterical," said Jennifer Miller, an artist and circus performer who has lived in Southside for 12 years. "Artists, including poor artists, have always been at the forefront of gentrification. It's clearly going on here."
Rabbi David Niederman, a Hasidic leader, said welfare-dependent Hasidic residents would be just as vulnerable as Latinos to the combined effect of welfare reform and rent deregulation.
"I hate when every issue goes the route of having the supposedly wealthy Hasidim set against the Latinos," Rabbi Niederman said. "Don't we all have the same common enemy: being poor?"
For the moment, people like a woman who gave her name only as Arelis Q. wait for the politicians to negotiate the policy questions -- welfare payments for shelter and the extent of the changes in rent regulation. She is a single mother who lives with her two children in a one-bedroom apartment on Union Avenue. There is no lock on the front door. The house tilts so badly that the living room couch is balanced by a two-by-four under one end. She pays $650. Welfare payments cover $286, with relatives making up the difference. Under Mr. Pataki's plan, there will be no government help if she faces eviction.
"Who knows what will happen," she said. "But I don't think the rent will go down."
 
Welfare Neighborhood
The nation's welfare system is being reshaped by an array of new laws and regulations. Since March 10, this series has examined how the changes come together in one Brooklyn neighborhood, Southside in Williamsburg. Other articles have examined fear of change, welfare fraud and the closing of a welfare office.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Maria Maldonado, above, with her son, Miguel Tejada, 10, fears that changes in welfare and rent laws will force them from their apartment in the Southside section of Brooklyn. Hasidic and Latino children play separately in the streets of Southside, left. Their families compete for housing in an area that, while poor, has many attractions. (Photographs by Angel Franco/The New York Times)(pg. 21)

A shelter benefit supplement, known as the Jiggetts allowance, was established after a state court ruled that the standard shelter benefit, which pays a maximum of $286 for a family of three, was not sufficient to pay city rents. HEADLINE: Bonds Stage Biggest Rally In a Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rebounded sharply yesterday in the strongest one-day rally for bonds in a month.
Prices were bolstered by speculation that European monetary union would be delayed and by rumors that the Treasury might eliminate an auction of 10-year notes. 
 Also, those investors who had bet that bond prices would drop in response to the May employment report were forced back into the market in an effort to try to stem their losses when bond prices began to rise. This short-covering rally extended the gains in bonds.
Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Money Watch in New York, said signs of a delay in Europe's push toward a single currency helped bonds because of the potential of foreign investors' rushing into the United States Treasury market.
Talk that the Treasury might eliminate an auction of 10-year notes at a quarterly refunding this year also strengthened prices. Dropping an auction would reduce worries about the market's ability to absorb new supplies of bonds.
A Treasury spokesman said that while he was aware of the market talk, no decision had been made on future 10-year auctions. During the last quarterly refunding, the Treasury's advisory committee did raise the possibility of cutting back the number of auctions of 10-year notes.
The price of a 30-year Treasury bond rose 17/32 , to 983/32 , yesterday. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.77 percent, from 6.88 percent on Thursday. The yield, which had been 6.91 percent a week earlier, is now the lowest since Feb. 26. For bondholders, the day's gains translated into about $12.19 for each $1,000 of bonds held.
Patrick R. Dimick, a Treasury market analyst for UBS Securities, said it was the biggest rally since April 29, when a report showing restrained labor costs dropped the long bond's yield by 13 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
Bond prices fell early yesterday after the Labor Department reported that unemployment had dropped a notch lower in May. The unemployment rate fell one-tenth of a percentage point, to 4.8 percent, the lowest level since November 1973. The department also said that nonfarm jobs rose by 138,000 last month. Analysts had expected an unemployment rate of 5 percent and a gain of 225,000 jobs.
Mr. Palash of MCM Money Watch said the upward revisions in the nonfarm payroll numbers for March and April were more than had been expected, suggesting that there was very little slowdown taking place. However, "with inflation still benign, there is no compelling reason for the Fed to tighten monetary policy at the July 1 and 2 F.O.M.C. meeting," he said, referring to the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets Fed policy.
While the May payroll gain was less than had been expected, the average of April and May was a gain of 231,000 jobs, little different from the 228,000 average in the strong first quarter. "This confirmation could be seen in the decline in the unemployment rate," Mr. Palash said.

HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE DECLINES TO 4.8%, LOWEST SINCE 1973

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate fell further in May to 4.8 percent, its lowest level since 1973, as Americans enjoyed an economy that has lately produced a remarkable combination of low joblessness and low inflation.
President Clinton immediately seized on the Labor Department report today, saying, "America's economy is the strongest it has been in a generation." In the last three years, the unemployment rate has fallen from around 6 percent and the nation has added more than eight million jobs while inflation has averaged 3 percent or less. 
 Even as the unemployment rate fell for the fourth consecutive month, the number of workers on payrolls rose by a relatively moderate 138,000.
The financial markets, which normally react badly to lower unemployment out of fear that it will lead to higher inflation, responded with unexpected strength today. The Dow Jones industrial average soared above 7,400 points for the first time and interest rates fell. [Page 31.]
While other factors contributed to the buoyancy of the markets, it was also a testament to the increasing confidence among investors that the economy was plowing new ground.
"The best of all possible economies just keeps rolling along," Bruce Steinberg, Merrill Lynch's chief economist, wrote in a report to clients this week.
These low unemployment figures have translated into increased job security for Americans and, more slowly, into rising incomes. Last month, hourly earnings climbed 4 cents, bringing the increase over the last 12 months to 3.8 percent.
As a result, analysts said, many workers are exercising new-found confidence to move and look for better jobs.
"There's a real sense of freedom to go look about," said Frederick Breimyer, chief economist at the State Street Bank and Trust in Boston.
Of Americans currently unemployed, 12.2 percent voluntarily quit their latest jobs in the belief they could readily find another. A year ago, only 9.4 percent of the unemployed were in the same category.
With the proportion of the population holding jobs reaching such a high level, the question now is how much stronger the job market can get without pushing pay and inflation up.
While fears remain among economists that such low unemployment will soon push up wages at an accelerating pace, many employers are becoming increasingly creative in finding ways to persuade scarce workers to join their companies. To remain competitive, employers are resisting raising the prices of their products, which also means they are reluctant to offer significantly higher wages. Instead, they are offering benefits like extra vacation time for new recruits.
Today's figures -- the first broad look at the economy's performance for the month -- showed little evidence that the economy was slowing down, as many analysts had predicted based on other recent indicators.
While payrolls expanded by just 138,000, less than expected, this was after the Labor Department made sharp upward revisions for job growth for March and April.
Some investors and traders appeared to interpret today's news as a sign that the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates at its next policy meeting on July 1 and 2, but that was an opinion many economists did not share.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said the Fed would be "concerned" about the steady decline of the jobless rate to 4.8 percent, and the strong payroll growth for March and April that is now much larger than first estimated.
Another Wall Street analyst, Rosanne M. Cahn of Credit Suisse First Boston, said that while the Fed might avoid a July increase, "by August there will be plenty of evidence that the slowdown was temporary."
"People may not be buying cars and clothes, but they're buying boats, jewelry, computers, all kinds of sporting equipment -- and they're traveling abroad like crazy," she said.
One reason employment is rising so sharply when the jobless rate is already low is the still large pool of some 66 million employable people, including students, who are neither working nor seeking work.
Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told Congress today that many of these people were being drawn into the labor force by the buoyant economy. These include retirees who see help-wanted signs in local stores and realize that convenient jobs can be easily obtained, welfare recipients under increasing pressure to find jobs and younger people leaving school.
"The size of the available labor force is not fixed," she declared.
May's payroll expansion was concentrated in health, lodging and other services. Construction also rebounded from a decline of 10,000 in April with the aid of favorable weather, the report showed. Manufacturing, however, lost 5,000 jobs as growth in printing and publishing, chemicals, electronics, industrial machinery and aircraft was offset by declines in food processing, apparel and a strike-affected automotive industry.
The exceptionally large revision lifted payroll growth in April to 323,000, the biggest in 14 months, from 142,000, while March growth was raised to 182,000 from 139,000, the report also showed.
The length of the private-sector workweek was unchanged last month, with factory hours and factory overtime edging down six minutes from recent peaks. The index of aggregate weekly hours climbed four-tenths of a point, to 140, the same level as in February.
According to the department's survey of households, job growth last month was 255,000, enough to trim the jobless rate one-tenth of a point since the labor force expanded by a modest 75,000.
The bulk of the improvement was for adult men, whose unemployment rate dropped to 3.8 percent from 4.2 percent, which was well below the 4.5 percent rate for adult women. As recently as January both men and women had the same jobless rate -- 4.6 percent.
At 12.2 percent of the jobless, the so-called quit rate of people who left their jobs voluntarily was up from 11.2 percent in April and from 9.4 percent in May 1996.
"This is a sign labor is getting new confidence" that could translate into higher wages, said Irwin L. Kellner, an economic consultant on Long Island.
Despite the low level of unemployment, the jobless rate remained at 10.3 percent for blacks and 7.4 percent for Hispanic people. For teen-agers, the rate was 15.6 percent, while 32.6 percent of black male teen-agers in the labor force were without a job.

GRAPHIC: Charts: "Paradise Found?"
Before the 1980's, the economic cycle seemed to be a steady ratchet, as ever-shallower troughs in the unemployment rate spurred ever-higher peaks in inflation and vice versa. But two long expansions since then seem to have broken this link. A generation ago, when the unemployment was last at 4.8 percent, price rises were headed for double digits; this time around, inflation is low and steady. HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL 3-7
 
Germany Puts Scientology Under Surveillance for Year
Germany placed the Scientology movement, which it says is bent on undermining its democratic society, under nationwide surveillance for one year. The organization said it would contest the decision in court. The German authorities seem determined to maintain pressure on Scientologists here and limit their activities. In the past Government surveillance has been largely focused on extremist political groups. 1
 
Croatian Candidate Attacked
The chief rival to President Franjo Tudman in Croatia's presidential elections was punched and whipped with a belt by a man in an army uniform. Vlado Gotovac suffered head injuries and was hospitalized after the attack, which took place during a political rally in Pula. Mr. Gotovac often said his campaign for the June 15 election was futile in the face of opposition by the machinery of state. 6
 
Blair Lectures Socialists
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain brashly counseled European Socialist leaders at a meeting in Sweden to discard "old style" ideas, predicated on more government spending and regulations, "or die." But Lionel Jospin, the Socialist who recently became Prime Minister of France, praised public services and warned against reliance on market forces. Mr. Blair, who British polls show has a record approval rating of 82 percent, went on to tell Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany that the European Union was out of touch with its own people. 6
 
Congress Moves Up China Vote
Republican leaders in Congress rescheduled the annual vote on whether to renew China's trading status, moving it to late June, a month earlier than planned, so that it takes place before the transfer of Hong Kong to Chinese rule on July 1. President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said that a close vote, even if it preserved China's trading status, could weaken the Administration's China policy. 7
 
U.S. Pressures Congo
President Clinton's special envoy to the Congo, Bill Richardson, arrived in Kinshasa and told President Laurent Kabila that American aid for the country was dependent on the new Government's progress on human rights issues, particularly the treatment of tens of thousands of Rwandan Hutu refugees wandering in the eastern part of the country. Mr. Kabila has denied reports that Tutsis among his troops have killed thousands of refugees. 4
 
No Surprises in Algerian Vote
Algeria's parliamentary elections were dominated by the National Democratic Rally, a party created two months ago to represent the interests of President Liamine Zeroual, a retired general, and the military. Opposition parties claimed widespread fraud. Fewer than two-thirds of eligible voters went to the polls; in the capital, Algiers, under half did so, apparently responding to calls for a boycott from the banned Islamic Salvation Front. 3
 
NATIONAL 8-10, 25
 
Defense Lawyers Plead For Sparing McVeigh's Life
A lawyer for Timothy J. McVeigh pleaded with jurors who had convicted him of bombing the Oklahoma City Federal building to avoid being influenced by the emotional impact of the case and to spare him from execution. In the first day of the defense case in the penalty phase of Mr. McVeigh's trial, the lawyer told jurors that the Federal raid on the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex., made Mr. McVeigh think that the Government "had declared war on the American people." 1
 
First Father Gives Address
President Clinton spoke at the graduation of his daughter, Chelsea, from Sidwell Friends School in Washington. He mixed political and familial sentiments. 1
 
Teamster Ally Is Charged
A fund-raiser for Ronald Carey, the teamsters' president, was charged with mail fraud, in what Federal prosecutors said was a scheme to embezzle union money for Mr. Carey's re-election campaign in 1996. The charges are expected to step up pressure on the Federal election monitor to order a new election. 1
 
Appeal to Court on Notes
The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court to order lower court judge to balance the interests of attorney-client privilege and the needs of the Whitewater counsel in deciding whether notes of Hillary Rodham Clinton's conversations with White House lawyers needed to be turned over to investigators. The Justice Department's petition increases the chances that the Court will agree to hear the case and delay the investigation by as much as a year. 10
 
General's Chances Lessen
Senators spoke more critically of Gen. Joseph W. Ralston of the Air Force, whose candidacy to become Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff is threatened because of an adulterous affair he had in the mid-1980's. 9
 
Immigration Law Criticized
A bipartisan Federal advisory panel sharply criticized a new immigration law, saying it did not provide adequate protection for genuine refugees seeking asylum in the United States. 9
 
NEW YORK/REGION 21-24
 
Former Student Sought In Murder of Teacher
Police searched three boroughs for a former student of a murdered Bronx high school teacher, calling him a prime suspect in the slaying. Investigators said they had lifted a fingerprint of the suspect, Corey Arthur, 19, from duct tape that was used to bind the teacher, Jonathan M. Levin, before he was tortured and shot in the head in his Upper West Side apartment last Friday. Mr. Arthur also left a partial message on Mr. Levin's answering machine shortly before a surveillance camera recorded someone using the teacher's bank card to withdraw $800 from an automated teller machine near his apartment, investigators said. Many students at the school where Mr. Levin had taught said they could not believe a former student could be involved in his murder. 1
 
Hospital Contract Is Ended
The city ended Montefiore Medical Center's contract to run Jacobi Medical Center, saying Montefiore's cuts in staff and failure to expand some outpatient services had jeopardized care. Officials said Montefiore flouted the contract almost from the day it was signed. The president of Montefiore denied that his medical center had violated its contract "in any material way." This was the first year that the city tied payments under such contracts to performance. 21
 
Sale Is Near for Helmsley
Leona Helmsley is close to selling her family's real estate company, Helmsley-Spear, to the partners of her late husband, ending a long-standing feud with the two men. 21
 
Shabazz Hearing Delayed
The need for more psychiatric evaluations again delayed a hearing in Family Court at which lawyers from the Westchester County Attorney's Office would lay out allegations against the grandson of Malcolm X, who is accused of setting fire to his grandmother, Betty Shabazz. A lawyer for the boy, Malcolm Shabazz, asked for an independent psychiatric examination. 23
 
Officer Who Was Shot Dies
A police officer died after being in a coma since he was shot last month while driving his car in the Bronx. Investigators said the officer, Brian Fasack, who was off duty at the time, had been the victim of a robbery. But many of the circumstances of his death remain murky. 22
