HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Jobless Rate Falls to 4.8%; Payrolls Rise Moderately
The nation's unemployment rate fell for the fourth straight month in May to 4.8 percent, its lowest level since 1973, as the number of workers on payrolls rose by a relatively moderate 138,000. 
 President Clinton seized on the report, saying, "America's economy is the strongest it has been in a generation." In the last three years, the unemployment rate has fallen from around 6 percent, and the nation has added more than eight million jobs, while inflation has averaged 3 percent or less. [Page 1.]
 
Xerox Buys British Stake
Xerox is finally taking full ownership of Rank Xerox, the London marketing and manufacturing operation it created in 1956 with the Rank Organization. Xerox will pay the Rank Group about $1.5 billion for its 20 percent of Rank Xerox. The deal will also bring Xerox's share of Fuji Xerox to half. [44.]
 
Treasury Issues in Strong Rally
Prices of Treasury securities rebounded in the market's strongest one-day rally in a month. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 17/32 in price, to 983/32 , pushing its yield to its lowest point since Feb. 26, at 6.77 percent, from 6.88 percent on Thursday. Prices were bolstered by speculation that European monetary union would be delayed. [32.]
 
HFS Plans Avis Stock Sale
HFS Inc., which acquired Avis in October, plans to sell 75 percent of a stripped-down Avis Rent-A-Car Inc. in a first-time public stock sale that may raise as much as $250 million. HFS will continue to own the Avis brand name and reservation system. [33.]
 
China Raises Hong Kong Stake
China Telecom said that it would buy 5.5 percent of Hong Kong Telecommunications from Cable and Wireless of Britain for $1.2 billion, raising its stake to 13.2 percent and furthering the Chinese Government's grasp on Hong Kong's basic industries. [34.]
 
Germany Delays Internet Trial
A German court delayed by weeks a trial that could redefine Internet law, that of a left-wing politician accused of aiding guerrilla acts with information linked to her home page. [33.]
 
Teamster Election Is Under a Cloud
The Federal Government said it was charging a campaign official working for Ronald Carey, left, the president of the teamsters' union, with mail fraud. It accused the fund-raiser, Martin Davis, who runs a direct-mail firm, of scheming to have the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and other groups illegally funnel at least $95,000 to the Carey campaign. The move is expected to step up pressure on the Federal election monitor to vacate the election and order a new one. [1.]
 
City Ends Montefiore Contract
New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation terminated Montefiore Medical Center's three-year contract, $113 million to run Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx, saying Montefiore jeopardized care by cutting back on staff and failing to expand some outpatient services. [21.]
 
Sale Near for Helmsley-Spear
Leona Helmsley, who has been battling the partners of her late husband, Harry B. Helmsley, over a real estate empire that stretches from modest garment district buildings to the Empire State Building, is close to selling the real estate company. [21.]

HEADLINE: China's Trade Status Remains 'Open Question' as Vote Nears

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
With animosity toward China growing on the right and left in Congress, President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said yesterday that it remained "an open question" whether Congress would vote to revoke China's normal trading status.
Mr. Berger spoke as the Republican leadership in the House rescheduled this year's vote on the trading status for late June, a month earlier than expected, to assure a vote before the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule on July 1. 
 Mr. Berger said that even a close vote that preserved China's status could prove "corrosive," undercutting the Administration's efforts to deal with China's leaders on a variety of issues, from the environment to the spread of weapons.
"It is difficult for us to move this relationship to a new level where we have a greater chance of solving problems if we don't have a national consensus behind the policy," Mr. Berger said in an interview in his office at the White House.
The trade arrangement is called "most favored nation" status, although it is the normal trading arrangement accorded most countries by the United States. China's status is currently subject to yearly review, and advocates of renewal this year have been concerned that any problem in the handover of Hong Kong, especially televised protests that could provoke police reaction, could jeopardize passage.
One Republican aide said yesterday that the vote was being moved up to deny opponents the opportunity to rally support. That suggested confidence that the House will preserve the status but concern that opposition could be stronger than it has been in recent years.
In a speech delivered in New York at the Council on Foreign Relations, Mr. Berger said that the fight to revoke China's status was the "one development" that could undercut American policy toward China and "do grievous injury to the interests of the United States."
In his speech, Mr. Berger defended the Administration's policy, which seeks to engage China through trade and economic development, while making clear American objections to violations of human rights, among other things. He also said the United States would monitor how China takes control of Hong Kong to insure that its traditions and freedoms thrive, but that punishing China by revoking its trading status would only isolate Hong Kong.
"The goals of the opponents to normal trading relations with China are ones we share -- advocating human rights and religious freedom, promoting fair trade, strengthening regional and global security," he said in his speech. "But the method they have chosen -- destroying our economic relations with China -- is profoundly misguided."
In the interview, Mr. Berger said the Administration was articulating what he called a "clear and coherent" policy toward China as Congress moves toward what is expected to be a pitched fight.
The Administration hoped this year would bring calmer relations with China, culminating in a summit meeting between President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin in the fall. Last year's debate ended quickly, as members in the House voted solidly -- 286 to 141 -- to renew China's status.
But this year the debate has flared, driven by a lack of improvement in China's human rights record, the impending takeover of Hong Kong and the controversy over campaign finance.
Mr. Berger argued that critics of China had chosen the wrong way to register their outrage. He said that the United States had "an arsenal of tools" to punish China, including more targeted sanctions, like those imposed last month on two Chinese companies for helping Iran develop chemical weapons.
As for Hong Kong, he said the United States expected China to abide by the agreement reached with Britain in 1984 to maintain Hong Kong's freedoms under autonomy. The United States would gauge that, he said, by seeing whether elections for a new legislature take place soon, the civil service and judiciary continue to work unmolested, the economy remains open, and freedom of religion, speech and association is maintained.
"Living up to that pledge is as much in China's interest as it is in Hong Kong or in ours," he said in the speech.
"A smooth reversion will promote China's international prestige," he said. "Handled badly, the transition will tarnish China."
He did not, however, specify what steps the United States would take if China at some point in the future violated those standards.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers to Push Futures Investigation

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
The United States Department of Justice will be asked next week by a group of Federal lawmakers to investigate the possible anti-competitive effects of a Chicago Board of Trade proposal to drop two cities that serve as delivery points for the exchange's corn and soybean futures contracts.
Two Democratic Representatives, John Dingell of Michigan and Marcy Kaptur of Ohio, are leading the effort to get a Justice Department investigation of the issue. 
 One of the delivery points that would be dropped by the Board of Trade -- Toledo, Ohio -- is in Ms. Kaptur's district. The other grain delivery point that would be eliminated is St. Louis.
Board of Trade officials were not available for comment on the lawmakers' plan to seek an investigation.
 The rate increase was the first by the bank, the Bank of England, since the new Labor Government last month raised rates and simultaneously removed the Government from future involvement in the decision-making process.

HEADLINE: Dow Adds 130, Putting 1997 Gain Near 1,000 Points

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
In yet another display of the market's seemingly bottomless store of euphoria, stock prices surged again yesterday, lifting most of the major indexes to new records.
Heavy demand for blue-chip stocks and fresh signs that the economy remains robust, but with few signs of inflation, have buoyed a stock market that continues to baffle even seasoned analysts. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average soared 130.49 points, or 1.8 percent, to close at a record 7,435.78 -- leaving the index just 13 points shy of a 1,000-point gain this year.
In fact, in just over five months, the Dow has climbed more than 15 percent, giving investors and Wall Street a great deal to cheer about.
"It's been one heck of a year," said A. Marshall Acuff, a market analyst at Smith Barney. "There were many years in history when people would have been glad to take 15 percent."
The rally yesterday was fueled in part by the bond market, where prices jumped and yields plunged after the Government released data showing that payrolls rose less than had been expected last month, even as the unemployment rate fell to a 23-year low. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.77 percent, its lowest level since late February, from 6.88 percent on Thursday.
Bond prices initially slipped yesterday morning on concerns that the unemployment data would be ominous for debt securities. But bond prices soared later, sending the market to one of its best one-day performances this year, partly because just 138,000 jobs were created last month, down from 323,000 in April.
The financial markets were also buoyed by reports that European monetary union might be delayed, primarily because of weakness in Germany, where new data show a surge in unemployment. The dollar hit its highest level against the German mark in nearly three and a half years -- 1.7423 marks -- before settling back in New York at 1.7258 marks, down from 1.7288 Thursday. The dollar also ended down against the Japanese yen at 114.60, compared with 115.72 on Thursday.
But longer term, analysts said, uncertainty in Europe could create stronger demand for the dollar, which is considered a highly stable currency; in contrast, the foreign-exchange market has grown increasingly skeptical that the planned European currency, the euro, will be strong. All of these factors should mean greater foreign demand for American securities, according to analysts.
While investors viewed the European developments favorably and the payroll data as benign, some analysts said yesterday's rally had less to do with such particular events and more to do with investors' seemingly boundless desire for stocks.
"Confidence is running high, mutual fund inflows are strong and investors want to own stocks," said Joseph V. Battipaglia, chief equity strategist at Gruntal & Company. "That's because the economy is strong enough to yield better-than-expected earnings but not enough for the Fed to raise rates."
Among the indexes setting records yesterday was the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, which rose 14.58 points, to 858.01. The Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks also peaked, up 2.15 points, to 387.14.
It has been that kind of year for the stock market. After two years in which the Dow gained more than 20 percent, few analysts expected stocks to play an encore.
But the market has foiled most bearish soothsayers. Despite a nearly 10 percent drop that ended in mid-April, blue-chip issues have racked up enviable returns. For example, shares of Wal-Mart are up 38 percent for the year; Coca-Cola, 29 percent, and Microsoft, 50 percent.
One reason large-capitalization stocks keep sizzling is that investors, continuing to see the global companies as safe bets, ride the wave of momentum buying out of fear that they will miss out on a big rally.
"There's pressure for performance," said Richard E. Cripps, a market strategist at Legg Mason in Baltimore. "We have more capital that wants to get into the market, and we have few good stock ideas."
Among the strong sectors, financial issues, like banks and brokerage houses, are booming, with the S.& P. financials index up 20 percent this year. And drug stocks are doing even better; the Amex pharmaceuticals index has gained 25 percent.
More impressive, though, are the broad market gains that have taken place in recent weeks. Small- and mid-capitalization stocks are now in growing demand.
Yesterday, advancing issues outnumbered those declining by more than 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange. And program trading, often a sizable factor when the Dow gains more than 100 points, played a smaller role yesterday, according to Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn.
Still, yesterday's performance was dominated by blue-chip issues. Within the Dow, 29 of the average's 30-component stocks rose yesterday, led by Procter & Gamble, up 3, to 136 1/4; Merck up 3, to 92 1/4, and J. P. Morgan, which gained 2 3/4, to 111 1/2.
Yesterday's run-up was the ninth time this year that the Dow has gained more than 100 points in a day. Recently, however, the Dow has been less volatile. For the week, the Dow gained 104.74 points, or 1.4 percent.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index also rose yesterday, climbing 14.79 points, or 1.1 percent, to close at 1,404.84. The index has gained 8.8 percent this year but has lagged behind recently, partly because of Intel's announcement that second-quarter earnings would be disappointing.
Despite the market's spectacular gains this year, many analysts continue to caution investors that a significant slump could lie ahead. The "wolf" is not at the door, Mr. Acuff at Smith Barney said, but that is of little solace to a longtime market watcher.
"The market, to put it mildly, is historically high," he said. "Some people say it's different this time, but I heard that in the 60's."

LENGTH: 1020 words

HEADLINE: Whitman's Borrowing Plan: Criticism May Not Go Away

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 6

 BODY:
When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman unveiled her multibillion-dollar borrowing plan for the state pension system in January, her top aides were stunned by the harsh criticism, even from members of her own party.
The Republican chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee called it a "wacko idea." The president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. called it her latest attempt to rob the public employee pension funds. And Wall Street bond analysts questioned Mrs. Whitman's handling of the state's fiscal affairs. 
 The plan, allowing Governor Whitman to balance her election-year budget by cutting this year's state payment to the pension fund, to $97 million from $687 million, became the most contentious issue that she has faced since taking office. Because it is New Jersey's largest borrowing ever and the first time a state has borrowed so much to reduce pension liabilities, the plan cast a spotlight on the Governor's fiscal policies and tax cuts, which she did not need in an election year.
Democrats joined the criticism, arguing that the borrowing plan was the most vivid example of Mrs. Whitman's efforts to mortgage the future to pay for her tax cuts. To the surprise of pollsters, their criticism appears to have resonated with some voters and contributed to the recent decline in Mrs. Whitman's popularity.
Now that Mrs. Whitman finally won hard-fought legislative approval for the deal late Thursday night, and signed it into law minutes later, her top aides expect to put the issue behind them. They say that voters will forget the acrimonious debate by November, when Mrs. Whitman faces re-election.
But her newly chosen Democratic opponent thinks otherwise. State Senator James E. McGreevey said in an interview after Tuesday's Democratic primary that he intended to make the borrowing one of three major issues in the race, along with high property taxes and auto insurance rates.
The two Democrats who lost the primary election to Mr. McGreevey, Representative Robert E. Andrews and Michael Murphy, vowed to support him today and to use the pension borrowing as an issue. "The Governor signed a bill today, and she also signed a death warrant for the Republican Party with this pension bond bill," Mr. Murphy said at a party unity lunch yesterday. "New Jersey will remember in November."
Although it remains to be seen whether Mr. McGreevey can take a complicated borrowing plan and turn it into a bumper sticker issue, he can count on Democrats in legislative races this year to amplify his message in cities and towns across the state.
Badly punished by the voters for supporting Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase in 1990, Democrats lost control of the Legislature in 1991. This is the first issue that they believe they can use to regain control. They need only six seats to take over the Senate.
"It gives us a very simple, concise message," State Senator Bernard F. Kenny, a Democrat from Hoboken, said. "The Governor had to borrow $2.75 billion to balance her budget."
In the Assembly, the Democratic leader, Joseph V. Doria, predicted that it would have major political fallout in legislative races. "This bond deal is hard to explain and easy to attack," he said. "If the Republican legislators who voted for this massive debt plan don't already know this, they have a cruel lesson to learn in the months to come."
But Senator Gerald Cardinale, a Republican from Cresskill, said he was confident that he would be able to defend the plan. "I'm a fiscal conservative," he said, "and this is a good plan for taxpayers."
Tom Wilson, Mrs. Whitman's campaign manager, also said that he was not worried about Democrats' criticism of the borrowing. "If they want to argue about economics, spending and taxes, we would be happy to have that discussion," he said. "I am very comfortable with the Governor's record, and I think that most voters are, as well."
While it will take Republicans only five months to find out whether the borrowing plan causes them trouble at the polls, it will be years before New Jerseyans know whether the bond issue was a brilliant fiscal move by Mrs. Whitman or her worst mistake.
Mrs. Whitman originally proposed borrowing $3.4 billion, but lowered it after Republican lawmakers objected. Under her revised plan, the state will borrow $2.75 billion to help pay off a $4.2 billion deficit in the state public employee pension system. The deficit was created during the last two decades when the state failed to put enough money aside to cover the cost of some benefits for retirees. That deficit ballooned during the Whitman administration from $800 million in 1994, in part because she lowered the state's payments and extended the payment schedule.
By using $2.75 billion from the borrowing, as well as $1.4 billion from investment gains on money already in the pension system, the state will eliminate the deficit this year.
The Legislature also voted on Thursday night to change the law and allow the state to use at least $2 billion from investment gains this year. State law previously required that the state take only 20 percent of its investment gains each year to help cushion the system from sudden downturns in the stock market.
Mrs. Whitman is also using $590 million in investment gains to lower this year's scheduled payment to the pension funds.
It will cost New Jersey taxpayers $12 billion to $14 billion over the next 35 years to cover the cost of the debt service on the borrowing. Annual payments on the debt service, which do not begin until next year, are less than $150 million for the next few years. Then they steadily climb to $505 million in the years 2021 through 2033.
Mrs. Whitman contends that the state is not creating new debt but is simply paying off existing deficit in a different way. She also argues that the plan will ultimately save taxpayers $45 million because the debt service payment on the bonds over 35 years will replace the state's previous 60-year schedule.
What she does not mention is that she extended the payment schedule on the deficit to 60 years from 40 years in 1994.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 11, 1997, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about criticism of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's borrowing plan for New Jersey's pension system misstated the amount she says the state would save. It is $45 billion, not $45 million.

HEADLINE: Into the Void

BYLINE: By Barbara Ehrenreich; Barbara Ehrenreich's latest book is "Blood Rites: Origins and History of the Passions of War."

 BODY:

AMERICAN NOMAD
 By Steve Erickson.
 256 pp. New York:
 Henry Holt & Company. $25. 
 You can see why Jann Wenner fired Steve Erickson. Assigned to cover the 1996 Presidential campaign for Rolling Stone, Mr. Erickson can't help running off into multipage riffs on such matters as the lives and oeuvres of Frank Sinatra and the obscure, L.A.-obsessed novelist Philip K. Dick. He's a lousy interviewer, tending to hit hard-eyed political operatives like James Carville with huge, soft questions on "the Meaning of America." And instead of chasing the candidates, he sometimes gets chased by them, as in the New Hampshire restaurant where he flees a stampeding crush of cameramen only to find Steve Forbes fleeing right behind him, a sick grin plastered to his face.
But who were you going to send to cover this season of collective ennui, when Americans briefly contemplated the great, unfinished project of democracy only to turn away in horror and self-loathing? Tim Russert, maybe? Even the immortal Hunter Thompson would have had trouble with '96, at least if he still believes you need drugs to induce a state of radical alienation from the content of our communal life. So you pretty much have to send a writer of surreal fiction, the author of novels where the sand dunes are drifting over a post-cataclysm Los Angeles and time is a loop, not a direction, endlessly returning us to the point of maximum loss. At least Mr. Erickson, whose cult following I signed up for after reading his novels "Days Between Stations" and "Tours of the Black Clock" some years ago, knows that there is a question about the meaning of America to ask.
For a while he carries off the pretense of being a more or less normal campaign correspondent. If he isn't exactly having fun yet, as his fellow journalists keep wanting to know, that's because of Mr. Wenner, who comes across as being a bit capricious and egomaniacal even for a national magazine editor. Besides, there is what you might call Mr. Erickson's "impostor syndrome" -- his niggling fear that everyone can tell he's not a real journalist but a representative of "the Enemy," whatever that may be these days.
Fortunately, neither handicap seems to have dimmed his eagle eye for the ambient madness, rage and yearning of the Presidential election season. He understands the cheap redemption white America sought in Colin Powell and how, when another high-profile African-American was acquitted of murder, white America decided to blow off redemption and stick with resentment and guilt. He notices creepy little details, like Steve Forbes's habit of making slashing gestures behind the lectern, where no one can see them, "as though the force of his conviction was something to be obscured and hidden, a secret passion, like renting pornographic videos." At best, Mr. Erickson functions like some high-tech psycho-medical sensing device inserted into the ravaged soul of American politics, observing, for example, of Lamar Alexander that "anyone boring enough that he had to wear a flannel shirt and slap an exclamation point after his name to make himself interesting was either sane to the point of inertia . . . or so metaphysically, bone-chillingly demented as to evoke the Void."
Then Mr. Wenner fires him, and Mr. Erickson becomes in some ways an even better witness to the events of '96 -- a nomad, downsized and adrift, watching the moiling candidates from an ever greater distance as he drives around the country listening to Patti Smith and Kurt Cobain tapes. Sometimes, in this phase, he doesn't seem to be paying enough attention to the campaign. But then, who was? "In a perverse way," he reflects, "I was covering the Presidential campaign perfectly, since it had slipped the moorings of logic as easily as I had." Besides, he was chasing after something a lot bigger -- the great Hegelian Geist that is America and that might be, for all we know, a good-natured Jeffersonian homesteader or a cold-eyed genocidal killer of Indians and Vietnamese. The answer seems to lie not in Chicago or San Diego but in Las Vegas and the radioactive deserts around it; "the American Empire's two most important contributions to the human race," he divines there, "were annihilation and fun."
Mr. Erickson's only failing, at least politically speaking, is that he's such a profoundly conventional guy: vaguely liberal on most issues, but all too ready to buy into such shibboleths as the Deficit and the Balanced Budget. Now maybe the deficit is what's sapping the polity, but if it's really just another bogeyman invented by the national superego, as some perfectly respectable economists argue, then the political process has become a whole lot more surreal than even Mr. Erickson guessed. What could be goofier than a campaign that was ultimately not about anything at all -- except perhaps the potlatch-style competitive raising and spending of huge sums of money? But Steve Erickson establishes one thing in this beautiful, crazed and weirdly patriotic book: Jann Wenner made a big mistake.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 30; Column 4; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1445 words

HEADLINE: CULTURE ZONE;
Taking Out the Trash

BYLINE: By Michiko Kakutani 

 BODY:
If, as the united States Government once believed, you are what you export, then America is in trouble.
During the early years of the cold war, the State Department and the United States Information Agency flooded Europe with demonstrations of America's cultural vitality, as the historian Richard Pells observes in his new book, "Not Like Us." There were concerts by Isaac Stern and Marian Anderson; plays by Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder and Tennessee Williams; performances of Broadway musicals like "My Fair Lady," and appearances by jazz greats like Louis Armstrong, Benny Goodman and Dizzy Gillespie. The export of art was supposed to be a proud advertisement for the American way of life -- for democracy, freedom and the esthetic energy of the New World. 
 Today, with the globalization of American culture, it's clear that we won not only the cold war but also the battle for the world's leisure time. Culture has become one of our most lucrative exports (second only to aerospace technology), and the entire planet now ogles Pamela Anderson Lee, flocks to "Ace Ventura" and grooves to MTV. The problem is that we're now exporting Rambo-esque violence and Disneyesque sentimentality instead of serious art, and we're advertising escapism, consumerism and what Benjamin R. Barber, the author of "Jihad vs. McWorld," calls "the ideology of having fun." Hollywood, Barber writes, "inculcates secularism, passivity, consumerism, vicariousness, impulse buying and an accelerated pace of life, not as a result of its overt themes and explicit story lines but by virtue of what Hollywood is and how its products are consumed." While "stories told to a tribe around the campfire knit people together and reflect a common heritage," he says that Disney movies -- which "weave mythic stories around cartoon identities" -- "seem to celebrate multiculturalism even as they eradicate real difference."
The question isn't why American culture has gone global -- as scholars have told us, this is a simple function of the ascendancy of the English language, America's early mastery of the techniques of mass communication, the growing international demand for audiovisual product and the glossy production values of American entertainment. The question is why we've gone from exporting the best our culture has to offer to the worst.
Once upon a time, it was writers like Hemingway and Poe who were embraced abroad, and film makers like Welles and Ford. Today, it's John Grisham (who has the No. 1 best seller in Britain and Germany) and Richard North Patterson (who's at the top of Australia's list), and auteurs like Sylvester Stallone, Renny Harlin and Chris Columbus.
Certainly the world has given us some lemons: France gave us deconstruction, and Britain gave us "Cats." But the world has also given us many wonderful things: movies by Truffaut, Fellini, Bergman and Kurosawa, and the magical realism of Jorge Luis Borges and Gabriel Garcia Marquez. It has given us Toyotas, Volvos, Armanis, soccer and sushi. In return, we've given the world shopping malls, theme parks, Big Macs, Planet Hollywood, "The Price Is Right" and endless reruns of "Dynasty" and "Dallas."
In 1995, "Seven" was the top-grossing film in Paris; "Die Hard 3" in Hungary and Japan. "The Celestine Prophecy" has become a best seller in Canada, Brazil, Sweden and Denmark, while the memoir of Amy Fisher was a best seller in Holland. Great Britain loves "Babylon 5," Estonia digs "The Dating Game," and Russia watches "Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman" and "Santa Barbara" every night.
Some of America's cultural exports are so awful that you begin to suspect that we're using the rest of the world as a vast toxic waste dump, and charging for the privilege. Even movies and TV shows that fail miserably in the States are often shipped overseas -- with lucrative results. Kevin Costner's infamous "Waterworld" made only $90 million at home but racked up nearly $176 million in foreign sales, and "Striptease" more than doubled its domestic box office abroad.
"Baywatch," that inane cavalcade of cavorting California hunks and babes, was initially canceled after one season on NBC, but it has gone on to be seen by more people on the planet than any other entertainment show in history. It's heard in 15 different languages and seen in some 144 countries, including Iran (where it brings in the top ticket price at illegal satellite-dish screenings) and China. As for Michael Jackson, his tarnished reputation and falling record sales in the States have done little to affect his international status as the King of Pop: although his 1995 album "HIStory" sold only three million copies in America, it sold an estimated nine million abroad. No wonder that his current tour, which has taken him to Asia, Australia and Eastern Europe, included only one scheduled appearance on U.S. soil -- in Hawaii.
In the realm of international commerce, books, movies and TV shows aren't regarded as art or even as entertainment but as commodities, and they're sold on a calculated basis of what will reach the largest of all possible audiences. Increasingly, they're distributed by huge conglomerates like Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, which owns not only 20th Century Fox, Fox Television and Fox Video in the States but also a large share of British Sky Broadcasting and Star TV, an Asian satellite network that reaches three dozen more countries.
Estimates of foreign revenues are now routinely figured into advances given to authors and budgets approved for movies. As production and marketing costs rise and the domestic moviegoing audience remains static, studios have begun to second-guess what will sell in Tokyo, Hamburg and Mexico City, as well as in Topeka and Orlando. The growing tendency to go for the lowest common denominator is accelerated further when it comes to exports. After all, action movies, with minimal subtitles, cross linguistic barriers more easily than dramas built on dialogue and nuance. (Boys with toys travel well, the saying goes.) Flashy visuals and special effects transcend cultural differences more easily than intellectual arguments. Physical humor translates more easily than verbal brilliance. And name-brand stars can "open" a movie globally more easily than a versatile character actor.
Is this why Sylvester Stallone received the Legion of Honor in France? And why Iranians love "Oprah" and "Dynasty"? And why the British are addicted to "The Ricki Lake Show"? One suspects that something more than an appetite for trash is involved, that part of the reason these exports are so popular is that they confirm people's closely held stereotypes about America -- particularly the image of a vulgar, grossly materialistic superpower. The Russians -- whose favorite TV program is "Field of Miracles," a game show modeled on "Wheel of Fortune" -- get to snicker at American capitalism even as they embrace it. The Iranians get to leer at -- and deplore -- American decadence and our obsession with money and sex. And the French, who have famously embraced Jerry Lewis, American comics and American B movies in the past, get to condescendingly praise American energy and rawness and feel culturally superior to us.
In "Not Like Us," Pells notes that Jean-Paul Sartre complimented American writers like Hemingway for "their stylistic restraint, their focus on physical action and their refusal to scrutinize or speculate" -- implying "that American writers would be well to leave the deep thoughts and avant-garde experiments to the French or the Germans."
For foreign countries, the dangers of America's growing export of cultural junk is obvious: it poses a threat to their indigenous cultures, values and economies. The danger for America is more insidious: the ratification of our global role not only as cultural imperialists but also as cultural imperialists with bad taste, and the development of what can only be called a boomerang effect. In a kind of self-fulfilling prophecy, more and more dumbed-down blockbusters are made in anticipation of what we think foreign markets want, and then foisted upon the world and Americans alike, making us victims, too, of our own patronizing export scheme.
As one former studio head told Entertainment Weekly: "It's less risky to make an $80 million Event Movie, because you can sell it globally and merchandise it With consumer products. You're better off making two or three $80 million movies than 15 movies for $20 million."
This, then, may be the payback that America suffers for using the rest of the world as a garbage dump: we become more mired ourselves in the trash that we so cynically produce.

HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: Dr. Fawaz A. Gerges;
Considering Iran Under Moderate Rule

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
THE recent election of a man considered a moderate as president of Iran has many political observers, including President Clinton, wondering and hoping that relations between the United States and Iran can be normalized for the first time in almost 20 years.
But Dr. Fawaz A. Gerges, a professor at Sarah Lawrence College and an expert on modern history of the Middle East, argues that the West should not expect major changes in Iran. On the other hand, he also rejects soundly the idea espoused by some that the West and the Islamic world are heading for a major confrontation, a so-called clash of civilizations. 
 Born in Lebanon and a naturalized American citizen, Dr. Gerges (pronounced zher-JESS) has written many scholarly articles about the Middle East and given lectures as well, including a recent series at the Reformed Church in Bronxville. His second book, "New Threat From the East? American Foreign Policy Toward Political Islam, From Carter to Clinton," will be published this year by Cambridge University Press. Dr. Gerges has taught at Sarah Lawrence for three years, where he holds the Christian A. Johnson Endeavor Chair in International Affairs and Middle Eastern Studies. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with him:
Q. What do you make of the election of Mohammed Khatami last month as Iran's new president? Will we see major changes in Iran?
A. Basically, the regime in Iran was hoping to have a status quo election. Suddenly, they lost control of the whole thing. It seems to me that there is so much alienation in Iran, in particular, on the part of the youths of Iran. And it's ironic because here you have a revolution that had as its main motive to improve the lives of the poor and the lower class. Yet, alienation runs very deep.
But we should not expect any radical changes. You have to accept the main principles and premises of the revolution to participate in the political process. Iran has what I call a relatively democratic process.
You can participate as long as you accept the main parameters of what the Islamic Revolution is all about. So in this particular sense, I don't think we should expect any radical changes. And the president does not have the ultimate say, in the sense of a British prime minister. The power resides in the hands of the ayatollah. I think we should not expect any changes there. Change has to come from the bottom up, not from the top down.
Q. Why are the young so alienated in Iran?
A. There is a generation that does not have much background about the shah. This generation is very alienated, and this particular generation wants to have freedom. This generation does not have as many opportunities as earlier generations. The clergy came on the promise that they really wanted to create a moral society. We hear now of great scandals and corruption. We hear of torture and killings and imprisoning youths. There is much dissatisfaction in Iran, and this dissatisfaction is related to the emergence of the youths, who are economically and politically marginalized and do not have the same strong feelings about the shah as the revolutionaries.
It has been 17, 18 years. Let's be frank about it. Most Iranians had expected the cleric regime to bring about some radical changes. There are no changes. In terms of economic statistics, the economic situation has deteriorated under the clergy regime in Iran. On every single scale. At the end of the day, they have to put bread on the table.
Q. You have disagreed with the clash of civilization hypothesis about the West and the Middle East. Would you define the hypothesis?
A. In an essay in "Foreign Affairs" in the summer of 1993, Prof. Samuel Huntington of Harvard argued that the fundamental conflict in this new world would not be primarily ideological or economic any longer, that the great division among human kind and the dominating source of conflict would be cultural. The clash of civilizations would dominate global politics. He argued further that the most important conflicts would take place along cultural lines separating the West from non-Western civilizations, particularly the clash between Islam and the West. This particular argument I would relate to the end of the Cold War and the collapse of the Soviet Union in that this idea of the march of Islam has gained currency in the West only after those events.
For some scholars and politicians, Islam has replaced the red menace as the new principal strategic threat to Western civilization. Professor Huntington made some of the most stimulating arguments in this area.
Q. What are your reasons for disagreeing?
A. My argument is that Islam is one of the most fragmented and splintered religions of the world. The notion of a unitary Islam is very misleading because of the multiplicity of interpretations. For example, when observers discuss Islam, are they speaking of the conservative Islam of Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Pakistan, or the revolutionary Islam practiced in Iran and Sudan? One of the major reasons behind the dynamism in Islam lies in its ability for constant renewal and adaptation. Unlike other religions, Islam has been interpreted and is interpreted continuously to meet and adjust to new conditions.
This is what the whole notion of the clash of civilizations neglects to mention, that it takes for granted that the Muslim world is united. I would argue that the clash of civilizations hypotheses is ahistorical because Islam is not monolithic. The idea of a timeless unitary threat exists in the imagination of some scholars.
Paradoxically, the idea of Islam on the march is propagated by a strange combination of rival political camps. The idea is propagated by some eastern regimes such as Egypt, Algeria and Israel, who are under assault by a vigorous Islamic opposition. It's also propagated by some elements in the West who want to turn the Eastern world into another enemy. And finally, it's propagated by some Islamic militants who resent the West's influence and advocate a confrontation with them.
The militants that really advocate a confrontation with the West represent a tiny fraction within the Muslim world. Unfortunately, this tiny minority is very vocal and dedicated and makes its voice heard by a variety of means, including violence. It's worth noting, by the way, that the overwhelming majority of Muslims live outside the Middle East. There are more Muslims living in Indonesia than there are throughout the Arab lands -- yet hardly any attention is given to the relatively democratic Malaysia, Pakistan and Jordan.
Q. What about Iraq? Can we expect any changes there?
A. The situation in Iraq is truly very complex. The American embargo -- the complete embargo -- I would argue has really consolidated the regime of Saddam Hussein. Many of Iraq's people have come to believe that America really is trying to punish the Iraqi people. Instead of blaming Saddam Hussein for his bloody actions and blunders, now they blame the United States. As you know, Iraq has one of the bloodiest security forces in the world. Dozens of coup d'etats have been attempted in Iraq since 1990-91. The question is, Will one succeed? Surely, the situation on a human level is very desperate in Iraq. Tens of thousands of children have died as a result of the embargo. There is famine, suffering on a large scale. All of those factors have contributed, unfortunately, to the consolidation of the Iraqi regime. When people are starved, they don't have time or energy for politics.
Q. How have you as a Lebanese-American been treated?
A. I think I am one of the fortunate few who has never personally encountered discrimination. But we know discrimination is widespread. After the Oklahoma bombing, more than 200 attacks took place against Arabs and Muslims after people and newspapers speculated about terrorists from the Mideast being responsible. In the minds of many Westerners, Islam has become synonymous with terrorists. The evidence supplied by the F.B.I. and the State Department paints a different picture. Take 1993, when radicals with Muslim backgrounds bombed the World Trade Center. According to the F.B.I., the bombing of the World Trade Center, as reprehensible as it was, was the only violent act committed domestically by people from Muslim backgrounds for that year. The F.B.I. and the State Department reported 72 attacks by Puerto Ricans, 23 attacks by left-wing groups, 16 by Jewish groups and one attack by an anti-Castro group.

HEADLINE: Stamford as a Factory Town, Making Locks, Trading Bonds

BYLINE: By BESS LIEBENSON 

 BODY:
A CITY'S progression from factory hub to research center to the country's third largest corporate headquarters is the coming-of-age story of Stamford. In its exhibition "Technology, Jobs and an American City" on view through Nov. 9, the Stamford Historical Society charts the city's evolution from past to present and into the future.
It's a tale of how Stamford metamorphosed from a factory city (a period lasting 100 years) to its 40-year reign as research center, to today's corporate culture. 
 "We're calling it from blue collar, to white collar to no collar," said Linda Baulsir, the Historical Society's executive director. "Initially we planned to focus on the technological advances that came out of Stamford's industry. But as our planning committee talked about it, we realized that technology did not occur in a vacuum, that we had to look at the infrastructure and the work force."
The exhibition, two years in the making, spreads through four galleries. Starting with Stamford's industrial development, players are revealed through old photographs, products produced locally, machines, videos and electronics. Voice overs, part of the W.P.A. Writers Project tell of their work life in Stamford.
Life-size figures clothed in the style of the time (created by the Stamford artist Anne Salthouse) punctuate different sections.
Nearly 150 years of Stamford's history is separated into four phases of economic growth: "The Lock Manufacturing Years," "The Research Years," "The Corporate Years" and "The Beyond."
In 1844 Stamford Manufacturing Company converted a 1790's grist mill, to pulverize tropical wood, and went on to become a leading manufacturer and world distributor of natural dyes. By 1900 Yale & Towne, the world's first manufacturer of mass-produced locks and pocketable keys, became the city's largest employer, turning Stamford into an active factory town. The company generated its own power, had its own foundry, provided health care, a company store, housing and an apprentice school. "Almost everyone in Stamford had someone, a relative or friend working for Yale & Towne," Ms. Baulsir said. Then, in 1924, Pitney Bowes invented a postage meter and became the largest supplier of postage meters in the world. Visitors enjoy putting envelopes through a display machine for a souvenir stamping of the exhibit.
Smaller but significant companies are represented by an upright piano, a sewing machine, a typewriter and a bicycle. Other products displayed reflect the influence of Phillips Chemical Company (milk of magnesia), Schick Dry Shaver Inc. (the electric shaver), Globe Slicing machine, Blickensderfer typewriter (whose cylinders are said to have predated I.B.M.'s Selectric by more than 50 years) and Bristol Myers Squibb Company (originally Clairol).
When manufacturers failed during the Depression, leaving behind large buildings that could be adapted, Stamford in the late 1930's redefined itself as a research city.
As Yale & Towne downsized, CBS Laboratories moved in to take advantage of the skilled work force. They developed a long player record, color television technology and a video recording system that was the precursor of the V.C.R. Machlett Laboratories, Inc. made night scopes during the Vietnam War and developed x-ray tubes for medical use. And the Perkin-Elmer Corporation developed the spectrophotometer, an instrument to analyze the composition and structure of organic molecules.
"In the Yale & Towne and Pitney Bowes era, we were inventing in the back garage," Ms. Baulsir pointed out, in contrast to "The Beyond" section where a virtual reality video of Swiss Bank, scheduled to open in downtown Stamford this fall, unveils a learning center and football-sized arena for 600 securities traders, part of a 12-acre financial services center.
Another section of the exhibition demonstrates how even quilts, one of the oldest crafts, have joined the computer age.
The Stamford Historical Society, 1508 High Ridge Road, Stamford, is open Tuesday through Sunday from noon to 4 P.M.

LENGTH: 911 words

HEADLINE: OUT OF ORDER;
Where the Elite Meet to Meet

BYLINE: By DAVID BOUCHIER; David Bouchier of Wading River is an essayist and commentator heard regularly on public radio.

 BODY:
CONFERENCES sprout like dandelions in the smooth lawn of summer. Every group in the tristate area, from grocery wholesalers to nuclear physicists, must hold an annual conference between May and September. Those who can't afford to go to northern Italy, or even to San Francisco, come to the wide open spaces of Long Island. At this time of year, you can't enter a hotel, a resort or a popular restaurant anywhere near the ocean without encountering a boistrous group of insurance salesmen or science teachers, over-excited at being away from home and wearing big labels saying things like, "Hi I'm Randy -- vice president for Revolving Door Maintenance."
The origins of the annual conference are lost in history. Students of human deviousness believe that conferences evolved from the universal habit of holding meetings. As everybody knows, meetings are a splendid way of wasting time, avoiding personal responsibility, and above all escaping work. In any large organization, your status depends on the number of meetings you attend. Really important people are in meetings from morning till night, and the people at the bottom do the actual work. 
 Conferences are inflated meetings, where more time can be wasted more efficiently at much greater expense. Nobody is immune to their delights. Academics have refined the art of conferencing to its highest point, dividing their fields into so many disciplines, sub-disciplines and sub-sub-disciplines that the skillful professor can spend virtually the entire year in conferences and never enter a classroom at all. Doctors and lawyers have the most luxurious conferences, in plush resorts in remote countries at the best time of year. In general, the wealthier the group, the farther they must travel from home in order to talk to one another. Small, nonprofit organizations end up holding their conferences in Phoenix in August, when hotel rooms are almost free. On Long Island, fancy conferences happen in the Hamptons, and humbler events are found in hotels just off the expressway. The final degeneration of the conference is the "retreat," held at a local community hall or at the boss's house for a single day. This is an infallible sign that the slush fund has run out, and employees would be well-advised to start scanning the small ads.
The conference flourishes as an institution, not because it is the slightest practical use, but because it offers escape without guilt. We've all read reports of recent research that tells the awful truth about hard-working parents -- namely that they really like to be away from their families. What better excuse to wave goodbye for a few days than a conference far from home? Nobody expects any results from a conference, so you have no performance anxiety. And, unless it happens to be a Baptist convention, nobody will censure your bad behavior. They will be too busy behaving badly themselves. It's like being back in college.
And it is good to spend time with your tribe. If you spend most of your waking hours working, say, on muffler repair or Mayan architecture, your family is sick and tired of hearing about them. Most time at conferences is spent in the intensive discussion of the secrets of the tribe and the rituals of tribal warfare. That's why conference programs are almost incomprehensible to outsiders, with titles like "Managerial Discourse on Quality Circles as an Organizational Innovation" or "The Clinical Use of Spondaic Vulgarisms in the Assessment of Hearing Aids."
The very best thing about conferences is that everybody wears a label, stating their name, their organization and their status. The act of peering at people's labels is often a good introduction. If you've ever wasted time at a party or in the post office, talking to somebody who may not be important and whose name you have forgotten, you will know how valuable this labeling habit is. It should be adopted by society at large. Food products must carry a label proclaiming the ingredients, and surely we social products should not be left behind. How useful it would be in everyday life if we all announced ourselves on our bosoms. When I meet somebody for the first time, I like to know not only their name, but their education, occupation, income level, marital status, politics ideal and actual weight, favorite author, allergies and attitude toward cats. Discovering all this could take hours of conversation. An expanded version of the conference label would make it quick and easy.
Conferencing is not all fun and games, of course. There are the actual meetings, which are invariably as tedious as a weekend locked in a hotel room with Ross Perot. Not all the people who volunteer to speak at conferences are gifted with eloquence, and often not even with the basic ability to articulate words or read a script. A "keynote speaker" is usually engaged for the opining session, who may be a distinguished expert or (if funds are tight) may have been hired from a speakers' bureau at the last minute and composed his or her inspirational thoughts on the L.I.R.R.
Everyone needs and deserves a conference from time to time, especially the poor and the unemployed who don't usually get such treats. It's one of those inalienable rights that comes under the general heading of "the pursuit of happiness": a few nights in a good hotel, free meals, lots of people to talk to and a big label to remind you and everyone else who you are.

HEADLINE: New Owners for the State's Only Zoo

BYLINE: By ROBIN F. DeMATTIA 

 BODY:
THE Beardsley Zoological Gardens in Bridgeport houses 300 animals and attracts more than 200,000 visitors annually from throughout the state and region. But the zoo -- which celebrates its 75th anniversary this year and has recently undergone a change of ownership to the Connecticut Zoological Society from the city -- was once home to 1,000 animals, including circus retirees and unwanted pets, and drew only local visitors.
The history of the zoo begins with well-known Bridgeport resident Phineas T. Barnum who, in the early part of the century, exercised his circus animals along the streets of Bridgeport. When people began to congregate in Beardsley Park to watch camels and zebras stroll by, the Parks Commissioner, Wesley Hayes, started a campaign for a city zoo to be founded in the park; it was 1920. 
 Within the first year 18 exotic birds were donated, including macaws, toucans, canaries, cockatoos, parrots, parakeets, pheasants and peacocks. The animals were a highlight of the 100-acre parkland, which had been donated in 1878 by James W. Beardsley, a wealthy cattle dealer.
By 1927 the Beardsley zoo had acquired exotic animals such as helmeted cassowaries, kangaroos, zebras and a camel donated by the Barnum and Bailey Circus. Then the zoo expanded at such a rate that by 1956 there were more than 1,000 animals in the collection, including vervet monkeys, a Skye's guenon, a Java macaque, a sooty mangabey, spider monkeys, ring-tail lemurs, woodchucks, a coatimundi, porcupines, Galapagos tortoises, spectacled caiman and several other varieties of reptiles. Around this time zoos began to shy away from having "postage-stamp" collections with many types of animals, instead opting to serve as breeding havens for endangered species. The Beardsley zoo adopted this philosophy, and by 1962 had only around 500 animals in its collection. Caring for the animals was a challenge for city workers, who were not trained zookeepers.
"We did everything by hand," recalls John Angelucci of Bridgeport, a retired truck driver for the city who helped at the zoo. "We used to cut our own hay, which we grew on an old farm on Bond Street, and we raised our own vegetables: sugar beets, tomatoes, cabbage." Each day Mr. Angelucci drove to the former Berkshire Bakery to collect truckloads of stale bread and to an A&P supermarket for donations of overripe or damaged fruit and vegetables.
Rich Cannone of Bridgeport, who retired in 1994 after 25 years as a Beardsley zoo keeper, also recalls the manual labor requirements. "We didn't have backhoes or bucketloaders," Mr. Cannone explained. "When we had to put manure on a dump truck, we did it by hand. And we had a lot more animals, and manure, back then."
He said today's zookeepers may have more education, but that "you still need a strong back and a willingness to get down and dirty in the mud" to be a zookeeper. Mr. Cannone recalled working with a dozen bison in an exhibition smaller than the current space that houses two bison. And years ago he had to hold animals himself -- including a leopard -- when cages needed cleaning because the exhibitions didn't have alternative spaces where animals could be safely locked away.
Robert Ramos Sr., of Stratford, who worked at the Beardsley zoo in the 1960's and 1970's, said, "Back then you got your experience on the job." But Mr. Ramos added that the employees "did more crazy stuff." For example, a co-worker used to swim with the seals in their pool. "Everything is more professional now," Mr. Ramos said.
Mr. Ramos said it became more organized when Gregg Dancho, who began volunteering at the Beardsley zoo in 1975, took over. Mr. Dancho began at the zoo as a way to advance his love for animals and earn class credits at Bunnell High School in Stratford. Though he wanted a zoo career, Mr. Dancho says the Beardsley zoo in 1975 "didn't really look like it was going anywhere, and I wanted to go where people really cared about their facility, like the Bronx Zoo."
Instead, he saw the Beardsley zoo's potential and became a full-time zookeeper in 1980 and the zoo's director in 1983. "When I became director I was able to implement some plans and saw the zoo move forward, and I felt better about staying."
The plans included meeting new zoo licensing requirements enacted by the Federal Department of Agriculture in the late 1970's and early 1980's. "There were stringent restrictions that forced a lot of zoos to close," says Phillip Handy, Bridgeport's director of parks and recreation. "They didn't want animals kept on concrete; they wanted them on nonpaved substances that were well drained. The regulations forced you to build new exhibits."
Mr. Handy says the city decided to update the zoo rather than close it. "It had been around a while and was the only zoo in the state, so it was important to maintain that stature."
Using state money, the zoo in 1986 modified the hoofed stock area -- home to bison, white-tail deer and pronghorn antelope. They also converted the former "monkey house" into a South American rain forest in 1992 at a cost of $1 million; the building now showcases monkeys, an ocelot and birds like macaws and scarlet ibis in an open aviary. Mr. Dancho pursued professional accreditation for the Beardsley zoo from the American Zoo and Aquarium Association in 1987. "We worked hard to get it," he said." The zoo, he went on, increased its education programs, reinstated the docent program, and focused on hiring professional staff with college backgrounds.
A year later the Connecticut Zoological Society hired its first full-time employee, Lisa Tryon, who became executive director. There are now six full-time staff members, and the society has trained more than 300 volunteers, who help run events and educate the public during zoo tours and programs. Ms. Tryon developed the Beardsley zoo's first newsletter, color brochures and television commercials.
Perhaps most importantly, the Connecticut Zoological Society's fund-raising efforts contribute to the Beardsley zoo. Last year, the society gave the zoo $504,000 to purchase items such as lab equipment, signage and exotic animal foods ($350 per month for bugs to feed the insectivores, for example.) The city's $608,000 budget for the zoo pays operating expenses.
All this changed at the end of May, however, when five years of negotiations to transfer ownership of the city-owned zoo to the Connecticut Zoological Society were completed. "The city wanted to sell the zoo and totally privatize it to make debt payments," Ms. Tryon explained. "But five years ago the society had only two full-time employees and one part-time employee, and didn't have the capabilities to run the zoo." She says the negotiations have resulted in more of a partnership. "The agreement is quite different than originally proposed. The city will help continue to maintain the zoo, the state will help and the society will manage the zoo with their assistance."
Mr. Dancho says the zoo transfer "won't have much of an impact on the workings of the zoo, but being a private entity will help us get support from private individuals and corporations."
But both Ms. Tryon and Mr. Dancho wish the state would provide more of a commitment to the Beardsley zoo, because it is the state's only zoo and a major tourist attraction.
"A poll by the American Zoo and Aquarium Association proved that more people go to zoos in one year than all sporting events combined," Ms. Tryon said. "It's still a huge, quality family experience. It's part of every child's experience to go to a zoo." She says that Gov. John G. Rowland expressed interest in furthering science education, and that the zoo helps teachers through class visits by more than 50,000 students annually. The zoo's educators and volunteers also visit schoolchildren statewide throughout the year during zoomobile presentations.
Over the next 10 to 20 years, construction should take place for an Asian plateau, Arctic tundra, educational complex with theater and exhibition hall, visitor services like food stands and restrooms, and an administration building.
"We've been focused on North and South American animals for so long it would be nice to set up new exhibit areas," Mr. Dancho explained. "We would like to bring in more endangered species and beautiful animals such as red panda, snow leopard and sun bear."
Mr. Dancho says the zoo could be a key to Bridgeport's revitalization: "When you talk about economic development, education, recreation, family values and quality of life, the zoo fits most of the bills."
 
Summer at the Zoo
Next SUNDAY, from 5 to 7 P.M., the zoo is the site of a children's concert with a Caribbean theme. On JUNE 21 a Summer Solstice Folk Festival takes place from 1 to 9.
More concerts -- JULY 12 with Hugh Blumenfeld and AUG. 23 with the Burns Sisters -- are planned. And not to be forgotten is the TEDDY BEARS PICNIC on AUG. 17.

HEADLINE: Paper Fights To Stay Alive

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA ROWE 

DATELINE: PEEKSKILL

 BODY:
ELEVEN years ago, three reporters combined their ambition with an American Express card and opened a newspaper on South Street here. They did not want to write about grand national plans or state policies. The Peekskill Herald would be a local paper -- as local as news gets -- with coverage of high school sports, mom-and-pop stores and plain folks living around the corner. But weekly coverage of this small, struggling city has buried the paper in debt.
Last month, Kathy Daley, the editor, and Regina Clarkin O'Leary, the publisher, took the unusual step of making their finances public and putting their future in the hands of readers. 
 "Can This Newspaper Be Saved?" they wrote in a headline over a front page editorial on April 10. "For 11 years, since the founding of The Peekskill Herald in 1986, we've told the truth," the editorial said. "Sometimes the truth was difficult to hear. What we are about to say is difficult to write."
They then said that $55,000 was owed to the Internal Revenue Service, New York State and various suppliers, in part because of financial problems with their parent company, Malibu Inc. in Manhattan, and because of uncollected revenue from advertisers. The newspaper is currently severing its ties with Malibu Inc.
If The Herald could not come up with $20,000 immediately, the publisher said, the I.R.S. would shut it down on May 2. "It was really hard to tell the public what we were going through -- we agonized over the decision -- but it's their paper," said Ms. Clarkin O'Leary, a Peekskill native. "We could have closed up, sold off the computers and pretty much paid off our debts. But we didn't want to do that -- creep out in the dark of night. People would be like, 'Where's our newspaper?' "
Within six days of the editorial, The Herald received more than 70 letters and checks from readers totaling $3,100. By the end of the next week, the paper had $8,000, and the I.R.S. extended its shutdown deadline to May 15.
Now, more than a month after their front-page plea, Ms. Clarkin O'Leary and Ms. Daley say they have collected more than $14,600, paid their taxes and are wondering how to thank hundreds of well-wishers they have never met.
Robert J. Kobel, a spokesman for the I.R.S. in Brooklyn, confirmed that all liens against the newspaper have been dropped, stopping any immediate action against it.
"It's the little guys out there, the regular readers, the people whose names we only know from the subscription list," said Ms. Clarkin O'Leary, marveling at the latest pile of cards and checks on her desk. One envelope included a lottery ticket and $50.
With her contribution, Sister Ann Thomas of St. Columbanus School wrote: "It matters to us very dearly if we were ever to lose your newspaper. You certainly will be in our prayers. God bless you."
Not every reader had such good wishes. Paul E. Ustic assailed The Herald for asking for help after supporting higher school taxes.
Others, like Michael J. O'Shaughnessy, criticized the paper's editorial stance, but contributed, nonetheless. "Although your voice is not my voice or that of countless other subscribers, your paper does serve a noble purpose in keeping the residents of Peekskill informed as to what transpires in their town," he wrote to the editor. "Thursdays would not be the same without you."
Residents have also come forward with more than checks. Edward Hartley, who owns a tax arbitration concern in Tarrytown, helped The Herald in negotiations with the I.R.S. Marcia Timonen Figueroa gave a Tupperware party and made $250 for the paper. The Student Council of Peekskill High School organized a car wash and contributed more than $400.
Since founding the paper, Ms. Clarkin O'Leary, 39, and Ms. Daley, 49, have built up a staff of 9 office employees, serving 3,800 readers. They still lack a full-time reporter, so Ms. Daley covers school board meetings after she has written the week's editorials. The production department -- a long table strewn with old papers -- sits outside Ms. Clarkin O'Leary's cluttered office. The two women, who used to deliver the paper themselves, said they each make about $21,000 a year. Rich Zahradnik, one of the original founders, left seven years ago, and is now with CNN.
This is not the first time The Herald has fought for its life. Gannett Suburban Newspapers, which owns most of the dailies in Westchester County, has been luring away advertisers since Day 1. As it has done in other municipalities throughout the county, Gannett bought The Evening Star, the only daily paper in Peekskill, in 1985, moved its offices out of the city and broadened The Star's coverage to include more of Westchester with less local news. "People complained about that a lot," Ms. Clarkin O'Leary said. "People in Peekskill didn't want to read obituaries from all over the place.
"Gannett's move left a perfect niche for The Herald's local focus. Each week, the paper dedicates itself to a different subscriber. On May 1, it was the 'Hometown Newspaper of Betty Teahan.' "
The police report included a complaint from Grand Union that there was a religious group on the premises of the supermarket. Stories focused on the school board race and highlighted a hospital benefit.
"The Herald is really about people and special events that are meaningful to the community," Mayor Frances S. Gibbs said. "The Gannett paper touches the high spots of the news. They're very different. We need them both."
The Mayor's sentiments are echoed statewide. Last year, New York weeklies had a 20 percent increase in circulation, largely because they provided the kind of information -- garbage pickup days, local school and crime reports -- that readers could not get elsewhere, said Michelle Rea, executive director of the New York Press Association.
Despite The Herald's loyal readership, money has always been tight. Last month, local businesses owed $20,000 in unpaid advertisements. About half have paid since then, some adding donations.
At the same time, the Peekskill-Cortlandt Chamber of Commerce is urging its members to increase their advertising in an effort to help both the paper and Peekskill's economy.
"People do read The Herald," William J. Powers, executive director of the Chamber of Commerce, said. "People do go into the stores after reading the articles about them. It obviously has a direct economic impact on the area."
No matter how much the community may seem to want its own newspaper, Ms. Daley and Ms. Clarkin O'Leary doubt that it can support one over time. They are investigating nonprofit status and group ownership plans.
Meanwhile, Peekskill residents cling to their beleaguered weekly. "Although I have very seldom agreed with editorial positions of The Herald," said one reader, Andy Joppa, "they have provided an invaluable public service in providing a forum for an issues debate. Without them, I think our community is lessened."

HEADLINE: Struggling to Turn a Life Around

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
THE story of Laura O'Brien's early life is like the stories of many other women at York Correctional Institution in Niantic. She began her life as a victim of physical and emotional abuse. She said she has nightmares about the way her mother tried to kill her and her sister by suffocating them with her hands or a pillow. Memories of the time her mother stabbed her and the day her mother tied her to a chair and turned on the gas still haunt her.
Ms. O'Brien's father tried to prevent her mother's rages by buying her things. The gifts, bought with fraudulent checks, made her mother happy and eased her daughter's fears. But the bad checks eventually caught up with her father, and he was arrested and served time in jail. While he was away, Ms. O'Brien became the caretaker of the family and again the target of her mother's abuse. She began shopping compulsively and writing fraudulent checks, as her father had done, in order to win her mother's love, she said. 
 Ms. O'Brien's search for security and love drove her into marriage at 18. But her troubles were far from over. Three weeks after the marriage, she went to jail for six months for check fraud. But that failed to cure her.
As she attempted to soothe her feelings of emptiness and loneliness, her addiction to spending money continued. "I bought items to make life easier for my husband and family: a motorcycle, a down payment on a house, vacations and clothing. I was in such a depression I didn't recognize my familiar behavior pattern. It was just like my life as a child," Ms. O'Brien said.
Today, the 28-year-old woman, who has three young children, has served four years of a 10-year sentence for check fraud. She spent a year of that time in maximum security after getting involved in disciplinary problems and attempting to hang herself, she said.
While in prison, Ms. O'Brien found help in turning her life around. She signed up for a new program offered by the prison leading to a license in cosmetology. She and six other women completed the program and passed the state licensing exam.
Ms. O'Brien also became a student aide and assists the cosmetology instructor with purchasing orders and inventory. She plans to present a record of her progress to a judge, who may reduce her sentence.
"This program is a chance for a trade I can rely on to support my family when I'm on the outside," Ms. O'Brien said. She added that her cosmetology teacher, Maryann Hough, has been a role model and a source of strength. "If it wasn't for Ms. Hough, I wouldn't be on the path I am today. She gave me back my self-esteem."
In 1996, 1,088 inmates in the state's 22 prison schools earned high school equivalency diplomas, which represents about a third of the equivalency diplomas awarded statewide.
Six hundred prisoners received certificates in one of 66 vocational programs, and 686 prisoners with special education needs received instruction, according to the state Department of Correction.
About 800 prisoners completed college courses, and 139 earned college credit through the state's community and technical colleges.
It's difficult to predict whether or not Ms. O'Brien's new training and confidence will keep her from returning to prison. There is a saying among women at York that they are not to talk about a woman who has been released, because as soon as her name is mentioned, she will be back.
Inmates speak seriously while in prison about going straight. Many take courses, get job training and drug treatment and attend support groups for prisoners with addictions. But without the support of family and friends in the community and help in finding housing and a job, the easiest road to take is the one that leads back to jail, said the Rev. Laurie Etter, the Protestant chaplain at York for 18 years.
"It's critically important to have the educational programs," Ms. Etter said. "But an extra step is missing. Greater effort should be put toward resettlement. Too many faces come back again. It's an alarming number. There are women I've known for 18 years who go in and out. As bad as it may be in jail, it's worse on the street. If a woman hasn't gotten in touch with her addiction, she can leave with all the best intentions, but it's much easier to turn back to what she knows, her addiction."
There is a shortage of agencies that work with men and women during their transition from prison to a free society, said Sister Nancy Audette, a member of the Sisters of Mercy and coordinator of the Resettlement Program in Hartford, which puts former prisoners in touch with agencies that assist them in finding housing, employment, education, food, clothing, substance abuse treatment and emotional support.
Prisoners are not required to enroll in a resettlement program, and some think they can make it on their own. But they often end up being taken by bus to a city and dropped off with little more than the clothes they are wearing.
Getting jobs after leaving prison is the toughest part for the women. Success depends on the contacts teachers at York make with people in the community.
Businesses are willing to hire former prisoners if they need their skills, so courses at York should teach as much specific know-how as possible, said the principal of the school, Evva Donn. "We try to bring people in from the community for demonstrations and do as much interview preparation and job skills training as we can."
In addition to cosmetology, women at York are offered nurse's aide training, computer and business courses and classes in culinary arts and restaurant skills.
The prison plans to start training for cleaning jobs in hotels, motels and offices, Ms. Donn said. Women prisoners have missed out over the years on many educational programs available to men, and York is still struggling to get a selection of college courses equal to that offered in the men's prisons, she added.
Once they leave prison, women seldom get emotional support from their families, Ms. Etter said. Relatives may love them, but they are either dysfunctional themselves or tired of being abused by the women. Many women get so sick on the street that they do something that is certain to lead to their arrest again. Then they can go to jail and regain their health for a while. If they stayed out, they would die.
Ms. Etter said she puts women prisoners in contact with churches from their home towns so they have a place to go and people who care about them after they leave prison. "Women who know enough to join a religious community do well," she added.
In the 1960's, Ms. Etter recalled, conditions in prison were better for women. There were fewer women inmates, and more government support was available. A woman could not be released until she had a place to live and plans for obtaining custody of her children and finding employment. Counselors working with inmates took a personal interest in reuniting families.
The emphasis today lies not on rehabilitation but on keeping a community safe and imposing longer sentences. And a large number of women are leaving prison without training.
Private agencies, like the Resettlement Program, are shouldering the responsibility for giving many former prisoners a new start. The program, sponsored by the Connecticut Prison Association, has grown each year since it was started in 1992. In 1995-96, the program assisted 900 men and women. That number is expected to increase to about 1,000 this year, Sister Nancy said.
The staff and volunteers carry an active caseload of between 250 and 300 clients, about a third of whom are in the community. They work with an inmate for about six months while he or she is still in prison and for about six months after release. They help inmates set goals, run support groups and match former prisoners with volunteers who serve as mentors.
The best way to keep a community safe is to encourage a former prisoner not to give up after he or she has a bad day on a new job and make sure they attend addiction recovery meetings, Sister Nancy said. Keeping them from returning to prison benefits the community economically, too, since it costs about $30,000 a year to house a woman prisoner.
"If I could have $1,000 a person for two months to give somebody the solid support system they need to get on their feet and stay out of prison -- and we know it does work -- we'd be saving $29,000 a year for each woman," Sister Nancy said. "We know that in a year's time, only about 10 percent of the people we've worked with go back to prison."
Selena Kilpatrick was jailed many times for check and credit card fraud. Last released in 1989, she runs a home in Groton for women recently out of prison who have H.I.V. The home is supported by the Southeastern Connecticut AIDS Project Inc. and private donations.
Ms. Kilpatrickfound teachers in jail who refused togive up on her, she said. They taught her to think problems through, and she discovered that she knew more than she thought she did. Ms. Kilpatrick uses the electronics and welding skills she learned in prison to restore old lamps. The money she makes from the sale of the lamps goes toward running the home in Groton. Ms. Kilpatrick also works as a home health aide, a private nurse's aide and a phlebotomist (someone who draws blood for tests and other procedures).
"When you first come out of prison, your whole life is spent running here and there getting new identification, a driver's license, a Social Security card and a birth certificate. That can become discouraging," she said.
But the new friends she met at the church she attended hugged her and cheered her on. "They said, 'Get up. It's okay. It'll heal. Let's go,' " Ms. Kilpatrick recalled. "They didn't know who I was. But they didn't care. They opened their homes and arms to me."
Ms. Kilpatrick's story is classic, Ms. Etter said. "The church nagged her until she changed her life. She didn't have a chance. That's what it takes."
