HEADLINE: School Wins Pupil-Improvement Award

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: PEEKSKILL

 BODY:
IT is not only students who earn gold stars for their schoolwork. The Uriah Hill Elementary School here, which Gov. George E. Pataki attended, recently received recognition as a New York State Title I Distinguished Progress school for its success in improving students' performance on standardized reading and mathematics tests.
The state Education Department gave the school the award because its third graders' performance on reading comprehension and mathematics tests has been steadily improving in the last few years. 
 Uriah Hill is one of five Title I schools in the state to receive that designation. A Title I school refers to a school where at least 50 percent of the students qualify for free or reduced-fee lunch programs.
At Uriah Hill, where there are about 270 students in first through fifth grades, 67 percent of the children receive public assistance.
"We reflect Peekskill as a community," said the principal, James Taylor, who spent nine years as principal of the Oakside Elementary School in the district before joining Uriah Hill last September. "We have working-class parents, executive parents and unemployed parents. We're really pleased with this recognition, and we want to maintain the academic success we've had. There were parents who sent thank you notes to us after the award was announced."
Mr. Taylor's pride in his students was obvious as he escorted a visitor through the neat and quiet brick building, its walls decorated with a rain forest mural and other art projects.
Children ran up to hug him and share news about their latest achievements.
In a third-grade classroom, students eagerly shared what they had learned about the famous people they had studied for a biography project, while children in a first-grade classroom sat attentively as a volunteer read them a story.
Some second graders, inspired by a lesson on different versions of the familiar Red Riding Hood fairy tale, were absorbed in writing in their daily journals, while others grappled with math problems or worked on computers.
Members of the State Education Department visited the school in April to evaluate the programs.
Among programs that have improved the students' reading scores are an extended-day program where children work on their reading before school begins, an after-school program to offer children help with homework and provide other activities, the aid of a reading specialist as part of a teaching team and a take-home book program to encourage students to read at home. The school is about to offer a summer program to encourage reading during vacation.
"One of the things we do every day is writing, where the children write their own stories," Janet Robinson, a reading specialist, said.
Mr. Taylor said, "We have a very academic-and kid-oriented staff." He acknowledged the work of Sylvia Fernandez Pade, the former principal who is now at the district's middle school, for helping Uriah Hill achieve statewide recognition. "School should be the best time of the kids' day," he said. "We treat these students as if they were our own children. School has got to be fun and nurturing. That's my philosophy." MERRI ROSENBERG

HEADLINE: A Special Issue: How The World Sees Us -- Power;
Shortsighted

BYLINE: By Grigory Yavlinsky 

DATELINE: RUSSIA

 BODY:
After the failed Communist coup in August 1991, America decided that true democracy had finally come to Russia. But that was far from true, because the old Soviet nomenklatura, including Boris Yeltsin, was still in place.
 The brief period of liberal Government, under Prime Minister Yegor Gaidar, ended in May 1992. When he was replaced some months later by Viktor Chernomyrdin, Russia regressed to a replica of the old Soviet system, with different titles. The bureaucracy, the absence of civil society, the existence of the old Soviet monopolies all created obstacles for people who wanted to live differently or start their own businesses. 
 To the United States, however, it was a new Russia, and its policy toward Russia changed drastically. In the Soviet period, Washington followed a two-pronged approach. While maintaining relations with the Soviet leaders, it communicated with the people directly -- through radio broadcasts and the United States Embassy in Moscow. In the late 1980's, Ambassador Jack Matlock turned the embassy into something like a club, where we could meet, discuss ideas and issues and learn about America.
 That is why Americans had an unlimited credit of trust in Russia in the early 90's; Americans had not confused the Government with the people. But then, suddenly, America seemed to recognize only the Government.
 This simplistic approach to Russia is typical of some American attitudes: there are good guys and bad guys. The good guys had won. Let's move on.
 In the Soviet period, American mass media blasted poor living conditions in Russia. Wages not being paid! Corrupt politicians! It's the Evil Empire! Now nothing seems to arouse American outrage on behalf of the Russian people. Wages not being paid? Corrupt politicians? It's a democracy -- no problem.
 But you can't have a democracy by fiat. More than ever, Russians need to hear about life in a democracy. Yes, in 1991 and 1992 we needed money, and we will be forever grateful to the American taxpayers for their timely help. Today Russia needs intellectual, moral and political support, and that requires a deep understanding of what is going on.
 Russians feel abandoned by America. We cannot understand why, if we have followed all your advice, we still face a profound economic decline. American economic advisers assumed that whatever was good for America had to be good for Russia. Inflation and the budget deficit were serious problems for the United States. Somehow, that became the focus of American advice to us: stabilize inflation, balance your budget and all will be well. But the two countries are completely different.
 The Soviet Union's economy was created by central planning. To create an effective market economy, we have to resolve the problems that America faced and we also have to change the monopolistic structures, implement private-property rights and have real privatization.
 Here are the questions I would like to ask an American economic expert. How did you deal with the robber barons and cartels during the Progressive Era? How did Theodore Roosevelt implement an effective tax system? How did you develop competition? This is what Russia really needs to know.
 Instead, we were told to stabilize inflation. And then, of course, "re-elect Yeltsin." So what happened? Russia re-elected Yeltsin and the West expanded NATO. What message does that send? Few Russians think that NATO is being expanded because you want to attack us. But it is a sign that you do not believe that Russia will become a democracy in the near future. You are expanding NATO because 100,000 people were killed in Chechnya, because we have an unpredictable leadership, because we have corruption, because there are enormous failures in economic reform.
 You should say so openly. I know that an enormous investment of time and money has been spent by the government, by the private sector, by foundations and universities in promoting the myth that Russia has achieved democracy. It would take great courage to admit that the taxpayers' money was wasted. But it is always better to be honest.
 Russians used to rely on America for the truth, for validation of their own perceptions of reality in Russia. When President Clinton came to Russia, the Russian people expected to hear something like this: "We Americans understand the difficulties you are facing. America has been through the Depression, has dealt with corruption and crime. Please do not think that corruption and crime are normal attributes of democracy." Instead all they saw was unstinting praise for the Government, which the people no longer trust.
 Reform is possible and reform is necessary. Do not give up on Russia. Tell the truth to us and to yourselves. It is the false political picture of what is going on in Russia that is creating the climate for business failure. American businesspeople are coming here with the notion that they can do business, as if Russia were California, Michigan or Texas. They find instead that they are expected to give bribes. They become frustrated and leave. Or they pay the bribes, which is bad for them and bad for Russia.
 Russian businesspeople are in the same fix. Today, to be successful, a Russian must be a close friend or relative of a high-ranking official. In Boston, a businessperson may not even know the names of the local bureaucrats. That is my dream model for Russians -- that they simply not know who the governor is. Translated from the Russian by Antonina W. Bouis.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Freehold Spurs Revitalization of Its Downtown

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
BY early fall, the transformation of a vacant, once blighted downtown block in Freehold into a mixed-use center is expected to get under way. The project is the latest chapter in the downtown's revitalization and the borough's efforts to retain existing businesses and attract new ones.
As now planned 50,000 square feet of retail and office space is to rise on the site at Mechanic and South Streets. A clutch of rundown buildings once occupied the block, which had become a hangout for drug users and a threat to the continued rebirth of this Monmouth County seat's six-block downtown, which has 325 stores, restaurants and businesses. 
 The project is being developed by the Eagle Group of Trenton in partnership with the borough, which initiated the redevelopment. Freehold declared the property blighted in 1994 and sold $3 million in bonds to buy it. Over the next three years the borough razed the buildings and relocated the residents and merchants who lived and worked there.
It did so, Mayor Michael Wilson said, because the block had become a "cancer that we had to stop from spreading."
The borough took a risk in the short term by acquiring the land, but in the long term it will be repaid from the site's redevelopment, Mayor Wilson said. The project, which most merchants supported, will also be a catalyst for more development in or near the downtown, he added.
Under the redevelopment agreement Freehold is contributing the land and Eagle is building the project. In turn, the borough will receive for 15 years, based on an agreed upon formula, a percentage of the rental stream from the project. It is expected to be completed by March.
Towns across New Jersey, in varying degrees, are stepping up efforts in the continuing campaigns to revive their downtowns, many of which have turned the corner in their battle against shopping malls. And with the state's economy and real estate market improving there seems to be renewed interest from lenders, investors and retailers in older suburban centers, said Donald R. Smartt, president of Downtown Managers, a consulting firm in Verona.
There are 125 downtown revitalization projects under way in the state he said, adding that 35 municipalities, including Freehold, also have created Special Improvement Districts, known as SIDs.
A 1984 state law lets communities set up districts in which property owners tax themselves to pay for improvements as well as services, including marketing, to spur business. But, Mr. Smartt said, "there are no magic bullets to revive downtowns." The key, he added, is to have the involvement of the public and private sectors and a master plan for the downtown that builds upon itself, one success at a time.
FOR Freehold, where a SID has been in place for five years, that meant taking an equity stake in the Mechanic Street project. Other communities are taking different approaches.
Two years ago Morristown, the Morris County seat, set up a mile-and-a-half-wide SID centered on Route 124 and running for two miles from Washington to Madison Street. Since then 60 to 70 new businesses have moved into the district for a total of 1,340, said Michael Fabrizio, executive director of the Morristown Partnership, which manages the SID.
Now, the partnership's main goal is finding tenants for an empty 130,000-square-foot former Macy's and four neighboring vacant stores, all facing the town's historic green, which is at the core of the SID.
A deal to redevelop the former Macy's building for up to four retailers is to close this summer, said Mr. Fabrizio. At the same time, work is to start on a 130-unit rental apartment project not far from the green.
The project supports the town's plan for residential development within its business district. It will rise on part of a downtown parking lot that the developer, the Applied Companies of Hoboken, is expected to lease from the Morristown Parking Authority for 98 years.
In Bound Brook, in Somerset County, the borough sold 13.5 acres of a 48-acre site it owns on Union Avenue (Route 28), a main retail corridor. The borough's reviving downtown, the heart of which has 200 businesses, is spread over six blocks along Main Street and its side streets.
The buyer of the 13.5 acres, at the southeast corner of Tea Street and Union Avenue, is the Advanced Group of Bedminster, which also has an option to buy the rest of the site. It plans to break ground in five weeks for 104,500-square-foot community shopping center, anchored by a 70,000-square-foot ShopRite, the first supermarket in years in the borough. The project is expected to cost more than $8 million.
"It will put land back on the tax roll and draw shoppers to the downtown," Mayor Frank J. Gilly said of the project. Shoppers must drive through the downtown, consisting mostly of arts and specialty shops, to get to the new center, added Mary M. Moody, manager of Historic Bound Brook Main Street Special Improvement District. This, she said, will help the businesses there.
Thomas S. Michnewicz, project manager for the Advanced Group, said his company had moved ahead with the project because of its location and the area's demographics showing that 48,000 households with an average income of $73,611 live within five miles of the site. He said having the borough support also shaved six months off the approval process.
What sets apart the $3.5 million Mechanic Street redevelopment in Freehold is that the borough took the lead, a step it has taken before. In the late 80's the borough spent $4.5 million on a renovation project that included the redevelopment of a promenade at the core of the SID.
In the intervening years it has done additional improvements, mostly to the area's parking lots, and last July it passed an ordinance allowing the Victorian houses in and around the downtown to be converted to bed-and-breakfast lodgings.
Redeveloping Mechanic Street was a necessary gamble "to keep everything healthy," Mayor Wilson said.
For Freehold "to issue bonds in advance of a redevelopment plan, which put it completely at risk, is unusual," said Christiana Foglio, president of Community Investment Strategies, a New Brunswick-based real estate consulting and developing firm that the borough hired to put together the project and market it to private developers.
"We see opportunities in these areas for projects that provide basic services, where the communities are willing to become partners," said Sidney L. Hofing, Eagle's president. As for the Mechanic Street redevelopment, designed as a complex of three Victorian-style buildings, he said the agreement with the borough "is equitable" and the area's demographics support the project. He said 23,731 families with an average income of $73,000 live within two miles of the site.
MONMOUTH COUNTY has leased 21,000 square feet of offices, providing the Mechanic Street project with an anchor tenant. Mr. Hofing would not disclose rents, but he said they would be slightly more than those for existing office and retail space, which is $10 to $12 a square foot, depending on size and location.
Other projects also are taking shape in Freehold. On Main Street, between Court and Sheriff Streets, an investor is converting an 8,000-square-foot building next to a vacant lot created by the razing of two county buildings within the last year. The building, which is expected to be converted by year's end, will house office and retail space and a community theater. Some of the land where the county buildings once stood will be used for parking, said Jane L. Carr, business advocate for the Freehold Center Partnership, which manages the SID.
The borough owns and is marketing for redevelopment a vacant 300,000-square-foot textile mill two blocks away that Bruce Springsteen, a native of Freehold, sang about in his ballad, "My Hometown." The Mayor said it goes like this:
They are closing down the textile mill
Across the railroad tracks.
Foreman says these jobs are going, boys,
And they ain't coming back.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Victoria Bok, DeWitt Clinton Jones 4th

 BODY:
Victoria Bok and DeWitt Clinton Jones 4th, who are specialists in housing and community development in Boston, were married yesterday by Donna L. Wadoski, a notary public, at the Camden Yacht Club in Camden, Me.
Ms. Bok, who is 35 and is keeping her name, is a project associate for the Boston Housing Authority, where she is the Federal community renaissance fellow. She graduated summa cum laude from Yale University and received a master's degree in public policy from Harvard University. 
 The bride is a daughter of Sissela and Derek Bok of Cambridge, Mass. The bride's father is a president emeritus of Harvard and a 300th Anniversary University Professor who teaches in Harvard's schools of education and government. The bride's mother is a distinguished fellow at the Harvard University Center for Population and Development Studies.
The bride is a granddaughter of the late Alva Myrdal, who won a Nobel Peace Prize in 1982, and the late Gunnar Myrdal, who won a Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1974.
Mr. Jones, 40, is the executive director of the Boston Community Loan Fund, which provides loans and investments to nonprofit organizations and businesses that build affordable housing. He is also the president of the board of the Penikese Island (Mass.) School, an institution for troubled boys. He graduated and received a master's degree in city and regional planning from Harvard. The bridegroom was a widower.
He is a son of Megan and DeWitt C. Jones 3d of Falmouth, Mass. The bridegroom's mother is an associate at the Center for Science and International Affairs at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government and is a former director of the Massachusetts Centers of Excellence Corporation, an agency that supported technology development in Boston. His father, who is retired, was an administrator and a mathematics teacher at Falmouth High School.
The bridegroom is a descendant of De Witt Clinton, who was a Governor of New York and a Mayor of New York City.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Boating Slips;
Marinas in Southern California Battle Landlords

BYLINE: By KEVIN BRASS 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
AS the demand for boating slips declines, Southern California marina operators are locked in a rent struggle with their landlords, the local government agencies owning tidelands and bayfronts.
H. P. Purdon, owner of the Shelter Cove Marina on San Diego Bay, is facing a possible rent increase, even though, he says, his slips are typically at least 15 percent empty. The San Diego Unified Port District, which controls San Diego Bay, is now having all of its marina properties appraised. 
 "They're always pushing for rent," Mr. Purdon said. "One of their mantras is to increase their revenue."
The dispute underscores the complexities of the relationship between the marina owners and the local governments from which they lease the land, and the permission to float docks and boat slips, on which their businesses depend. Government agencies like the San Diego Port District typically lease out tidelands and bayfront property to private companies, which build and operate the marinas.
As landlords, the government agencies say they are charged with maximizing the return on the property for taxpayers. "We're not out to raise rents, we're out to determine what the fair market rent should be," said Thomas Morgan, senior director of real estate operations for the San Diego Unified Port District.
Leases for marina sites, typically for 40 years, call for marina operators to pay between 15 to 25 percent of their annual gross revenue to the controlling government agency. Most leases allow for periodic reviews of lease rates.
In Marina del Rey, a popular boating center a few miles south of downtown Los Angeles, the Los Angeles County Department of Beaches and Harbors is "actively renegotiating" marina leases, according to Dennis Heitmann, chief property manager for the agency.
In some cases, the county is moving to return the rents to 25 percent of the marinas' annual gross. . Many rents were lowered a few years ago, in response to cries for help from marina owners. Current levels range from 16 to 22.5 percent.
"None of our appraisals have called for a lower rent amount," Mr. Heitmann said.
Other agencies are taking similar steps, even though marina owners complain that their industry is in the midst of a severe depression. Vacancy rates are "a fairly compelling argument that the economy is not great and the marinas can't afford" the rent increases, said Richard Cloward, executive director of the San Diego Port Tenants Association.
As recently as 1990, there were long waiting lists for boat slips in most Southern California marinas. But the market went through a complete turnaround, industry analysts say. A change in recreational habits, a downturn in the economy and imposition of a 10 percent Federal tax in 1990 on boats costing $100,000 or more are among the factors blamed for a dramatic downturn in boat sales. The tax was repealed in 1993.
As golf and other activities grew more popular, total boating industry revenues slid from $17.9 billion in 1988 to about $10.3 billion in 1992, according to the National Marine Manufacturers Association. During the same period, the number of "inboard cruisers" -- the large yachts that sell for more than $200,000 and are the boats most coveted by marina operators -- fell 75 percent.
Although the overall boating industry is rebounding, Southern California has been slow to respond. Cuts in the military and aerospace industry changed the demographics of the region. San Diego County alone lost 30,000 military industry jobs from 1991 to 1996.
Along with the jobs, there was a migration of boats out of Southern California. At one point, in 1992, a study by marina operator Almar Ltd. concluded that 42 percent of the used boats sold in California were shipped out of the state. Of the 35,000 slips in Southern California, about 6,000 are currently vacant. Many of the region's marinas report vacancy rates close to 30 percent.
On San Diego Bay, the boat slip vacancy rate is about 25 percent, according to marina owners. "I think a lot of [marina owners] would sell, if they could," said Mr. Purdon.
IN 1989, Mr. Purdon's company bought the 160-slip Shelter Cove Marina, built in 1953, for $3.5 million. The 12,000-square-foot complex, which includes 160 slips, offices, recreation and bathrooms, was renovated in 1993 at a cost of $3 million.
In 1991, when waiting lists were common, Mr. Purdon's company purchased another marina, a 42-slip operation on the peninsula of Coronado for $400,000. The Coronado facility is currently 60 percent vacant, Mr. Purdon said.
"People are just not enamored with boating right now -- it's a lifestyle thing," said Mr. Purdon, who is executive vice president of the Marina Recreation Association, a Sacramento-based trade organization. Construction of new marinas has almost completely ceased in Southern California, Mr. Purdon said. Earlier this year, the San Diego Unified Port District sent out a request for proposals to develop a new marina in National City, on the southern portion of the bay.
Calls to develop marina land are rare, and usually highly coveted. In addition to a 40-year lease on the bayfront land, the Port was offering to dredge the bay. But, with the market in the doldrums, not a single qualified party submitted a proposal, according to Port records.
The National City proposal "just didn't pencil out," said Kevin Mansfield, director of acquisitions and planning for Westrec Marina Management, one of the largest marina operators in the country. Westrec operates more than 40 marinas around the country, but none in California.
Although it actively pursues opportunities in Southern California, in general, "pricing values are greater in other parts of the country," Mr. Mansfield said.
The Port's attempts to build the National City marina angered existing marina owners in San Diego, who say the project would only worsen existing vacancy problems. Port officials hope the marina project will spur redevelopment in the National City area.
Marina owners often find themselves in competition with their landlord government agencies. In San Diego Bay, the Port District operates more than 400 moorings -- anchorages not serviced by docks. For the right to anchor their boats and row to shore, boat owners pay $2 a day, which the marina owners believe undercuts their business.
Just south of Los Angeles, the City of Long Beach operates more than 3,700 slips in two locations. Faced with vacancy rates that hover around 30 percent in its downtown marina, the city is planning to add bathrooms, laundries, security and other amenities to make it more attractive to more overnight boaters.
"It is very competitive between the private and public marinas," said Douglas Parsons, superintendent of operations for the marine bureau of the city's Department of Parks, Recreation and Marinas.
With vacancy rates high, the rents marina owners charge boat owners have been declining, according to Randy Short, chief operating officer for Almar Ltd., which has been in the marina business for 25 years. The marinas charge boat owners from $5 to $18 per foot a month, based on the slip or boat size, whichever is greater. "There has been an active price war in the marina industry since 1992," Mr. Short said
To better compete, Almar, which owns four marina properties in California, plus another in Cabo San Lucas, Mexico, spent $3 million in 1989 to redevelop the docks and other facilities of its San Diego marina property and an additional $4.5 million to refurbish its marina in Ventura, Calif., north of Los Angeles.
"It will be a long, long time before I recover that investment," Mr. Short said.
Some analysts believe the Southern California boating market is set to improve. A 1995 report prepared for the California Department of Boating and Waterways predicted that from 1995 to 2010 the number of boats using marinas and moorings will increase by 76 percent. But marina owners point to figures from the National Marine Manufactures Association showing a decline of 5 percent in boat sales last year, compared with the year before.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 9; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 319 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN -- UPDATE;
Latest Plan Joined by Counterplan in Landmarks Fight at 250 Water St.

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
It's the project that just won't die: For 14 years, Milstein Properties has tried to build on the parking lot it owns at 250 Water Street in the South Street Seaport Historic District. At least a half-dozen designs -- some as tall as 43 stories -- have met with vocal neighborhood opposition. Only one, for a 10-story office building, was approved by the Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1991, and in that case the economy intervened to prevent construction, said an executive vice president of Milstein Properties, James M. Yasser.
But all that may be about to change. 
 For while the latest Milstein proposal, for two apartment towers -- one 14 stories, the other 30, has languished before the commission for a year, the delay may work in its favor, as members who have opposed any high-rise development in the district over many years leave the commission and are replaced by appointees of Mayor Giuliani, who is known to favor development in the area.
Still, while local residents who oppose the plan and local politicians sympathetic to their cause say they suspect that the Milsteins are deliberately dawdling, the opponents have not been idle. They are trying to rally support for a competing low-rise design, for a row of five- and seven-story town houses, put forth by the Seaport Community Coalition, a neighborhood group. Community Board 1 recently endorsed that proposal.
State Senator Martin Connor, Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, the local Assemblyman, recently demanded that the commission review the alternative design and vote on the Milstein proposal by the end of June. But neither a review nor a vote has been scheduled, said the panel's chief of staff, Terri Rosen Deutsch. Mr. Yasser said Milstein executives also have not studied the town house alternative, but he added that they "definitely plan to look at" it. BERNARD STAMLER

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Who's Watching Out For the Shareholders?

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
AS a shareholder in a mutual fund, you expect the fund's directors to look out for your interests, first and foremost. But if the fund company pays a director $100,000, will he still do so? What if he gets a pay package worth $400,000?
A Federal judge recently addressed this issue and concluded that directors who rake in such amounts by sitting on multiple boards for one fund company might no longer be disinterested, independent directors. Essentially, directors who make too much become "house directors" of the firm, the judge said in refusing to dismiss a lawsuit filed by a disgruntled shareholder.
Should his opinion stand, it "would require extraordinary structural changes" in the fund industry, according to the Investment Company Institute, a fund trade group. 
 Just whether the fox is watching the henhouse is a matter of increasing concern. The top industry watchdog, Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, says he is paying close attention to the role of independent directors and whether they adequately look out for shareholders, particularly in regard to fees.
Don Phillips, president of Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking company, said the objectivity of directors has been called into question in recent years. Independent directors are the guardians of the industry, he said, "but there has been more evidence that certain independent directors are acting more in the interest of companies than of shareholders."
Under Federal law, at least 40 percent of a mutual fund's board must be directors who are not employees of the management company or otherwise linked to it. But it is common for directors to serve on more than one board at a fund company and to receive compensation from each fund. The amount of money can really add up, as it did for some directors in the latest lawsuit.
Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the company involved in the litigation, has asked the court for permission to file an immediate appeal or to reconsider a dismissal. The Investment Company Institute has filed a friend of the court brief supporting Scudder.
The case was brought by Robert Strougo, a shareholder of the Brazil fund, a closed-end fund managed by Scudder, after it announced a rights offering. He contends that the fund's directors approved an offering that hurt existing shareholders but led to higher management fees for Scudder. In the suit, which seeks damages from Scudder and the fund's directors, he also contends that the fund's four independent directors served on so many Scudder boards and were so highly compensated that they had become "house" directors.
Judge Robert W. Sweet of Federal District Court in Manhattan let the lawsuit stand in the case of three directors: one who received about $400,000 in deferred and immediate compensation from Scudder in one year, one who received $132,023 and another who made $54,997. It was dismissed in the case of another who made just $13,868 and served on only one Scudder board.
The judge's ruling on May 6 was in response to Scudder's request to dismiss all claims. No trial date has been set on the underlying matter pending decisions on other motions, including the latest request by Scudder, which declined to comment.
The judge wrote that "where, as here, a director's actions are alleged to establish that he or she may be acting in the interests of the adviser, the receipt of substantial remuneration from a fund complex does call into question the director's independence."
At what point pay might be considered excessive is a matter of dispute. Among fund groups with more than $25 billion under management, the median total compensation for a director is $76,250, according to a 1997 trustee compensation survey by Management Practice, a consulting firm specializing in mutual fund governance. Compensation drops to $55,000 for fund groups managing $10 billion to $25 billion and to $28,750 for groups with $5 billion to $10 billion. The figures are based on data from 224 fund groups with 1,130 directors. In all, the industry has about 2,000 directors.
It is worth noting that the range of compensation within these bands is very wide, said Meyrick Payne, senior partner in Management Practice. Perhaps more important, the 120 directors in the 14 biggest fund complexes are by far the most powerful and, presumably, the highest paid.
For example, Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest fund company, retains nine independent trustees who sit on the boards of all its funds. But the practice is common at the biggest fund groups. A survey by the Investment Company Institute found that nearly three-quarters of 190 fund groups reported using the same directors on all their funds' boards in 1994.
"That's a story in itself," Mr. Meyrick said. "Nowhere else among American financial companies is power so concentrated" as at the big fund companies.
In its brief supporting Scudder, the fund trade group said that having independent directors serve on the board of only one fund would be "costly and highly inefficient." And when asked about the practice, Fidelity stated that it believes the judge's opinion is incorrect and undermines the trustee structure used by the majority of the industry.
The Scudder case is not the first time these issues have been raised. When fund companies began adding retirement plans for directors in the early 1990's, industry critics objected, saying that such lucrative payments would affect directors' judgment.
"Directors are supposed to be watchdogs, and if that means voting against management and getting fired, so be it," said Geoff Bobroff, an industry consultant.
Some industry trackers are less concerned about the amount earned by a fund director than how it is awarded. John Rekenthaler, publisher of Morningstar Inc., points out that directors' fees are a small part of investors' expenses in midsize or large funds. What is needed is an economic incentive for directors to work on shareholders' behalf, Mr. Rekenthaler said. "I don't care if directors are well paid, if the fund is delivering shareholder value by performing well at a reasonable cost."

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Sold on the Simple I.R.A.

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
When it comes to retirement plans, some decisions are simple, says T. Rowe Price, the fund company in Baltimore.
Even though Price decided against selling Simple 401(k) retirement plans for businesses, it has proceeded with Simple individual retirement accounts, and the I.R.A. version is selling well, the company said. 
 Both types of accounts -- Simple stands for Savings Incentive Match Plan for Employees -- were permitted under legislation signed last year. The law was intended to encourage small businesses to add pension plans by easing the administrative burden on small employers.
 But after studying both types of plans, Price concluded that a typical company's costs would be higher under the Simple 401(k) plan than under a conventional 401(k) and rejected the concept.
The Simple I.R.A., though, costs less and is easier to administer than a Simple 401(k), Price calculated. Businesses with no more than 100 workers generally can set up either a Simple I.R.A. or a Simple 401(k).
Business owners seem to agree with Price. Several hundred companies have begun Simple retirement plans with Price this year. And more than three-quarters of them did not have a retirement plan previously, Price found.
Furthermore, there is significant awareness of the Simple plans, according to a survey commissioned by Price and conducted in early March by Hollander Cohen & McBride, a market research firm in Towson, Md. The poll, of 179 business owners with 5 to 35 employees, found that 51 percent of the companies with retirement plans were aware of the Simple format, as were one-third of businesses without plans. In all, 22 percent of the companies aware of the new plans said they were considering them.
"This survey suggests that the Simple plans have been well-received by business owners, and over time, the plans may help extend tax-deferred retirement investing to small-business employees," said Jeanette M. LeBlanc, manager of small-business retirement plans at Price.
 
The Money Funds Vs. the Banks
Money market mutual funds have offered a higher-yielding alternative to bank savings accounts for more than 20 years. Now the funds seem to be taking aim at another bank profit center: checking accounts.
Seventy-seven percent of the 670 retail taxable money funds already offer check-writing privileges, as do 81 percent of tax-exempt money funds, according to a survey by the IBC Money Fund Report, a newsletter in Ashland, Mass. But special fees have made many of the funds too expensive to use as substitute checking accounts, cautioned Peter Crane, managing editor of the newsletter.
Only 82 money funds offer unlimited check writing with no minimum on check amounts, the survey found, and many of these come from smaller fund companies. Among the yield leaders, the Strategist Money Market fund offers check writing, for example, but it charges $2 for each check written for less than $100.
"Most of the larger, more well-known money funds have check minimums of $250 to $500, so investors shouldn't cancel their checking accounts just yet," Mr. Crane said. "But we expect some of the larger money-fund players to test the waters in the unlimited checking area in coming months."
Rising bank fees could also help make the money funds more competitive, Mr. Crane said.
 
Index Funds, on Sale
As a flood of money continues into index funds, competition is heating up, which translates into lower costs for investors.
Charles Schwab & Company, which reduced the average annual expenses on its four index funds in February, is shaving even more off now by creating a new series, called Select Shares.
The new shares require a minimum investment of $50,000, but carry very low expenses. The shares in the Schwab S.& P. 500 Select fund charge only 0.19 percent of assets a year -- the same cap recently chosen by the Fidelity Spartan Market Index, which previously had a cap of 0.45 percent. The Fidelity fund has a minimum initial investment of $10,000.
In their expense rates, Schwab and Fidelity have undercut the Vanguard Index 500 fund, which charges 0.20 percent of assets but allows a minimum investment of just $3,000 for most accounts.
For the other funds in Schwab's Select Shares series, expenses on the Schwab 1000 Index will be 0.35 percent of assets; Small Cap Index, 0.38 percent, and the International Index fund, 0.47 percent.
To discourage short-term trading, Schwab assesses an early withdrawal fee of 0.50 percent on shares in the Schwab 1000 and Small Cap Index funds sold within six months of purchase, and 0.75 percent for Schwab International Index.
 
Only the Fee-Only
Investors who are leery of paying commissions have a new tool for finding fee-only financial planners. The National Association of Personal Financial Advisors, in Buffalo Grove, Ill., has created a certification mark, really a fee-only logo, to signify that advisers are compensated solely by their clients. To join, planners pay a $100 application fee and an annual $100 licensing fee. Advisers can apply by calling (800) 366-2732 or by visiting the group's World Wide Web site at www.napfa.org. The group says it has more than 600 members.
 
New Funds
Vista Small Cap Opportunities aims for long-term capital growth by investing primarily in equities of companies with market capitalizations of up to $1 billion. Its co-managers will be Jill Greenwald, co-manager of Vista Small Cap Equity, and Ron Zibelli. The sales charge is 4.75 percent.
 
New Managers
Timothy Ghriskey, the head of value equities at Dreyfus and manager of eight Dreyfus funds, has picked up the Dreyfus Fund from Ernest G. Wiggins Jr., who has left the company. Mr. Wiggins's other position, as director of equity research, has been filled by Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at Dreyfus and the manager of three Dreyfus funds.
Peter Langerman, senior vice president and director of Franklin Mutual Advisers, adds the title of chief operating officer.
Putnam Investments has consolidated its domestic and international equity groups under Tim Ferguson, former overseer of international equities. He picks up the domestic group from Peter Carman, who resigned recently to head the global asset-management business at Citicorp.
 
In Brief
Nicholas-Applegate Capital Management agreed to acquire Credit Lyonnais International Asset Management-Asia, subject to regulatory approval.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS;
A Once-Powerful Association Seeks to Slay New Dragons

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
In one of its landmark battles, the Brooklyn Heights Association helped to slay the mightiest of all New York dragons: Robert Moses.
In 1950, under intense pressure from the politically powerful association, the city's public works czar backed away from a plan to plow through the heart of the neighborhood with an elevated highway. Instead, Brooklyn Heights got a two-tiered, submerged expressway, the Promenade above it and, most importantly, unobstructed views of the lower Manhattan skyline. 
 Forty-seven years later, downtown Brooklyn is undergoing its largest development boom since the 1950's. Whether it is a park or luxury housing, some of it is expected to be built on the Brooklyn Heights waterfront. The organization is girding for battle over what will take shape on the river, as well as other issues.
To lead the way, the 30-member board of the association elected Deirdre A. Carson as its new president on May 13. Ms Carson is an attorney who specializes in zoning and land use issues.
"Deirdre is very much the right person at the right time. Attorneys with land use and planning skills are worth their weight in gold," said Judy Stanton, the association's executive director. "We have to look at what is going to happen over the next decade. We have to make sure that the area stays consistent."
Ms. Carson cited as priorities during her two-year term, creating a Brooklyn Bridge park on five piers, mitigating the impact of the reconstruction of the Brooklyn Queens Expressway, which Heights residents fear will draw more traffic onto their streets, and creating a new conservancy for the Promenade.
Ms. Carson hopes to persuade the Governor to finance the association's 10-year effort to create a Brooklyn Bridge park through the state environmental bond issue.
"The economy is good. The bond money is there," Ms. Carson said. "It's the right time to do it."
In some ways, Ms. Carson represents change for what, at the age of 87, is believed to be the city's oldest neighborhood association. As a 46-year-old woman, she does not fit the stereotype of past presidents -- an older white male. (Ms. Carson is the group's third female president.)
Whether the Brooklyn Heights Association is up to its newest battles remains to be seen. Critics and supporters agree that the association's power has been diluted since the 1960's, which is when the Heights was designated as the city's first historic district. In 1984, for example, the group lost a major court battle in an effort to block the development of Pierrepont Plaza, a 19-story office tower on the edge of the community. But with a $400,000 war chest for potential battles now in place, it remains among the city's most powerful neighborhood associations.
The planning and development issues are not the only items on Ms. Carson's agenda. The association has been criticized as being a club intent on improving the quality of life only in its neighborhood. Ms. Carson said she believed that the criticism is unwarranted.
Leonard Gelstein, a Heights resident who served on the board in the 1970's, said the organization remained too focused on its own priorities. "What they don't pay attention to is the needs of all the population," he said. DAVID ROHDE

GRAPHIC: Chart: "SCORECARD: Battling Builders"
The Brooklyn Heights Association was founded in 1910 and is regarded as the oldest ongoing neighborhood association in the city.
 
WINS
1945 - 1950 - Helped block plan to build the Booklyn Queens Expressway through the neighborhood. The alternative highway route, below street level, led to the creation of the Brooklyn Heights Promenade.
 
1965 - Designated the city's first Historic District.
 
1988 - Stopped plan by the Jehovah's Witnesses to build a residence at the foot of Columbia Heights. The project was built instead on Sand Street.
 
LOSSES
1980 - Fought developer's plan to build a 51-unit, 15-story apartment building on the site of the Hotel Margaret on Columbia Heights. Battle ended in developers favor but building reduced to 11 stories.
 
1980 - 1981 - Failed to keep Burger King restaurant off Montague Street.
 
1984 - Lost court fight to block Pierrepont Plaza office building.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TRIBECA;
Greenwich St. Has Moved Into Fast Lane but Brakes Are On

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
Sixteen years ago, when she first visited Arthur Unterman's studio apartment at the Independence Plaza housing complex on Greenwich Street, Catherine Zehr thought she was at the end of the world. Sand blowing off the barren Battery Park City landfill stung the eyes and gave the neighborhood a Sahara-like feel. Empty lots outnumbered stores and restaurants. Urban renewal had left Greenwich Street 100 feet wide, roomy enough for at least six lanes of traffic, but the street was usually deserted.
After Ms. Zehr, a children's clothing designer, and Mr. Unterman, a lawyer, were married, they stayed at Independence Plaza. But the larger apartment where they live overlooks a very different TriBeCa from the one they first knew. 
 Old buildings are being converted to million-dollar lofts. Well-known restaurants dot the streetcorners, including some, like Nobu and TriBeCa Grill, in which Robert DeNiro, a local resident, is a partner. The TriBeCa Film Center, which Mr. DeNiro also owns, houses offices for film companies. And traffic, lots of it, hurtles down highway-wide Greenwich Street at highway speed.
To slow that traffic, a plan for the "greening" of Greenwich Street first took shape in 1987, when Shearson Lehman Brothers built an office tower between Hubert and North Moore Streets and provided $9.5 million to narrow Greenwich Street and plant trees. John Petrarca, the chairman of Community Board 1's landmarks committee and a member of Friends of Greenwich Street, the nonprofit group overseeing the project, said that at the time, Independence Plaza's owners would not agree to help maintain the "greener" Greenwich Street and that much of the money eventually went to a school now being built in Battery Park City.
The city's Economic Development Corporation recently approved a $2 million proposal that would reduce the number of traffic lanes to two from six. Work was to have started later this month, but Mr. Petrarca said that it has been postponed for at least a year because of engineering problems.
And there is opposition to the plan among some businesses. The TriBeCa Grill's manager, Tracy Nieporent, said he wanted no fewer than three traffic lanes, so as not to discourage his mostly uptown clients from visiting in taxis and limousines. Mr. Nieporent said the community board has not been responsive to his concerns, so he has contacted the Economic Development Corporation and other city agencies in the hope that a compromise can be reached. But Mr. Petrarca's group says the plan is final.
Ms. Zehr and other residents say crossing Greenwich Street has become a harrowing experience. A new narrower street, she said, "can't come soon enough." BERNARD STAMLER

HEADLINE: Why People Get Rich;
Good or Bad, Greed Is Often Beside the Point

BYLINE: By ANDREW HACKER; Andrew Hacker teaches political science at Queens College. His book, "Money: Who Has How Much and Why," is being published this month by Scribner.

 BODY:
GREED connotes coveting, demanding, keeping more than you should rightly have. Hence the negative images of Midas and his insatiable appetite for gold and of Scrooge gloating over the misfortunes of others. But does the charge of avarice apply to charmers like Tiger Woods and Julia Louis-Dreyfuss?
In fact, there's a public ambivalence about the upward flow of money. Americans know the rich are getting richer: The Internal Revenue Service counts four times as many households declaring incomes over $1 million compared with 15 years ago, computed in constant dollars. Yet today the character of Gordon Gekko, the corporate-raiding antihero of the 1987 movie "Wall Street," seems overdrawn. Even those unsettled by the shift in wealth seem hesitant about framing the discussion in moral terms. With the ascendancy of free markets generally accepted around the world, debates focus less on whether greed is good or bad than on specific checks on excess: on when or which superpayments may be deserved.
 
The Pay Minuet
 
 Case in point: "Seinfeld." Ms. Louis-Dreyfuss and Jerry Seinfeld's two other sitcom sidekicks -- Jason Alexander and Michael Richards -- each asked $22 million, or $1 million per episode, for the coming season, and settled for $13 million, or $600,000 per episode. That's $25,000 per sit-minute, more than the starting annual salary of a child-abuse investigator. Greed? Not necessarily. The three knew that NBC (an arm of General Electric) has a booming balance sheet, much of it owing to them. The money was there, so why shouldn't they have their share? Viewed this way, their millions look more like equity. Moreover, even stars cannot count on lengthy careers; today's outsized salaries are tomorrow's retirement checks. And of course a big part of the equation is that Americans like the Seinfeld crew.
The pay minuet involves consenting adults. Jim Carrey has been getting $20 million per movie, and this basketball season Michael Jordan got $300,000 per game. But are actors and athletes overreaching when they accept the highest bid of a studio or team? Thus far the public hasn't been blaming stars for rising ticket prices.
Similarly, Tiger Woods's first $60 million for endorsements came before he won the Masters, and he hardly had to crowbar it out of his benefactors. So here, too, the charge of excess doesn't easily fit. Since Mr. Woods has been seized upon as a national symbol, and looks set to live up to his potential (and has even begun doing so), his rewards are not begrudged.
Star systems also permeate more staid professions. The 1,059 partners in New York's top 10 law firms averaged $1.04 million in 1995. (For all lawyers, the national median is $72,144.) But those lawyers own the firms where they work, and Americans don't usually cavil if proprietors take what they like from the till. Nor can it be charged that they underpay their underlings: associates can get $100,000 while still in their 20's.
Still, the bottom line is that the firms' clients are willing to pay high fees for what they think is the best talent. Charging whatever you can get would become suspect if needed goods or services were kept in short supply. But that situation doesn't apply in the legal profession: the country has 880,000 lawyers, and clients are not bereft of choice.
 
Just Take It
 But what about executive pay? Since 1990, Philip Knight, Nike's chief executive officer, has seen his fortune quadruple, to $5.3 billion from $1.2 billion. The reason may be simply stated: people choose Nike shoes, and investors like the company's stock. So it seems incongruous to charge Mr. Knight with greed just because the money keeps rolling in. Still, part of his billions come from the shoes' being made in Asia at very minimal wages, and fortunes from underpaid labor seldom fare well in public esteem. Mr. Knight would undoubtedly reply that manufacturing overseas makes his products affordable here, which puts critics in the position of wanting to make people pay more for their Air Jordans.
Corporate executives are employees, like most of the rest of us. And like most of us, they can also be fired, as happens from time to time. Still, their relationships with their boards of directors tend to be friendly, especially where pay is concerned. Last year, the median compensation package for chief executive officers at the 100 largest companies was $3.3 million -- the highest it's ever been in corporate history, even with inflation factored in. And the gulf between executives and lower tiers on the payroll has been growing. In fact, C.E.O.'s often receive raises just as their personnel departments are sending out pink slips.
 
Keeping Score
 But opinions on corporate pay are divided. More Americans are buying stocks and mutual funds, or count on invested pensions, so many do not begrudge extra millions to executives who make them money.
Then again, even Forbes magazine has found itself saying of soaring pay: "It Doesn't Make Sense!" Raising eyebrows are some C.E.O.'s who apparently want to see how far they can push their pay envelopes. The $45 million that Michael Eisner has averaged from Disney in recent years is more than 13 times the corporate norm. With stock options and awards of $998 million, Roberto Goizueta of Coca-Cola has made nearly 100 times more than his executive peers make on average.
True, both have done well by their shareholders. But so have many other C.E.O.'s who are not nearly so lavishly paid. And at least a few who could have pushed for that kind of compensation have chosen not to.
Yet greed, if that's what it is, isn't always about money, and this further clouds the issue of whether it's good or bad. Motives for acquisition are varied, starting with the simple joy of winning. Dollars can be a way of keeping score, whether the game is Rupert Murdoch (net worth: $3.2 billion) vs. Ted Turner ($2.1 billion) or how one's paycheck compares with a colleague's down the hall. Media moguls like Mr. Murdoch and Mr. Turner may crave one more network or newspaper chain, the better to set their imprint on the world -- or perhaps to show long-ago schoolmates who ended on top.
 
Glass Houses
 In fact, Americans have fairly settled standards about who deserves how much. Thus they don't like the heads of health maintenance organizations getting hefty bonuses when they will only pay for one-day maternity stays. And past a certain point, people begin to wonder why someone wants even more, and the speculation is not always flattering.
At the same time, it is not clear how far the urge to acquire drives the economy. If anything, the reverse may be true. For many political and economic reasons, the 1990's have surpassed the 1980's in creating opportunities for becoming rich. And those who do, much like the rest of us, see no reason to refuse what comes their way. If that is perceived as greedy, then a lot of people are living in glass houses.

PUB-DATE: June 8, 1997

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3516 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT: For This We Sent You To College?;
Jobs May Be Plentiful, If Not So Glamorous

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

 BODY:
AS sure as the promise of a spring day, millions of proud parents have been descending lately on the nation's campuses, snapping pictures of their daughters and sons collecting college diplomas.
Parents and students alike have been preparing for this moment for decades, before many parents took out second mortgages and the typical graduate piled up $12,300 in debt to help cover bills for tuition, room and board that average $10,000 a year. Now it is time for that steep investment, as much as $130,000 in the case of some elite private schools, to return dividends. 
 There is plenty of good news for those receiving undergraduate degrees this year, but with just enough caveats to keep some people on edge.
Over all, the job market for the 1.2 million graduates this year is the strongest in memory, partly because companies, in their aggressive downsizing drives of recent years, may have laid off too many workers of their parents' generation.
Many Ivy League graduates and those with degrees in highly marketable areas like business administration and computer science can expect plenty of job offers at high pay. And the nation's highest-profile student, Chelsea Clinton, is unlikely to find herself behind a counter waiting on customers when she graduates from Stanford, where she will be a freshman this fall. In contrast, those with weak grades and little patience for job searches may struggle to find work, as they always do.
But just how good is it for the rest of the army that is resolutely marching out of the classrooms and into the real world?
It turns out to be pretty good indeed for a broad swath of the newly minted grads. Many had the luxury of choosing among several job offers months before commencement exercises began. And starting salaries are, for the most part, higher than they were last year.
But even in such upbeat times, the jobs can be far from glamorous. For instance, Rachel D. Gunderson is busy making sure there is enough dirt on the shelves of Target stores. After graduating from the University of Wisconsin, she landed a job ordering potting soil for the chain. Linda C. Roman, of the University of Florida, has signed on at Kraft Foods to improve the packaging for cottage cheese and sour cream.
In fact, many new graduates are fast learning a lesson that their predecessors have had to accept over the decades: they have landed at the bottom of the workaday ladder, with plenty of dues to pay before they step up to the next rung.
And for a growing number of graduates, that ladder isn't even the one that they -- or their long-suffering parents -- originally had in mind. For them, it is not always clear why an expensive education was needed.
"None of my friends ever told me about the car-washing part," said Julie A. Schenk, 22, who turned down two other offers to work as a management trainee at Enterprise Rent-a-Car after graduating in December from the University of Dayton.
Ms. Schenk, whose major was communications management, isn't the only one washing cars -- 5,000 members of the Class of 1997 are expected to sign up with Enterprise, where cleaning is just one of the dues-paying chores.
Others have taken similar training jobs at department store chains, where they wait on customers.
That can leave some parents horrified that their children don't have more to show for all the financial sacrifices.
"It is like sticker shock," said Kevin J. Nutter, the career services director at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. The problem for people in this group isn't that they won't find work, "but that they may not find what they think is good work," Mr. Nutter said.
That is because the number of service-sector jobs has grown as the number of management positions has shrunk, he said. At the same time, so many people are now graduating from college that a degree no longer carries the cachet that it did even a generation ago.
If the experience of recent graduating classes is any guide, many in this year's crop will quickly grow dissatisfied. Members of the Class of 1994 at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, for example, were asked a year after they graduated whether their college training was being put to good use.
"Almost 40 percent considered themselves underemployed," nearly double the percentage of recent years, said David S. Bechtel, director of the university's career services center.
But there is little complaining so far from the new graduates.
"I had a lot of friends who were working for Enterprise, and they all spoke highly of it," said Ms. Schenk, who said she was not disappointed in her job, despite being surprised by some of her duties.
Others who have crossed over to the working world in recent months are also making do or even flourishing.
Following are four tales from the trenches that offer hope and guidance to those just now trading in their diplomas, caps and gowns for briefcases and business suits.

Rental Clerks
Joining a Fraternity With 12-Hour Days
 Few parents who squirrel away money for years to pay college bills picture their children hanging up a hard-won diploma behind a rental car counter, but about 10,000 moms and dads will watch it happen this year.
Indeed, Enterprise Rent-a-Car is probably hiring more members of this year's graduating class than any other company. The 5,000 graduates scheduled to join Enterprise will be paid $22,000 to $30,000, depending on where they live, and all will start out behind the counters of the company's 3,000 branches around the country.
Most graduates who join Enterprise -- along with their parents -- must first get over the idea of working for a car rental company.
"Recruiting is tough," said Andrew C. Taylor, president and chief executive of Enterprise, based in St. Louis. Some of those who accept jobs have a hard time breaking the news to their families. "What do you think their parents' reaction might be?" Mr. Taylor asked.
Still, satisfied Enterprise hires said they found the jobs refreshing because the company is so entrepreneurial, offering responsibility and a chance to move up quickly.
Mr. Taylor's company tends to hire men and women who are a lot like him -- friendly, clean-cut and active at college in fraternities or sororities or team sports. Oh, and they must not be too proud to clean cars from time to time, either.
"The management of this business started behind a rent-a-car counter," Mr. Taylor said, telling how he recently pitched in to vacuum a car during a visit to a busy Enterprise branch.
Consider William D. Lucy, 25, who was a member of Delta Chi and played intramural volleyball and flag football at Southwest Missouri State University in Springfield. He graduated last year with a 3.2 grade-point average, with a major in marketing and a minor in management.
"I did not go to college thinking I wanted to rent cars," Mr. Lucy acknowledged. Instead, "I saw myself going into business."
The affable Mr. Lucy, who likes to grasp your shoulder when he shakes your hand, had several sales jobs to choose from, but Enterprise looked the best to him. Since starting in March in St. Louis, Mr. Lucy has been working 12-hour days, what passes for normal at Enterprise, starting at 7:15 each morning. He pins a gold name tag -- just plain "Bill" -- on his gray suit and greets customers as they walk in the door.
He rents cars during the morning and evening rushes -- including driving to pick up customers at their homes or offices, Enterprise's trademark service touch. In between, he calls body shops on behalf of renters whose cars were crumpled in accidents. When the mechanics take longer than promised, he calls the renters' insurance companies to arrange for extensions of Enterprise rentals. Once a week, Mr. Lucy spends part of the day delivering pizza or doughnuts to mechanics at nearby repair shops and secretaries at local offices, trying to win business for Enterprise with his company's equivalent of taking a client to lunch.
Now, Mr. Lucy sees himself as the businessman he always wanted to be. "I'm wearing a suit every day," he said with a proud smile.
About 25 percent of Enterprise's trainees will grow dissatisfied and leave the company within six months. Most of those who remain will have a chance to apply for a promotion within a year. Those who make the grade get raises, are named assistant managers and have their salaries tied to the performance of their branches.
If Mr. Lucy does well, he could turn out like Cory A. Phillips, 26, a 1992 graduate of Columbia College in Columbia, Mo., who joined Enterprise 14 months ago and has already been promoted twice.
"If you prove yourself, you don't have to worry about spending two years before you become a manager," said Mr. Phillips, now a branch manager in St. Louis. The training means that all managers learn the business from the bottom up and have a financial interest in seeing it succeed, he said.
Mr. Taylor, the chief executive, said he thought of his company "as a confederation of small businesses run by entrepreneurs."
The strategy seems to have worked: Enterprise now has 31,200 domestic employees but just 1,000 at its corporate headquarters, with 700 of those responsible for keeping the company's computer network up and running. The privately held company has grown 25 percent a year for 11 years, and now has the largest fleet in the rental car business. It avoids airport business, concentrating instead on the so-called replacement niche, providing rentals for customers whose cars are being repaired or who just need an extra set of wheels for a while.
Mr. Taylor, a business major who graduated from the University of Denver, was social chairman of his fraternity, Tau Kappa Epsilon. Things haven't changed all that much he said with a smile, in the three decades since he graduated.
"You see," he said, "I'm the social chairman of a very large company."
 
Packaging Developer
Trading the Stage For Live Culture
 Linda C. Roman started her college career as a theater major who made ends meet by working as a waitress. "Every once in a while I see someone on TV I waited tables with," she said.
But Ms. Roman, too, has left waitressing behind for a full-time job in culture -- in "live cultures," that is, the kind that produce sour cream, cottage cheese and chip dips.
After changing her major to chemical engineering, Ms. Roman was offered a job in Glenview, Ill., at Kraft Foods, which is owned by Philip Morris and is the country's largest packaged-food company. She helps develop the packaging for 126 varieties of Kraft products, chief among them Breakstone's sour cream, Light 'n Lively cottage cheese and Kraft creamy onion dip.
Kraft plans to hire 85 new graduates like Ms. Roman this year to help sell more Jell-O, Stove Top Stuffing, Maxwell House coffee, Kool-Aid, Toblerone chocolate bars and Cheez Whiz spread, paying salaries of $21,000 to $42,000. Thousands of similar entry-level jobs will be filled at companies like General Mills, Nabisco and Frito-Lay; Procter & Gamble will hire more than 700.
When Ms. Roman, 31, graduated last August from the University of Florida in Gainesville with a grade-point average of 3.75, she had long since sewn up the job at Kraft; its offer was one of five that came her way. So in the weeks after graduation, she took the time to portray the Wicked Witch in a children's play before moving to the Chicago suburbs last September to begin at Kraft.
There, she works in her cubicle or in a lab, and has so far visited five of the six factories where her sour creams, dips and cottage cheeses are made, making sure the plastic tubs and boxes work properly and helping to develop better packaging for future products. In the lab, she measures and tests the packages, checking, for instance, that when a customer opens a lid, it peels off smoothly and doesn't tear. "I love the consumer end," she said.
She didn't expect to. Ms. Roman recalls her negative reaction when she came upon Kraft at a college recruiting fair. "When I first saw Kraft, I didn't want to work for them," she said. She thought that serious chemical engineers worked for oil and chemical corporations, she said, not a company best known for macaroni and cheese.
Kraft's competitors face similar hurdles. A glossy brochure distributed by Procter & Gamble at recruitment fairs shows young employees standing proudly next to their wares: Metamucil, Sure deodorant and Charmin toilet paper.
Still, one irresistible force lured plenty of candidates to the Kraft recruiting booth on campus. "They had free food," Ms. Roman said with a shrug. After a summer internship in which she helped develop apple-cinammon-flavored cream cheese, she discovered that she liked applying what she learned in the classroom to the real world of supermarket shelves.
Being an actress might be more glamorous, but her father, Kenneth Roman, said he used to worry about her plans to make a living on stage. "Two out of a thousand make it," he said.
Now, Mr. Roman says he feels his daughter has a secure future. "I really had no idea that she would go into engineering," Mr. Roman said. "I feel very proud."
Indeed, his daughter is among those that Kraft found through its college recruitment program. Kraft focuses its recruiting efforts on a short list of large colleges and universities where it previously had success: Ohio State, Wisconsin, Penn State, Purdue, Howard, Florida and Michigan State, along with Illinois and Northwestern -- schools that are relatively near its headquarters in Northfield, Ill.
Kraft weeds out some students in short, on-campus interviews, then brings the rest to Chicago for further screening. Students check into a hotel the night before their interview to find duffel bags full of -- what else? -- Kraft food. With the economy booming, recruiters try to decide quickly whom to hire.
"If you wait to make an offer," said Karen Y. Vaughn, a senior human resources manager at Kraft, "the good students are gone."

Merchandise Analysts
From Shirt Buying To Dirt Buying
Deep inside a building in downtown Minneapolis, past the rows of cubicles watched over by a giant Winnie the Pooh and dozens of other stuffed animals, beyond the spot where the furry animals give way to plants lining the offices, is the desk of Rachel D. Gunderson, 22.
Ms. Gunderson, a graduate of the University of Wisconsin at Madison, is one of the newest merchandise analysts at the headquarters of Target, the discount-store chain.
"I'm in charge of soil," Ms. Gunderson said. As in potting soil. Target sells about 20 different bags, and it falls on Ms. Gunderson to make sure there is enough on the shelves of the chain's 750 stores nationwide.
Buying dirt for Target is typical of the entry-level responsibilities that thousands of this year's graduates will soon assume. The Dayton Hudson Corporation, based in Minneapolis, owns Target, Mervyn's and three department store chains: Dayton's, Hudson's and Marshall Field's. The company plans to hire 1,150 graduates this year at starting pay of $30,000 to $34,000. Dayton Hudson's competitors -- including the May Department Stores, Neiman Marcus, J. C. Penney, Kmart and Federated Department Stores -- together hire thousands more.
Ms. Gunderson, who graduated with a 3.0 grade-point average in December, started her job in mid-April. A journalism major who specialized in marketing and had a minor in business, she turned down an offer from Andersen Consulting and instead took this 8-to-5 job, which came with 12 weeks of training.
Ms. Gunderson inherited the potting-soil responsibilities from her designated mentor. She is learning how to send electronic orders to Target's suppliers, how to use spreadsheets to show soil sales histories and how to project how many bags of dirt Target will need on hand when an ad for potting soil appears.
Jacqueline T. Punch, central human resources director for Dayton Hudson, said competition for high-quality graduates was fierce. "There is definitely a sense that they can be very selective," Ms. Punch said. "The last two years it has really become more difficult."
Still, Dayton Hudson hires only 5 to 7 percent of the students it talks to, so the competition goes both ways.
The entry-level merchandising jobs go fast. "This job is like the most sought-after position" at the Carlson School of Management of the University of Minnesota, said another new Target merchandise analyst, Douglas M. Fischer, 23.
After graduating in March with an accounting major and a 3.0 grade-point average, Mr. Fischer was put in charge of buying stationery at Target. His best day so far came when he pushed a button on his computer to order $350,000 worth of paper and envelopes.
Across the street, Rebecca E. Johnson, 23, who graduated from the University of Michigan with an art history degree and a 3.4 grade-point average, is a merchant trainee for Dayton's. Her job is to help select the men's shirts and ties for the department store chain.
By the time Ms. Johnson, Ms. Gunderson and Mr. Fischer hand their shirt buying, dirt-buying and stationery-buying responsibilities to the graduates of 1998, they could be well on their way to solid futures at Dayton Hudson. Within five years, successful new hires earn $45,000 to $70,000 as full-fledged buyers, Ms. Punch said.

Technical Assistants
Helping Hands For Various Clients
 Andersen Consulting is a ubiquitous name at college career fairs. More than 150,000 seniors -- about 13 percent of the nation's graduating class -- sent their resumes to the company this year. About 4,200 will be hired by Andersen Consulting, the management and technical consulting arm of Andersen Worldwide.
So what do all those new hires do? Think of Andersen Consulting as a giant temporary firm, only with far better pay (starting salaries are $31,000 to $45,000) and more challenging assignments than those of, say, Kelly Services or Manpower Inc.
Many Fortune 500 companies depend on Andersen Consulting to send teams of energetic, well-educated workers to complete short-term tasks or complicated grunt work -- like making various computer systems talk to one another -- for which they don't want to hire their own staff.
Companies also use Andersen for more traditional management consulting jobs -- to guide strategic planning, for instance -- but Andersen hires mostly M.B.A.'s for those spots.
The Dallas office is one of 23 nationwide for Andersen Consulting, but only a small percentage of its employees in the region work in the tidy offices on the 54th floor of a glass skyscraper downtown. Most report to the offices of Andersen clients in the area for a few weeks or months, then move to another project at a different client.
Malane Rogers, 23, is a good example. She graduated from the University of Arkansas in December with a degree in industrial engineering and a 2.9 grade-point average. She started at Andersen in February, and travels each morning to the Dallas office of Texas Instruments.
Her task is to pull detailed financial data from Texas Instruments' huge mainframe computers and fashion them into easy-to-read reports for company executives. When a vice president wants to check quarterly revenues in a certain region, Ms. Rogers finds the needles in the data haystack.
Well before she graduated, Ms. Rogers had four other job offers, and would have had more had she not tightly limited her interviewing to companies in which she was keenly interested.
Thousands of graduates like Ms. Rogers are hired by Andersen and its brethren in the consulting field -- Price Waterhouse and Ernst & Young's consulting arms, as well as computer consulting firms like Electronic Data Systems. The Big Six accounting firms -- including Andersen Consulting's sister company, Andersen Accounting -- hire still more thousands for traditional accounting jobs.
Kim K. Dodson, 23, turned down 11 other offers to sign on at Andersen Consulting. She graduated from Texas A & M with a 3.4 grade-point average, having majored in business analysis, and started work in February. She wears a gold Aggie ring -- a popular accessory in Andersen's Dallas office -- with her business suit. For the last six weeks, she has been driving to the Fort Worth offices of Burlington Resources, an oil and gas company, to help program its computers.
Also working on Burlington's new computer codes is Nichole A. Inloes, 22, a December graduate of Texas A & M with a major in marketing. She programs Burlington's computers to cut checks automatically for energy royalties.
She is glad she chose Andersen over the other company that offered her a job: Enterprise Rent-a-Car.
Her father, Gerald T. Inloes of San Antonio, said he was looking forward, now that the college expenses were past, to resuming the family's trips to the beach at Corpus Christi and an annual vacation in Las Vegas, luxuries the Inloes had been doing without.
Still, the financial sacrifice was worth it. "I don't regret it for a second," Mr. Inloes said. "I am just so proud of her."
