SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 3; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 944 words

HEADLINE: The World;
You Spy? Let's Talk

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

 BODY:
MI5, the British foreign intelligence service, placed its first help wanted ad a few days ago, offering "a career like no other" and listing a telephone number to call.
But a smart-aleck hacker infiltrated MI5's answering machine. Thousands who responded heard a message from "Colonel Botch of the K.G.B.," the old Soviet espionage outfit, promising callers their resumes would be forwarded to Moscow. Aspiring James Bonds were shaken, not stirred. 
 Times are tough for the world's spy services. Their mystique has all but evaporated. Bereaved by the cold war's close, bereft of their old enemies, betrayed by their own spies, American, British and Russian intelligence want fresh blood. Each is shopping for new talent, each in its own way.
The Russians are trying to turn their traitors into double agents. On Tuesday, Gen. Nikolai Kovalyov, head of the Federal Security Service, the successor to the K.G.B., announced on television a telephone hot line he had set up for Russian citizens spying for foreign powers. The deal: 'Fess up, do your duty for the motherland and you can get two paychecks, one from us and one from your foreign paymasters. This is what the once fearsome and secretive spy service has come to: pleading for charity on TV.
To attack the international mafias that are flourishing in Moscow, Russian intelligence is also hiring crime-busting gumshoes. Bring your own gun, a bad attitude and a short life expectancy.
The British spy service's ads seek a more buttoned-down breed: business managers and university graduates with four years' work experience. They note that British intelligence officers have had past lives as marketing executives, teachers, fund-raisers, overseas aid workers, teachers and -- heaven forfend -- reporters. The Brits, like the Russians, are focusing on drug smuggling, organized crime and terrorism.
And the Central Intelligence Agency -- well, the C.I.A. has been placing help wanted notices (no, they're not called "classifieds") for 17 years. Last year it ran about 60 newspaper ads and about 120 ads in magazines and professional journals, from The Economist to Ebony. The agency's website (www.odci.gov/cia) just listed openings for computer whizzes, language instructors, psychologists, theatrical effects specialists (experienced in cosmetology, makeup and costuming), and leather and fabric crafters skilled in "fabrication." There is still call for false-bottomed diplomatic pouches.
The agency, though, also wants young spies. "More than a job, this is a way of life," its latest ad says. "It demands an adventurous spirit . . . a forceful personality . . . superior intellectual ability . . . toughness of mind . . . and the highest degree of integrity." Advanced degrees and military experience are pluses, as are "backgrounds in Central Eurasian, East Asian and Middle Eastern languages."
Boiled down to the basics, that ad might read: Wanted -- 25-year-old Asian-American woman with M.B.A. and working knowledge of automatic weapons, expert in computer programming, fluent in Turkic and Uzbek. Middling salary, long hours, utter anonymity. Call the C.I.A. -- please.
The agency badly wants Asian-Americans and African-Americans, who can blend into a marketplace in Kinshasa or a bazaar in Beijing a lot easier than a white guy. But they are hard to find and to keep, the agency has discovered.
In the 1950's, the C.I.A. skimmed the cream off the Ivies, Wall Street and Madison Avenue. In the 1990's, potential spies have either skills worth more than the salaries the agency can pay ($32,507 to start), or experience well shy of the C.I.A.'s deep needs. That Asian-American M.B.A. can go to Morgan Stanley and make serious money, without having to pass a lie-detector test.
To make matters worse, the C.I.A.'s hiring and personnel systems have been "deteriorating for the past 15 years," the agency's executive director, Nora Slaktin, told Congress last September. Between 1979 and 1996, she said, "there have been five major studies of the agency's human resources system with a total of 66 recommendations" but only one recommendation, an annual report card, was instituted agency wide.
As a result, she said, "We invest large amounts of money in hiring exceptionally skilled employees but fail to give them the best opportunities to grow and flourish. We invest too much money targeting, screening and hiring our employees to lose them or to use them ineffectively."
 
Career Killers
 So what is the C.I.A. to do? It says it is changing the way that it hires, trains, retains and promotes people. Its director-designate, George J. Tenet, said at his confirmation hearings that this was the single most important task before him. As Ms. Slatkin testified, "we have pigeon-holed employees in positions for too long." In the future, she said, anyone will be able to compete for any position. Training will be career-long. Pay will be linked to performance.
But last week the new generation of spies was reminded that intelligence is a profession peculiarly susceptible to Murphy's Law. A former C.I.A. station chief, Harold J. Nicholson, the agency's own Colonel Botch, was sentenced to 23 years and seven months in prison on Thursday for selling the Russians every secret he had learned in his 16 years with the agency. Among them were the identities of many of the 1994, 1995 and 1996 graduates of the C.I.A.'s school for spies -- trainees he himself had instructed in the black arts of espionage.
Thanks to Mr. Nicholson, many of those young officers are now condemned to desk-bound drudgery far from the back alleys of the world -- to careers like any other.

HEADLINE: Pricing the Convenience of A.T.M.'s

 BODY:
"Is Your A.T.M. Ripping You Off?" by David J. Morrow (May 4) discussed the fees assessed to withdraw cash from the nation's automated teller machines. The article drew varied responses from readers.
 
To the Editor: 
 As bankers in the Midwest, we were astonished to read the article about the fees at A.T.M.'s. The business of securing cash appears much different from where we sit. Here are a few examples:
* The article said the cost of cashing a $100 personal check at a check-cashing service in New York was $1.10, compared with $2.50 at an A.T.M. that levies surcharges. To test that idea here, I spent an afternoon trying to cash a personal check at such a service in Columbus, Ohio. The best deal I could find was at a cost of 10 percent, if I had more than five times that amount in a checking account. So that $100 check would cost the Ohio consumer $10, plus the cost of money sitting in deposit.
* It's difficult here to believe that "legislators and consumer watchdog groups are worried about the impact of the new fees on the nation's 11,867 credit unions." Credit unions take great care of themselves and their customers at the expense of taxpaying citizens. Bank customers already pay to pick up the trash, pave the streets and defend the country for the tax-subsidized credit unions and their customers. Midwesterners have no problem if banks make the credit unions foot their own A.T.M. bill. After all, banks and their customers built and paid for the A.T.M. networks.
* In Ohio we're accustomed to paying more for product and service convenience. When we buy bread at a convenience store, it costs more than at the grocery chain. When we make a phone call from our hotel room it costs more than at the pay phone in the lobby. To advocate that government should control the price of these or a checking account or A.T.M. access seems un-American. Banks, like every other business, charge market rates for their products. It's called capitalism and, the last we checked, it was the preferred economic system throughout the United States.

ANNIE HALL
Columbus, Ohio, May 5
 
The writer is director of the office of public policy at the Banc One Corporation.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
Jobless Rate at 23-Year Low
Isn't it wonderful how politicians, with a straight face, can take credit for just about anything? President Clinton can't even persuade Congress to send him a flood-relief bill without all sorts of empty cans clanging along behind it, but when the unemployment rate fell to a 23-year low of 4.8 percent, there he was trumpeting that it was on his watch. "The American economy has now added 12.3 million new jobs since I took office," he said, "and unemployment has now been below 6 percent for almost three years." Just how good was Friday's employment report? Hard to say. The other big number is added jobs, and May's number was a modest 138,000. But an added twist was that the Labor Department revised the April number from 142,000 to 323,000. Slippery things, these statistics.

EUROPE
Zigzagging Toward Unity
Europe's road to that mighty union is proving bumpy indeed. France can't seem to decide what kind of Government it wants, with last week's pendulum swing giving a decisive election victory to the Socialists, with their promises to focus on jobs, jobs, jobs -- and to forget budget deficits. And in Germany, which has lost over a million jobs in five years, a union agreement opened up the possibility that companies in trouble can cut wages 10 percent. That's quite a change in a country for famously rigid work rules. For the moment, at least, this is all good news for people with dollars, for the tremors weakened both the franc and the mark.
 
BEYOND FRACTIONS
Hey, Can You Spare an Eighth?
"So, what did you sell the stock for?" "Oh, $11.3125 a share." Huh? This is English? This is the best that higher math, computerized trading and zillion-dollar Wall Street minds can come up with -- trading stock not for $11.25 or $11.50, but for an otherworldly 11 5/16? Alas, yes. It supposedly has something to do with Spanish pieces of eight, but you know the real reason: more little odd fractions, more "golden crumbs" to be scraped up by Wall Street. Last week, Nasdaq said it would look into decimal pricing -- but it isn't exactly rushing, promising nothing but an opinion by Labor Day. The New York Stock Exchange, though, vowed to go decimal by 2000. Some people thought that was rushing things, since computers already have to cope with the "year 2000 problem." Poor Wall Street, they fear, will blow a fuse if it has to deal with both at once.
 
McDONALD'S
Poor Little Rich Company
The business world has an odd definition of a company in trouble. Consider McDonald's: revenues and earnings have set records every year since 1955, and the McDonald's brand name is now called the mightiest in the world. So clearly, this is a faltering business calling for drastic action -- like that mystifying 55-cent promotion the company mercifully laid to rest last week. What was it, exactly, that cost 55 cents? That was never quite clear; you often needed a calculator to figure out if you were saving money. McDonald's felt it had to try something, though, because -- horrors! -- it isn't growing as fast as it used to. Could it simply be that people can eat only so much fast food?
 
THIS SPACE AVAILABLE
Place Your Ad Here
It's coming: the world as one giant advertisement. If you read a magazine in public, you risk a littering fine as the ad inserts flutter out. Ads are creeping into "public" radio and TV (though they're called "enhanced announcements," or some such doublespeak). The mighty Jeep plowing fearlessly through the wild in "Breakdown," or the Mercedes taking on T. Rex in "Lost World," is a pure midmovie commercial. Teen-agers have somehow been coaxed to become walking billboards for brands like Tommy Hilfiger. And now the New York City's Metropolitan Transportation Authority wants us to carry advertising in our wallets, with Metrocards about to be embellished with Modell's ads. Pretty soon you'll hike to some glorious peak and find a sign saying, "This view brought to you by . . .
 
FUEL STANDARDS
A Ticket to Guzzle
By 2001, Ford says it is going to turn out 250,000 cars, mini-vans and pickups that burn either ethanol or gasoline. Certainly sounds like good news on the clean-air front, right? Take a closer look. First you've got to find a station that sells ethanol -- there are now about 40 nationwide. And then you'll have to pay about 15 percent more a mile to use it. Take a wild guess how many of those 250,000 drivers will stick with gasoline. So why did Ford bother? Simple. Federal rules on fuel standards are so, well, fanciful that these dual-fuel vehicles, even though they seem likely to have a minuscule impact on gasoline use, still earn Ford points with the clean-air police. And this, in turn, means Ford is allowed to turn out more of those gas-guzzling monsters that are taking over our streets.
 
EDUCATION
Starting From Scratch
Pretend that higher education is a used car. After years of fixing the brakes, fighting the rust, living with the rattles, you yearn for a clean slate. But philanthropists who want to put their stamp on education can't exactly ditch a college as easily as an old car -- they must usually content themselves with trying to nudge an institution in a new direction. Usually, but not always. Last week, the F. W. Olin Foundation, frustrated with what it called the overspecialization in engineering training, simply went out and bought itself a shiny new college. It is committing $200 million -- the biggest gift ever to higher education -- to create Franklin W. Olin College (named for the founder of the Olin Corporation, who died in 1951) near Boston. The foundation should bear in mind, though, that the second a new car leaves the showroom, it's a used car.
 
CAMPAIGN FINANCE
Creative Checking
Michele Lima of New York City received an invitation to a Democratic fund-raiser this spring. Nothing unusual about that. After all, she wrote a $3,000 check last year as her small contribution to the Democratic cause. One puzzling thing, though: Brian Lima said last week that his mother had never donated to political campaigns. Oh, and one more thing: Ms. Lima died a decade ago. This is just one of what Federal investigators suspect were countless examples of fraudulent donations to the Democrats, including checks from phony corporations. The Democrats have professed their desire to return hundreds of thousands of dollars in questionable contributions, but guess what: they often can't find the donors.
 
HONG KONG
Protesting Too Much?
When someone says "We are not panicked" or "We are not in trouble," one might think of a certain President who tended to say, "I am not a crook." No, Hong Kong's business tycoons say, there's nothing to panic about as July 1 approaches -- the day Hong Kong becomes part of China. They are scared, though, but it's not the China part that scares them -- it's their fear that American investors will panic. It's like the stock market -- traders don't care about the day's news anywhere near as much as they care about how other investors react to that news. If America gets scared by shadows in Hong Kong, the damage will be real.

HEADLINE: Dr. Dostoyevsky's Diagnosis;
Deep in the Russian Soul, a Lethal Darkness

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
THERE are few more shocking trips one can take in Russia than to the general wards of a major hospital. Despite the well-publicized problems of the Russian health care system, it is not the hospitals themselves, or their staffs, that give alarm: it is almost always the age of the patients and their condition.
"Lung disease, heart attack, cancer, alcohol poisoning, high blood pressure." Tanya Rodinova, a 20-year-old nurse at this city's Hospital Number 4, reeled off the afflictions of five men, none of them yet 50. "The usual stuff. They are all going to die." 
 It may sound dismissive, but it is certainly true. Russian men are dying in middle age at a rate unparalleled in modern history: from too much smoking, too much vodka, horrid diets, little exercise and the enormous stress of rapid economic change and social dislocation since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. Suicides are on the rise, so are murders, and some Russians wonder if yet another less tangible factor should be added: the gloomy Russian psyche. It is not the first time the question has been raised.
"It is the indifference toward everything that is vital -- toward the truth of life, everything that nourishes life and generates health," Fyodor Dostoyevsky wrote in 1876, complaining of what seemed to be the incurable darkness of the Russian soul. "In our day this indifference -- compared, let us say, with the outlook of other, European nations -- is almost a Russian disease."
It is not clear that such pessimism over the future and the health of the nation was justified 100 years ago. There can be no doubt that it is now. An astonishing drop in life expectancy for Russian men over the past decade, combined with one of the lowest birthrates on earth, has turned this country into a demographic freak show.
There is almost no current demographic fact about Russia that would fail to shock: per capita alcohol consumption is the highest in the world, nearly double the danger level drawn by the World Health Organization; a wider gap has developed in life expectancy between men (59) and women (73) than in any other country; the mortality rate of 15.1 deaths per 1,000 people puts Russia ahead of only Afghanistan and Cambodia among the countries of Europe, Asia and America (the rate for the United States is 8.8); the death rate among working-age Russians today is higher than a century ago. And there is much more.
"The current death rates present the clearest possible threat to the national security of Russia," a special report to President Boris N. Yeltsin recently concluded. "Only extreme measures will help us out of this demographic crisis."
 
Societal Suicide
 Yet the health crisis has received little top-level attention and almost no money. The Government spends less than 2.6 percent of the gross national product on health care, far below the levels of other industrial nations. For the most part, it has been nationalist politicians and health care advocates who have led the debate on the mortality issue, casting it as "genocide" for the Russian people.
"I don't think when you are killing off half a million able-bodied men every year, it is unfair to call that genocide," said Aleksandr Prokhanov, the extremist editor of the newspaper Zavtra and the intellectual leader of the nationalist opposition. To him and his allies, the figures reflect the economic changes of the Yeltsin era.
"How many have to die before we realize what is going on here?" he said.
Most demographers say the slide in health began long ago and was covered up by inconsistent and contradictory statistics. Whatever the reasons, the figures for the past five years are worse than ever: the mortality rate for Russian men age 40 to 49 was 16.3 per 1,000 in 1995, 77 percent higher than in 1990, when it was 9.2.
Even the good news is hard to take: Life expectancy for men may actually have risen slightly in 1996 from the previous year -- simply because the most vulnerable young people have already died. The raw number of sick children, appallingly high by any standard, appears lower this year only because so few children have been born over the past several years.
"It has become an issue of ethics, of morality and of politics," said Dr. Valery Yelizarov, a demographer at Moscow State University. "No society can survive such patterns for long. What bothers me most is how people assume it is inevitable, part of the Russian male mentality. Russian men have always had an indifference to their health. But it has to stop or the consequences will be too awful to predict."
Soon after Dostoyevsky noted the "Russian disease," demographers carried out the nation's first major census and projected that by this time the population would be 400 million. Instead, it is 147.5 million, and the most recent report to Mr. Yeltsin suggests that if new health and education initiatives are not adopted soon the population of Russia will decrease by as much as 30 million in the next 50 years.
The implications of such change are stark. Of the 3.5 million people under age 60 who died in Russia over the past five years -- a figure with parallels in modern history only during vast famines or prolonged wars -- most have been working-age people desperately needed to help lift Russia from its depression.
In 1940, working-age people accounted for 40 percent of the population and the elderly 8 percent. Now the figure for the elderly is triple that proportion, nearly 24 percent, while that for working-age people has been cut in half.
 
No Confidence, No Children
 And there is no sign of relief. Despite a slight rise in life expectancy, the Russian population fell by 480,000 last year, the steepest such decline in any year since World War II, according to state statistics.
"You do have to ask yourself how long can this go on?" said Carl Haub, a demographer with the Population Reference Bureau in Washington. Russia's low birthrate -- only Italy and Spain have lower ones -- is a clear reflection, he said, of a lack of optimism for the future among Russians.
"You keep expecting it to turn around and it doesn't," he said. "Obviously there are very significant long-term implications to all this. People often focus on the death rate. And in Russia, of course, it is bad. But the birthrate and the health of children who are born play a much larger role than the death rate. They are the future of the country."

LENGTH: 937 words

HEADLINE: Labor's Lost Love;
A Union Comeback? Tell It to Sweeney

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
SINCE taking the helm of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. 20 months ago, John J. Sweeney has learned more than he would like about Newton's third law of motion: every action has an opposite and equal reaction. He has discovered that every move labor makes to dig itself out of its hole is countered by a move to shove labor back in.
Last fall, the 13 million-member labor federation spent more than it ever had before in the hope of recapturing Congress for the Democrats, but that only spurred corporations to contribute more to Republicans, thus largely negating the unions' push. Now labor is doubling its budget to recruit new members, but that has merely encouraged business to hire even more pinstriped consultants and lawyers to beat back the unions. 
 "Every action does generate a reaction, and at the end it's not clear whether labor is better off or worse off," said Gregory Tarpinian, executive director of the Labor Research Association, a consulting group. "At the same time, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has no choice but to keep on pushing ahead."
Certainly labor's rank and file and liberals in general have applauded Mr. Sweeney's effort to bring labor back from the dead. But countervailing forces are strong.
Despite his campaign for new members, the number of unionized workers fell over the last two years by nearly 500,000, pushed down by powerful forces like downsizing and the flight of jobs overseas. And then, of course, there is a new economic mood. Decades ago, many Americans grew up in pro-union, pro-New Deal households and saw themselves as members of the working class, but now many Americans see themselves as part of an upwardly mobile middle class that views unions as irrelevant.
There is a new political mood, too. Not only did the Democrats fail to win back the House and Senate, but Congress in many ways is more hostile to labor than it was before Mr. Sweeney became the federation's president. The first legislation House Republicans took up was a bill to overhaul the 60-year-old law on overtime, which is sacrosanct to labor. The House passed the bill, and it awaits a Senate vote.
And while the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has built up many chits with the White House, President Clinton has ignored many of labor's wishes. He signed the new welfare law, despite labor's opposition. In choosing a successor to Labor Secretary Robert Reich, he shunned labor's No. 1 choice, former Senator Harris Wofford, naming instead Alexis Herman, a distant second choice. And he is expected to seek to expand the North American Free Trade Agreement without the protections demanded by unions.
In an interview, Mr. Sweeney resisted suggestions that progress had been slower or harder than expected. "I really think that things are going great," he said. "I couldn't be more enthusiastic about the excitement that I see when I travel around."
He noted that more than 1,000 college students enrolled in a union internship program last summer that aimed to turn them into labor activists. He also noted that 725 people attended a recent conference in Miami, never a hotbed of unionism, on how to recruit workers. And in April, he noted, more than 20,000 activists from dozens of unions trekked to Watsonville, Calif., to propel an effort to unionize strawberry workers.
Downplaying any setbacks, Mr. Sweeney had a practical message: Unless labor continues plowing ahead with its efforts at regeneration, it is doomed to continue its decades-long slide. To plow ahead, he is pushing strategies like strengthening ties with the clergy and minorities, rebuilding moribund city labor councils and redoubling efforts to recruit women and low-wage employees, like janitors, nurses' aides and even workfare workers -- a fast-growing group that labor fears is taking away union jobs and pulling down wages.
Mr. Sweeney, labor experts say, has a rare window of opportunity to turn things around after the movement drifted toward oblivion during the 15 years that his predecessor, Lane Kirkland, ran the federation. Buying into Mr. Sweeney's strategy, labor leaders, often a churlish, tight-fisted bunch, have pledged money and manpower to organizing and politics -- although only about 15 of the 78 unions in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. are vigorously recruiting new members. As for the rank and file, it is showing more enthusiasm than it has in decades; many more members of the machinists, service employees and hotel workers unions, for example, are volunteering evenings and weekends to organizing campaigns.
In light of labor's recent setbacks, it has dawned on many union members that expectations for a quick rebound might have been unrealistically high.
The obstacles are daunting and public apathy pervasive. Labor still often comes up empty handed from lengthy strikes, like that at the Detroit newspapers. Many union locals are still headed by $150,000-a-year bureaucrats who critics complain care more about their Cadillacs than about organizing. Labor has struck out in recruiting workers in one of the nation's fastest growing industries: computers, including manufacturing, software and data processing.
Mr. Sweeney says expectations of a quick turnaround are naive. "Anybody who has thought about it knows that for the kind of growth and level of changes we need, we have to build an entirely new foundation," he said. "The decline has been a long time coming. What we're doing now is a huge undertaking. We made a start on it last year, but the bottom line is about rebuilding a progressive voice in our country. That's something that has been needed for a long time, and it's not going to happen overnight."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
God Is Also a Cosmologist

BYLINE: By MARGARET WERTHEIM; Margaret Wertheim is producing a documentary about science and religion for public television.

 BODY:
BEHOLD how through my effort God is being celebrated in astronomy." So wrote Johannes Kepler, the world's first astrophysicist, in 1595. For Kepler, as for Newton, the cosmos was a reflection of God. Its very structure mirrored the holy trinity.
The idea of the universe as a reflection of God has become unfashionable in scientific circles since the Enlightenment. Yet given a recent survey that found that 40 percent of American scientists believe in a personal God they can pray to, it is clear that being a scientist is not incompatible with religious faith. 
Last month, the Center for Theology and the Natural Sciences, in Berkeley, Calif., hosted an international gathering of cosmologists and astrophysicists to explore just how contemporary cosmology, the scientific study of the universe, might be compatible with various religions. Each of the three monotheistic faiths were represented: Judaism, Christianity and Islam. Though not all participants believed in a personal God, it was evident that numerous religious interpretations could be sustained by one cosmology.
Joel Primack, a cosmologist at the University of California at Santa Cruz, suggested an analogy between the inflationary model of cosmological origin and the myth of creation in the cabala, a body of Jewish mystic writings dating from the late Middle Ages. God is believed to have sent a shaft of light into the empty space from which he had withdrawn. The light overflowed into the 10 aspects of God that form the core of the cabala, the sephirot, and created the universe. "Of the 10 sephirot," Mr. Primack said, "the first three correspond fairly closely to concepts from the theories of inflation and eternal inflation."
 
A Bubbling Potential
 The first of the sephirot is Keter, a symbol of God's infinite potential to create. It can be likened to what cosmologists call "eternal inflation," the infinite bubbling potential from which they believe the universe arose before the Big Bang. The second, Hokhmah, is the bursting through of the universe from the realm of pure potential to actual physical existence, which, Mr. Primack says, is like the initial blinding instant of the Big Bang itself. The third, Binah, is the female womb in which creation expands, which he sees as analogous to the unfolding of space, time and matter out of the Big Bang.
But Andrei Linde, a Stanford University physicist who developed the theory of eternal inflation, does not see any similarity between his theory and monotheistic beliefs. "According to eternal inflation, there is not just one universe but many different universes," he said, "with different laws of physics operating in each of them. New universes are coming into being all the time, hence the name eternal inflation." Mr. Linde warns against any superficial religious interpretation of this theory but suggests that it might be paralleled to the polytheism of Indian religions.
Given that all the scientists study the same universe with the same set of mathematical laws, how do they explain their various religious positions? The English physicist John Barrow from Sussex University said the fuzziness of cosmology might be an explanation. "Cosmology is a peculiar science because it is so close to many unanswerable questions," he said, so it is not always clear what the science is telling us. "The evidence is open to multiple interpretations."
Sometimes it verges on theology. "Theological tradition often informs the development of science," Mr. Barrow said.
 
Translating Traditions
 Mr. Linde said, "When scientists start their work they are subconsciously influenced by their cultural traditions."
The central idea of modern cosmology -- that there must be one set of laws describing everything -- comes from the monotheistic tradition, he said.
Modern cosmology has even incorporated ideas about the Judeo-Christian God, said Edward Harrison, an astrophysicist with the University of Massachusetts.
"Astronomers often don't appreciate how the definitions and properties ascribed to God were eventually translated into properties of the universe," he said. "Take, for example, the idea that God is everywhere and occupies no point." This became the notion that the universe is the same everywhere and has no center, known as the cosmological principle.
One point on which almost everyone at the gathering agreed was that cosmology does not necessarily bump humanity from its exalted position in the cosmos. Bruno Guiderdoni, a Muslim astrophysicist from the Institute of Astrophysics of Paris, argued that cosmology is "teaching us that we are at the top of a huge cosmic building." The universe of man has to be old (and hence enormous) because it needs time to have synthesized all the elements that make up human bodies -- carbon, nitrogen and so on.
 
The Integrity of Nature
 The Jesuit astronomer William Stoeger of the Vatican Observatory Research Group at the University of Arizona at Tucson said that since scientists now know the atoms of human bodies were forged in the stars, modern cosmology shows how humans are woven into the entire cosmic network. Science, he said, also reinforces the Thomist theological tradition of the "functional integrity of nature." Scientists now know, for instance, that if the law of gravity was even slightly stronger or weaker, planets could not form in stable orbits around stars. Life could not exist -- at least not human life.
But is there really a functional integrity to the universe? While this idea is inherent in Judeo-Christianity, Mr. Linde challenged it as another monotheistic interpretation of the scientific evidence. "In a polytheistic culture," he said, "they may not think this way at all."

HEADLINE: Scared Straight;
The Wisdom of Children Who Have Known Too Much

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
RAHMEL MILLER still hears an occasional gunshot at night from his apartment building in Harlem. And there are still fistfights after school among his fellow fourth graders at P.S. 194 on West 144th Street.
But Rahmel, who is nine years old, says he feels a lot safer than his older brother did when he was starting high school only a few years ago, at the height of the epidemic of violence touched off by the advent of crack cocaine and the guns and gangs that followed. Rahmel doesn't feel the need to carry a gun, he doesn't aspire to be a drug dealer and when he leaves for school in the morning, his mother doesn't kiss him good-bye as if it was going to be the last time, as she did with his brother. 
 These are small but significant signs of how life has changed for young people in Harlem and in other inner cities across much of the nation as the record levels of murder and violence have begun to recede. The latest figures from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, released last week, showed that serious crime fell again in 1996, for the fifth straight year, with murders declining sharply to their lowest level since the late 1960's.
Equally important, Rahmel's story may also be an important part of the answer to a mystery that has confounded criminologists, law enforcement officials and politicians: What has been driving the crime rate down? Different experts have their own favorite explanations, many reflecting society's decreasing toleration of lawbreaking: innovative police tactics, more criminals in prison, tougher gun control laws.
Other specialists point to the baby boom's aging out of its prime years for crime. Some have begun to wonder if the improving economy, with all its new jobs, may have helped -- though criminologists have long doubted that there is any connection between employment and crime rates.
But on the streets, young people offer another theory, an explanation backed by social workers, probation officers and psychiatrists who work with juveniles from troubled families in poor neighborhoods. They believe there has been a shift in attitudes among the young people themselves.
 
Once a Thug
 "People are getting smarter," said Salahadeen Betts, a 20-year-old neighbor of Rahmel's on 144th Street. "It's no more doing things on a whim. Before, people would say, I want to sell drugs, because it was the cool thing to do.
"Now people are thinking and planning, they are more educated about guns and drugs," said Mr. Betts, who said he had been shot at and had been in jail, and that his high school teachers thought he was a "thug."
Precisely what has brought about this change is a subject of debate among the teen-agers and the people who work with them.
For Mr. Betts, the turning point came when a close friend was shot and killed on a street corner, "Right in front of me," while playing dice.
"Me not getting shot meant something," said Mr. Betts. "Maybe somebody had to die for me to learn." He is now a college student and a volunteer in an after-school program at P.S. 194 run by the Rheedlen Centers for Children and Families, a nonprofit agency that offers services to poor children in Harlem.
Interviews with a dozen other students and volunteers at the Rheedlen Centers program at P.S. 194 showed similar experiences. Almost all had seen someone shot, and all had a close relative or friend who has been incarcerated.
In Boston, Bill Stewart, a probation officer, said he also saw the effect on children who had seen violence: "They saw what was happening and were witnesses to it. It was too unpleasant. They remember their mothers crying and their older brothers not coming home, for no reason, and they don't want to be a part of it."
And it isn't just the youngest who have recoiled from the gun culture. "Guns and violence are much less socially acceptable than they were a few years ago," said Dr. Carl Bell, a psychiatrist and a former gang member himself who is now chief executive officer of the Community Mental Health Council, a nonprofit agency on the South Side of Chicago.
 
A Parent Problem
 Dr. Bell sees this change daily in the children who are sent to his clinic, most of them victims of abuse whose parents are on drugs. "These kids are real clear that drug addiction is not a good thing and that the violence that goes along with it in the family is not a good thing," Dr. Bell said. "They will sit there ard tell you they want to be a drug addiction counselor or a policeman, to correct the problem."
In New York, although Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and former Police Commissioner William J. Bratton have credited their introduction of aggressive stop-and-frisk police tactics for much of the city's stunning decline in violent crime, the young people at P.S. 194 bitterly disagree.
"How come when the violence goes down, it's because of the police, and when it goes up, it's us?" asked Mr. Betts.
"I don't think the cops have done a thing to lower crime," he added, except to stop young black men without cause. Every one of the dozen young people interviewed knew of someone who had been stopped by the police -- unfairly, they thought -- in recent months.
Milton Bright, an 18-year-old high school student, said he was recently stopped by police officers as he was coming out of a park with a straw in his mouth. "They said I was smoking weed," said Mr. Bright. "It was awfully long weed."
The young people did acknowledge, however, that the new police emphasis on arresting juveniles found with handguns and making criminal cases for gun possession has deterred many teen-agers from continuing to carry guns. "The first time I had a gun, I had a .32 in my sweatpants, it was so easy to see I was crazy," said James Bellamy, a 24-year-old college student. Now, people he knows are much more cautious: "They keep their guns at home. They don't want to be arrested."
The young people and the experts do agree on one factor that has reduced shootings -- the stabilization of the drug market. When crack was first introduced in 1986, the old heroin distribution channels broke down. "Everyone was selling crack, even the kids, each doing their own thing," Mr. Bellamy said. "That led to a lot of conflict, with guys saying, 'You standing on my corner,' and shooting each other."
Now, Mr. Betts said, "the heads," or big dealers, are all older, in their 30's, and they are more organized. For these dealers, he said, "it's like a regular business, with employees, and they invest their profits in stores and beauty parlors and support their wives and children."
Another important difference, for the young people, is the introduction of after-school programs and greater adult attention to their problems as neighborhoods belatedly tried to respond to the increase in violence. "Five years ago, to be a man, you had to have a gun," said Treston Lambert, a 21-year-old student at Baruch College. "None of my friends believed they could finish high school or go to college."
 
Just Fistfights
 "Now there are alternatives," said Mr. Lambert, like the Rheedlen Centers program at P.S. 194, which has 500 students, ages 6 to 22, in after-school classes.
Geoffrey Canada, the president of the Rheedlen Centers, said the younger children today "do not have as much direct involvement with handguns" as their older siblings did a few years ago. They have heard shots fired, he said, but haven't seen a gun themselves.
"For these younger kids, violence is very much just a matter of fistfights," a return to the more familiar pattern of 15 years ago, Mr. Canada said. "Then, I considered fistfights a terrible thing, but now it is almost refreshing."
Still, some of the young people themselves worry that in a few years a new generation of teen-agers, not knowing the lessons of the last few years, will revert to greater violence. "It's coming back," said Mr. Betts. "The little kids I work with have no family values."
Candice Whitehead, a 10-year-old at P.S. 194, loves books but does not like her school because of all the fights. She is a cheerleader, and at a recent basketball game, the cheerleaders from another elementary school "called us sluts," Candice said. That led to some grabbing and punching.
"When you are at school," she said, "you're supposed to be learning, so you can get a fantastic job."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1368 words

HEADLINE: Zaire's Fall Jolts Neighboring Angola's Frail Peace

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: LUANDA, Angola, June 3

 BODY:
In an important spillover effect of the war in Zaire, Government troops in neighboring Angola have attacked territory controlled by their longtime rebel enemies, who lost their most important backer when Mobutu Sese Seko, the Zairian dictator, was defeated.
Military officials and diplomats say the Angolan Government, which signed a peace treaty with the rebels in 1994, has launched offensives south of the town of Dundo deep in the country's diamond territory. 
 Government officials say they have simply been trying to patrol their border against armed militias and soldiers loyal to Mr. Mobutu who are trying to escape the former Zaire, now known as Congo.
But Western diplomats and United Nations officials say the fighting has been taking place south of Dundo in remote mining areas rather than on the Angola-Congo border. These areas -- largely stretches of savanna but threaded with diamond-rich riverbeds -- have been producing income for Angola's rebels, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known as Unita.
In recent days, United Nations officials say, planeloads of diesel fuel, rations and ammunition have arrived in the area. They report having seen tanks and artillery guns passing by and heard the sounds of mortar shells. There have also been reports of more than 100 wounded Government soldiers, and displaced villagers reportedly have begun to arrive by the thousands in surrounding villages and towns.
Since the Government and the former rebels are supposed to be observing a peace agreement, the Government's actions have raised questions about whether it intends an all-out assault on the country's diamond areas. The aim of such a move would be to crush Unita once and for all.
The attacks have set off a frenzy of diplomatic activity, with United Nations officials and Western diplomats traveling between President Jose Eduardo dos Santos in the capital and the Unita leader, Jonas Savimbi, in the southern town of Bailundo, trying to avoid a total breakdown of the peace agreement.
"We are trying to convince the Government not to get cocky," said one official close to the talks, who requested anonymity. "It's important for them to show restraint now."
The last 32 months have been Angola's longest period of stability in more than two decades. The country, which has enough oil, diamonds and rich farmland to be wealthy, plunged into a civil war almost immediately after independence was won from Portugal in 1975. Unita, part anti-Communist force, part the personality cult of the forceful Mr. Savimbi, was supported by the United States and South Africa. Soviet arms and Cuban fighters were aligned with Mr. dos Santos and his Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola.
After the cold war ended and the sponsors withdrew, the two sides signed a peace pact in 1991. But when Mr. dos Santos won an election, Mr. Savimbi went back to war. This time battles were even fiercer and were fought in the cities as well. Angolan industry was destroyed.
Since November 1994, the Government and the rebels have been involved in a new peace effort. But it has been marked by delays and skirmishes. Although some steps have been taken to preserve the peace, the country has been in a kind of stalemate, with the Government in control of oil-producing areas and most cities, and Unita in control of diamond areas and much of the countryside. Most roads are impassable, and except for the capital, Luanda, there is little evidence of economic improvement.
United Nations officials say that the peace accord has been a success. There are few battles. Some 70,000 Unita soldiers have been sent to quartering sites, where they are disarmed and wait to receive tools and other provisions so they can return to civilian life. And in April, after many delays, Unita finally began taking part in the coalition Government that the peace treaty calls for. It sent 70 members to take their seats in Parliament. Eleven Unita leaders became Cabinet ministers or deputy ministers, and nine Unita generals have been absorbed into the Government army, as have 11,000 Unita troops.
The peaceful transfer of administrative authority over some Unita territories has begun, and it progressed last week even as the Government attacked.
But some analysts say these are still largely paper accomplishments. No one believes that Unita sent its best soldiers into the quartering sites, and only 34,000 weapons were collected, many unusable, from the 71,000 troops, 26,000 of whom then disappeared from the quartering sites.
Unita soldiers supported Mr. Mobutu's troops in their fight for Zaire, and thousands are believed to be in the neighboring country still, over Angola's northern border. Estimates on the strength of these forces vary widely, from 2,000 to 15,000.
Political analysts say that Unita troops caught off guard and still recovering from the Mobutu defeat may be particularly vulnerable right now. The Government may well be able to wrest the diamond territories from Unita by force. But the experts warn that such a move might not end the war. More than 40 percent of the population is believed to support Unita, and guerrilla and terrorist attacks might continue.
What is clear, however, is that the events next door have dealt a mighty blow to Mr. Savimbi, who for decades relied on Zaire as a haven and a conduit to smuggle diamonds out and bring weapons and food in. Some analysts say that before Mr. Mobutu was toppled, the two sides -- each with income and territory -- were negotiating peace on a more or less equal footing. Now the Government has an obvious advantage.
The head of the United Nations peacekeeping delegation in Luanda, Alioune Blondin Beye, said he hoped the shift might speed the process of peace along.
"The hope," he said, "is that Unita, knowing it has lost this asset, will take the political route."
But others fear the shift may force Unita to act in desperation or the Government to press its advantage.
"There is no question we are at a critical stage," said a diplomat who has lived in Africa for years, speaking on condition of anonymity. "There is certainly cause for concern."
It has long been recognized that Mr. Savimbi would be unlikely to give up the diamond areas without a fightand repeated efforts have been made to negotiate a pact that would continue to give Unita members revenue from the area even after they ceded control of it.
Mr. Savimbi has been offered diamond concessions, shares in several private mining operations and a share in the giant Government diamond authority, Endiama. But exactly how much of a share remains unresolved, with Mr. Savimbi holding out for more than the Government wants to give him.
Some officials see the attacks as a kind of saber rattling intended to persuade him to take the deal being offered. But others say the Government has grown impatient with Unita and plans to take advantage of its upper hand.
The rebels, generally press-savvy and accessible to reporters, have been oddly subdued in their public reaction to the attacks.
One official close to the peace process says Unita has expressed its concern but seems willing to overlook the attacks as long as they do not spread.
But some experts fear that the peace effort may be further complicated by a split within the rebel movement.
On May 30, a key negotiator for Unita, Isaias Samacuva, was badly beaten by a group of men shouting, "Traitor! Traitor!" This was widely interpreted as a warning from Mr. Savimbi to Mr. Samacuva and other Unita leaders who seem determined to pursue peace quickly.
United Nations relief workers were able to visit the Dundo area briefly last week and reported that about 2,500 refugees had entered the nearby town of Nzage. They described fierce fighting to the south. Several large mining enterprises function in the region, which operates in a kind of Wild West atmosphere. An array of armed scavengers roams the area, among them renegade generals and South African mercenaries.
In the last two weeks, however, some mining companies have closed. The diamond giant De Beers, for instance, has shut its office in Cafunfu in Unita-held territory.

HEADLINE: Towns in Washington Bringing Back Poetry in Street Names

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, June 6

 BODY:
For drivers in rural western Washington, there once was a charm to traveling on a road with a name, not a number. Rolling down Rainwater Road beat driving 19th Avenue Northeast. A trip down French Creek Grange Road was more idyllic than the same drive on 167th Avenue Southeast.
Those old names, and many others like them, were changed in the late 1970's to numbers to make it easier for emergency workers to find houses on a grid system anchored by the north-south freeway, Interstate 5. In the interest of quicker ambulances and Cartesian simplicity, officials in suburban areas around here erased the poetry and history from the maps. Fidelity Hall Road, Green Lantern Road, Picnic Road and Potato Road were among the names consigned to the archives. 
 Now, Thurston and Snohomish Counties, along with some towns, are trying to reclaim the names of their country roads. The counties are adding the historic names of some streets to their current designations, giving them two names, while the towns of Lake Stevens and Lacey are replacing some current street names with their former designations, to honor historic families and preserve a sense of small-town life.
Beneath the 36th Avenue Northeast sign in South Bay, Thurston County recently added "Ames-Huntley Road." The original name honors two families who ran the cedar mill and raised livestock.
Lake Stevens, in Snohomish County, plans to change 124th Avenue Northeast back to Main Street.
"We truly believe that Main Street identifies where the centers of towns are," said Mayor Jay Echols of Lake Stevens, population 5,100, and 60 miles northeast of Seattle. Mr. Echols said the change would help efforts to revitalize the downtown area.
In Snohomish County, about 150 roads go by both number and name. The numbers are in green and white, and the historic names are on brown and white signs.
Frank Jenkins, a real estate photographer who moved here from Ohio, derided a street-numbering system that he said took numbering to its illogical conclusion. He cited the former Kline Hill Road west of Issaquah, with each of its eight switchbacks dutifully numbered.
"In this world where everything is being homogenized, it's great to have local flavor," said Shanna Stevenson, a senior planner with Thurston County, which includes Olympia, the state capital.
The county historic commission felt too much was lost in the numbering and wanted to spur interest in local history by offering street signs to the public for $60. Under the program, if the residents of a street want its former name restored, they obtain permission from the county commissioners, then purchase the official signs from the historic commission.
The numbers still have their fans. Bill Hoffman, manager of transportation system planning for the Department of Transportation in King County, which includes Seattle, said: "With all these strange names, for an engineer like me, I go 'Aw, this is awful!' With Killarney Place or Baloney Whatever, cul de sacs and circular streets, finding our way around is really difficult."
But in an age of passwords, PIN's and credit card numbers, Mr. Jenkins finds such names more esthetically pleasing. He mused out loud whether he should start calling himself by his Social Security number. "There are plenty of Franks around," he said.

HEADLINE: Old Animosities Aside, Americans Are Touring Iran

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: SHIRAZ, Iran

 BODY:
A truly extraordinary sound, one that had for years been unimaginable in this country, echoed from a corner of a popular restaurant in Shiraz during a recent lunch hour. A dozen American tourists were talking excitedly about the sights they had seen that day.
When their Iranian guide realized that a foreign newspaper reporter was also on the premises, he became almost apoplectic with fear and anger. 
 "We can have no mention of this tour in the press," he said. "The conversation is over. Go away and forget this, do you understand?"
But as he was speaking, several members of the group gaily called out comments.
"Write that this is a fantastic place to visit!" said one. "Write that we're having an amazing trip!" suggested another. A third added: "The people here are wonderful to us. We haven't heard a single negative word."
Afterward, a pained tour operator accompanying the group sought to explain his Iranian colleague's agitation.
He said that this was the first American tour group to enter Iran in years, perhaps since the 1979 Islamic revolution, and that the Iranian guides he had hired were very nervous, fearing reprisals from their Government if any news about the visit leaked out.
The next evening, though, the owner of the American travel agency that had arranged the tour called to say that she had checked with the Iranian authorities, and that they had no objection to publicity. It would harm no one, she said, to report that American tourists are now welcome in Iran.
Still, the guides' concern was not surprising in a country that has had such a troubled relationship with the United States. During the recent presidential election campaign here, Iran's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, pledged that no matter who was elected, Iran would continue to "stand against America."
The United States was a principal supporter of the late Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who was overthrown and forced to flee in 1979 after a series of protests led by Islamic clerics. Revolutionary militants later stormed the United States Embassy in Teheran and held American diplomats hostage in an extended drama that produced intense anti-Iranian sentiment in the United States.
More recently, the United States has imposed economic sanctions on Iran that have had a measurable though not overwhelmingly negative effect on the country's economic development.
Officials in Washington say that the measures are justified because the Iranian Government supports international terrorism, seeks to subvert nearby states and is arming itself in ways banned by international treaties.
The State Department has issued a warning asserting that travel in Iran "remains dangerous because of the generally anti-American atmosphere and Iranian hostility to the U.S. Government." It added that, since there is no United States Embassy in Iran, travelers cannot count on the "protective services" that consular officers provide in other countries.
In May, the United States announced that it was imposing sanctions on two Chinese companies it said were helping Iran produce chemical weapons. Iran rejected the assertion, which one newspaper called "the latest of U.S. intrigues against Iran."
Despite those serious problems between the Governments, though, Iranians seem remarkably friendly to the few American who visit here. They sometimes ask, as a shopkeeper in the sacred city of Qum did recently, "Why is Clinton so hard with us?"
But American correspondents who traveled through the country covering the presidential election campaign last month were greeted with smiles and warm welcomes.
There are still a few anti-American murals on walls here, like one in Teheran that shows bombs falling from the stripes in an American flag and bears the slogan "Down With the U.S.A."
But they are balanced by spray-painted graffiti like one in Isfahan that says, "I Like U.S.A."
Many of the sites that were jammed with foreign tourists in pre-revolutionary days are now almost empty, with only occasional groups of European and Japanese tourists mixing with the local residents. This is due in part to the discomfort many foreigners still feel toward Iran, which is viewed in many quarters as a rogue state, and in part to the Government's ambivalent attitude toward tourism.
Some officials here see tourism as an ideal way to earn hard currency and expose foreigners to a gentler side of Iran. But radicals believe that it opens the country to corrupting Western influences, gives hostile intelligence services an opportunity for espionage, and emphasizes aspects of pre-Islamic Persian history toward which they are less than enthusiastic.
"They don't like anything that has to do with kings," said an Iranian guide at Persepolis, a magnificent archeological site from which a royal dynasty ruled this region 2,500 years ago. "In fact, they don't like promoting anything that isn't Muslim."
In August the Iranian Government announced that it would begin issuing visas to foreign tourists. Soon afterward, Janet Moore, who owns and operates Distant Horizons, a travel agency based in Long Beach, Calif., came here for a series of meetings with Government officials. She left with a promise that she could begin bringing tourists here in 1997.
"We listed Iran in our catalog, saying that we would have one departure in May and one in October, each limited to 15 people," Ms. Moore said. "The tours were filled within 24 hours after we issued our catalog. We expanded to offer six tours instead of two, and they're all full."
Each tour lasts 18 days and is accompanied by a foreign specialist on Persian or Muslim culture. Destinations include Persepolis and the nearby city of Shiraz, the lush Caspian coast, the holy city of Mashhad and Isfahan, where some of the world's most spectacularly colorful mosques are to be seen.
"The first thing people asked when they called was: 'How can you be doing this? Isn't it illegal?' " Ms. Moore said. "The answer is that the United States does have a trade embargo against Iran, but it does not include travel."
"The Iranian people have been incredibly welcoming," she said. "When we were at the gate of the shrine in Mashhad, which is the holiest city in Iran, people were crowding around us and saying, 'Welcome, welcome, we're glad you're here.' Women were coming up and kissing the women in our group. It's quite amazing considering the state of relations between the two countries."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Iran has been issuing tourist visas since August, and even Americans have responded. Iranian women toured the Persepolis archeological site. (Staton R. Winter for The New York Times)
 
Map showing the location of Shiraz, Iran: The new American tours of Iran include Shiraz and Persepolis.

HEADLINE: Conflicting Views Put Republicans in a Bind on Cutting Taxes

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
As it sets out to enact the first big Federal tax cuts since 1981, the Republican majority in Congress is struggling to reconcile the conflicting demands of its two most influential factions.
The social conservatives want to slash taxes for families, and the economic conservatives argue that the party's top priority should be to stimulate more investment by cutting capital gains taxes. 
 Their dueling priorities, which have long defined the battle for the party's ideological soul, will clearly be on display in the coming week as the Congressional tax committees begin drafting legislation to carry out the $135 billion tax reduction included in the bipartisan balanced budget agreement.
The agreement won formal Congressional approval on Thursday.
Republican leaders defended the $135 billion package as the best they could get from President Clinton and Democrats in Congress and as a welcome antidote to a series of tax increases that started in 1982 and continued through 1993 as the nation's economic focus turned to narrowing the Federal budget deficit.
But the Republican leaders acknowledged that the package would not be big enough to accommodate the tax-cutting demands from all the party's constituencies, not to mention those from the Clinton Administration.
"It's putting a large square peg into a small round hole," said Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who was an architect of the tax cut in 1981 and is now chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. "It isn't going to be easy."
The intramural Republican tension will play out against a background of more traditional partisan squabbling over the makeup of the tax cut. Many Democrats in Congress are insisting that the tax legislation not skew the cuts to favor the wealthy at the expense of the poor and working classes.
Liberal Democrats are considering proposals that would largely limit breaks in the capital gains tax to the sale of small businesses and farms, arguing that a broad-based cut would be nothing more than a sop to investors who have reaped big gains in the red-hot stock market.
The Administration is aiming its firepower not at capital gains or a per-child tax credit, but at preserving its proposal for $35 billion in tax breaks for college education. Although the balanced budget agreement calls for a package of college tax breaks "consistent" with those backed by Mr. Clinton, the proposal faces strong opposition from Republicans and is dogged by a notable lack of support from Congressional Democrats.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, is in a particularly difficult position. To come up with the full $135 billion allocated to the tax cut, the budget accord requires him to find $50 billion in new revenue to help pay for it.
Although he is willing to go along with an extension of a tax on airline tickets that could raise up to $35 billion, he has rejected nearly all other revenue-increasing proposals as thinly disguised tax increases. His lone big alternative -- eliminating a tax break for producers of ethanol -- has been rejected by Speaker Newt Gingrich as politically impossible.
As a result, Republicans face the possibility of having to scale back the tax cut to $125 billion, a level that would make meeting all the pent-up tax-cutting demands from within the party that much harder.
In one sign of how Republicans will deal with the bind, Mr. Archer said today that his proposal would limit the per-child credit to children 17 and under, compared with 18 in an earlier proposal by Senate Republicans and under a Republican bill vetoed by President Clinton two years ago.
Nowhere will the tradeoffs for Republicans be more difficult than in balancing the call for a big family tax credit, the top goal of the religious right and other social conservatives who have provided much of the growth in the party's electoral base over the last 20 years, against calls for a deep reduction in the capital gains tax, the primary objective of the Wall Street wing and the supply-side economists who reshaped the party's thinking in the early 80's.
The social conservatives have been pressing for a $500 credit for each child younger than 18 for families with incomes up to $110,000. The proposal would cost $105 billion over five years, or more than three-quarters of the sum available for tax cuts.
For the "pro-growth" economic wing, the goal is cutting the top rate for capital gains, to 19.8 percent from its current 28 percent, while allowing investors to factor out the effects of inflation in calculating increases in the value of stocks, bonds, real estate and other assets. Such a change would cost an additional $30 billion or so over five years.
Together, the child credit and the capital gains cut would take up nearly the entire tax cut. But in addition to Mr. Clinton's insistence on $35 billion for college tax breaks, Republicans have pledged other tax cuts, including a reduction in inheritance taxes and an expansion of tax-free deposits or withdrawals from Individual Retirement Accounts.
Over all, the Republicans are $100 billion short of what they need to meet all the tax-cutting demands over five years.
Most Republicans in Congress pledge fealty to both the social and economic conservatives, and there is no open rift between the camps on Capitol Hill. Still, although groups like the House members who were first elected in 1994 are adamant about passing the child credit, many Republicans on the tax-writing committees acknowledge privately that there is little long-term benefit to the economy in the proposal.
But they said the political appeal of the proposal was so strong -- and the interest groups backing it so powerful -- that there is no gain to them in opposing it.
Mr. Clinton has long backed a scaled-down version of the child credit, which is also supported by traditional Democratic constituencies like organized labor.
Republicans said they were quite likely in the end to scale back the child credit and the capital gains cut more or less equally in an effort to insure that neither camp felt slighted. But the Republicans said the continuing jockeying for advantage would help shape the party's long-term priorities.
"This is incredibly important for the Republican Party," said Gary Bauer, director of the Family Research Council, a powerful conservative lobbying group that champions the child credit.
"Somewhere along the line, the party has got to decide whether it believes American wealth is essentially made up of things -- machinery, stock and all the rest -- or whether American wealth is essentially human capital, its people," Mr. Bauer said. "I believe it's human capital, and I believe the party of Lincoln and Reagan ought to be taking the lead on that argument."
Mr. Bauer said that he would be willing to compromise by lowering the income ceiling for families' eligibility but that he would otherwise continue to press for as much as possible to be spent on the credit.
Economic conservatives argue that the child tax credit has no economic justification, because it simply rewards people for having children. They say that reducing the capital gains rate would spur savings and investment, promoting growth and prosperity by improving productivity and creating jobs.
"My argument would be that you need capital gains tax relief for economic growth and a healthy social environment," said Mark A. Bloomfield, president of the American Council on Capital Formation, a business-backed lobbying group.

HEADLINE: Liberty, Equality, Bon Appetit

BYLINE: By Diane Johnson; Diane Johnson, who divides her time between Paris and San Francisco, is the author of "Le Divorce."

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
The French paradox used to refer to the way French people eat delicious high-cholesterol food yet stay thin and have fewer heart attacks, while Americans glumly pick at healthful carbs and keep getting fatter. After last Sunday's elections, "French paradox" could refer to French theories of economics. The new Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, promises to address the future by retaining the indulgent social policies of the "past," and to reduce the deficit by shortening the workweek to 35 hours and raising the minimum wage.
All this drives Americans mad, of course. Remember how people used to mutter about high suicide rates in Sweden's welfare state, puritanically implying cause and effect? Americans are always being told it is inevitable that we move on to the mean, lean, downsized world of the future, with the unfit dropping by the way. 
 But the defeat of John Major's Government in Britain and Jacques Chirac's conservative coalition in France came when voters were given a choice, often very specific, between an American economic model and conception of society and what seemed the rather old-fashioned lefty social protections people were used to. Their answer was "No" to American-style capitalism, and to the violent, deteriorating societies they think it produces. Is there a message here for us?
One reason we are confused by the paradoxical refusal of the French to subscribe to what we have felt to be an inevitable economic model is that we have allowed our economics to be tangled up with our (Judeo-Protestant?) ideas of morality. We are a self-righteous, moralistic nation. It's "right" to work hard. Gain is "good." The idle do not "deserve" handouts. We are never pragmatic, and often adopt social policies that are neither efficient nor humane because, given a choice, we would rather be right than safe or comfortable.
The French don't seem to have this moralism problem. They are good at managing paradox. Maybe it comes from their form of rather self-indulgent Roman Catholicism, which allows them to confess and continue, and pays little attention to restrictive rules about divorce or contraception, for example, but does seem to take seriously notions of humanity and brotherhood.
And beyond, or in spite of, religion, they seem to have the idea that life should be pleasant. Everyone should have five or six weeks of vacation. Babies stay in the hospital for a week or more to give mother and child a good start. Working mothers have day care. Early retirement for people who work at hard jobs (and those who don't) is supported -- despite inconvenient strikes by the people who are asking to quit at age 50 or 55 with generous pensions.
A Jospin supporter was quoted during a campaign rally as saying, "people have a right to a little Utopianism nowadays," meaning they've earned it after the hardships of the Government's feeble attempts at belt-tightening. Those efforts were never convincing, and never explained. Will the French eventually have, as we say, to pay the piper?
Certain things about France may not suit us. A French citizen accepts a certain measure of conformity to achieve social harmony. Diversity is not particularly admired -- they attempt to be inclusive by treating each person, whether from Mali or Morocco, as French.
We, in our fashion, can jeer at utopianism, but the French have managed their high-cholesterol utopia rather well up to now, as their superb infrastructure of trains and metros, their Vuittons and Chanels, their sumptuous museums and low crime rate attest. We could do well to look at their successes instead of, Protestant nation that we are, gloomily contemplating hell.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Philippe Lardy)

HEADLINE: Timor Rebels Widen Attacks on Indonesia Rule

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DILI, Indonesia, June 7

 BODY:
A truck carrying 26 policemen and soldiers braked ahead of a bend on a lonely highway. Guerrillas in the bushes threw a grenade and opened gunfire, killing 17 of them.
The ambush was the climax of a week of rebel attacks that seemed to signal a new phase in the secessionist campaign of East Timor. 
 For more than 20 years, a small band of separatists has fought Indonesian rule. Usually they stayed in the rugged mountains of the interior, taking shots at passing army patrols or committing sabotage.
But the cat-and-mouse tactics stopped in late May with a string of daring attacks that killed as many as 42 soldiers, police officers, civilians and separatists.
Some guerrillas stormed a remote military outpost. Others briefly overran a police station in Dili, the provincial capital. After stabbing officers inside, they picked up police rifles and fired at soldiers before being killed or captured.
Polling stations were also burned before the parliamentary elections on May 29. As many as nine civilians accused of cooperating with the authorities were slain by rebels.
After six days of raids, the guerrillas then returned to the hills.
"This is a very blatant act of terrorism," Foreign Minister Ali Alatas said on Friday in Jakarta, the national capital. He maintains that most East Timorese want to be citizens of Indonesia, which has poured millions of dollars into economic development after long neglect by Portuguese colonialists.
The police said they had arrested 130 suspects after foreign journalists were barred from the province this week. Human rights groups voiced fears that the army would inflict heavy reprisals on civilians.
Military officials maintained that all suspects were being well treated. They and the Foreign Minister concede that rights abuses have occurred in the past but argue that such cases often have been exaggerated by opponents of Indonesian rule.
On Friday, Mr. Alatas announced that his country had canceled a deal to buy nine F-16 fighter jets from the United States after repeated condemnation of Indonesia's human rights record in Congress.
Until the latest wave of attacks, the military maintained that only 80 separatist fighters operated in the hills. Supporters now say there are 10 times that many.
One opponent of Indonesian rule is Bishop Carlos Ximenes Belo, who shared the 1996 Nobel Peace Prize for speaking out on behalf of East Timor's majority Roman Catholic population. About 90 percent of the rest of Indonesia is Muslim.
The Bishop has charged the Indonesian authorities with torture, beatings, arbitrary arrests and political disappearances of Timorese.
Jose Ramos-Horta, an exiled separatist leader who was awarded the peace prize with Bishop Belo, said the guerrilla attacks, particularly on civilians viewed as collaborators, underscored the need for peace talks.
Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations plans to convene talks this month between Mr. Alatas and Portugal's Foreign Minister, Jaime Gama. The two sides have often met before with no result.

HEADLINE: New Housing Is Approved For Brooklyn

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
In an effort to help reduce both an acute housing shortage and long-running tensions between Hispanic and Hasidic residents of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the Giuliani administration has approved a $25 million plan to generate scores of new housing units in the area.
Under the plan, 82 affordable two-family houses would be built in the Hispanic part of the neighborhood, while Hasidic residents would be allowed to convert old manufacturing buildings into condominiums. 
 The plan, which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani could announce as early as today, would seek to end a stalemate on the future of housing in the overcrowded, often emotionally volatile neighborhood. It also has political benefits for the Mayor in an election year, perhaps enhancing his efforts to win support from Hispanic voters and solidifying his standing among the politically potent Hasidim.
Construction of the new houses is to begin on land the city has taken as part of an urban renewal effort. The plan designates Los Sures, a Latino neighborhood organization, as the sole sponsor of the project, and will seek to allow residents with incomes as low as $20,000 to buy the houses. The plan calls for a $5 million capital investment, and $15 million or more in loans and other subsidies.
The zoning revisions amount to a major achievement for the Hasidim, who are desperate for housing and whose forays into traditionally Latino sections of the neighborhood have provoked concern and protests. The plan would allow the Hasidim to develop as many as 1,600 market-rate condominiums in old manufacturing sites along Flushing Avenue and in a portion of the neighborhood known as the Broadway Triangle.
As part of the plan, the Mayor will also announce a $3 million effort to expand day care for Latino residents, many of whom are being moved into workfare programs for welfare recipients. City Hall has committed to build a day care center in the Southside section of Williamsburg. The center, which will serve as many as 180 children, will be run by Nuestros Ninos, a highly regarded day care provider in Southside.
