HEADLINE: For Main Suspect in Teacher's Slaying, an Unfocused Life, Marked by Crime

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
When their lives first intersected at a high school in the Bronx four years ago, Jonathan M. Levin was a graduate student working as a substitute English teacher and Corey Arthur was a restless 15-year-old in his class, a marijuana-smoking rapper who had committed a robbery and was sliding into deeper trouble.
Over the 1993-94 school year, the young man was a chronic truant. By spring, his arrests had begun -- for heroin possession in April, for cocaine possession in June and July. By September, he had been convicted, sentenced to one to three years and, instead of being imprisoned, was sent to an upstate boot camp for young first offenders. 
 During the next seven months at the Lakeview Shock Incarceration Facility near Brocton, N.Y., he faced a hard discipline he had never known -- exhausting 16-hour days, razor wire fences, bugles before dawn, exercises and forced marches under bellowing drill instructors, as well as drug treatment and group therapy.
He emerged in the spring of 1995, a 17-year-old with an apparent resolve to straighten out his life. Though expelled from William Howard Taft High School for his felony conviction, he earned an equivalency diploma and enrolled in a remedial program at Bronx Community College. But the dream quickly faded: he dropped out after a semester, unable to pay tuition, and began to drift again.
Acquaintances said he became an aspiring rapper, styling himself "Big C," and said he sometimes performed in Manhattan clubs. But there is no record that he had any regular work. His family in the Bronx rarely saw him after he moved in with a girlfriend in Brooklyn last winter, and he spent his days hanging out in Harlem and Bedford-Stuyvesant, sidewalk-rapping, playing pickup basketball, sometimes getting high with friends.
Kabar Allah, 32, of Bedford-Stuyvesant, said that several times in the last year he had smoked marijuana with Mr. Arthur, and that Mr. Arthur had spoken of mugging people.
"The only thing he talked about was getting money -- any way he could get money," Mr. Allah said. "He always wanted to have money but never wanted to get a job. His M.O. was to stick black people up or whoever he can."
While the last four years had been a roller coaster for Mr. Arthur, Jonathan Levin, the 31-year-old son of Gerald M. Levin, chairman and chief executive of Time Warner, had achieved many of his goals. He had earned a master's degree at New York University, become a full-time teacher at Taft and won the respect of scores of students, for whom he was a down-to-earth mentor who understood their problems and gave them dinners, outings and kindness.
"He was more like a friend than a teacher," said Henry Bautista, 19, a Taft senior who was in Mr. Levin's English class in the 1994-95 school year. He recalled that Mr. Levin brought a radio to class to play rap music, rapped himself and talked knowledgeably about sports and other subjects of interest to students, but rarely about himself.
It was unclear yesterday what relationship, if any, Mr. Levin and Mr. Arthur had in the classroom or beyond the year in which they were teacher and student. Mr. Levin's willingness to help troubled students may have brought them into proximity, and Mr. Arthur's mother recalled having met Mr. Levin once.
Somehow, in ways and for reasons that were still unknown yesterday, Mr. Arthur's life intersected again recently with that of his former English teacher. And last Friday, the police believe, Mr. Arthur, now 19, called Mr. Levin and went to his small apartment at 205 Columbus Avenue, near 69th Street. There was no forced entry, suggesting that Mr. Levin admitted his visitor.
In the cluttered apartment, investigators said, Mr. Levin was bound with duct tape, tortured with a knife to get his bank card number and killed with a single shot to the head. The bank card was used to take $800 from the victim's bank account at a nearby automatic teller machine about the time of the murder. A surveillance camera picture was too fuzzy to identify the person who withdrew the money.
But later, the investigators said, Mr. Arthur became the focus of suspicion: his fingerprints were found on the duct tape used to bind the victim, and Mr. Arthur had tried to use a credit card that had been stolen from Mr. Levin.
With his picture on file -- a prominent scar high on the forehead -- Mr. Arthur became the object of one of the city's most intense manhunts of recent years, with stakeouts at seven locations he frequented and teams of detectives talking to scores of people who might know his whereabouts. He was taken into custody yesterday in Bedford-Stuyvesant.
Mr. Arthur's family -- his mother, Penny Bostick, and his half-siblings, Christopher, 13, and Crystal, 5 -- had no comment. On Thursday, Mrs. Bostick said that her son knew Mr. Levin and that she had met the teacher once. She admitted that her son had been in "teen-age kind of trouble," but said she believed he was not capable of torture and murder.
Neighbors at 800 Grand Concourse, a Bronx garden-apartment cooperative where the family has lived since 1993 and where Mr. Arthur lived until moving to Brooklyn about six months ago, concurred with the mother, calling him a polite youth who sometimes bought burgers and fries for homeless people in the area.
"I don't think Corey's capable of doing something like that," a 35-year-old neighbor who identified himself only as Jimmy said before Mr. Arthur's arrest. "They're treating him like he's already guilty. They shouldn't jump to any conclusions."
Corey Arthur, or Arthur Corey as he sometimes called himself, was born in New York on Dec. 18, 1977. Little is known of his early life. A family friend said he was raised by his mother and a grandmother, but little could be learned about his father, who died about a month ago, or his stepfather. From 1988 to 1992, the family lived at 2 Arlington Avenue in Brooklyn, just south of the cemeteries of Cypress Hills.
The youth enrolled at Franklin K. Lane High School in Queens. His academic record was not available, but the investigation of his background revealed that in October 1992, when he was 14, he was taken into custody by the authorities and suspended from school for robbing a student. He was given juvenile offender status, and the case records were closed.
In July 1993, the family moved to the Grand Concourse in the Bronx. Mr. Arthur enrolled at Taft the following September and was assigned to courses that included Mr. Levin's English class. Although his academic record was not available, school officials said he was a chronic truant over the ensuing school year.
Acquaintances from his old neighborhood, near the Bronx Borough Hall, said Mr. Arthur regularly smoked marijuana, like many students at Taft, and was captivated by rap, not least because of a connection to a well-known promoter of rap, Sean (Puff Daddy) Combs, the chief executive of Bad Boy Entertainment. Mr. Arthur was said to be either a friend or a cousin.
By the end of the school year, the truant had begun to run afoul of the law in more serious ways. On April 28, 1994, he was arrested and charged with possession of seven glassine envelopes of heroin. On June 17, he was arrested for possessing 200 vials of crack cocaine, an amount sufficient to warrant a presumption under the law that he intended to sell them. On July 19, he was arrested on a cocaine possession charge.
In August, the three arrests were consolidated and he pleaded guilty to one count of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the third degree, a Class B felony. Although sentenced to one to three years, he was allowed the option of going to the Lakeview boot camp.
He entered the camp on Sept. 7, 1994, and was released on parole on April 6, 1995. During that time, he was formally expelled from Taft because of his felony conviction.
But the rigors of the paramilitary life apparently instilled a resolve in Mr. Arthur to straighten out his life, for he quickly enrolled in a study program for dropouts and by June had taken and passed a test for a high school equivalency diploma.
In September, he enrolled at Bronx Community College, which is open to anyone with a high school diploma. He took remedial English and math, a required orientation and career development course, health studies and physical education. School records show that he left before the end of his first semester and owed part of his tuition.
On Nov. 28, while attending the community college, Mr. Arthur was arrested for jumping a turnstile at a subway station in the Bronx. He pleaded guilty to the misdemeanor in Bronx Criminal Court on Feb. 13, 1996, and was given a conditional discharge, meaning that the charge would be dropped if he stayed out of trouble for a year.
Out of school again and unemployed, Mr. Arthur spent his days on the streets of the Bronx, Bedford-Stuyvesant and Harlem, rapping and playing basketball, according to teen-agers who know him. Some said he used a connection with Sean Combs to get rap gigs at Manhattan nightclubs, including the Tunnel and the Latin Quarter. But lawyers for those clubs said there were no records of his employment.
Jamel Blackwell, 15, who said he played schoolyard basketball with Mr. Arthur, recalled an incident several months ago in which they were walking together near Yankee Stadium when another teen-ager tried to mug Mr. Arthur and steal his sneakers. He said Mr. Arthur fought the would-be mugger and drove him off.
Mike Gonzalez, 16, said Mr. Arthur got him a ticket to Black Expo, a rap festival, last October, and said he found it hard to believe such a person would commit a brutal murder.
"He was the quiet type, minding his own business," Mr. Gonzalez said. "He never bothered anybody."

HEADLINE: On the Internet, Term Papers Are Hot Items

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

 BODY:
When Bill Clinton vowed that every 12-year-old in America would be able to log on to the Internet, he probably did not have in mind logging on to the Evil House of Cheat or Cheater.com to download term papers on "Hamlet," Crazy Horse or Mayan architecture.
But many educators are increasingly alarmed or furious about the spread of dozens of Web sites offering such illicit help. They include traditional term-paper mills and guerrilla operations set up by college students in their dormitories, altogether offering tens of thousands of term papers that can easily be downloaded and turned in by students as their own work. 
 It is not clear how many students actually submit, under their own names, papers that have been obtained from the Internet. But the spread of the term-paper sites highlights a problem that has many educators veering between optimism about the Internet, seeing it as a scholar's dream of access to unlimited information, and concern that it has become a slacker's paradise of free computer games, pornography and term papers.
"A lot of people download papers and just change the names," said Samantha Brenner, a 17-year-old junior at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan. "There aren't a lot of original papers that get written anymore. I just think it's the latest way to be lazy."
Many students say that their peers are more likely to use the papers for ideas than to submit them outright and that the fear of getting caught makes the on-line papers more a diversion than an invitation to wide-scale plagiarism. But the flood of information to be used or abused at sites with hundreds of thousands of viewers explains the ambivalence many educators feel these days toward the ubiquity of the Internet in academic culture.
"Sometimes the Internet is the library and sometimes it's the mall, and though I love big metaphors, I haven't found one for the Web," said Tom Rocklin, director of the Center for Teaching at the University of Iowa, who has written a paper about the on-line term-paper sites. "It seems to be too many things at once to get into a metaphor.
"I know some faculty members think there's a real evil genie out there. I don't see a reason to panic, but it's definitely made something that's been out there in the past much easier to do."
It does not take an Internet wizard to find term papers on the net. Typing in "term papers" on any of the big search engines immediately brings up long lists of sites that sell or give away term papers or write them to order.
Whether it is "Post-Modern Ethnography," "Aphasia and the Acquisition of Syntax," "Theme and Image of Women in Dante, Petrarch, Boccaccio and Rabelais" or "Prenatal Care: A Cost-Benefit Analysis," papers on almost any subject are available for free or for sale on the Internet.
Sales of term papers are not new. Companies who do research have advertised on campuses and in publications like Rolling Stone for years. And every university has stories of fraternity-house filing cabinets stuffed with term papers.
What is new is the number of places where papers are available, the ease with which they can be obtained and the often brazen ways that do-it-yourself Internet sites now flaunt the ability to cheat and plagiarize electronically.
Most established for-profit sites include elaborate disclaimers, saying that the information can be used for research purposes but not submitted as a student's own work, though purchasers often have other intentions. It is illegal in most states to sell papers with the expectation that they will be handed in as students' work.
But many less professional sites are far less circumspect.
"So what time is it?" the Cheat Factory site reads. "When is that assignment due? When did you get the assignment? Oh well, what can we say, check out our files and take whatever you wish!"
Salvatore Ciampa, a 21-year-old student at York University in Toronto, who set up his fledgling site and does not charge for papers, said he did not have time to put on his site all the papers coming his way and had no problem with students' choosing to use the papers as their own.
"I guess I just like the attention," said Mr. Ciampa, who said he was changing his major from economics to mass communication.
It is clear that at least some of the papers are finding their ways into classrooms as original papers.
Anthony Krier, a reference librarian at Franklin Pierce College in Rindge, N.H., said he had received more than 500 requests from teachers and deans, worried about plagiarism, for a list he had put together identifying about 50 Internet sites that offer term papers.
About 25 inquiries, he said, have come from teachers and professors who had already caught students using on-line papers under their own names. A handful of the requests for his list, Mr. Krier said, came from students, apparently seeking access to the sites for improper purposes.
"This seems to be snowballing," said Mr. Krier, who said that he now found twice as many sites as he did when he first looked in January.
Often, the commercial sites charge $6 to $10 a page. Compounding the problem is the number of papers that are posted on academic or personal home pages.
Dorian Berger, who just finished his freshman year at Harvard University, said he had posted a number of his papers on the Internet so they could be read by more people. He said it soon become clear that his site had become a favorite of students trawling for good reports to copy or lift material from.
"I am now getting E-mails from people from around the world asking for papers on every conceivable topic," Mr. Berger said, whose papers include "Confucianism and the Rise of Industrialism in East Asia" and "Darkness in Shakespeare's Macbeth." "I feel that I am some type of multinational cheating company when all I wanted to do was offer my papers as research information to people on the Internet."
While some educators are alarmed, many say the benefits of the Internet far outweigh the limitations.
Bruce Leland, an English professor who is director of writing at Western Illinois University, said the sites were a challenge to professors to do their jobs better. He said teachers were unlikely to be fooled if they tailored assignments to work done in class, monitored the students' progress -- from outline to completion -- and were alert to papers that were radical departures from a student's past work.
"I don't want this to be yet another reason for people to say, 'Yes, the Internet is something evil that's corrupting our youth,' " Professor Leland said. He added that many on-line papers were so bad that no one was likely to benefit from them.
"Everyone who is mortal has at least one flaw," begins one less-than-A-quality paper on "Macbeth." "Some are more serious than others. For example, some people have addictions to gambling, while other people can't remember to put the milk away after they use it. After a while, though, a person's flaws come back to haunt them. The tragedy 'Macbeth' is no exception to this."
Still, the term-paper sites are a reminder that the Internet is far more of a mixed blessing than it sometimes appears to politicians.
"If this is the information superhighway," said Mr. Berger, the Harvard student, "it's going through a lot of bad, bad neighborhoods."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A CLOSER LOOK: Internet Access to Term Papers"
There has been an explosion of Web sites that distribute and, in some cases, sell term papers for legitimate or illegitimate use. The sites allow users to view and use other people's research. Some condone plagiarism and others condemn it. Here are two examples.

HEADLINE: ON HOCKEY;
A City's Spirit Roars Back With the Red Wings

BYLINE: By Joe Lapointe

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
In front of the City-County Building is an enormous statue officially called "The Spirit of Detroit" and colloquially known as "The Jolly Green Giant." These days, he wears a size 360 Red Wings hockey jersey with its emblem of a winged wheel.
The residents of Hockeytown wear smaller jerseys to pose in front of him for photographs. At his feet is a broom dyed red to symbolize the four-game sweep of the Stanley Cup finals, which ended last night with a 2-1 Red Wings victory over Philadelphia in Joe Louis Arena. 
 When Commissioner Gary Bettman presented the Stanley Cup to captain Steve Yzerman after the game, he made a short, pointed speech about the "mystique and tradition of the Detroit Red Wings."
"This is Hockeytown!" Bettman said.
After the ceremonial procession, the red-clad fans streamed out of the arena to begin a long night of celebration in the downtown district.
 Some headed toward the Spirit statue. All week long, it has been the focus of Detroit's hockey Woodstock atmosphere as the community celebrates its first drink from the cup since 1955.
From this spot on Friday afternoon, the fans could hear the music of a free rock concert across Jefferson Avenue at Woodward Avenue.
If they followed the sound past the big fist sculpture, the Joe Louis monument, to Hart Plaza, they could see and hear Mitch Ryder's band playing under the warm sunshine in the cool breeze off the Detroit River that separates the city from Canada.
Ryder, the lead singer of the Detroit Wheels in the 1960's, added a special number to his repertory of hits like "Devil With a Blue Dress On." The extra tune was the theme from "Rocky," the Sylvester Stallone film about a Philadelphia boxer.
"We want to make our Philadelphia guests feel welcome," Ryder told his cheering audience. "Nothing wrong with the Flyers. They're just in the wrong place at the wrong time."
Many Detroiters get a sense of civic self-esteem from their sports teams, although the moniker Hockeytown -- painted over center ice at the arena -- isn't yet as well known as Motor City or Motown.
"We tend to manifest our national image through our sports teams," Ryder said between sets. "Detroit is a working-class community. It's a one-trick pony. If it wasn't for the car industry, we wouldn't have the city. We'd still be fur trappers, speaking French."
That reference was a tribute to those who founded Detroit almost three centuries ago. The Wings are one of the National Hockey League's oldest teams, established during the Roaring 20's, when Henry Ford and other automobile pioneers were building a boom town. The current hockey success is just one example of a sports and municipal renaissance during a relatively flush economic cycle.
Construction of new stadiums for the Tigers and Lions, both downtown, is expected to begin this year. The Renaissance Center, an architectural monstrosity built on the riverfront 20 years ago, is being taken over by General Motors, which might give the place the focus and purpose it has lacked.
Although much of downtown and the central city remains blighted and abandoned, the unemployment rate is down, the crime rate is down, car sales are up and property values are rising.
In terms of hockey, the region is a mecca. Aside from the Wings, the Detroit area includes teams from two of the four major college leagues, a top team of the minor International Hockey League, two major junior teams from the Ontario Hockey League, a newly established permanent training facility for Team U.S.A.'s top junior players, two dozen local boys who have made it to the N.H.L. and a peculiar consciousness smuggled over the airwaves from neighboring Canada.
It can be heard on local sports-talk radio, which constantly plays a scratchy recording of the late Foster Hewitt greeting his radio listeners on "Hockey Night in Canada" with the words: "Hello, Canada and hockey fans in the United States and in Newfoundland and a special big hello to Canadian servicemen overseas."
The downside to the mood yesterday was anxiety over the inevitable celebration. When the Tigers won the World Series in 1984, the celebrators overturned and torched a police car outside the ball park, leaving a distinct, negative impression. When the Pistons won their second straight National Basketball Association championship in 1990, seven people were killed and many others were seriously injured.
Thirty years ago, five days of race-based rioting left 43 people dead and hundreds of buildings burned, creating a downward spiral that lasted for a generation.
Detroiters of a certain age, like Ryder, remember the mood here just before that riot: an upbeat city making Mustangs and muscle cars. Back then, the Wings were regularly in the cup finals and the Supremes and the Temptations were rolling hit after hit off Berry Gordy Jr.'s assembly line.
It was an optimistic place. Back then, as now, the motto on the city seal, carved into the wall behind "The Spirit of Detroit," read "Speramus Meliora" and "Resurget Cineribus." The words mean "We Hope for Better Things" and "It Shall Rise Again From the Ashes."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sergei Federov hoisting the Stanley Cup, won by the Red Wings for the first time since 1955. (Reuters)

SECTION: Section 5; Page 10; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2771 words

HEADLINE: WEEKEND GETAWAYS;
Washington, for Grown-Ups

BYLINE: By JAN BENZEL; JAN BENZEL is the deputy editor of the Travel section.

 BODY:
THERE'S something dreamlike about returning as a visitor to a city in which you once lived: both you and the city are the same, but changed. I was feeling somewhat spectral on a recent spring weekend, driving into Washington, where, young and single, I'd had a permanent address.
I snapped out of it at the first traffic circle. When Pierre L'Enfant created a plan for the city in 1791, he envisioned a Federal showplace with grand avenues sweeping across the orderly perpendicular numbered and lettered streets. Circles would mark the big crossroads, where monuments could be erected as occasion arose. 
 Driver panic can also arise. Not to mention passenger panic, evident in my husband, Stu, who had lived there once, too, but who didn't remember enough to navigate. Still, Washington operates at a hospitable pace, and we soon found our way in and out of the counterclockwise swirls. And we instantly became tourists, brandishing maps and flipping through guidebooks. A rare weekend away was no time to be proud.
It was raining, but no matter; we'd done indoor-outdoor contingency planning. We were staying at the Four Seasons in Georgetown, where we could ditch the car. The building, planned originally as a Holiday Inn, is not as grand as downtown hotels like the Willard and the Hay-Adams, but it fit my requirements: a king-size bed and a health club. If the drizzle persisted, we could pace on the treadmills, swim in the lap pool and bake in the sauna. If the sun came out, we would run in Rock Creek Park or on the towpath along the C&O Canal. Although the Metro, Washington's clean, quiet, cathedral-like subway, does not stop in Georgetown, the museums and restaurants we wanted to visit were all a quick walk or cab ride away. With our small daughters bunking at their cousins' for the weekend, we'd have no one's shoes to tie but our own. All the sleep, art and exercise we could manage were tantalizingly within reach.
Before checking in, we stopped at the Kreeger Museum. Opened to the public in 1994, the museum is the former home of David Lloyd Kreeger, an insurance company lawyer and lover of the arts who had a big hand in making Washington a cultural capital. Among his passions were post-Impressionist and Expressionist paintings, sculpture and African art, and he persuaded Philip Johnson to design the house as a livable showcase for his collection. The domed house was finished in 1967.
Built of soft travertine stone and glass walls, it sits discreetly on Foxhall Road, west of Georgetown, in one of Washington's most elegant residential areas. We'd reserved spots on one of the two daily tours, and our guide told us that Mr. Kreeger had requested that the walls be covered with carpeting so he could pad around the house at night, rearranging his Monets and Picassos: the carpet wouldn't show the nail holes.
The collection includes some atypical works: a representational Mondrian, of a dying sunflower in shades of blue and peach; a Gauguin pastel of his children looking sad after he took off for Tahiti. A couple of traditional African figures, a man and woman, were supposedly intended to help spouses get along with each other. The art is mostly intimate, the kinds of things you'd want to have around the house. Rodin sculptures no more than a foot and a half high were scattered about; on one table was an endearing Brancusi, the bronze head of a sleeping child, whose weight you could imagine perfectly in the palm of your hand. A Calder floated in a foyer.
The dining room (Mrs. Kreeger's favorite) is lined with Monets, including a Giverny scene in deep blues, and we gazed through the glass wall at the sculpture court, populated with voluptuous pieces by Noguchi and Henry Moore, among others. Just below, raindrops rippled a turquoise swimming pool.
I had requested a room at the hotel with a view of Rock Creek Park, only to realize as we began to unpack that there was more parkway than park out the window, and an incessant hum of traffic. Could we possibly switch rooms? But of course.
We were whisked to Room 446, furnished with a yellow and blue pheasant-bedecked spread and curtains and reproduction armoire and writing table. The room wasn't big but pleasant and much quieter; it looked out over a courtyard. I was won over by the tiny book light on the bedside table, a marriage-preserving appliance for late-night readers like me. In the bathroom, thick terry robes hung on the door and a phone on the wall; a fresh orchid bloomed by the sink and the mirror turned out to be steamproof.
After tea and a scone (good but when the bill came to $12, I decided we'd be eating elsewhere for the weekend) in the greenery-filled terrace room, I headed out for a walk on the brick sidewalks of Georgetown, leaving Stu to plug in his laptop at the dataport in our room. The sun had emerged, as had a cheery Friday happy-hour crowd, which spilled out of the restaurants and bars along M Street and Wisconsin Avenue. I passed the pre-Revolutionary Old Stone House, a carpenter's home in Colonial days. Finished in 1766 and now a National Park site, it is flanked by a lovely garden and fronted with a white picket fence.
For dinner, we met our friend Jackie at Vidalia, a warm, lively downtown restaurant with an emphasis on American cooking and wines. Crab cakes, peppery lamb, asparagus wrapped in phyllo with a deliciously smoky prosciutto-flecked sauce and focaccia topped with carmelized onions were all terrific. The lemon chess pie, which Jackie wisely ordered, made me want to move back to Washington immediately.
Saturday dawned clear and cool. La Madeleine, a bake shop and restaurant a few doors down on M Street, with irresistible breads and great coffee, offered an inexpensive alternative to the hotel breakfast (we also discovered that there was good coffee and fruit free all day at the health club; I spotted others in the corridors who had fetched breakfasts there.).
A run on the bike path through Rock Creek Park led us to a back entrance of the National Zoo. Like many attractions in Washington, it is free, so you can drop in even if you've only got a few minutes. We went to pay our respects to Hsing-Hsing, one of the two giant pandas China gave the United States in 1972 after President Nixon's visit; their attempts to reproduce were followed with as much interest as those of Charles and Diana. Ling-Ling, his female companion, died a few years back, and so Hsing-Hsing roamed his sprawling compound alone, waiting for his bamboo breakfast. The California sea lions hadn't been fed yet either; one lazily amused himself, gliding upside down underwater, eyes closed.
Most fun were the orangutans, for whom a Seussian structure of posts and cables has been constructed from their habitat to an orangutan institute across the way called the Think Tank, where their communications skills are being studied. While zoogoers craned their necks, the hairy creatures climbed along the cables, big melon bellies hanging out.
A top-hatted doorman greeted us back at the Four Seasons. "Ah, you've been running!" he exclaimed, and opened a shiny brass compartment by his station. "Water?" he offered, producing two bottles. "A cool cloth?" He held out a small tray of rolled white washcloths. Just like home.
We had to hurry to get to the big Picasso show in the East Building of the National Gallery. We joined a no-elbow-room crowd in I. M. Pei's soaring pink Tennessee marble building, gathered for the survey of Picasso's accomplishments before he turned 26. The audio tour provided insulation from the other viewers and plenty of information about Picasso's studies, friends and lovers, and the work gave us an idea of how his skill, style and emotional depth developed. By the time he was 20, his friend Carles Casagemas had committed suicide, a loss reflected in his Blue Period paintings; a few galleries later, the more hopeful harlequins of the Rose Period begin to appear, from a time when Picasso reconnected with his friends and fell in love with the earthy Fernande Olivier.
We rested our eyes and museum-weary legs at Pesce, an unassuming restaurant and fish market near Dupont Circle. Tuna bruschetta was dotted with capers and drizzled with fine olive oil, just right for lunch, and the reasonable wine list had a good selection of French and Italian wines. Dessert was good too, especially a cocoa creme brulee. (I got only a taste, not having had the sense to order that one either.) We stopped at Kramerbooks & Afterwords, decades earlier possibly the first bookstore to have incorporated a cafe, and were glad to see that it still seemed to be thriving, showing off books by big-name Washingtonians like Robert Reich and Katharine Graham.
With rain threatening again, I passed up the rambling gardens at Dumbarton Oaks -- it was too late for the fabulous spring blooms anyway -- and poked my head into the 19th-century mansion. Philip Johnson had been here, too; he'd designed a wing for its pre-Columbian collection, rounded this time, but again with glass walls, giving the place more the feel of an arbor than a museum. In comparison, the music room in the mansion proper is wonderfully over the top, especially its wooden beamed ceiling elaborately painted to copy a 16th-century Loire Valley chateau.
I had only a few minutes left for what has always been my favorite Washington museum, the Phillips Collection. I sped past Renoir's "Luncheon of the Boating Party," Vuillards and Bonnards, Matisses and more Picassos, before the guards looked at their watches and pointed to the door.
For some live entertainment, we were counting on the Capitol Steps, six actors practicing take-no-prisoners political humor at Chelsea's, a packed supper club on the C&O Canal in Georgetown. (Members of the troupe have been performing in New York, but better to see them on their home turf.) The usual suspects came in for a sound drubbing in show tunes and pop hits with cannibalized lyrics: Bill and Hillary (channeling Eleanor Roosevelt and Gandhi) of course, Tipper and Al, Newt, Connie Chung, computer geeks, the N.R.A. and, casting their net internationally and beyond, Netanyahu, Yeltsin and life forms on Mars. The showstoppers, though, were "Lirty Dies," a couple of monologues by a fast-thinking silver-tongued guy who flips the first letters of his words around, making relatively sanitized accounts of sex scandals sound filthy enough to make Howard Stern blush. After hummus and kebabs at Bacchus, a Lebanese spot on a quiet street near Dupont Circle, we briefly considered heading to Adams-Morgan to hear some African music but decided we were too old to stay up any later.
Adams-Morgan, the area just north of Dupont Circle lined with clubs and small restaurants of various ethnicities, is lively in the daytime, too, with people who actually live there out walking and shopping or, in nice weather, sitting on stoops. We had a good, late all-American breakfast at Cashion's Eat Place, a funky-elegant space with a high, unfinished ceiling. I gave dessert one last try and was disappointed again: the berry crisp topped with homemade ice cream was too sweet and gooey, but Alberta Hunter on the sound system was some consolation. Besides, I'd had my dose of hedonism for the day: a rubdown at the fitness club with Art, a chatty masseur with a passion for Frisbee Golf, who did some skillful rearranging of my shoulder blades and relaxed the rest of me with a combination of Swedish and shiatsu maneuvers.
Time was running out, but we headed for one last stop at the recently opened Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial. Picnickers were on the mall, paddleboaters on the Tidal Basin, and after stopping to ask a couple of times we found the entrance, between the Tidal Basin and the Lincoln Memorial.
The photographs I'd seen of the memorial did not do it justice. Unlike the monuments to Jefferson, Lincoln and Washington, the F.D.R. Memorial doesn't announce itself in the Washington skyline. Low to the ground, it demands that you enter it.
That Sunday afternoon, hundreds of people were making their way through the series of outdoor spaces defined by red South Dakota granite walls, alive with cascading waterfalls and small pools. Open to the sky and dotted with shade trees, it is its own park. Four spaces, a guide was explaining to one group, represent Roosevelt's four terms in office. Words from his speeches are carved in bold letters in the stone.
Roosevelt's statue seems small, showing him sitting, draped in a cloak, an ordinary man with his dog Fala by his feet. A woman in a yellow sari posed with her son before the statue, standing solemn and proud. Around the corner was Eleanor, standing, with three tow-headed boys laughing and hanging on her arms. Two teen-age girls had shed their shoes and dabbled their feet in one of the several pools. On the last wall were words from F.D.R.'s 1941 State of the Union Address:
FREEDOM OF SPEECH
FREEDOM OF WORSHIP
FREEDOM FROM WANT
FREEDOM FROM FEAR.
We headed home, refreshed and inspired.

 CORRECTION:
A listing last Sunday with an article about Washington misstated the weekend room rate at the Four Seasons Hotel in Georgetown. It is $260 a night through June 30, with or without the Picture Picasso museum package. The $199 rate for the package is in effect only from July 1 to 27.

PUB-DATE: June 8, 1997

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3066 words

HEADLINE: A Special Issue: How The World Sees Us;
America the Inescapable

BYLINE: By Josef Joffe 

DATELINE: GERMANY

 BODY:
Something funny happened on the way down from the cold war.
 Not so long ago, young Europeans used to burn the American flag. Now they wear it -- like that big brash replica of Old Glory knit into a line of pricey Ralph Lauren sweaters. When hurling rocks at the local American cultural center, these kids used to sport Che Guevara on their chests; today it is "Tommy Hilfiger" and "DKNY." 
 Unconsciously, they might be making more than just a fashion statement -- like the mullah in Teheran who had just completed a two-hour tirade against "Am'rikah" in front of the former United States Embassy on the anniversary of the takeover. Grabbing a Western journalist by the arm, he smiled and said, "We don't really hate you Americans." Drawing close, the crowd that had just been screaming "Death to America" nodded vigorously. And the cleric pulled a pair of Ray-Bans out of his robes, as if to say, "Look, man, I'm cool, too."
 Even the European left, which cut its teeth on the anti-Vietnam and anti-nuke rallies of the 1970's and 1980's, has rediscovered America. Consider, for example, Britain's new Prime Minister, Tony Blair, whose minions were all over the 1996 Democratic convention in Chicago to learn how to run a Clinton-style campaign. A less-inspiring, but still-telling example: Neo-Nazi punks are more likely to taunt German burghers with the extended middle finger -- strictly an American import -- than with the stiff-arm Hitler salute.
 On the verge of the 21st century, the United States isn't just the "last remaining superpower." It is a continent-size "demonstration effect," which is a locution sociologists prefer to value-laden terms like "model." Why this comeback, considering that in decades past, the United States was rather a model to abhor? America stood for capitalism at its cruelest, social and racial injustice, economic failure and cultural decadence. And, of course, for ruthless imperialism masked by self-serving, moralizing cant.
 One explanation is the demise of the Soviet Union and the end of the cold war. While fighting in the trenches of bipolarity, Big Brother remained an unloved benefactor, like a rich but obnoxious relative you can't afford to cross. Washington was always demanding loathsome proofs of fealty from its allies. Don't finance this Soviet gas pipeline. Don't go to the Moscow Olympics. Punish the "evil empire." Take our nuclear missiles.
 Worse, the United States instilled angst. Fearing entrapment in quarrels not their own, Europeans liked to see themselves as hapless victims of American hauteur. If war broke out, Europe would turn into the "shooting gallery of the superpowers." Dependency bred resentment and then aggression -- the unconscious desire to discredit or vilify a troublesome patron who disturbed the peace while purporting to protect it. If the United States could be tainted as a cultural inferior and as the home of Cowboy Imperialism, then no loyalty was due -- that was the subliminal logic of cold-war anti-Americanism.
 Today's conflicts are but a pale copy of the cold-war years: a bit of Helms-Burton, a tit-for-tat on meat imports. Europe, indeed, much of the world, can stand back and take a more relaxed view of Mr. Big. Also, what is the countermodel? As long as the Soviet Union persisted, as long as a flawed dream was still married to great power, socialism served as a realistic utopia to hold up against the perversion of capitalism that was America. Now only North Korea and Cuba clutch the torch -- failed societies whose company even the faithful will not cherish.
 Of course, America was always No. 1, no matter how rich doomsayers like Paul Kennedy became with books like "The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers" 10 years ago. Kennedy and his epigones spawned a school of thought called Declinism. The British historian from Yale and co-declinists like David Calleo ("Beyond American Hegemony") and Walter Russell Mead ("Mortal Splendor") thought that America was like Hapsburg Spain of the 16th and 17th centuries: arrogant, overreaching, oblivious to the fact that military ambitions were outpacing economic resources.
 Apart from ignoring the numbers (Philip II's Spain and Louis XIV's France devoted more than 75 percent of spending to the military, while Washington allocated less than 30 percent), the Declinists fundamentally misunderstood American power. Hapsburg Spain was strong as long as it was rich. A key source of wealth was gold and silver from its Latin American possessions. When that dried up, Hapsburg's muscle shriveled.
 America's wealth is different; it comes not from silver mines but from production and, above all, from relentless adaptation and innovation. If steel falters, let's do microchips; if the Japanese grab the camera market, Hollywood will flood the world with movies. Unlike Hapsburg's, America's riches aren't dug from the ground; they roll out of labs, research outfits and universities. And that is an inexhaustible resource.
 But there is much more. Hapsburg et al. were like the Big Blue of yesterday, when it had a lock on mainframes and not much else. Hapsburg and France had big armies because they were rich and populous. But they were just as vulnerable to the competition as was I.B.M. when the PC age dawned. Britain, though much smaller, could throw many and diverse assets into the balance. It had the better fleets, and it enjoyed the great strategic advantage of insularity. It was backed up by a far-flung trading network, and tapped into the exponential growth unleashed by the Industrial Revolution. Finally, Britain could leverage superb diplomatic skills into alliances that proved the undoing of the Philips.
 With respect to the diversity of power, America is Britain cubed. Think of the United States as a gambler who can play simultaneously at each and every table that matters -- and with more chips than anybody else. Whichever heap you choose, America sits on top of it. It is the largest economy, the fastest-running job machine and, again, the world's biggest exporter; even the dollar, declining since the mid-80's, has been rising against its former twin-nemeses, the German mark and the Japanese yen.
 America's armed forces, though shrinking, are racing into the 21st century while the Russian Army is disintegrating and the Chinese are just beginning to modernize. The Persian Gulf war was a sneak preview, a duel between Saddam's huge but clumsy World War II army and Stormin' Norman's battalions practicing for World War IV. It was cruise missiles against bunkers, laser-guided bombs against dug-in tanks, satellites against spotter planes, radar-fooling bombers against antiaircraft guns, G.P.S. (Global Positioning System) against map and compass.
 While Europeans can't find the money for their "Eurofighter," a new combat plane that will be all-but-obsolete when it enters the inventory, the Pentagon has deployed stealth aircraft against which there is presently no defense. It is testing weapons that can knock out a tank at a hundred miles. Planners are playing with robotics and space-based weaponry as well as with spooky, nonlethal stuff that will immobilize enemy soldiers before they ever get to the FEBA (army-speak for "forward edge of battle").
 To bring it down from the sci-fi level, look at Bosnia. At the beginning, in 1992, the Europeans told the U.S.: "Hands off, this is our war." It was ended (for now) in 1995, when the U.S., grudgingly accepting the responsibility that comes with being No. 1, dispatched a handful of cruise missiles to Pale, the capital of the Bosnian Serbs. The Tomahawks swooped in silently and invisibly, reminding the Serbs' leader, Radovan Karadzic (and his patron in Belgrade, Slobodan Milosevic), that they were suddenly up against a different kind of opponent than the British and the French.
 In global diplomacy, nothing happens unless Washington shakes off its lethargy and grabs the helm. North Korea is above all an East Asian nuisance that should be dealt with by China, Russia and Japan. But only Washington can defang Pyongyang's nuclear ambitions. In the Middle East, the French never get past meddling; only Bill Clinton can knock heads when Israelis and Palestinians overreach.
 Culturally, America's clout is so overwhelming that its oldest ally, France, is once more building Maginot lines -- this time not against German panzers but against American movies and even words. You know you're on a roll when other governments threaten their own citizens with hefty fines for calling a lavage voiture a "car wash." Chances are that French deejays (sorry, make that disque tourneurs) might be fired for playing "Meat Loaf," unless they use the linguistically correct moniker Faux Filet on the French Parade de Frappe.
 The United States as No. 1 and soaring -- that was not supposed to happen. And it may not last. The history books say that Mr. Big always invites his own demise. Nos. 2, 3, 4 will gang up on him, form countervailing alliances and plot his downfall. That happened to Napoleon, as it happened to Louis XIV and the mighty Hapsburgs, to Hitler and to Stalin. Power begets superior counterpower; it's the oldest rule of world politics.
 For now, that rule does not operate. The French would like to take the Americans down a peg or two, but they have a hard time corralling the Germans, Brits and Italians. Actually, these were only too happy when Richard Holbrooke and the Navy's cruise missiles bludgeoned the Serbs to the negotiating table. The Russians and Chinese huddled in Moscow in April and came up with a "strategic partnership" against you know who -- somebody who wants to "push the world toward a unipolar order." It barely made the last page of the news section. What are they going to do? Will Boris Yeltsin go to Beijing for credits, computers and know-how? Will China risk its most important export market?
 There is something anachronistic about such textbook moves. It's like trying to surf the Web with a typewriter. In the old days, power grew out of the barrel of a gun; the more barrels (and men), the better. A nation became great by grabbing territory. By that measure -- population and size -- China, Russia and Canada should rule the roost. But they don't.
 There are two ways to crack this paradox. One is a traditional answer: Only the United States is a truly global power, with global interests and the global wherewithals for intervention. This is why everybody looks
 to Washington when it comes to chastening the Saddams and the Karadzics. But nasty as these fellows are, they do not define the essence, or the bulk, of 21st-century world politics.
 And hence the second, and new, answer. Unlike centuries past, when war was the great arbiter, today the most interesting types of power do not grow out of the barrel of a gun. As the Harvard political scientist Joseph S. Nye Jr., dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, put it, power has become "less coercive and less tangible." He coined the term "soft power" to contrast it with the traditional currency of clout.
The classic way was to force other nations to do what they did not want to do, ultimately by costly war. Today there is a much bigger payoff in "getting others to want what you want," and that has to do with "cultural attraction" and "ideology," with "agenda setting" and holding out big prizes for cooperation, like the vastness and sophistication of the American market. On that gaming table, China, Russia and Japan, even the West Europeans, cannot match the pile of chips held by the United States.
 Are people risking death on the high seas to get into China? How many are willing to go for an M.B.A. at Moscow U.? Imagine a roomful of 14-year-olds -- from Germany, Japan, Israel, Russia and Argentina. Obviously, they would all be wearing Levi's and baseball caps. But how would they relate to one another? They would communicate in English, though haltingly and with heavy accents. About what? The Fugees, Beavis and Butt-head, Ace Ventura, Michael Jordan. They would debate the merits of Nike versus Converse, of Chameleon versus Netscape. Sure, they would not discuss Herman Melville or George Gershwin, but neither would they compare notes on Dante or Thomas Mann. The point is that they would talk about icons and images "made in the U.S.A."
 One has to go back to the Roman Empire for a similar instance of cultural hegemony. Actually, there is no comparison. The cultural sway of Greece and Rome, of France in the age of Louis XIV and Napoleon, of Germany between 1871 and 1933 never reached much beyond the economic and educational elites of the Western world. But America's writ encircles the globe, penetrating all layers of society. Modern mass culture, for better or for worse, is American.
 Nor is it just a matter of McDonald's and MTV. Why would Helmut Kohl, Germany's chancellor-in-perpetuity, send his two sons to Harvard and M.I.T.? The answer is sad and simple. Heidelberg and the Humboldt University of Berlin no longer measure up, though German universities served as the model for the rest of the world in the late 19th century. When Europeans today bemoan the decline of their universities, they look across the Atlantic for ideas. European academics who want to demonstrate class have to publish in the standard-setting American journals. European intellectuals would rather place their articles in the New York Review of Books than in Commentaire (France) or Merkur (Germany) -- just as the hoi polloi would rather watch American movies.
 "The Discovery of America" is the title of a cover article in Capital, the German business monthly. Reporting on a survey of business leaders, the magazine writes: "80 percent say that the future belongs to the American system." The boss of the German Federation of Industry calls the American labor market -- with its flexibility and mobility -- "a model for Germany." Even beyond German boardrooms, words like "downsizing," "restructuring," and "shareholder value" have become household terms.
 The magazine Der Spiegel, a bastion of anti-Americanism in the heady 60's and 70's, writes admiringly about the "Jobwunder in Amerika." The leftish weekly Die Woche grudgingly praises America's work ethic and its willingness to let the markets call the shots. Why? "In 20 years, the U.S. has thus managed the greatest quantum-jump of the industrial age -- from manufacturing into the service and communication society." A lead story in the Swiss magazine Weltwoche proclaims: "America, you are better off." In the magazine Focus, the Labor Minister of Chancellor Kohl's home state writes a column titled: "What We Can Learn From America." Der Stern, another former America-basher, asks: "Is It Better to Study in America?" Subtract a few reflexive swipes and the answer is "yes."
 Why is it suddenly "America the Beautiful?" And how long will it last? Fashions change, Wall Street can go bust, Europe with its 12 percent unemployment rates will eventually restructure. Sometime in the next century, there will be a Russian resurgence, and China's double-digit growth rates will spawn a great military panoply. But it is far harder to foresee a turnaround in the fundamentals of American "soft power."
 China, Russia and Europe are strong in some areas and potentially mighty in others. But their cultures do not "radiate." They do not offer a universal allure -- values and ways of doing things that appeal to the rest of the world. Take Japan. Its consumer electronics have conquered the planet, and its banks are not far behind. O.K., throw in sushi too. But how many people want to dress and live like the Japanese, or send their children to Tokyo University?
 Sure, the United States dominates music and movies in part because American companies control the global distribution networks. But in the 1920's the Germans were the cinematographic pacesetters, as were the French and Italians in the 1950's and 1960's. India produces many more films than does Hollywood, but all the distribution channels in the world couldn't turn Indian movies into global blockbusters.
 One explanation is obvious. America has the world's most open culture, and therefore the world is most open to it. America keeps drawing the world's best and brightest, allowing them to rise to the top within one generation. That makes for a universalist culture with a universal appeal. But there is more. We live in an "American age," meaning that American values and arrangements are most closely in tune with the new Zeitgeist.
 Whether it is the "modes of production" (as Marx called it) or modes of organizing our private lives, traditions are being cracked right and left. The trend is toward individualization, nonhierarchical cooperation and breathless innovation. Creativity rather than order rules. These values have always defined American culture, but today they are shaping Europe and Asia willy-nilly because otherwise they could not keep up.
 In the information age, you cannot afford telephone monopolies that, if they could, would still sell black rotary phones connected by mechanical relays and copper wires. When the premium is on innovation, traditions are out -- and so are production methods that force individuals into the straitjacket of top-down management. Why did Big Mac blanket the world? Not just because culinary abomination is convenient, cheap and timesaving. It also promises a bit of individual freedom, as certified by an angry Hamburg parent: "My kids don't have to be at the dinner table anymore when they can stay out and wolf down a couple of Quarter Pounders."
 Rome and France had to conquer territory before they could conquer minds. America's culture is unique; its power comes from pull, not from push. Even the French will acknowledge that nobody ever used a gun to make people learn English (the American-accented version, of course) or watch Hollywood's latest.
 The great British philosopher John Locke, theorizing about the "state of nature," wrote, "In the beginning all the world was America." Today he might muse, "All the world is becoming like America." That is a nightmare for the guardians of traditional culture round the world. But how can they stop McDonald's and Microsoft, Harvard and Hollywood? By adapting, competing and improving. But isn't that the American way, too?

HEADLINE: A Sense of Entitlement

BYLINE: By Judith Martin; Judith Martin, who writes the Miss Manners syndicated newspaper column, is also a novelist.

 BODY:

RAGE FOR FAME
 The Ascent of Clare Boothe Luce.
 By Sylvia Jukes Morris.
 Illustrated. 561 pp. New York:
 Random House. $30. 
 Reading Sylvia Jukes Morris's "Rage for Fame," the first of a projected two-volume biography of Clare Boothe Luce, is like being on confidential terms with someone who hates her boss. At first, you react with sympathy and astonishment to a barrage of anecdotes about the most selfish schemer who ever lived. But as the stories keep pouring forth without relief, you begin to notice that although some of them illustrate outrageous behavior, others could as easily be interpreted benignly. Finally, all that relentless hammering perversely tempts you to secretly switch your sympathies to the beleaguered villain.
Clare Boothe Luce may have possessed a sense of entitlement that is amazing even by today's standards, but she also had amazing accomplishments. Before she was 40 she had had several first-rate careers -- as managing editor and writer at the original Vanity Fair; as a successful playwright whose best work, "The Women," is still performed; and as a politician who, in her first electoral campaign in 1942, won a seat in the United States House of Representatives. Even when she dabbled in fields in which she did not reach the top -- as actress, athlete, foreign correspondent -- her achievements were impressive.
She was apparently also outspoken and unapologetic. It is she who, through her letters, diaries and old-age reminiscences to Ms. Morris, chiefly supplies the evidence that she was unusually ambitious, promiscuous, cynical and acquisitive. Working some of the same territory as Pamela Churchill Harriman (notably Randolph Churchill, a mere trifle to Luce, who had such other lovers as Bernard Baruch and Joseph Kennedy), she makes that heroine of recent biographies and obituaries seem bashful.
But looks and the love of powerful men cannot deliver the kind of success she kept winning. That took self-education and hard work. Born in 1903, the illegitimate daughter of a ludicrous beauty whose aspirations did not go beyond comfortable (and duplicitous) courtesanship, she pushed herself intellectually and drove herself physically long after acquiring fame and fortune several times over. Beneath this biography's censorious tone there are indications that she was passionate, funny, adventurous, original and ravenously interested in the changing world.
But Ms. Morris, the author of "Edith Kermit Roosevelt: Portrait of a First Lady," will hardly allow her new subject the smallest uncontaminated virtue. Having her girlhood friends as bridesmaids is interpreted as seeming "deliberately to have chosen the plainest and most garishly dressed attendants, to set off her own beauty." Keeping her bedroom neat "betrayed a compulsive, not to say precious tidiness." When she was struck by a sense of mortality at her mother's death and wrote an effusive love letter for her second husband, Henry Luce, to receive if she predeceased him, she was "again casting herself at the center of an imagined drama." Although she endangered her life by rushing to fighting fronts in both Europe and Asia, "her interest in war was not so much journalistic as voyeuristic." It must have been a crowd's ovation that made her realize that she would find "the giant arena she had sought since adolescence" in politics -- not her interest in political philosophy, economics and military strategy dating back to when she was probably the only member of New York's smart set who read The Congressional Record.
A typical analysis is this: "Throughout her life, Clare kept in contact with friends and acquaintances whose horizons were narrower than her own. She needed ego-boosters to support her queenly aspirations, or commiserate with her when her spirits were low. In March 1920, she visited old school friends in Illinois and later that spring had others to stay in Sound Beach, while she tried out, unsuccessfully, for the U.S. Olympic swimming team. Beguiled by her beauty, brains and life force, these acolytes were unaware that, given the opportunity, Clare preferred intellects equal if not superior to her own who could teach her about literature, politics and world affairs." Doesn't this mean simply that she was loyal to old friends, whom she visited and entertained, and interested in meeting stimulating new people?
This volume, which brings the story up to her election to Congress, covers only Luce's ascent; the next volume will presumably take her downhill. As with the boss-hating confidante, one can only hope that someday Ms. Morris will find more agreeable work.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 100; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 785 words

HEADLINE: LIVES;
An American in Turin

BYLINE: By Andrea Lee; Andrea Lee is an American writer living in Turin, Italy.

 BODY:
"They were the strong guys, who could do whatever they wanted," my husband said. "Like the G.I.'s, like Gary Cooper. They were rich. All of them were kings: newspaper kings, zipper kings. They ate ketchup and mustard, and they wore Stetson hats and ridiculous ties." He is Italian and grew up in Rome in the 1950's and was reminiscing about what he thought of Americans as a child, his words conveying a mixture of awe and mild hostility.
Talking with Italian friends, I realize that nearly a half-century later, the basic attitude remains. Only the focus is different. The view of American military might, worshipful after the war, predictably negative in the leftist 1970's and 80's, has settled into a shrugging tolerance. And Italians -- rich now themselves after the postwar economic boom -- no longer regard the United States with envious admiration. Envy of Americans nowadays centers on the idea of the United States as a leader in technological and artistic innovation and in personal freedom. Italian kids, like kids from Sao Paulo to Shanghai, are hooked on American popular culture, the epicenter of original cool. Mingled with this is an idea that young Americans are more independent of their families, freer to choose the direction of their careers and lives. This is a heady idea in Italy, which, beneath a veneer of modernity, remains a bastion of conservative Catholic culture where children live at home until their 30's. "Americans my age are much more individualistic," said a 25-year-old student who had visited Chicago on an exchange program. "But ... Americans don't have real families like ours." 
 There is always that "but," ushering in the cherished negative view of Americans as talented savages, lacking enough tradition to have even developed a proper language. (Many Italians believe that Americans speak "American," a kind of colonial patois as distinct from the Queen's English as Portuguese from Latin.) Added to this is a growing impression of Americans as violent. "I'd love to take a long automobile tour of the United States," a film director from Rome told me. "but I'm worried about all the crazy things you hear." Friends here have been surprised to find that the first time I saw a gun fired on the street was at a drugstore holdup in Milan.
What I find most curious in my Italian friends' view of America is their unshakable idea that the United States is ethnically uniform. This is especially surprising because Italians are the greatest regionalists in Europe. Yet I know that well-educated, well-traveled Italians still find it difficult to grasp the idea of Hispanic- or Asian-Americans. "Yes, I know she was born in the United States," a Milanese friend told me, speaking of a young third-generation Chinese-American brought up in Oregon. "but you can't say she's American."
In Italy, genuine Americans are supposed to be Middle Western WASP's. (They can also, in special cases, be inner-city blacks.) American religion is considered to be a vaguely fundamentalist Protestantism. To support this vision, sophisticated Italians make a leap of faith. New York, Miami, Los Angeles, they tell me, are not America. America, the real America, is a shopping mall in Missouri.
I've mellowed enough over the years to respond to such remarks with only a subtle smile. The fact is that these stereotypes have often stimulated me to reflect on my own ideas about America. What makes an American?
What, for that matter, makes an Italian? In 10 years, I've seen dramatic changes in the population here. With a huge recent influx of North and Central Africans, Asians and South Americans -- and now boatloads of Albanian refugees -- Italy is following the rest of Europe in becoming a society of many colors and religions: more like America. It's a process that has left Italian politicians and populace in a state of bemusement. As all the world knows, the Miss Italy elected last year was a young black woman born in the Dominican Republic, an event that evoked unseemly protests and set many Italians gazing wistfully back at the days when the most visible foreigners were those American zipper kings in their Stetsons.
Looking around these days, I can understand why my Italian friends cling to the fantasy of a monocultural America: in the midst of their own struggle with change, it's comforting to imagine that an ideal state of things exists somewhere overseas. And the evergreen stereotype of the vulgar American evokes a pleasant nostalgia for a more provincial past, when Italy was for Italians. Just the other day, my husband leafed through a Lands' End catalogue. "Look here," he said in a satisfied voice, "they still wear ridiculous ties!"

HEADLINE: Build Rail Cars Here

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I was delighted to read that the Long Island Rail Road is placing modern double-decker cars on some of their routes ("L.I.R.R. Double-Deckers," letter, June 3). But I wonder why these trains are being purchased from Japan. 
 Here in Connecticut we have the skilled people (a lot of them unemployed) for building nuclear submarines and helicopters. I'm appalled that we can't use some of this potential to design and build the new trains locally.
 
JOEL L. ROSENBAUM
New Haven, June 3, 1997

SECTION: Section C; Page 14; Column 4; Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1017 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Cultural Clashes, Abroad or at Home

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

EXILES
Three Short Novels
By Philip Caputo
353 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25. 
 The title "Exiles" and the name Philip Caputo seem almost tautological. In his previous six books -- two of them memoirs, "A Rumor of War" and "Means of Escape"; four of them novels, "Horn of Africa," "DelCorso's Gallery," "Indian Country" and "Equation for Evil" -- Mr. Caputo has repeatedly explored with considerable skill the alienating effects that warfare in foreign countries, most hauntingly Vietnam, have had on Americans.
So it is predictable enough that two of the three short novels in "Exiles" are set abroad and focus on extreme cases of cultural conflict. In one of them, "Paradise," a white couple tries unsuccessfully to impose economic self-sufficiency on the black natives of a tiny island in the Torres Strait of Australia. In the other, "In the Forest of the Laughing Elephant," four American soldiers and "a hill tribesman" track a huge man-eating tiger in the jungles of Vietnam.
But what makes "Exiles" extraordinary is the lead story, "Standing In," which is set mainly on the Gold Coast of Connecticut and which concerns neither warfare nor foreigners. Here Mr. Caputo brings fresh subtlety to the psychology of exile. It is one of the most engaging works of fiction he has yet produced.
Both of the other novellas certainly seize your attention effectively enough. In the paradoxically titled "Paradise," a badly sunburned man washes up on Nettles Island in a rubber life raft, the apparent victim of a shipwreck. As the islanders nurse him back to health, his behavior begins to unsettle the delicate balance of power between the black natives and the white administrators who are trying to make the island's fishing business profitable.
Yet despite the story's steadily mounting tension, there is something predictable about the natives' outmaneuvering of the colonialists. We've read this story before. Mr. Caputo seems almost to be acknowledging as much by naming his shipwrecked character Barlow (an echo of Conrad's Marlow) and by parodying Conrad's narrative-within-a-narrative technique by making the sea story that Barlow tells a complete fabrication.
The novella "In the Forest of the Laughing Elephant" re-explores the conflict between civilization and nature in Vietnam. Lincoln Coombes, an American soldier struggling to overcome his secret fear of combat, sets out to prove his manhood by killing the tiger that has stolen into his encampment and made off with Valesquez, the company's mess sergeant, in its fangs. Witnessing the tiger's departure, Coombes felt "as if he were being brushed by a fur-covered pickup truck."
Han, the hill tribesman Coombes has taken along as his guide, advises him that the beast is a "Ghostiger" and therefore impossible to kill. But Coombes makes his men throw their wristwatches away so that they will lose all sense of time in their pursuit of this possibly mythical beast.
Again, as in "Paradise," the story builds powerfully, with Coombes's Ahab-like obsession threatening to destroy his entire squad. But it's hard to escape the feeling that this story has been told before. And even the slightly derivative mood is broken when Coombes, who wants to outsmart the tiger, has the following politically correct exchange with a member of his squad who wants to gun the animal down in a salvo of "auto crossfire":
"Sure," says Coombes sarcastically. "It's what we're all about."
"Who?"
"Us. Americans. We subdue the wild. We overcome. It's what we've been all about since Plymouth Rock."
Right. With the Puritans no doubt gunning down gigantic tigers for their Thanksgiving dinners.
It is only in the longer "Standing In" that Mr. Caputo's narrative achieves real psychological freshness. Here Dante Panetta, grieving for his recently deceased mother, is thrown from his sleeping berth when the train he is riding north from Florida to Connecticut for her funeral comes to a sudden stop in the middle of the night. Going from car to car in search of a conductor to explain the delay, Dante comes upon an older woman smoking a cigarette in the dark. They fall into conversation and discover the proximity of their homes in Connecticut and the vast social gulf between them: Dante is a barber who plays in a second-rate band at night; the woman, Greer Rhodes, is an old-line Yankee aristocrat who sells real estate to fill her time while her husband works as a stockbroker.
The train begins to move again. The two say good night and are about to part when Greer sees Dante's face in the light, and says, "Oh, my God." The next morning Greer and her husband, Julian, reveal to Dante that he appears to be the identical twin of their late son, Clay, who died in an accident while serving as a Naval pilot in the Persian Gulf war. The Rhodeses then offer Dante a lift from Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan to Connecticut. Grateful for relief from his loneliness, Dante accepts. Before long he will have given up his life in Florida and moved in with the Rhodeses to become a substitute son to Greer.
What makes "Standing In" come particularly alive is the combination of mutual emotional need and sexual attraction that draw Greer and Dante to each other. To further complicate matters, Clay turns out to have been homosexual and to have died under scandalous circumstances, facts that Greer has always rigidly denied. Dante's willingness to become a substitute son offers her a chance to practice further denial. But is Dante himself heterosexual? And even if he is, can he bear the pressure of being looked on as a parasite by the Rhodeses' snobbish friends?
Summed up so tersely, "Standing In" may sound like a soap-operatic parody of a story by John O'Hara or John P. Marquand. But Mr. Caputo's characters, for all their neediness and inclination to deceive, turn out to have depth and moral resonance. The choices that Dante finally has to make reflect the instability of the American social dynamic, which, in the perspective that Mr. Caputo lends it, can be seen as a kaleidoscope made up of nothing but exiles.

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Up 7.7% in April

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
Orders for machine tools rose 7.7 percent in April from the month before, posting the fourth monthly increase in a five-month period, according to an industry survey.
Orders from American companies for domestic- and foreign-produced machine tools rose to an estimated $801 million in April from a revised figure of $744 million in March, a joint report from the Association for Manufacturing Technology and the American Machine Tool Distributor's Association said today. 
 Previously, the industry groups reported that estimated orders rose 9.3 percent in March to $721 million. Orders totaled an estimated $659 million in February.
For the year to date, estimated orders rose 22 percent, to $2.7 billion. Estimated April orders were 61 percent higher than the $497 million reported in April 1996.
"The significant growth in demand reflected in April orders may be an early indicator that Detroit is beginning to place orders with our industry again," said Albert W. Moore, president of the Association for Manufacturing Technology.
For several months this year, machine tool makers experienced weakening demand from the auto industry, one of their biggest customers.
Machine tools are used to shape and assemble metal in products ranging from diesel engines to dishwashers. Analysts watch their sales as a guide to industrial output, consumer demand and business investment.
Today's report is in line with a Commerce Department report on overall orders to United States factories for durable goods, a broader category than machine tool orders. In April, orders for big-ticket goods rose 1.4 percent, the Commerce Department said.
Actual machine tool orders rose 7.7 percent in April, to $584.51 million from a revised $542.66 million in March, the industry groups said.
April orders jumped 24.2 percent in the Midwest, which accounts for more than half of all orders. They rose 1 percent in the West, dropped 13.9 percent in the Northeast, and eased by 2 percent in the South.
Exports of machine tools by American manufacturers, which are counted separately from domestic orders, rose 1.4 percent, to $45.67 million in April from $45.03 million the previous month.

HEADLINE: MEDIA: PUBLISHING;
Newspaper owners proselytize business sense to their reporters and editors.

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson 

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to their marketing strategies, newspaper publishers are trying any number of ways to appeal to their readers. But on internal matters, publishers are showing a growing unanimity about marketing of a different kind -- campaigns aimed at getting their reporters and editors to accept the realities of the newspaper business these days.
For several decades after World War II, as newspapers grew rich in money and prestige, most reporters and editors thought that all they had to do was write and edit to the best of their abilities, and that it was up to "the money side" -- marketing, circulation and advertising -- to worry about where the profits would come from. After all, going into the 1960's, newspapers were read almost daily in more than 90 percent of the homes throughout the country. 
 Describing his early days as a reporter at The Charlotte Observer in North Carolina in the 1950's, James K. Batten, the former chairman of Knight-Ridder Inc. and a hero to many in the business, put it this way, in a 1989 speech at the University of California at Riverside:
"In all departments of too many dailies, we tended to take our customers pretty much for granted. Not consciously, in most cases, but you could see it in our reflexes. We prided ourselves on our ability to tell our critics to go to hell. We were, after all, 'the press,' beholden to no one."
Mr. Batten, who died two years ago, was not engaging in idle reminiscence. Competition for time and money means that fewer and fewer households now read a paper daily. With so many other media clamoring for their attention, readers are in no mood to be taken for granted, Mr. Batten said. "The days when we could do newspapering our way, and tell the world to go to hell if it didn't like the results, are gone forever," he continued in his 1989 speech.
Now, eight years later, publishers across the country are gearing up to the task of making their reporters and editors -- sensitive, creative and prickly in protecting their independence as they may be -- more alert to the cold facts of the newspaper business. And few publishers have been as blunt about promoting this task as John F. Oppedahl, publisher and chief executive of Phoenix Newspapers Inc., which publishes The Arizona Republic.
"Despite the fact that we distribute our consumer products in a remarkable number of homes in most markets," Mr. Oppedahl said in a speech to the International Newspaper Marketing Association in April, "many of the folks who work for newspapers are insular, insulated and inordinately focused inwardly. It's good some times to try to redirect attention outside the building at our customers -- both readers and advertisers."
So not long ago, The Arizona Republic conducted mandatory business-information sessions for all 375 newsroom employees, where reporters and editors got a lesson on their markets and their readers. The sessions produced a few "Why should we care?" responses from the newsroom, Mr. Oppedahl said, but they also seemed to have a good effect.
Around the same time, the Associated Press Managing Editors Association, made up of newspaper editors around the country, has formed a Business Literacy in the Newsroom Committee, which will report later this year on similar efforts at dailies elsewhere to pry open newsroom windows to the cold blast of the marketplace, if only a little.
"I think we are all comfortable doing journalism, very good journalism, and not paying much attention to the business," said Janet Leach, managing editor of The Cincinnati Enquirer, who is head of the committee. "Sure, we all have an idea who our largest advertisers are, but we also have to be more aware of the customer who is reading the paper, and the advertisers, and the community."
Ms. Leach said The Asbury Park Press of New Jersey, The Richmond Times-Dispatch and about half a dozen other dailies had also begun training sessions for reporters and editors. Among those papers is The Miami Herald, one of the Knight-Ridder papers, which has become a leader in this movement.
There are dangers in all of this, according to people who want to maintain the wall between the lofty church of the newsroom and the sordid counting room. Those dangers run deepest at the confluence of news values and business interests, said Steve Geimann, president of the Society of Professional Journalists.
"I think it would be very valuable for reporters and editors to have a greater awareness of how business works in general," said Mr. Geimann, who is also a senior editor at Communications Daily, a trade paper. "I think a lot of people get into the business without a proper grounding in how the economy works and how businesses work."
The danger arises, Mr. Geimann said, when business interests begin to impinge on news values. "The independence that the journalist seeks is separate from the preoccupations of the ad-gathering process, and when journalism values and business values come into conflict, the journalist always has to come down on the side of the readers."
Mr. Oppedahl of The Arizona Republic was quick to agree. "We are not talking about tailoring our stories to our advertisers," he said in response to a question about his desire to make The Republic's Tuesday issue -- a traditionally weak advertising day -- more appealing.
"We want our people to be made aware of who our readers are, because the idea is, if we get the readers, the advertisers will follow."
