HEADLINE: U.S.-Latin War on Drugs Replacing Blame With Cooperation

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: KEY WEST, Fla., June 6

 BODY:
When officials from all over the Western Hemisphere assembled here this week, they wasted no words on empty predictions of quick victory in the war on drugs. Instead, they focused on a less ambitious goal: working together, rather than at odds with one another, on drug policy.
This focus comes after years of mutual sniping about who was really at fault for the United States' drug problems -- Americans for consuming so many drugs, or other countries for supplying them. 
 Last month, a weeklong trip by President Clinton through the Caribbean Basin produced a declaration that called for increased cooperation between the United States and its Caribbean neighbors that Washington has said is now the cornerstone of American drug policy.
An estimated 200 law enforcement and military officials, representing some 40 countries, attended the three-day conference here, which ended on Thursday and was organized by the United States.
As usual, officials claimed increased success in interdicting shipments of drugs and reducing areas of production. But Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, said at a news conference that the most noteworthy recent development might well have been that "finger-pointing is down by 90 percent."
For instance, Latin American and Caribbean nations argued in the past that the drug problem was primarily one of demand and therefore mainly the fault of the United States; those nations have muted some of their criticism, in part because drug consumption by their own citizens is growing. Likewise, the Clinton Administration has recently sought to change both the tone and substance of its pronouncements.
On his visit to Mexico, Costa Rica and Barbados last month, Mr. Clinton spoke of the United States as a drug-producing nation, much like Mexico or Colombia, and acknowledged more explicitly than in the past the seriousness of the American drug consumption problem. His remarks were repeated here by General McCaffrey in his speech.
"This is something new, and it gives a different tone to this meeting," said Michel Amiot, the director of the European Union's drug control program in the Caribbean. "I was flabbergasted."
Mindful of past American promises, though, foreign drug control officials also said they were waiting for Washington to translate the good intentions into actions. "The United States is saying all the right things, but it is not yet doing all the right things," an official from an English-speaking Caribbean nation said.
In recent years, the United States has negotiated so-called shiprider agreements with Caribbean nations. Such accords, controversial on small islands fearful of threats to their sovereignty, permit American drug agents to pursue drug traffickers into the territorial waters or airspace of signatory countries.
Last month, just before Mr. Clinton's arrival, Jamaica and Barbados, the last holdouts in the English-speaking Caribbean, agreed in principle to such agreements, leaving only Cuba, Haiti and Suriname without such an accord.
An early opportunity to test the cooperation arrangement is expected in the next few months, when the United States and several Caribbean nations will undertake "Operation Summer Storm." It calls for increased joint patrols throughout the region, using both aircraft and high-speed naval and coast guard vessels.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Get Involved? No Alternative For Teachers

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
THE noble calling of putting other people's troubles on your own shoulders has suffered serious blows with the vicious killing of Jonathan Levin. He got involved, this rich young man who taught at a Bronx high school and went out of his way to get to know his poor students.
What it got him is dead, or so many New Yorkers are thinking now that the police say that a former student talked his way into Mr. Levin's Manhattan apartment and, with another man, murdered him. Even if the details of this case change in coming weeks, it is safe to say that some city teachers will think twice about how involved to get with their own young charges once the dismissal bell has rung. 
 Marc C. Britou Jr. also got involved, and it killed him, too, at the ridiculously early age of 14.
This schoolboy from Brooklyn was on a science field trip to Philadelphia last June 22 when his good friend, Jason Moore, jumped or fell into a swimming pool at the motel where they were staying. Marc dived in to save his buddy even though he, like Jason, couldn't swim a lick. Both died, Marc right away and Jason, also 14, after 10 days on a life support system.
So what is the lesson: that you get close to others at your peril? That it is wiser, certainly safer, to keep your distance?
Safer, maybe. But wiser? Not at all, Sam Penceal said yesterday to 140 students at Middle School 61 in Crown Heights, where he is the principal and where Marc and Jason went.
"Marc gave his life for Jason," Mr. Penceal said. "I'm not saying you have to give your life for someone. But it is important that you give a part of your life to someone or something."
THE principal did not have Jonathan Levin in mind, but he might as well have. After talking to the students, Mr. Penceal made the point that teachers must give of themselves, too, no matter what the risks. "That's a lesson being lost on a lot of kids these days: not to forget those who come behind you," he said.
The occasion yesterday was the formal reopening of a city playground that had been renovated and named Marc and Jason's Playground, in honor of the boys who were friends in life and in death. It sits behind M.S. 61 on Sterling Street, a handsome collection of swings, slides, sprinklers and tennis and basketball courts -- redone at a cost of $585,000 and designed in a swirl of colors meant to evoke the Caribbean, the area of origin for both boys' families. Indeed, Caribbean accents reverberate all along the school's corridors.
While civic leaders spoke -- people like the local Councilwoman, Una Clarke, and Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern -- a few teachers half-listened, their attention focused more on the dozens of students selected to attend the dedication ceremony.
Of course, he has to involve himself in their concerns, said Gerald Joshua, a special-education teacher, for "otherwise, there's no value in life."
"To be remembered for something noble, that's how life extends itself beyond the grave," Mr. Joshua said, adding that involvement for him also meant involving poor people more in the economic forces shaping their neighborhoods.
PAULA MARTIN, a sixth grade social-studies teacher, was not so sure that a horror like the Levin murder would scare off teachers who want to break down the barriers of race and class that often exist between students and their instructors.
"You can't always look at the potential risks," Ms. Martin said. "You have to look at it as how many people we can reach. Those people who are meant to be good teachers will be good teachers. They're not going to be deterred. The ones not meant to be teachers drop out, anyway, in the first five years."
A few yards away, the families of the two dead boys sat side by side. The mothers, Marie Britou and Claudette Moore, hugged each other, two women united by grief and by a low-boil anger over not knowing just how their sons ended up unsupervised in that drowning pool -- clearly a case of some teacher's not getting involved enough.
"We talk a lot -- encourage each other," Mrs. Moore said. "That's what we do."
Mrs. Britou nodded. "I don't know why Marc was in the water," she said, "but he was always there for his friend. That involvement was the way he was."
It was Mrs. Moore's turn to nod agreement, and to talk about what an ordeal the last year had been.
"It's good of them to remember the boys in this way," she said, looking around the playground. "At least I'll have some place to come and remember them."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
That knock at the door of the bull market party? Small caps.

BYLINE: By David Barboza 

 BODY:
HERE they come. They may be late arrivals to this year's bull market jamboree, but the stocks of small companies are finally attracting widespread interest.
For about six weeks now, small-capitalization stocks have been surging. Yesterday, for instance, the Russell 2000 rose 0.76 point, to 387.90 -- its 10th closing high in three weeks. That came out of a month in which the index easily outperformed the Dow by rising 11 percent in May, its best monthly showing in a decade. 
 And that has many investors wondering: Is this the long-awaited revival of the small-cap stocks or simply a short-lived spurt for the little guys?
An informal survey of Wall Street strategists suggests that small caps should keep rallying as investors shop for small, undervalued companies.
"This is just the beginning of a comeback rally," said Claudia E. Mott, director of small-cap research at Prudential Securities. But Ms. Mott cautioned that unless small companies report strong second-quarter earnings growth this year, their stocks could slump once again.
Earnings projections for small companies have often been unreliable in recent years. Even so, analysts say that there is growing optimism about the prospect of further small-cap gains in the next few months.
Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley, contends that large-capitalization stocks are vastly overvalued, and that small-cap stocks are a much better buy now. He is not advising investors to sell their holdings in large caps, which continue to perform well, but to plow new money into small caps, partly because large-cap momentum cannot go on forever.
"The market is a function of truth and beauty," he said. "Truth is on the side of small caps; beauty on the side of large caps -- they're popular. But there's no telling how far momentum can carry you."
Some analysts believe that small caps could also benefit from the coming move to rebalance the Russell 2000 index by swapping companies based on their market capitalization. When that happens, analysts say, the newly added firms could get a lift from mutual funds that track the Russell index.
Of course, no one knows for sure, but at the very least, many analysts say that the rally in small-cap stocks augurs well for the market, largely because it suggests greater demand for stocks.
"This is a healthy sign that the market is broadening out," Mr. Wien said. "For a while we had large multinationals dominating. But this is a time when small caps play catch up."
The gains in small-cap stocks are being attributed to a number of factors, including the renewed strength of small technology stocks and heavier cash flows into mutual funds that invest in small-cap companies.
A dearth of new issues -- or small companies going public -- may also be aiding small caps. This year, initial public offerings are down 50 percent from the 1996 pace in dollar terms, according to the Securities Data Company.
"There's very little supply of new issues," said William Paternotte, an investment strategist at Alex. Brown & Sons. "So, in effect, investors had to put money into companies already on the market."
But more important, analysts say, is the relative attractiveness of small caps. "They're just extremely cheap on any historical basis," said Jeffrey Brown, a small-cap analyst at Salomon Brothers. "That's driving a lot of the bulls to say they're too cheap to pass up right now."
According to Salomon, the Russell 2000 is trading at a steep discount to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Based on projected earnings through next April, the price-to-earnings ratio of the Russell 2000 is 15.6, compared with 17.3 for the S.& P. 500 -- among the widest gaps in a decade, Mr. Brown said.
And that has proved enticing to investors, many of whom bid up the prices of health care and small technology stocks last month.
In recent weeks, Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman Sachs & Company, has issued a number of reports about how small caps offer "attractive relative returns" when compared with large-cap stocks. And while she conceded that large companies have the benefit of access to global markets, she said that such factors did not fully justify the disparity in stock returns.
"How much more do you want to pay for the large companies?" she said. "We think the reason to buy small caps is because they're attractively priced. There's good profit growth there."
One reason some strategists remain cautious, though, is that small caps have not outperformed large caps since 1993, largely because large caps are much more liquid and, in recent years, have had an outstanding record of beating earnings estimates.
Some other analysts argue that the current rally is just a rebound from a nasty downturn that began last year. In fact, between May 1, 1996, and April 30, 1997, the Russell lost 2 percent while the S.& P. 500 rose 22 percent -- the largest 12-month disparity for the two indexes since the Russell was formed in the late 1970's.
And, despite their surge in May, small caps continue to lag far behind large caps this year. While the Russell 2000 is up 7 percent this year, the S.& P. 500 is up 16.5 percent.
"One month of relative outperformance doesn't convince me that we're in the middle of a small-cap bull market," Mr. Brown said. "Normally small caps outperform at the beginning of an economic expansion, not where we are right now."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. to Cut Auctions and Increase Issues

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Treasury said yesterday that it was changing its auction schedule to include a new five-year inflation-indexed note this year and to reduce the number of auctions of conventional 10-year notes to four a year from six. It also said it planned to add a 30-year inflation-indexed security in the future.
While the announcement of a reduction in the supply of new debt issues should have lifted the overall market yesterday because of the tightening of supply that it portends, the effect was minimal because market participants had already priced in that eventuality last week. Besides, the dollar, which often moves parallel to the bond market, was weaker, and some investors took profits after last week's rally and amid a vacuum of economic data that kept volume low. 
 The benchmark 30-year bond dropped 19/32 , to a price of 97 17/32 ; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.82 percent, from 6.77 percent on Friday. Traders noted that the thin volume added much to the session's volatility.
In announcing the changes in the inflation-indexed securities program, Lawrence H. Summers, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, said he was pleased with the market's response so far to the new type of securities, which are intended to compensate for rises in consumer prices. In January the Treasury auctioned $7 billion of 10-year inflation-indexed securities; in May it sold $8 billion more of the same security in an effort to build liquidity.
"In July, we will offer our first inflation-indexed securities with a five-year maturity, and in October, we expect to reopen this issue," he said.
Mr. Summers added that the Treasury expected to offer a new 10-year inflation-indexed note in January. The 30-year indexed bond is to be added during the next year, as a regular schedule for auctions of the three maturities of this type of securities begins.
And as a result of the growth in this program, as well as the decline in the Federal budget deficit, which is expected to drop below $100 billion this year, "we will cease offering conventional 10-year notes in the months of July and October, effective immediately," he said.
During the current quarter, the Treasury is planning to retire a record $65 billion in debt.
At the first auction of the indexed notes in January, demand exceeded supply by more than 5 to 1, more than double the demand of a sale of similar conventional securities. However, with inflation near its lowest level in decades, demand was more subdued at the April auction.
The indexed notes rise and fall in value with changes in the Consumer Price Index, with inflation adjustments added to the principal and payable at maturity. If market prices fall over an extended period, the value of the notes will never drop below their originally issued principal.
Elsewhere, the Treasury conducted its regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills, which analysts said went well, with the three-month bill going for an average rate of 4.94 percent, up from 4.93 percent last week, and the six-month bill averaging 5.20 percent, down from 5.22 percent a week ago.

HEADLINE: Richard S. Aldrich, 73, Banker And a Former City Councilman

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Richard S. Aldrich, a cousin of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller who was elected to a two-year term as a Republican councilman at large from Manhattan in 1963, died on Friday in Massachusetts. He was 73 and lived in Providence, R.I., his birthplace.
The cause was cardiac arrest, which he evidently suffered in an ambulance en route to a Fall River hospital, family members said. 
 Mr. Aldrich, a nephew of the Governor's mother, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, moved to Manhattan in 1960 from South America, where he was an executive with the International Basic Economy Corporation, an economic development organization.
While working at the corporation's headquarters in New York, he won the Republican nomination for the Council in a primary election in September 1963, after charges that Rockefeller had insisted upon his getting the party endorsement. Rockefeller denied those allegations. In 1965, Mr. Aldrich withdrew as a candidate for re-election.
He was an investment banker in New York from the late 1960's until he moved to New England in 1978.
At his death, he was a vice president and a co-owner of both The Portuguese Times, a Portuguese-language weekly newspaper published in New Bedford, Mass., and a Portuguese-language cable channel in New Bedford.
Mr. Aldrich was a son of another Richard S. Aldrich, who was a Republican Congressman from Rhode Island, and Janet Innis Aldrich. After military service in World War II, he graduated in 1949 from Yale.
He is survived by his wife, Frances; two daughters, Frances Llopis of Madrid and Abby Gray of Baltimore; two sons, Richard S. Aldrich Jr. of Manhattan and William Stuart Aldrich of Glen Ellyn, Ill.; eight grandchildren and a sister, Janet Lawrence of South Hamilton, Mass.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Plans More Dual-Fuel Mini-Vans

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 9

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation plans to announce on Tuesday that by this autumn, all of its mini-vans with 3.3-liter engines will be outfitted for the 1998 model year with the equipment to burn either gasoline or ethanol, the National Ethanol Vehicle Coalition said today.
Roughly a third of Chrysler's 550,000 mini-vans last year were equipped with this size engine, the most recent for which figures were available this evening. A person close to Chrysler confirmed that the company was planning the announcement. 
 The announcement will follow one by the Ford Motor Company, which said last week that beginning next year it will assemble 50,000 to 60,000 dual-fuel Ford Ranger pickup trucks annually.
Auto makers have emerged as ethanol supporters because they are preparing to build hundreds of thousands of vehicles that can burn ethanol, gasoline or a combination of both, so as to claim huge credits toward Federal fuel-economy standards. The credits, which allow auto makers to build more sport utility vehicles with high profits but poor fuel economy, apply even if customers only choose to put gasoline in their dual-fuel vehicles.

HEADLINE: Tax Proposal Offers Wall St. Some Relief

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
For Wall Street it could have been a lot worse.
The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, put forth a wide-ranging tax plan yesterday, and his proposals contained some relief that would be welcome on Wall Street: phasing out the corporate alternative minimum tax, reducing capital gains for middle- and lower- income investors, expanding the use of independent contractors instead of employees and continuing tax preferences for both 100-year bonds and for stock options. 
 But there were also a few bitter pills scattered among the proposals by Mr. Archer, the chief Republican tax writer.
Potentially the most painful proposal would require companies to register tax shelters with the Government. That would alert Internal Revenue Service auditors in advance to creative new tax avoidance strategies, whereas now they have to hope to find them after the fact.
The rest of the bad news was mostly limited to proposals to tighten or eliminate tax gimmicks, such as a device by which investors in credit card debt could delay reporting December interest income until the next year.
The biggest dollars are in Mr. Archer's proposal to phase out the alternative minimum tax for corporations by the start of the year 2006, which would cost the Government $33.9 billion in reduced taxes over the next 10 years if enacted.
"I am sure he will have a very tough time with that one," said Robert Willens, a tax specialist at Lehman Brothers.
Mr. Archer also proposed eliminating the alternative minimum tax for small companies, but he proposed to keep it for individuals with some adjustments for inflation.
Mr. Archer also proposed a slight reining in of the Morris Trust, a device that allows for tax-free spinoffs of companies. The device is called a Morris Trust after a taxpayer who won a case allowing a 1966 tax-free spinoff.
A likely spark for the proposed changes, Mr. Willens said, was a May 19 deal in which the E. W. Scripps Company said it would buy six newspapers and two broadcast stations from Harte-Hanks Communications, paying as much as $625 million if the Morris Trust is preserved and $775 million if it is not.
"I suspect the tax writers looked at that and said to themselves, 'There's $150 million we can pick up in just that one deal,' " Mr. Willens said.
Mr. Willens said at least $50 billion of deals involved Morris Trusts in the last year, but Mr. Archer's proposal is so modest that it is estimated to raise only $2 billion over 10 years.
Mr. Willens also predicted that Mr. Archer's proposal to end shorting against the box, a tax avoidance strategy that involves selling borrowed shares of stock while retaining one's own shares, might not produce the $1.2 billion of added tax revenue over 10 years that Mr. Archer predicts. The reason is that many people might shift to borrowing against their shares and a tax rule would then allow them to deduct the interest they pay, provided that they have interest income from other investments.
Many executives will breathe easier knowing that Mr. Archer has taken the tax treatment of stock options off the table. Options create a tax deduction for companies without a cash outlay, a major reason that companies are expanding them as a form of payment not just for executives but for the rank-and-file as well. The cost of options is borne by existing shareholders, whose ownership stake is diluted.
Cyclical industries like steel and autos would face only a slight reduction in their ability to use net operating losses to reduce income taxes in profitable years. Currently companies can use losses to offset profits in three prior years and then carry any unused losses forward for 15 years. Mr. Archer proposed two years back and 20 forward, which he estimated would raise $1.8 billion.

HEADLINE: 50 YEARS: JACKIE ROBINSON -- A Baseball Celebration;
Helping Students Lead Good Lives, Like Robinson's

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
During Betty Adams's childhood in Memphis, her parents portrayed Jackie Robinson as the paradigm of the qualities she was expected to emulate. Marian Anderson, Ralph Bunche, relatives and neighbors were also employed to teach life lessons, but Robinson always remained special.
"In certain situations," Adams said, "my mother or father would say, 'What would Jackie Robinson do?' " 
 Decades later, the question is central to Adams's daily work as the president of the Jackie Robinson Foundation, an educational charity created by Robinson's wife, Rachel, after his death in 1973.
Adams came to the foundation in 1986 from the National Urban League. "It was in its formative stage," she said during a recent interview in her modest Manhattan office, which also houses the Robinson archives. "It was poised for growth. It had a good reputation and a good track record."
The 50th anniversary of Robinson's breaking of the modern major league color barrier has provided a platform for the foundation to launch a three-year drive to raise an endowment of $12 million.
The annual dinner, held in March, raised $1.2 million, and Major League Baseball pledged $1 million more. Other sources include an annual jazz concert, to be held June 29; the yearly golf tournament, scheduled for Aug. 18; corporate donations; gold and silver commemorative coins to be issued July 1 by the United States Mint; a Radio City Music Hall celebration in September, and licensing royalties.
Although the notion of expanding the foundation's mission beyond education has been discussed over her 10 years as president, Adams said the directors always return to the roots: providing four-year college scholarships of up to $20,000 to needy minority-group students who show a potential for community leadership.
"We question whether we're making the best use of our resources," Adams said. "But the need is so tremendous. We always come back to education as a tool for the advancement of minorities and a commitment to young people."
Since 1973, about 500 scholarships have been awarded for students to attend 62 colleges and universities. There are currently 141 Robinson scholars attending college. "Last year," she said, "we received 3,000 applications. Of those, 1,500 met our basic requirements, and we made 43 awards." For the coming school year, the roster of scholars will increase by 50.
In a report filed with New York State, the foundation said it raised $1.75 million and distributed grants of $554,489, in the year ended June 30, 1996, up from $1.4 million raised and $516,630 distributed in the previous year. Some of the major contributors last year included General Electric ($92,500), Chesebrough Pond's ($77,000) and Coca-Cola ($25,000).
The foundation is in much the same market as charitable organizations like the United Negro College Fund, Upward Bound and A Better Chance.
"These days, with the societal and economic trends, it's hard to raise money no matter what your name is," Adams said. "The whole world knows the Jackie Robinson name, but they're not as familiar with the work the foundation does. Our products, our scholars and alumni are our best salespeople."
The scholars must do more than collect annual checks of up to $5,000. They must have a desire for leadership and community service, and must regularly apprise the foundation of their progress and problems.
"The idea Rachel had was not to simply count the number of scholarships awarded, or to pat ourselves on the back for our 92 percent graduation rate," Adams said. "But how do these young people conduct themselves in their personal and professional lives and how do they interact as citizens?"
Once a year, the foundation brings the students together with the alumni in New York for a networking weekend. "On Sunday, Rachel conducts a kind of 'Come home to Mama' seminar," Adams said. "We say, 'We know how well you're doing academically. We know your academic goals, but what have you done lately to help someone?' They share their triumphs and their difficulties. And if you have a difficulty, you have to share what you plan to do about it."
John Skipper, a scholar from 1981 to 1985 at the University of Pennsylvania, said he benefited greatly from the guidance and in turn is a mentor to current scholars. Now a lawyer for Con Edison, Skipper said: "It's definitely special for the guidance and the assistance. I got my interview with Con Ed because of the foundation."
The foundation is trying to nurture students into leading lives Robinson would be proud of; the work continues what Robinson taught by example, what Rachel Robinson preaches and what Adams's parents imparted.
"I think if Jackie were around he would be pleased," Adams said, "but he would be peppering me with questions about why we can't do more and faster."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Betty Adams, the president of the Jackie Robinson Foundation, which is in a $12 million fund drive. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Compelled by Shabazz's Situation, Hundreds Give Blood

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
Half a block from the Harlem boulevard named for her slain husband, Malcolm X, Dr. Betty Shabazz was honored yesterday with something more vital than a street sign: the blood of hundreds of New Yorkers, who gave of themselves for a woman who few of them knew but all admired.
The blood drive, organized by The Amsterdam News and the Carver Federal Savings Bank, drew donors of all complexions and convictions, whose contact would usually be limited to street corner bump-and-run but who yesterday spent hours in intimate conversation while they waited to give a pint of blood. 
 There in the bank basement, fanning themselves with medical intake forms, was Ted Yanow, an elderly doctoral student in sociology; Fred Richardson, a caseworker for the city's Administration for Children's Services, and Jenny Burton, an aspiring singer. There was Bahia Lee, a home health aide; Ruth W. Messinger, a candidate for Mayor, and Bruce Thornton, a cook in a Harlem church.
There was Steve Feyl, a Bronx librarian; Monique Jaysura, a dietary aide at Harlem Hospital Center, and Edward Lewis, a Long Island business consultant. There was Carolyn Lyons, a retired nurse; Thomas L. Clark Jr., the bank president, and Coral Caporale, an Upper West Side lawyer.
All came because they were compelled by the latest tragedy to befall Dr. Shabazz, who was burned nearly to death last weekend in a fire the authorities say was set by her troubled grandson, Malcolm. Dr. Shabazz, 61, remained in extremely critical but stable condition at Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx, with the next in a long series of surgeries scheduled for tomorrow.
"She needs our blood, and she needs our prayers," said Mr. Lewis, dapper in a seersucker suit. "This is what's great about this city, how it comes together in time of need. But we ought to do this more often, not just in times of crisis."
Yesterday's blood drive, which will be repeated both Thursday and Friday at the same location, 75 West 125th Street, was one of the most successful in recent memory, according to Linda Levi, a spokeswoman for the New York Blood Center. The donated blood will be used to replenish the supply at Jacobi, where Dr. Shabazz will need repeated transfusions of plasma because of dehydration, as well as white cells to fight infection.
The drive had attracted more than 400 donors by nightfall yesterday and yielded 265 pints of blood. The blood was of all types and far exceeded Dr. Shabazz's needs. It will be dispersed to 250 hospitals in the New York region and is a windfall since summer is a time of dangerously low supply.
Yesterday's donors each had different motivations, some personal and some political, in addition to the general sense that a good woman, and an icon of modern black history, had been dealt another hand of grief. "I gave blood to you because of the blood your husband lost when he was alive," one donor wrote on the cards that all filled out for the Shabazz family. "I don't know you, but I love you."
The donors waited patiently outside the bank in the early morning, as the hair-braiding booths and the army recruiting stand opened for business. Once inside, they moved without complaint from one hard plastic chair to the next, finally reaching the cots where their blood would be drawn and the canteen where they were rewarded with Lorna Doones and orange juice.
For Ms. Burton, the singer, the motivation was a 20-year friendship with Dr. Shabazz's eldest daughter, Attallah. For Mr. Yanow, the doctoral candidate, it was a lifetime of fighting apartheid. For Mr. Richardson, the caseworker, it was the daily immersion in the lives of children so like 12-year-old Malcolm Shabazz.
For Ms. Lyons, the retired nurse, it was a payback for the time Dr. Shabazz spent as her teacher at Medgar Evers College, in a course called religion and culture in nursing. For Ms. Lee, the home health aide, it was a way of saying thank you to her own mother, who cares for her child while she is at work.
For Ms. Caporale, the lawyer, it was a way to bring her faith alive outside the walls of a church. For Mr. Thornton, it was a pleasing contrast to the time years ago when, unemployed, he sold his blood for money. And for Mr. Feyl it was just an accident. He had come to 125th Street to buy a Krispy Kreme doughnut and had seen the sign.
Ms. Lyons, crippled by arthritis, was disqualified from giving because she takes heart medication. But she did not view the time as wasted. "I just made a new friend," she said, gesturing toward Mr. Lewis.
They had been strangers an hour before, when happenstance put them in side-by-side chairs. Now he rose chivalrously, handed her her cane and kissed her goodbye. "The important thing is you were here," he said. "You tried."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Questions From West 47th Street

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
This column is for the stranger who asked me two questions on West 47th Street in New York City, and for anybody else who wants to know.
First, some news. A mission of inquiry to China headed by a leading expert on persecution of Christians reported the following yesterday: 
 Beijing's campaign against the Christian underground is increasing. Persecution is generally worse than any time since the dreadful early 1980's.
The Government has targeted leaders of the clandestine "house churches" of Catholics and Protestants brave enough to insist on freedom of religion and of worship. Sentences of years at hard labor are commonplace; some leaders have not been heard from since their arrests months ago.
Now, the questions from the stranger, who wore the hat and frock coat of many Orthodox Jews and stopped me in the street.
"Why are you writing so much about Christians?" he asked.
"Well, in various countries they are being persecuted, so I . . ."
He held up a hand. "I know why. You think if you write about that it will be good for the Jews, right?"
"Yes, but that's not . . ."
"All right, enough, so keep writing," he said pleasantly, and walked off.
Of course it will be good for Jews if persecution of Christians or Buddhists or people of any faith is known and fought. And yes, I hope if awareness of persecution of Christians spreads it will create at last a national human rights movement in America against religious and political persecution, both.
Maybe then business executives will voluntarily stop enriching the persecuting government and so . . . that's fantasy. China's religious persecution is not news to them; they could have acted years ago.
Most of all, persecution of Christians must be written about with consistency because it is taking place with consistency -- more, not less.
And because of this: Although more Americans are aware and demanding action, they are not getting it from Washington. Western democracies are all pious believers -- in increasing trade, not increasing religious freedom.
And this: If public anger against China's persecution continues to grow, Congress might push President Clinton into some economic reprisal. Washington bears a direct responsibility. It uses the U.S. economy to bolster the persecuting government, its army, police and Communist Party, by investments, imports and floating of Chinese bonds.
So back to the report. The carefully small mission was headed by Dr. Paul Marshall, author of "Their Blood Cries Out," an important book on persecution of Christians (Word Publishing, 800-933-9673), and sponsored by the Puebla Program on Religious Freedom, of Freedom House.
While some provinces are particularly repressive, the mission found that persecution has been stepped up in all areas from which it could get reports, about half of China. The pattern is not local but national.
Despite or because of the years of repression, China's Catholic and Protestant churches are showing "explosive growth." The official "patriotic churches" where Christians can go without fear of arrest naturally have had the largest growth.
The underground churches reject the Government's control -- registration, licensing of clergymen and what they can preach, authority over appointments, including bishops.
Evangelical clergymen say that about 40 percent of prisoners in the hard-labor camps of Henan Province were sentenced for belonging to the Christian underground.
But the underground church also increases dramatically. The report (copies from indispensable little Puebla: 202-296-5101) adds: "Underground leaders say the commitment required in China to practice one's faith leads to a strong, disciplined and growing church."
Footnotes for the stranger on 47th Street:
1. President Clinton abandoned his promise to link trade to human rights in 1994. He said that in return the Chinese would ease oppression. Later that year, the new wave of Christian persecution began. The screws were further tightened in mid-1996, and since, consistently.
2. The report says that in the past year police have beaten and tortured underground Christians with electric cattle prods and drills, sometimes in front of relatives forced to watch.
That's why.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Insurance Acquisition Reflects Industry's Shift
Safeco, a big West Coast insurer of homes and automobiles, said that it was paying $2.83 billion for American States Financial in a transaction that exemplifies the insurance industry's move toward specialization. 
 Safeco will increase its main property and casualty business by nearly 50 percent, and American States' parent, Lincoln National, will abandon property and casualty to devote itself to selling life insurance and annuities and to investment management. [Page D4.]
 
$900 Million for Rental Giant
A subsidiary of Atlas Copco of Sweden plans to acquire Prime Service, a big American rental equipment company, for $900 million in cash. The deal will provide a windfall for Investcorp, which controls Prime Service. [D2.]
 
$541 Million New York Cable Deal
Cablevision Systems agreed to acquire systems covering more than 820,000 customers from Tele-Communications in a $541 million deal that would solidify Cablevision's dominant position in the New York metropolitan area, with more than 2.5 million customers. Cablevision stock rose sharply on the news. [A1.]
 
Tax-Cut Plan Is Outlined
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, disclosed his plan for the first big Federal tax cut since 1981, sticking by his party's promise to reduce taxes on capital gains and on families but prompting criticism from Democrats that the plan favors the wealthy. [A1.]

The plan contained some other provisions that would be welcome on Wall Street, including a phasing out of the corporate alternative minimum tax. But there were also a few bitter pills, including the possibility that companies might be required to report tax shelters. [D6.]
 
Stocks Continue to Set Records
The Dow industrials flirted with the 7,500 level for the first time, rising 42.72 points to close at 7,478.50, as records fell on a broad front. [D10.]
 
The bond market weakened, however, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury rising to 6.82 percent from 6.77. The Treasury said that it was changing its auction schedule to include more inflation-indexed securities and fewer sales of conventional 10-year notes. [D20.]

China's Computer Purchases Cited
China has bought 46 American-made supercomputers since President Clinton deregulated computer exports in 1995, Government officials say. It may be using them to design nuclear weapons that could reach the United States, experts say. [A1.]
 
Ford Pays Dealers to Buy Back Cars
Seeking to prevent a growing number of off-lease cars from further depressing used-car prices, Ford Motor has begun paying dealers to buy these vehicles instead of returning them to the auto maker for sale at auction. [D9.]
 
Continental Seen Choosing Boeing
Continental Airlines is expected to announce that it will buy 35 wide-body jets from Boeing. The agreement will make Continental the third United States airline to name Boeing as its sole supplier of jets, arrangements that have been criticized by Airbus. [D2.]
 
Court to Weigh Harassment Issue
The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether the Federal law that prohibits sex discrimination and sexual harassment on the job applies to people of the same sex. [D26.]
 
Finding Against Law Firm
A judge has found that the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy violated procedural rules by failing to disclose properly its representation of a company in bankruptcy and, in a separate matter, one of the company's largest creditors. [D6.]

Hundt Against Ads on Public TV
The chairman of the F.C.C., Reed E. Hundt, said that public television stations should reject a proposal to experiment with commercials in prime-time programs on Friday and Saturday nights. [A20.]

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
IBJ Schroder Moving Within Manhattan

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
IBJ Schroder Bank and Trust Company, the United States investment banking arm of the Industrial Bank of Japan, will receive $3.1 million in public subsidies for moving its headquarters from One State Street Plaza to 180 Maiden Lane, both in lower Manhattan, under an agreement with city and state economic development officials.
The subsidies include $1 million in city and state sales tax exemptions and $800,000 in energy discounts. IBJ Schroder could receive another $1.3 million in sales tax exemptions if it expands its work force by 420 people over 22 years. 
 The deal is to be voted on today by the city's Industrial Development Authority.
City and state officials said IBJ Schroder turned down a more lucrative offer to move its 500 employees to 90 Hudson Street in Jersey City.
At 180 Maiden Lane, it is expected to lease 193,000 square feet for 20 years.
The building is owned by the CNA Financial Corporation, which in turn is controlled by the Loews Corporation.
Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said: "Sometimes, when your board is in Japan, Jersey City versus Maiden Lane doesn't make much of a difference. That's what we were up against."
 DAVID M. HALBFINGER

HEADLINE: Developer Plans Sports Center For $1 Billion In Rockaways

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
A company connected to one of the world's best known development groups, the Reichmann family of Toronto, has proposed building a vast $1 billion entertainment and sports complex, including a hotel and convention center, on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, officials said yesterday.
The project, which would be built on 307 acres of city-owned beachfront land in the Arverne section, would include movie theaters, an indoor ski slope, skating rinks and a pool, and would create more than 10,500 permanent jobs, said Jeffrey Goodman, a spokesman for the development company, Heathmount Arts and Entertainment Corporation. He added that the company owners hoped to start building in 2000 and finish two years later. 
 The complex ranks as one of the most elaborate ideas proposed for the Arverne urban renewal area, which has been the focus of many failed projects over the years since Mayor John V. Lindsay's urban renewal bulldozers pushed over the area's crumbling summer cottages in the late 1960's.
But before breaking ground, the developers would face enormous questions and obstacles, ranging from their financial backing to the huge investments in transportation and other infrastructure that they say are needed in the Rockaways and that would have to be paid for by New York State and the city.
"It's an interesting proposal that could greatly benefit the Rockaways," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said. "We are working closely with the office of the Borough President to assess the feasibility of a project of this magnitude."
Heathmount and Borough President Claire Shulman's office announced the plans for the project after Ms. Shulman met with local officials yesterday to discuss it, and details began to leak out.
Heathmount's chief executive is Albert Reichmann, one of the three Reichmann brothers who made Olympia & York into one of the largest property companies in the world, only to see it collapse in the early 1990's. Heathmount's founder and president is Abraham Reichmann, the son of another brother, Ralph. Since the Reichmann empire crumbled, several family projects that had been announced with great fanfare by municipal leaders have amounted to little more than colorful drawings by architects. In 1994, for instance, Paul Reichmann and the investor George Soros went to Mexico City to announce an ambitious plan to redevelop the city's historic core, but the project never went forward.
But Mr. Goodman said that Heathmount had secured private financing for the Rockaway Peninsula complex, which would be called Destination Technodome, as well as for a similar project near Toronto that would cost $700 million in Canadian funds. "The financing is definitely in place for Toronto and New York," he said. "Anybody would be foolish to be skeptical."
Mr. Goodman said the project would proceed as long as the state and city were able to provide infrastructure improvements, including new roads, sewers, better public transportation, toilets and ample parking. He declined to estimate the cost of the improved infrastructure, which would likely prove a thorny issue.
"When you're looking at a billion-dollar investment and thousands and thousands of jobs, the infrastructure investment by the state and city should be considered very seriously," said Ms. Shulman, the Queens Borough President.
Ms. Shulman said that Albert and Abraham Reichmann approached her a few months ago with the proposal. "I was a little skeptical at first," she said. "But they kept pursuing it. I finally realized a few weeks ago that they were for real because they had invested big dollars in research. They're interested in moving as quickly as possible because they feel that whoever gets in first, will get the business."
Beyond questions of financing and infrastructure, the Canadian company will have to contend with a host of other issues that accompany a project of this size. The company will have to work out terms to buy the land from the city, said Dan Andrews, a spokesman for the Borough President's office.
In addition, because the Rockaways are bordered to the north by the Federally protected Jamaica Bay, the developers will have to deal with environmental issues -- not to mention possible concerns of local residents over increased traffic.
Plans to develop the Arverne site with hotels, apartments or theme parks have been floated before without success.
In 1991, for instance, a partnership led by Forest City Ratner Companies gave up on a plan to develop all 307 acres with a $1.5 billion project of 7,500 apartments, as well as shopping malls, recreation centers and parks. The company said the downturn in the city's real estate market damaged the prospects for the project.
Mr. Goodman said that Heathmount was approached by state officials after the company unveiled plans last fall to build a similar complex in the Toronto area. The project was one of two chosen by the Canadian Government to redevelop a former military base in the city of North York, he said, adding that the company expected to break ground next April and have the complex completed in 2000.
The Mayor of North York, Mel Lastman, said he felt confident after the Reichmanns' private backers had assured him of the project's financing.
"Ours is very close to happening," Mayor Lastman said, explaining that the complex still needed to go through a local review.
Mr. Goodman said that the Reichmanns saw the Toronto and New York sites as the start of a worldwide chain of sprawling entertainment and sports complexes. The Rockaways, Mr. Goodman said, were chosen over two cities in Asia and Europe that were also bidding to attract the second complex.
The Reichmanns "liked what they saw," he said. "They liked the people they were meeting."

INTERNATIONAL A3-17
 
Sales of Supercomputers To China Raise Concerns
Government officials said the 46 American-made supercomputers purchased by China since President Clinton deregulated their export in 1995 could help the Chinese design more efficient or lighter nuclear warheads that could be put on missiles able to reach the United States. A1
 
Support for Fujimori Dwindles
Peruvians' approval of their President, Alberto K. Fujimori, has plummeted in the past two months, according to polls that show his approval rating at 39 percent. The rating had soared in the immediate aftermath of his ordering a raid to end a hostage crisis in Lima, but the continuing poverty and his autocratic leadership have led thousands of citizens to protest. A12 

Network Backs Moscow Mayor
Center TV, owned and operated by the city of Moscow, made its debut in Russia. The director of the network said its main goal was to spread the image of Yuri Luzkhov, Moscow's powerful Mayor, across all of Russia. Mr. Luzkhov is widely seen as a strong candidate to run for President in the year 2000. A3
 
Discontent Grows in Kenya
Tired of Government corruption, Kenya's beleaguered middle class has rallied to calls for reforming the Constitution to give President Daniel arap Moi less power. Popular protests have recently turned violent, but Mr. Moi has refused to meet with opposition politicians or to consider constitutional changes until after elections, scheduled for later this year. A9
 
Coup Leaders Find Few Friends
Leaders of a coup in Sierra Leone toured the region in search of support, but meetings with officials from other West African countries produced little backing. Nigeria, meanwhile, continued building up troops off Freetown, the Sierra Leone capital. James Johan, Sierra Leone's representative to the United Nations, accused the coup leaders of planning to massacre their opponents in the event of any outside military intervention. A5
 
Barricades Divide Brazzaville
Fighting continued for a fifth day between the national army of the Congo Republic and a militia loyal to a former head of state. Heavy street fighting and rockets and mortar fire pelted the capital, Brazzaville, which French military sources said had been cut in two by makeshift barricades. A11
 
Haitian Premier Resigns
Rosny Smarth resigned as Prime Minister of Haiti after several months of strikes and violent protests demanding his removal. Mr. Smarth, who had tried to reduce government spending and privatize state-owned utility companies, complained that forces loyal to former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide had rigged a runoff election for the Haitian Senate next week against him. A13
 
NATIONAL A18-25, D24-26
 
G.O.P. Tax Plan Would Cut $135 Billion Over 5 Years
The chief Republican tax writer unveiled his plan for apportioning the first big Federal tax cut since 1981, making good on his party's promise to reduce tax bills for investors and families but prompting criticism from Democrats that the plan favors the wealthy. Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said the tax cuts would be worth nearly $135 billion over the next five years, paid for in part by about $47 billion in new revenue. The centerpieces of his plan are a reduction in the top rate on capital gains from the sale of stocks, bonds and other assets and a credit for many families of up to $500 per child A1
 
General Withdraws Name
The Air Force general who was in line to become the next Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff withdrew his name from consideration after trying without success to persuade lawmakers on Capitol Hill that he was worthy of the job despite his adulterous affair several years ago. After a discouraging round of meetings with members of Congress, the officer, Gen. Joseph W. Ralston, announced his decision in a statement released at the Pentagon. Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said he renewed his search for a nominee and had asked General Ralston to remain in his post as vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs. A1
 
Link Seen in Atlanta Bombings
Leaders of a task force investigating a series of bombings in Atlanta said today that they were "all but positive" that the same person or persons had planted bombs at a lesbian nightclub and at a building housing an abortion clinic, and that they had "increasing confidence" that those incidents were linked to last summer's explosion at Centennial Olympic Park. A1
 
Clinton Vetoes Flood Bill
President Clinton made good on his threat to veto an $8.6 billion emergency flood relief bill because of unrelated provisions, volleying it back to the Republican Congress almost the moment he received it. Each side sought today to portray the other as being to blame for denying long-term relief to flood victims in 33 states. Mr. Clinton said the Republicans had left him no choice but to veto the bill, citing several provisions, including one that would prevent Government shutdowns in budget disputes. A21
 
Bribery as Grounds for Appeal
The Supreme Court ruled in favor of a convicted Illinois murderer trying to prove that his trial was tainted by judicial corruption. In an opinion by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, the Court said the death-row inmate was entitled to try to build a case that the Chicago judge who presided over his trial -- and who later went to prison for accepting bribes -- was unduly favorable to the prosecution because no bribe was paid in this case. The decision overturned a ruling last year by the Federal appeals court in Chicago, which said evidence of William Bracy's guilt was compelling while his charges of judicial bias were speculative and weak. D26
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-12
 
Future of Rent Regulations Focuses on Vacancy Issues
The battle over the future of state rent laws is now focuses almost entirely on one issue: whether landlords should be allowed to raise rents as much as they want on regulated apartments that become vacant. The State Senate's Republican majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, who six months ago called for abolishing most protections in two years, now supports a more gradual phase out over 12 years or more through the policy of deregulating apartments once they are vacated. But Democrats want the system to continue indefinitely. A1
 
Man Held in Murder of Wife
Ten days after he was released from jail in exchange for pleading guilty to charges of beating his wife, a Queens man killed her and two children, authorities said. Richard Lyle Timmons, 33, was found in the apartment with one of his wrists slashed in an apparent suicide attempt. He has not been charged. B3
 
Prom Baby Alive at Birth
A baby born in a bathroom at a high school prom in New Jersey on Friday was alive during birth, Monmouth County officials said, but they have not determined whether the 6-pound, 6-ounce boy was breathing independent of the mother after the umbilical cord was cut. If the baby's lungs were functioning on their own, prosecutors said that they could file murder or manslaughter charges against the girl, who left the little boy's body in a trash container in the bathroom, then went back to the dance floor. BUSINESS DAY D1-22
 
French May Slow Euro Pact
The new French Government said that it could not yet approve a previously negotiated agreement that is crucial to the proposed single European currency, the euro. The French Finance Minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, said his Government needed both more time and stronger measures aimed at relieving unemployment before it would approve the so-called stability pact.The announcement abruptly torpedoed the carefully laid plans by European leaders to give formal approval to the measure at a meeting next week in Amsterdam. SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1248 words

HEADLINE: Cablevision Moves to Acquire 10 More Local Cable Systems

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Promising 100 television channels, high-speed Internet access and telephone service, the Cablevision Systems Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 10 cable television systems in the metropolitan area covering more than 820,000 customers from Tele-Communications Inc.
The $541 million deal would solidify Cablevision as the dominant cable television company in the New York City area, with more than 2.5 million customers. Cablevision said the larger network would allow the company to offer new packages of advanced communications services from Hempstead to Hackensack, including super-crisp digital television images, enhanced local news and, for some customers, more than 1,000 movies available with the touch of a button. 
 Cable television companies across the country have made grandiose pledges before, and broken them. But technology consultants and financial analysts said that operating a large, contiguous network would allow Cablevision to deploy some, though not all, of the planned services cost-effectively.
The deal requires Federal and state approval; state regulators did not foresee any problems. But consumer advocates said they would fight the deal.
The 10 systems Cablevision would acquire are on Long Island, in New Jersey and in Rockland and Westchester Counties. Cablevision, based in Woodbury, N.Y., is already the nation's sixth-largest cable television operator, serving about 3.8 million customers, including about 470,000 in New York City. Time Warner Inc. is the biggest cable television company in New York City. It has about 1.1 million customers.
"The transaction is a win-win," said James L. Dolan, the chief executive of Cablevision. "It might be actually three wins -- a win for T.C.I. and a win for Cablevision, but even more so for the consumers who we serve. We now have the concentration on the New York area to begin to offer the services like telephony and high-speed modems and educational services and programming services specially dedicated to the consumer in their locality."
The term telephony refers to standard voice telephone service, which Mr. Dolan said Cablevision intends to offer over its cable network. Using high-speed cable modems, electronic devices that allow computers to communicate with networks like the Internet, computer users would be able to view television-quality video.
The electronic hardware of the future may not come cheap. Cable modems cost hundreds of dollars and the high-definition digital televisions of the future, which will be needed to view film-quality images, are expected to cost thousands of dollars.
But some of the advances Cablevision has promised would not require expensive new purchases.
Mr. Dolan said Cablevision intends to develop a new cable channel for Westchester County that would show viewers a glimpse of rush-hour roadways using cameras already in place for radio traffic reports. "If you live in upper Westchester and commute to New York every day, that commute can take anywhere from 40 minutes to two hours and 40 minutes," he said. "In one minute and 30 seconds you will be able to find out about each snare-up."
Cablevision has come under pressure from shareholders and Wall Street to reduce its heavy debt burden of $3 billion, but financial markets reacted enthusiastically to the acquisition, even though Cablevision would also assume about $669 million of T.C.I.'s debt. Shares of Cablevision closed at $44.375, up $9.75, in heavy trading on the American Stock Exchange, while T.C.I.'s shares rose $1, to $16.0625, in Nasdaq trading.
Many financial analysts calculated that Cablevision had acquired hundreds of thousands of subscribers for less than they were worth.
Consumer advocates were not so positive. Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Washington office of Consumers Union, a consumer group, said his organization would seek to stop the deal at the F.C.C. "and in any antitrust venues." T.C.I. is also taking a 33 percent stake in Cablevision, and Mr. Kimmelman said that would push T.C.I. over Federal limits on how many customers a cable company may serve.
"This looks to me like a back door effort to expand T.C.I.'s dominance over the cable marketplace," Mr. Kimmelman said. The Federal Communications Commission did not return calls seeking comment last night.
State regulators, however, seemed cautiously optimistic about the deal's chances for regulatory approval. The deal needs approval from both the F.C.C. and state regulators. Cablevision expects to complete the acquisition within a year.
"I would simply say that it appears to hold out the prospect of two potential benefits," said John F. O'Mara, the chairman of New York State's Public Service Commission, referring to Cablevision's promises to offer enhanced television services and to enter the commercial and residential telephone market.
"By owning the market it makes it a lot easier to market your service," said Jessica Reif Cohen, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. "Upgrading now makes more economic sense. If you're going to upgrade a system, it makes much more sense in a dense area."
T.C.I. executives said that their local customers would benefit from becoming Cablevision subscribers.
"We think that a 2.5 million-subscriber footprint will bring greater value to the customers than the alternative" of staying with T.C.I., said Leo J. Hindery, the president of T.C.I.
Direct-broadcast satellite services have won about 5 million customers in recent years and cable television operators, who serve about 65 million customers, have responded by attempting to enhance their offerings and consolidate their operations in limited geographic areas.
"The cable system was built town by town, but what made sense 20 or 30 years ago doesn't necessarily make sense now," said Bruce A. Leichtman, a cable analyst for the Yankee Group, an information technology consulting firm in Boston. "What's happening in the cable industry as a whole is clustering."
A prime selling point of the direct-broadcast satellite services has been their broad menu of sports and movies. Movies sometimes can begin as often as every 15 minutes. Cable has rarely been able to compete. With cable's limited number of channels, it can cater to only so many tastes. But by spending money on new technology, cable operators can increase the number of available channels.
"Now you have on cable one Arnold Schwarzenegger film and one film of busty women and they start every two hours," said Emily Green, an analyst for Forrester Research, a high-technology consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. "That's an area cable really wants to improve."
But marshaling the technology to provide video on demand, or a movie with a click of a button, has proven more difficult than simply adding channels.
"Video on demand has not proven to be cost-efficient," Mr. Leichtman said. "That probably won't happen so much."
But Cablevision has been aggressive for years. Under its chairman, Charles F. Dolan, and his family -- including James, his youngest son -- Cablevision has grown from its Long Island stronghold to become a fast-moving media company.
Since 1995, the company has spent $860 million to acquire 85 percent of Madison Square Garden, along with the Knicks, the Rangers and the MSG Network.
The latest deal gives the Dolan family its longest reach yet.
"This gives Cablevision one heck of a large cluster in the No. 1 market in America," Mr. Leichtman said.

HEADLINE: CONGRESS AND TAXES: DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA;
Head of House Panel Offers Plan to Help Revive Capital

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
To stem the steady flow of people leaving the District of Columbia for the cleaner, safer environs of the suburbs, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee proposed a $325 million tax relief plan today for residents and businesses in some parts of the city.
As part of a larger tax-cut proposal to be presented to the committee this week, the chairman, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, has included a plan to cut Federal income taxes for people living in some of the poorest sections of the city and creating tax incentives for new businesses in the same areas. 
 His plan is the latest Federal effort to address what many lawmakers and Clinton Administration officials consider a national embarrassment: the sorry condition of the nation's capital, where power has passed from the elected mayor to a federally appointed financial control board.
The board has prompted change in virtually every municipal agency, but the city continues to suffer from an array of urban ills, including high crime and dilapidated roads and bridges.
Tax relief has been viewed as a way to reverse the trends, by luring people and businesses back to the city, expanding the tax base and providing more money for improved services. Soon after Republicans gained control of Congress in 1994, Speaker Newt Gingrich became an early proponent of the strategy, but Mr. Archer resisted.
Mr. Archer's spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said, "He has never been a big fan of carving out one part of America and giving it a special tax break."
Mr. Fleischer added that the chairman's support came after a request from Mr. Gingrich.
Today, Mr. Archer described his plan as a modest start.
"The single biggest thing the District of Columbia needs to do is create an environment that is healthy for people to live and to work and to educate their children," he said at a news conference.
The proposal would designate "enterprise communities" where residents would pay no more than 10 percent in Federal income tax. Capital gains taxes for certain business properties would be eliminated in these communities. It also calls for a newly created Economic Development Office to provide $75 million in tax credits to Washington businesses.
The plan won the cautious support of the Administration, which has proposed a similar, $300 million economic incentive plan.
Eleanor Holmes Norton, the city's nonvoting delegate to Congress, said that she was encouraged by the Archer plan but that it did not go far enough in creating benefits for middle-class residents. She has proposed capping personal Federal income tax for District residents at 15 percent.
Mr. Archer said his plan would give tax relief "where it will do the most good, to lower-income middle-class people, where we think the District needs the most help."
Raymone Bain, a spokeswoman for Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., said Mr. Barry favored a plan closer to Mrs. Norton's.
